review:
Let's be honest, who hasn't heard of CS2? You buy Prime, get your weekly drop, open your case, and just keep repeating that forever. Get ready to play with a bunch of apes on your team, run into hackers, or even face off against bots with wallhacks and aimbot!

Seriously though, the game is awesome, but it can be a bit stressful. It's easy to understand but hard to master.

[h1]🎯 Огляд: Counter-Strike 2 (CS2)[/h1]

[hr][/hr]

[h2]🕹️ Геймплей[/h2]  
[i]Класика в новому тілі.[/i] CS2 зберігає дух CS:GO, але рушій Source 2 усе змінює.  
Рухи плавні, стрілянина важча, дим фізичний — все це змушує звикати навіть ветеранів.  
[i]Гра стала глибшою, але менш передбачуваною.[/i]

[hr][/hr]

[h2]🌐 Мережевий код[/h2]  
Після оновлень ситуація стала кращою — хіти реєструються стабільно.  
Але [b]64-tick[/b] усе ще тут. У 2025-му році це виглядає сумно.  
[b]Мріємо про 128-tick сервери офіційно.[/b]

[hr][/hr]

[h2]🎮 Графіка[/h2]  
Source 2 зробив гру красивою: освітлення, деталізація карт, ефекти.  
[b]Але ціна за красу — FPS.[/b]  
[i]Навіть на потужному залізі бувають дропи в самий розпал раунду.[/i]

[hr][/hr]

[h2]🚨 Античит[/h2]  
[b][u]Це головна проблема CS2.[/u][/b]  
VAC практично безсилий. Читери є навіть у Premier.  
Репорти майже не працюють, а бани — рідкість.  
[i]Без сучасного live-античита — це не кіберспортивна платформа, а рулетка.[/i]

[hr][/hr]

[h2]🐌 Оптимізація[/h2]  
[i]CS2 вимогливіша за CS:GO, але стабільності бракує.[/i]  
[b]FPS стрибає навіть на нових ПК[/b], на Overpass чи Mirage часті просідання.  
Це не той рівень, якого очікуєш від гри з мільйонами гравців.

[hr][/hr]

[h2]🛠️ Виправлення багів[/h2]  
Valve оновлює гру, але дуже повільно.  
Деякі баги існують місяцями, наприклад:

[list]
[*]зникнення зброї  
[*]непомітні хіти  
[*]ламані спавни  
[/list]

[b]Це знищує довіру навіть серед лояльних гравців.[/b]

[hr][/hr]

[h2]📌 Висновок[/h2]  
[b]Counter-Strike 2 має величезний потенціал.[/b]  
Але [i]зараз[/i] — це більше технічний бета-тест із гарною картинкою.  
Поки немає античита, стабільного FPS і регулярних патчів —  
[i]говорити про повноцінну заміну CS:GO ще рано.[/i]

[hr][/hr]

[b]⏱️ Час у грі:[/b] [i]35000+ годин[/i]

CS2: A Problem-Filled Experience

The game is problematic from top to bottom. AWP flick shots land behind where you're aiming. There's no optimization. I shoot the enemy — they don’t die; I shoot a wall — it registers as a headshot. A teammate who passed in front of me a second ago somehow still seems to be in front of me and takes a bullet to the head.

Cheating is another disaster. VACnet is absolutely insufficient. Deathmatch and other modes are unplayable due to bot accounts farming weekly rewards.

The subtick system is broken. It doesn’t work as we were told — tick intervals still exist and even affect how fast we can peek in-game. Errors that never occurred on 64-tick servers happen frequently on subtick servers.

The smoke bug that was fixed in CS:GO works again in CS2. Even at the Major, bullet registration and hitbox issues occurred on LAN. So it’s not just us — the problems are clearly visible even at the professional level.

And while all this is happening, Valve releasing new skins honestly feels like mockery. None of the issues we complained about for years in CS:GO have been fixed — in fact, they’ve only much worse in CS2.

Anyway, when’s the new skin collection dropping, Valve?

📚 Studying
💼 Applying for jobs
🤝 Talking to real humans
💘 Experiencing love
👨‍👩‍👧‍👦 Family bonding
🏋️‍♂️ Becoming the Sigma I was meant to be

Instead, CS2 gifted me:

🎓 A PhD in Slurs, courtesy of voice chat
🇷🇺  Fluent Russian and Mandarin
💢 A Major in Anger Issues
🧠 Questionable social development
😵‍💫 Insomnia 

And somehow…
10/10 — would queue again and disappoint my ancestors.

P.S. Practice your aim. We’re all trying to defuse trauma here, not just the bomb. 💣

I've been playing Dota 2 for 12 years now, off and on throughout my life it is one of the few constants. In high school, my friends and I spent many nights playing when there was only one courier. In college I played once or twice a year on my rented laptop from school. During the pandemic It was a way for my brothers and I to connect when we couldn't actually visit each other. It holds a great place in my life.

[h3]The Good[/h3]
- Gameplay is dynamic, engaging and rewarding once you get the hang of it. There are so many moving parts that when you make your first big play, there is very little that can match the feeling of satisfaction when played just right. 
- Flourishing Pro Scene: If you want to get better there are countless new and old pro players that stream or release content on Youtube to help you improve, and often times Discord chats to find players to play with.
- Semi Consistent Updates: They just released one of the biggest updates the game has seen since Talents were released in 2016, or neutral items were released in 2019, or when they DOUBLED the size of the map in 2022. Valve isn't afraid to experiment with this game, and while you can get stuck on a single patch for a long time, you can always know that Valve Devs are working on something truly different to add.

[h3]Negatives[/h3]
- Mental Health: This is a team game. I love it for that, but playing with others can be frustrating and demoralizing. You can also find yourself "chain queuing" which after multiple losses can really effect your mood outside the game. My girlfriend and I have a rule that I cant start a game after 10pm because if i lose badly sometimes I will be too angry to fall asleep or talk before bed. You have to find these ways to look inward yourself, and without barriers it can really negatively impact you.
- The Community: I said it a bit above, but if you're new to online games there is so much racism, sexism, anger etc. I've met really great people playing dota, but the brain tends to remember the bad eggs. Remember there is a mute button.
- Communication from Valve: There can be crickets from valve sometimes. They ARE working on stuff, but if you read reddit to much you can get a bit riled for no reason.

Overall, best game I've ever played by a long margin.

Great fun game if you've got friends and play around at lower ranks trying stuff out. However, this game has one of the most toxic fanbases in existence, second only to maybe LoL. If you intend on playing solo, do your sanity a favor and just avoid this game like the plague. You will be flamed, griefed, have slurs screamed at you, etc. if these players perceive even a microsecond of sub-optimal play.

Ah, Dota 2, the game where toxicity flows like a never-ending river and the community is as welcoming as a pack of hungry wolves. Strap in, folks, because this rollercoaster of emotional distress is about to make you question your life choices.

Let's start with the community, shall we? A lovely bunch, really, if your idea of lovely involves getting flamed for daring to pick a hero someone else wanted. And don't even get me started on the joy of encountering smurfs who stomp around like they own the place, leaving a trail of shattered dreams in their wake.

But wait, there's more! Ever wanted to experience the thrill of spending an hour in a match, only to have your hopes dashed by a single misstep? Congratulations, Dota 2 has got you covered. And let's not forget the joy of watching your teammates rage quit faster than you can say "GG."

And don't even think about trying to improve. Sure, you could watch tutorials, read guides, and practice till your fingers bleed, but why bother when you can just blame your losses on everyone else? It's the Dota 2 way!

But overall, despite the salt mines and the occasional dumpster fire of a match, I would still recommend this game. Because beneath all the toxicity lies a surprisingly addictive experience that somehow keeps you coming back for more punishment. So, if you're ready to dive headfirst into a cesspool of salt, frustration, and occasional glimpses of actual gameplay, welcome to Dota 2. Just remember to bring a hazmat suit and a healthy dose of sarcasm. You're gonna need it.

League of Legends but:

1.    Too zoomed in so you can't see whats happening. 
2a.  Stuns and silences that last literally 6 - 8 seconds to remove all chance of counter-play.
2b.  Because of this BKB is needed on 99% of all heroes, giving a few second window where you get to play.
3.    Hero speed is much faster and the map is much bigger, combined with point 1 and its constant panning.
4.    Jungle role is still not a thing, and the jungle is way less interesting.
5.    Hero balance is non-existent. heroes hard counter each-other. Games are decided in hero select.
6.    Somehow even a more toxic community.
7.    Items are less diverse, and it seems the only way they can develop interesting ones is to give them all 
       active abilities, making the game a memory game of what item is in what hotkey slot.
8.    Blink is still an expensive item you need to buy, forcing you to chose between mobility or power, making
        it impossible to play a hero that needs a blink in a losing lane.

I've hardly ever played or tried the game, but recently I thought it may be fun to give it a shot. 

This game is pure unadulterated dog shit, it's a terrible new player experience, coated with an over-abundance of gimmicky abilities and crowd control. It's like if you let a group of 12 year old's develop a competitive MOBA title.

The extreme level of different abilities and vast power-spikes can turn a fun and engaging early game experience into a god awful immune to literally everything Slark one-shotting your entire team EVEN if they're fed.

DOTA just simply does not hold up with the level of competitive integrity that other similar titles offer. The overpowered, overloaded, over-the-top skills quickly get old as you're constantly left scratching your head after the 5th team of people that all speak different languages after waiting 40 minutes to finally get a good match where someone doesn't abandon and waste all your time.

The game is not salvageable it will die. Inevitably. In the very least at least some small places in the world will keep the player count around 200k~ for a while, though once all the old folks get tired of it.. That's it. 
R.I.P DOTA

Incredible depth and nuance with high skill ceilings and the most integrated and expansive client of any moba.   The game feels very premium outside of annoying bugs in the game viewer. 

The community also has a high skill level (creating a pretty high skill floor) which can make even unranked games overwhelming for new players.

If you can make it through the steep learning curve you will experience a tactical moba far beyond the rest of the field.

I recommend turning on anonymous mode when starting out to mute other players, the community is toxic and obnoxious towards new players.

Left LoL after finding this game around 1 year into playing league with friends in highschool(about 2014). I loved Dota right off the bat, the first thing that stuck out to me was that nothing except cosmetics can be bought or unlocked.

My League friends unfortunately never got it. I had to keep playing League with them, they refused to give the game more than a few hours each. Crushed me, still bitter about that to this day.

My love for Dota turned into a total obsession. I learned as much as I could, and played whenever I had the time. I was so inspired by Fear and Dendi's stories in Free to Play, I wanted to go the distance myself. I saw Dota as the one path for me to turn my boundless enthusiasm for strategy games into freedom from jobs I didn't love and a place I didn't want to live. The one rope I could use to pull upward into the future I wanted for myself. Of course, I decided to become a professional Dota player. 

This wasn't meant to be.

I was working as a busboy at the time and would work my shift and come home at night and play, then work again without any significant breaks. I would go 24-48hrs without sleep regularly to play as much Dota as I could without missing any work. Went to 1 LAN and placed 2nd, that was one of my favorite experiences in my life. Also met people from all over the world and learned words(mostly curses heh) from languages I would have otherwise never encountered, got to practice my Spanish a bit too. I grew so much as a person from the interactions I had in Dota. It shaped me.

Despite my extreme(and overzealous and counterproductive in retrospect) dedication I never got above 3.6k MMR. What happened instead was that I ended up in the mental hospital from playing between 5 and 22 ranked matches a day and not sleeping on top of working my full time job bussing tables(which I worked as hard as I could at as well). When I got to the hospital I was 135lbs(I am 5'11") and hadn't eaten or slept for 6 days, and was in full blown manic psychosis. Maybe if I had been provided for and fully supported during this time(and born without bipolar disorder) by my parents, I could have done it. We'll never know, but that's what happened. What I did was the epitome of the adage: "burning the candle from both ends". I flew too close to the sun and crashed and burned in the flames of psychosis and malnutrition. 

It's been almost 6 years since that episode of mania. Don't worry guys, I'm fine now, I sleep and eat every single day and have never had a recurrence of mania. I use medication to stabilize my mood whenever that pattern fails. Although I still enjoy the game a lot, I really only play turbo on and off since that's what I have time for. Gone are the dreams.

I know I spent a lot of time on this game, and I will regret somewhat my failure to become pro for the rest of my life. At one point it was everything to me. I lived, breathed, and dreamed it. That said, I look back on all that time with nostalgia and fondness. This is a game that will one way or another leave an impression on the rest of your life. You will either give up at less than 50 hours, or you will never forget it. 

How can I not recommend that?
It's a masterpiece.

P.S. 
Here's my dotabuff if you want to see my schedule during that breaking point: https://www.dotabuff.com/players/34646363/activity

I played DOTA 2 back on the WarCraft 3 days.  I wasn't an addict then.  Fasft forward to DOTA 2 release, I resisted playing.  Eventually my son asked to play a game that sounded to me like DOTA.  I been addicted ever since, and he's been playing since he was 6 years old.  The new patch I thought is a great way to freshen the game.  I hope they do radical changes like this every year to keep people into the game.   I see quite a few negative reviews.  Anyone who wants no change but is willing to play for 30 years can go back and play the WC3 with the mod, that thing is frozen in time forever.

I have to admit the game is starting to wane with me too, but thats not because of the changes.  Its hard to keep up with the game trends to remain relevant in playing.  

Kudos to the makers of DOTA 2., keep evolving!

When I bought the game, previous the full release, it was interesting. Occasional discussion with people that takes it to seriously in your team, but overall it was a fun game.

Now, the game is fully packed with sweats and cheaters... and the few casuals and newbies to feed their ego. Can't recommend to a new player at all, unless you don't value your time or are a masochist. 

For casual players like me, that plays once a month at most, is a no no.

Their main problem is not the cheaters (that's normal in most online games), it's the matchmaking system which is a joke. Regardless of your skills/stats, you'll be most likely put in a match against tryharders with thousands of hours that know the exact weight of every object including their character pants, or at what angle you should shot to headshot someone hundreds of meters away with the slingshot they just found in some kid's treasure stash. 
Even though I like the challenge in games so I can improve, it's pointless since this is a battle royale, where 80% of your time is matchmaking and preparation. If matches where quick like CS would be fine.

The fix would be quite easy though. Matching people of similar stats, and then if not enough players fill it with bots. Casuals would prefer to deal with that instead of forehead web-camers.

When this game came out, it was one of the most fun and addictive games I'd ever played. I played my HEART out for a long time. Then came the hackers. I didn't play for years.  I recently reinstalled it, been having a blast again!  Then alas... once again came the hackers. They are in nearly every game. If you aren't playing against them, they are on your team. I will admit, it's more fun when they are on your team... but still. I gotta take a break again, because at this point, it's unplayable.

PUBG will always hold a special place in my heart. The gun mechanics, the tension of every firefight, and that adrenaline rush while pushing for the Winner Winner Chicken Dinner—it's just pure goosebumps. I still remember watching Shroud dominate the battlegrounds with insane plays—those streams were legendary and made me fall even deeper in love with the game. A timeless classic.❤️❤️❤️
if you like getting  locked on through smoke and shot across the map with shotguns this game is right up your alley!

I really enjoyed playing PUBG. The realistic graphics, intense firefights, and strategic gameplay kept me fully engaged. I love the thrill of surviving until the very end. It's definitely one of the best battle royale games I've ever played.

The atmosphere is incredibly immersive – whether you're sneaking through the grass or fighting for your life in the final circle. Every match feels different, and teamwork really makes a difference.

If you're into tactical shooters and battle royale games, PUBG is a must-play.

PUBG – chaos, laughter and a little lag in the bargain

I play PUBG about three times a week and there’s always something going on! The best part is the community – jumping in with your friends, screaming in voice chat, and trying to survive the chaos together. Sometimes it works out. Sometimes… well, you know – you forget to switch to automatic mode and die embarrassingly quickly 😅

The game is really fun, but I have to admit that the lag sometimes ruins a perfect headshot or a nice flank. Will they fix it? Then it’s 5 out of 5 right away!

Highly recommend to anyone who likes laughter, excitement and teamwork (and is patient with a little technical mess sometimes).

I’ve sunk thousands of hours into PUBG over the years and it’s still one of the most intense and rewarding battle royales out there. The gunplay, pacing, and overall feel of the game are unmatched.

But in the past year or so, things have taken a hit — especially for players in Australia. Since local servers were shut down, it’s been harder to get decent matches. High ping, long queue times, and being forced onto overseas servers have really dulled the experience.

It’s still a great game at its core, but it feels like it’s slowly being left behind — at least for us down here.

Used to be whole towns wouldn't even have a single rifle and you felt super lucky just finding an automatic firearm right out the gate. In my experience, around 40% of the matches I played had at least one blatant cheater wall-hacks, aimbots, you name it.

It's honestly exhausting. There's nothing more demoralizing than making it to the final circle, only to realize the last two players are obvious cheaters. And when it's happening this, it's hard to justify sticking around. Until cheating is actually handled not just talked about in patch notes it’s hard to recommend this game to anyone

I love a lot of what Apex Legends has to offer. The gun play is one of the best in any game I have ever played and the charachters are very fun. However I can’t recommend the game strictly on the monetization. For example before this new season (24) there were leaked mini battle passes for all of the new legends that would add a ton of progression that was desperately needed. It would have given the players something worth playing for. But what does EA do? Make you pay 10$ for each one. This isn’t even mentioning the collection events that cost 300+ dollars to complete. They also just added a new mobile game pay system that makes you pay to unlock something cheap and then to unlock something free. All the skins are also egregiously overpriced in general. It’s all there to just make you spend as much money as possible it’s trash. They don’t really care about the players they care about the money that’s it. The balance changes are often mediocre and  don’t always fix all the problems they should. EA is lucky the foundation of this game is as good as it is otherwise people wouldn’t put up with the gross monetization. If your a new player that know you won’t buy anything then maybe give it a try. Otherwise steer clear it’s not worth your time until EA gets it together and starts to care more about the player base.(which will never happen)

Only professional gamers, streamers and sweatlords who desperately want to be streamers play Apex on a daily basis : If you aren't playing like them, you're gonna get destroyed pretty fucking hard, on every single confrotation. There is no room to think and planify. 

For all of them, every single aspect in Apex is taken so serious they feel entitled. They treated Apex Legends as a national esport; one wrong move (ex.: not landing on a high contested POIs), and you'll get verbally abused by your teammates. Thinking outside of the box is a blasphemy to them.

The MMR/SBMM/ whatever matchmaking Respawn is using is the worst experience ever : Unless you have amazing skills, you'll lose a series of matches in a row. 100% Guarantee. Then, the game will put you into an easier lobby so you get a couple of kills, and after that match, Respawn will send you to high skilled lobbies for you to lose more. Wow! What an amazing system, Respawn! So fair and balanced ! And of course, the fans are okay with this. "Protect the lower skilled players", my ass : Respawn's MMR takes those low skilled players to feed the more talented players and streamers, and I know, because I'm one of the low skilled players. Even with an overall 1K/D, Respawn will make sure you'll get fucked by better gamers against your skills, even you have the worst K/Ds, and you feel your skills aren't up to the challenges.

Speaking of matchmaking, every lobby, either pubs or ranked, feels like the biggest tournament even conceived : If you try to have fun in the lobby (by that, I mean not play the exact same way the progamers/streamers/sweaties are playing), you lose. Simple as that. And then when you try something else they don't like (ex.: play strategically with placements and loot), you'll receive toxic abuse. There is no middle ground in this game. As long as heirlooms recolours are selling high, Respawn seems okay with a toxic community.

It's sad, really, because the gameplay is one of the best FPS around: there is not another game close to what Apex is offering (except Titanfall 2, in some ways).

Having fun in a videogame is a foreign concept at Respawn, and its community as a whole seems to agree with the devs's vision.

If you're a casual, look somewhere else. Trust me, there are games deserve more your time than Apex Legends.

EDIT : Went back for one more season, and my review still stands. Matchmaking is garbage and Respawn really hates casual players. STAY AWAY FROM APEX LEGENDS.

Sep 2nd, 2023:
I don't often write reviews, but I feel compelled to express my disappointment with Season 18.

The matchmaking system is seriously flawed. In many instances, I find myself pitted against either low-level cheaters or seasoned predators, which has seriously hampered the enjoyment for my friends and me. And this is on non-Asian servers; I can only imagine what the experience would be like there.

Regarding the in-game shop and events, the offerings have been lackluster at best. It seems that Respawn and EA are attempting to recoup losses from Seasons 16 and 17, but the current state of the game provides little incentive for financial investment. This is coming from someone who has purchased over 1,200 gold skins and 22 heirlooms. If things continue this way, I foresee a significant decline in the player base, and it's disappointing that the developers don't seem to acknowledge this.

The gameplay itself has become so unbalanced that it encourages teaming, which in my view undermines the competitive nature of the game. It's evident that the studio's focus has shifted away from the needs and experiences of average players. I've decided to step back from the game for now and will consider returning once improvements have been made.

——From a greatly disappointed player

[h1] Here is a new review of Apex Legends (old review season 16, new review season 22) [/h1]

I have now played Apex for 1400 hours. I've been actively playing it with friends since Season 12 and at the beginning the game was playable. In the meantime it has deteriorated to the end point. EA could have made Apex a really good game, but they tried to turn it into a money-making machine....

[h2] Individual points of criticism: [/h2]

[h3] The game itself: [/h3]
Dous was taken out (big mistake in my opinion). In Season 22 there is not even a normal Apex Battle Royal anymore but only "Trios Revival". This means that there is not even any variety and Apex can no longer be played normally. If you want to play normal Apex Battle Royal you now have to play ranked which will be fun with the current matchmaking which is not available.

[h3] Matchmaking: [/h3]
The matchmaking is still non-existent and has gotten worse in parts. When I play ranked with friends of the same rank we get Master and Predator in the match. It's the same in the gamemodes.

[h3] Sound problems and bugs: [/h3]
In the time between season 12-22 ea has not managed to fix bugs like sound problems, package loss, glitshes, server crashes and far more bugs. Since I have been actively playing the game again, hardly anything has changed and more bugs have been added.

[h3] Money Greed: [/h3]
The store offers skins that cost 30-50€ for the fact that they look frankly ugly. The battlepass, for example, can no longer be bought normally with apex points. you can get it for free through tasks [b] BUT [/b] if you want everything from the battlepass you have to pay at least 10€. you only get 2 legendary skins, 10 extra exotic shards, 10 level instant unlocked and have the possibility to play all legends during the season even if you haven't unlocked them yet.

[h3] Unclear graphic design/bugged graphic design: [/h3]
In the menu, things like battlepass challanges or the battlepass itself are extremely confusing. ingame, the graphics are sometimes buggy.

[h3] Not suitable for new players: [/h3]
From my own experience, new players have no fun with apex and quit after about 20 hours of play. the reasons are mostly the bugs, that they have to play against masters or high levels and that everything is extremely chaotic and confusing.

Respawn's gunplay and movement are simply unmatched. No other game on the market except for maybe Call of Duty has guns that sound, feel, and look as good as the guns in Apex. It simply feels really nice to shoot things in Apex. It's truly the best of what the FPS genre has to offer. However, here's a big and stinky but: EA. These two letters, when put next to each other, strike fear into the hearts of five generations of gamers. The game is currently riddled with bugs, hackers, a scam-dominated meta, stale game modes, piss-poor matchmaking, and more. What does EA make respawn focus on instead? Pumping out more skins and collection events. This season is the most egregious one so far in this regard, with recolored skins littering the shop and events. Meanwhile, Mobile has 3 more legends than us, a highly - and I mean HIGHLY - requested team deathmatch mode, and tons of other cool features that the console/PC versions can only have wet dreams about. Thank you EA. You truly have the reverse Midas touch, where everything you touch turns into piles of doodoo.

Apex Legends is a disappointing game that fails to live up to the hype. The graphics are bland and uninspired, the controls are clunky and unresponsive, and the gameplay is repetitive and boring. The selection of weapons and characters is limited, and the matchmaking system is unreliable, frequently matching players with people who are much higher or lower level than they are. The in-game microtransactions are also a major problem, as players are constantly bombarded with ads for new skins, weapons, and other cosmetic items. Overall, I wouldn't recommend Apex Legends to anyone looking for a fun and engaging multiplayer experience.

Respawn is not the same company that made Titanfall 2 anymore. This is published by EA so you know there's no real progression unless you spend ungodly amounts of money for skins that don't look good. You would think for a game with such good movement, EA would realize how good this game could be. Unfortunately the pros in this game aren't good enough to move to another game, and any new players immediately leave because this game also lags like crazy. There is literally no reason to play this game. I have played it since launch, and it's not like it's gotten a 2.0 or health update to the game. I'm begging you, please just don't play this game. But if you do, add me I guess.

Preface: I do recommend this game - Only for short lengths of time. Maybe an hour or two TOPS. Any more than that and you run the risk of rage quitting and uninstalling due to one or more of the issues I list below. You have been warned.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------

This game has now been around for over 2 years. PLENTY of time for the developers to establish a trusting relationship with their players/users. Typically, that is what a decent developer does: A swath of players will complain about a certain aspect of the game and the developers will actually listen and at least make attempts at fixing the problems.

NOT. IN. THIS. CASE. EVER.

I understand that a portion of what a game developing company does is supposed to generate revenue for the company - And they do! A separate, and equally important, aspect is that the company is also supposed to improve the game by listening to their users and addressing issues in a timely manner - hopefully, before their users get angry enough to drop the game altogether.

This is precisely where EA/Respawn have failed. And I will break it down for you, precisely HOW they have failed.

1. Cheaters:
This game has an inordinate amount of cheaters. There really is no easy way to say it. And it is OBVIOUS and BLATANT. EA relies upon the absolutely defunct Easy Anti-Cheat system. Please, hold your laughter... In their defense, however, they have made sure to spread rumors of a revamped anti-cheat system, designed specifically for Apex. The real issue is how LONG they have been spreading this rumor. I can only assume that it was a PR stunt to quiet those complaints of cheaters. How can I make that assumption? Mainly because they seem to focus on things of little or no consequence - Like adding badges to shield batteries and medkits... I mean, what?! Why would you focus on cosmetics when you have a huge cheater problem?!

2. Match-Making (MM):
Very rarely have I seen an MM quite as laughable as the one being used in Apex. I understand that there it a lot of complexity involved, what with ranked splits resetting every month (for the most part) and making everyone, essentially, noobs. But, there is a SUPER easy way to fix it (which I will detail later). I understand why they do the ranked split as well: they want to force players to play more often to keep their ranking high - DUH! The more players there are, the more likely it is that they make money and that those players will spread the word so that even more players will play and give them even more opportunity to make more money. But an MM based solely on your current in-game rank is absolutely asinine. And that is just ranked. What if you don't play ranked? Good luck! You could be paired against ANYONE, professional players and noobs alike.

3. Maps:
Currently, there are a total of five maps in Apex (for BR). Every season they have two maps in rotation for pub games. TWO. And those two maps rotate every hour or so. For ranked matches, they use ONE. Over and over, on and on... Maps should be randomized except in tournaments. Going into a game, you should not know where you are going to land, what characters you should be playing, etc. It should be a friggin' BATTLE ROYALE! Formulate your plan based on who is on your team and what the map is, ad-hoc, just like everyone else. No one should know what map your're landing on until the drop ship starts its flight across it. Add some aspect mystery to the game.

4. Weapons:
There is a good selection of weapons in the game, but the real issue is with practicality. Take, for instance, the so-called top sniper rifle in the game - the Kraber. It's supposed to be a .50-cal sniper rifle. It LOOKS great, but that's where the good news ends. If you hop into the firing range and test out all of the sniper rifles available to you, you will catch the glaring issues. The Sentinel, the Longbow, and the Charge Rifle all use sniper rounds (NOT a .50; Something smaller like a .308). All three can reach WAY out and touch your enemy. The Charge Rifle can literally reach all the way across an area of the map - over 800m. The Sentinel and Longbow can shoot pretty accurately to 400+m (depends on optics in use, graphics, screen size, FOV, etc). With the Kraber, the bullet starts dropping wildly at just 200m. Yeah...the highest-powered weapon in the game, using the highest-caliber bullet can BARELY eke out a 400m hit with accuracy. Let's add to this the 30-30 Repeater and the G7 Scout - A heavy ammo, medium range pew-pew and light ammo medium range pew-pew, respectively. Both of these rifles can out-shoot the Kraber with accuracy. WHY? And the Charge Rifle - Why does this not use energy ammo? I mean...CHARGE Rifle...it shoots a beam of light!...sigh...

5. Legends:
Don't get me wrong, there is a use for every single legend in the game. Whether it be for hiding, sniping, guarding, tracking...it's useful stuff. It is also getting really out of hand. First, how many freaking legends does a game like this need? At some point in the near future, you could probably have a pub match where every single player in the game is a different legend. I'm not even joking though I wish I were. Second, when EA unveils a new legend, they typically add it to the game and then they forget its existence. No re-balancing of legends, no fixing bugs, etc. And if they DO fix something with a legend, it is usually a heavy-handed nerf beyond what anyone that actually PLAYS the game was expecting. The abilities of the legends are pretty unique, but the overall effect of those abilities is copied across other legends. The exception to this is both Loba and Lifeline. Loba has her black market (so you don't have to hunt around an area if you know what you are looking for) and Lifeline has her health drone - The only legend that can heal your flesh-wounds. Other than those two, you can pretty much classify all other legends into categories like defense, offense, or recon and their abilities, while varied, have ultimately the same effect on the game. Offense legends can quickly get up in your face and kill you, defense legends can slow your entry into an area while sapping your health, and recon legends can track you and your team down. Simple. And boring too. Meh.

On to my ideas on how we can fix BOTH the cheater AND MM issues in Apex:

1. New DB table - Player AVG DMG (>10) Last 10 Games (PAD).

2. New DB table - Player AVG DMG Rating (PADR); 11-300: Rating 0; 301-700: Rating 1; 701-1200: Rating 2; 1201-2000: Rating 3; 2001-3200: Rating 4; 3201-4200: Rating 5 (AND account marked for review); 4200+: Rating 6 (Insta-banned - If the pros can't do it, pubs can't either without cheating).

*NOTE - Keep in mind that these are averaged over the last TEN games where damage done was greater than 10.

3. Players can only be matched with other players of the same PADR -/+1.

4. Teams have an AVG DMG Rating (TADR) of ((PADR1+PADR2+PADR3)/3)-1 (always rounded UP) for BR Trios. 1 player with R2, 2 players with R3 would be ((R2+R3+R3)/3)-1=R2. Teams can only be matched with other teams of the same TADR.

THREE birds, one stone. Fix MM, catch a boatload of cheaters, AND the games are more fun because you are playing with players very close to your own skill level instead of non-stop sweats OR non-stop noobs.

*I'm not saying it is not possible to play a 4K+ DMG game. I AM saying it IS impossible to play 10 *consecutive* 4K+ DMG games without cheating. Again, if the pros can't do it, neither can the pubs without programmatic assistance (cheating).

September 19, 2022 (Season 14)

Favorite battle royale, the one multiplayer game that I enjoy even when I am not doing well in it. Fun immersive characters, changing the game enough every few months to keep it fresh and interesting, much different from Warzone. which I played before that made me burst blood vessels every time I instantly died from walking into the wrong room or outside or anywhere. You have lots of health and shields in this, also abilities. You don't die easy so when ever I lose it's no big deal. I accept it as a fair fight. Not just that scenario when you walk into a room where an all black skin is in a corner with a gun that kills you in 0.0001 seconds giving you absolutely no time what so ever to react. Apex is a great game... 

Edit for July 23, 2024 (Season 21)

I've played this game for almost 4 years. I will still stand on my position that this is the best BR available. That being said, there isn't much competition and no other online multiplayer BR game holds a candle to everything this game has to offer but... it is now reaching an unplayable point for me, which is devastating because I always really had fun playing this game nearly every day up until season 20 dropped. I'm not trying to jump on the band wagon like everyone else just hating the game for the monetization shift. I understand inflation is a thing. The game needs to keep generating money to keep the team staffed so they can continue to develop and evolve the game as the seasons progress and I'm an adult, I have money, I spend money, I spend so much time playing this, $10 is nothing to me, charging $20 instead of $10 is nothing I am concerned about. I saw a flat of water go from $3 to $8 over the last 4 years so to see the game charge $10 twice over 12-15 weeks is nothing. Played BR like Warzone for a year in 2020 and that had $10 seasons that were only 8 weeks so I don't see the battlepass price as an issue. It's the matchmaking that ruined the game for me. I can't have fun casually playing the game anymore. Competitive sweats and the current player base (that has severely declined since 2022 came to an end) ruined game. There is no chill casual fun players like me anymore. The official Apex discord active players have dipped like 95% since I started playing. The only people still playing are lifers that only live to try to be the best at this game. Everyone that is still playing has stats and achievements in the game I could never dream to come close to attaining. I get in a match, me, the casual play in his 30s that never got a 3K badge, never came close to 20 kills, can't be bothered to play ranked but tried and was impossible to pass platinum 4k and played the game almost every day forr 4 years and just hit 9000 account kills. I only play in lobbies where everyone is a Wraith, Octane or Pathfinder that has 4K 20kill master/pred badges and 85,000+ kills on said legend... 

I just play to die now. I can't do anything in the lobbies I'm placed in. The games aren't fun. Since none of my rl friends can be bothered to play the game anymore, I try the discord lfg channel, if I don't give up after 35-45 minutes looking for people to play with, I end up playing with terrible people that shouldn't be playing video games, mostly, if I can find decent human beings to play with, the games are still terrible. Just play to die, since season 20 my KD has been cut in half, the only kills I get aren't even cool or feel good, the only way I can play now is to 3rd party and steal someone else's kill. Like nothing about this game feels good anymore. I need to play with = skill players to enjoy the game again. If SBMM is a thing, I should not be in the lobbies that I'm in whenever I try to play. If SBMM is not a thing, then this game is impossible for any casual player or anyone thinking about trying this game for the first time. Just not fun anymorer

Bugs, more bugs, in the lobby bugs, in-game bugs, garbage servers, more and more cheaters (aimbots...wallhacks...you name it), questionable design/game mechanics...the usual BR scene after X amount of time. Apex could be great - there are aspects to it that are fantastic such as the movement, the variety of legends and weapons to choose from, even the colour palette and map design (for the most part)...but the bugs, the poor servers and the cheaters are going to be its eventual downfall if Respawn doesn't get its act together soon, especially with new FPS games on the horizon. Personally, I could never get over the bizarre choice to have punches deal absurd damage (at least early game with white/blue armour) while 10-20 rounds of light/heavy ammo more or less hits for the same amount. It's a weird, one-step-too-far case of 'jumping the shark' or 'nuking the fridge' that's been in the game since day 1.

The fundamental mechanics of the game is also clearly conducive to 3rd party opportunism from the get-go and, once past the mid-game stage, serves up Gold/Red shield bullet-sponge fiestas ad nauseam. More often than not I have more fun in the early stages of a game when white/blue and maybe the odd purple armour is mostly all you see. I'm inclined to think that the game would be less tedious if Respawn had stopped at Purple or Gold armour (the latter being very rare). 

Ultimately though, for all of its good qualities, Apex just isn't hitting the mark for me anymore. The bugs, the bad servers and the bypassed Easy anti-cheat just makes for a BR that could be great, but often serves up a disappointing experience that is more of a miss than a hit. As always though, your mileage may vary.

The result of this is I end up stopping after only a handful of games, either because MM'ing or the randoms I get matched with end up sabotaging the fun.

Unless you have a group you can consistently play  with or you're just extremely patient, I don't recommend this one.

Important Info in Terms of Service:
• Mods are a bannable offense

Collected Data Types:
• Identifiers / Contact Information: Name, user name, gamertag, postal and email address, phone number, unique IDs, mobile device ID, platform ID, gaming service ID, advertising ID (IDFA, Android ID) and IP address
• Protected Characteristics: Age and gender
• Commercial Information: Purchase and usage history and preferences, including gameplay information
• Billing Information: Payment information (credit / debit card information) and shipping address
• Internet / Electronic Activity: Web / app browsing and gameplay information related to the Services; information about your online interaction(s) with the Services or our advertising; and details about the games and platforms you use and other information related to installed applications
• Device and Usage Data: Device type, software and hardware details, language settings, browser type and version, operating system, and information about how users use and interact with the Services (e.g., content viewed, pages visited, clicks, scrolls)
• Profile Inferences: Inferences made from your information and web activity to help create a personalized profile so we can identify goods and services that may be of interest
• Audio / Visual Information: Account photos, images, and avatars, audio information via chat features and functionality, and gameplay recordings and video footage (such as when you participate in playtesting)
• Sensitive Information: Precise location information (if you allow the Services to collect your location), account credentials (user name and password), and contents of communications via chat features and functionality.

I used to play this game. I spent money on it. And then Rockstar decided the anti-cheat would stop working on my linux machine. That's an extremely anti consumer decision and I will never buy a rockstar product again.

HOW this game sold so damn much and is praised as one of THE games of all time is a mystery to me. 

.Mediocre story with boring characters who pale massively in comparison to GTA protagonists we've had in previous games.

.boring cookie cutter missions with very few memorable moments or set pieces. game missions feel heavily linear and automated like im riding a roller coaster not playing a game.

.bland boring bare empty open world with fuck all to do and not much to see. lots of unused empty space and the condensed tightly packed city ares with "content" are very bare bones and uninteresting to be around for more than 5 minutes. all there is to do is shoot brain dead npcs and cops until the busted wanted system takes you down. THAT'S ALL THERE IS TO DO.

.combat and shooting is just serviceable. nothing terrible nothing special, which in a game all about cars and mostly shooting, being mediocre at gun play isn't good.

.the online is a gigantic mess and has always been a mess since its conception. don't even bother. there's too much wrong with online for this review.

this game certainly is decent at presenting the ILLUSION of a breathing interact-able open world, but seeing a series as free and open as GTA get watered down into almost nothing is quite depressing.

GTA V – Still the King of Open-World Games

Even years after release, GTA V is an absolute masterpiece. The world of Los Santos is massive, detailed, and full of life — you can spend hours doing missions, causing chaos, or just exploring. The three-character story is brilliantly written, with unforgettable moments and cinematic heists.

Add GTA Online into the mix and you’ve got hundreds (if not thousands) of hours of gameplay. Whether you're robbing banks with friends, buying high-end apartments, or parachuting out of a jet while being chased by cops, it never gets old.

Runs great on PC, supports mods, looks incredible at high settings, and feels like it was made for this platform. An all-time classic — and still a must-play.

10/10 – Chaos, comedy, and crime at its absolute best.

im new to the game and 5 black dudes rape me with mk2

I loved GTA V—it’s really good. From beginning to end, I was hooked. I love the fact that you can customize the characters and their vehicles. Though I kinda wish they brought back a system like in GTA: San Andreas, where the character could get jacked as f*ck or fat with a PH lol. Also, I wish my bois had more haircut options.

Gameplay-wise, it’s really solid. I love the graphics, and I really enjoyed the combat system—especially Michael’s special ability during fights. But overall, Franklin’s ability was the one I used the most.

The story was really good too. The only part I didn’t like was Trevor’s mission in that shipping business or crate thingy—that part really slowed the game down for me.

Overall, it’s a really good game—almost perfect. And like, who in their right mind would kill anyone, bro? Especially for me, since this was the first game I ever finished story-wise. I even stuck around for a bit after just to buy stuff for my characters—especially my bois Franklin and Michael, sheesh.

Rating: 9.5/10

This game will always have a special place in my heart. I still remember the first time I played GTA V on PS4 when it launched—pure magic. The story was absolutely mind-blowing, and the ability to switch between Michael, Franklin, and Trevor mid-mission was just so satisfying and revolutionary at the time. Rockstar truly created a masterpiece that set a new benchmark for open-world games. Timeless.10/10❤️❤️❤️

This game saved my life.

I am 27.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiraling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.

Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 ♥♥♥♥ing minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.

After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.

Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.

I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.

Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you

[h1]Grand Theft Auto V – 100% Completion Review[/h1]
[i]All achievements earned, story completed with all three endings, 100 percent checklist fulfilled, every Strangers & Freaks mission finished[/i]

[b]GTA V is the culmination of everything Rockstar had built toward in open-world design.[/b]
Completing it fully highlights both its staggering ambition and the creaks beneath its legacy systems.

You switch between Michael, Franklin, and Trevor, three flawed protagonists whose intersecting arcs revolve around crime, ego, and identity. The writing is sharp and often hilarious, but also bleak and cynical. It rarely aims for emotional resonance, instead leaning into spectacle and chaos.

[b]Mission design is cinematic and varied.[/b]
Heists are the centerpiece. They offer planning, execution, and a sense of payoff. Driving feels great. Shooting is solid but standard. Character-switching adds tactical variety, although the AI is occasionally unreliable. A full completion run requires everything from collectibles and random events to hobbies and real estate, some of which feel like filler.

[b]The open world is the true star.[/b]
Los Santos is layered with detail. Pedestrians react, radio stations are packed with personality, and the game constantly surprises you with small touches. It is still one of the most fully realised digital cities ever built.

Some systems show their age. The economy is easily broken. Random events repeat. Yet the world continues to feel alive.

[hr]

[b]GTA V is vast, refined, and often brilliant, even if it buckles under its own weight at times.[/b]
To complete it is to see both its genius and its contradictions. Few games offer this much, even ten years later.

gta 5 is like “what if crime, but make it a sitcom with guns and therapy issues.”

you’ve got three lads:
– michael, retired crime dad with a pool, a midlife crisis, and kids who hate him.
– franklin, just tryna escape the hood but keeps getting dragged into nonsense.
– and trevor. literal feral goblin man. lives in the desert, probably eats glue, might be immortal.

story? it’s a wild ride. starts with a simple heist, ends with explosions, betrayals, and trevor probably naked screaming at a cow.
you switch characters like changing radio stations. one minute you're doing yoga with michael, next minute you’re flying a jet into a prison.
and franklin’s there, being the only one with brain cells.

world’s massive. like actually too big. get distracted every 3 seconds.
“gonna do a mission—”
oh look, tennis.
oh look, a dog.
oh look, a man doing yoga on a cliff, time to ruin his life.

cops are psychic. shoot a tyre in the desert, and suddenly the FBI’s up your arse with a helicopter and bad attitude.
driving feels good though. shooting too. and the online? oh boy. it’s like gta but on meth. flying bikes, orbital cannons, 12-year-olds screaming in your headset. chaos simulator 3000.

graphics still hold up. story’s solid. humour’s dumb, violent, and brilliant.
everyone’s terrible. no moral compass, just vibes and crime.

9.9/10. deducted 0.1 because trevor once fed me to a pig. emotionally. not physically. i think.

I only started gaming about 6 months ago, and GTA V was one of the first big open-world games I tried. All I can say is  this game blew my mind.

The freedom is insane. I spent my first few hours just driving around Los Santos, crashing into stuff, getting distracted by side missions, stealing helicopters I had no idea how to fly... it was pure chaos, and I loved every second of it.

Then I got into the actual story, and wow  switching between Michael, Franklin, and Trevor never got boring. Each one has their own vibe and their own mess of problems. Trevor’s missions? Straight-up unhinged. Michael’s felt like a crime drama. Franklin’s felt real. Somehow it all just works.

As a beginner, I appreciated that the game didn’t overwhelm me. The controls made sense after a while, and there’s always something fun to do, even if you’re not great at aiming or driving yet. It lets you goof off and still feel like you’re progressing.

Haven’t even touched GTA Online yet. Just the single-player alone has been worth it.

If you’re new to gaming like me  this is a wild, funny, sometimes brutal game that makes you get why people love gaming so much.

Take-Two and 2K games (including Gearbox & Rockstar Games) have silently updated all their games' Terms of Service, turning this game as well as all of their other games into software capable of data farming. Additionally, their Privacy Policy mentions sharing data with ad networks and marketing analytics; it is very explicit that they intend to farm data from you and use it for frivolous monetary gain.

***While Take‑Two disclaims using "spyware", they explicitly reserve broad permissions to monitor, record, store, and analyze user data: including voice, gameplay, and profiles. That’s not spyware in the "deliberately malicious" sense, but it’s still sweeping surveillance capability permitted by legal provisions you agree to.
[READ BELOW for more about Take-Two's update statement regarding the issue]

Important Info in Terms of Service:
• Unsanctioned mods can be a bannable offense (depending on their arbitrary definition of bannable mods)
• Display of Cheats/Exploits is bannable
• Forced arbitration clause and a waiver of class action and jury trial rights for all users residing in the United States and any other territory other than Australia, Switzerland, The United Kingdom, or The Territories of The European Economic Area
• You can be banned for using a VPN while connecting to online servers
• Cannot access game content on a Virtual PC

Collected Data Types:
• Identifiers / Contact Information: Name, user name, gamertag, postal and email address, phone number, unique IDs, mobile device ID, platform ID, gaming service ID, advertising ID (IDFA, Android ID) and IP address
• Protected Characteristics: Age and gender
• Commercial Information: Purchase and usage history and preferences, including gameplay information
• Billing Information: Payment information (credit / debit card information) and shipping address
• Internet / Electronic Activity: Web / app browsing and gameplay information related to the Services; information about your online interaction(s) with the Services or our advertising; and details about the games and platforms you use and other information related to installed applications
• Device and Usage Data: Device type, software and hardware details, language settings, browser type and version, operating system, and information about how users use and interact with the Services (e.g., content viewed, pages visited, clicks, scrolls)
• Profile Inferences: Inferences made from your information and web activity to help create a personalized profile so we can identify goods and services that may be of interest
• Audio / Visual Information: Account photos, images, and avatars, audio information via chat features and functionality, and gameplay recordings and video footage (such as when you participate in playtesting)
• Sensitive Information: Precise location information (if you allow the Services to collect your location), account credentials (user name and password), and contents of communications via chat features and functionality.

*DISCLAIMER*: T-T/2K/Gearbox has put out a statement regarding the misleading statements surrounding the EULA in their games:

"Take-Two generally does not seek to take action against mods that are single-player only, non-commercial, and respect the intellectual property"

(1) Take-Two Does Not Use Spyware
Take-Two does not use spyware in its games. Take-Two's Privacy Policy applies to all labels, studios, games, and services across all media and platform types such as console, PC, mobile app, and website. The Privacy Policy identifies the data activities that may be collected but this does not mean that every example is collected in each game or service.

***This sounds, to me, an awful lot like: "we won't spy on you or collect your info, we swear. BUT, we reserve the right to per the agreement, y'know, in case we ever did want to." Whether they act on the provisions outlined in their EULA or not, the provisions themselves are unethical.

Look, it's GTA.  At this point everyone probably knows what to expect.  

This review is just for the single player/story mode, although some points probably translate to multiplayer too.  

Rockstar does a pretty amazing job creating open worlds, a variety of fun vehicles, memorable characters, and parodies of modern culture that give you a chuckle.  That hasn't changed in GTA5.  

That said, GTA5 is not a perfect game.  It wasn't when it came out and certainly isn't now.  For example, anything your character does on foot is just awful.  It feels like playing GTA3 back on the PS2 (not a compliment).  They control like a baby giraffe still figuring out how its legs work.  Running is a chore.  Gunplay hasn't really aged all that great.  And while some dialogue is hilarious, other bits seem like they were written by a tweenager a remarkably immature sense of what's funny or edgy.  

Upside:  Maybe room for improvement with GTA6?

Grand Theft Auto V: A Timeless Open-World Experience Worth Every Minute

GTA V remains one of the most engaging and dynamic games I’ve played to date. Its expansive open world, thrilling gameplay, and endless activities make it nearly impossible to get bored—once you start, hours can fly by without even realizing it.

The multiplayer mode amplifies the experience, turning Los Santos into a vibrant playground where you can team up, compete, or simply explore with others. The depth of content is impressive—from a massive variety of vehicles, weapons, fashion styles, and mini-games, to story-driven missions that keep you on your toes.

While the game is already incredibly immersive, there are a few features I’d love to see in future updates: the ability to invest in stocks like in story mode, a real estate trading system where you can buy and resell homes, and even pet-raising or horseback riding for more interaction with the world.

The only minor drawback is that the map, though detailed and packed with life, could benefit from being a bit larger to support even more exploration.

Overall, GTA V is more than a game—it’s a whole lifestyle. Whether you're a solo explorer or thrive in chaos with others, there's always something new to discover.

🟢 Level Design : [i]Los Santos feels alive. From mountains to downtown alleys, everything flows well[/i]
🟢 Lifetime : [i]30-50h for the story mode[/i]
🟢 Physics : [i]Driving is arcadey but punchy. Ragdoll and destructibility are still satisfying[/i]
🟡 Gameplay : [i]Switching characters is a strong idea, but missions rarely push the formula forward[/i]
🟢 Graphics : [i]Still good thanks to regular updates[/i]
🔴 Scenario : [i]A mixed bag. Fun in tone, but lacks the emotional weight and cohesion of GTA IV[/i]
🟢 Soundtrack : [i]Massive licensed playlist, strong ambient music[/i]

Great game, shame about the company

Let me be clear – GTA V is a masterpiece. But Rockstar as a company? A bureaucratic black hole where support tickets go to die.

I lost access to my Rockstar account and spent weeks trying to prove I'm the legitimate owner of a game I legally bought on Steam. The response? Cold silence or robotic copy-paste replies.

Rockstar makes billions, but can’t be bothered to implement a proper account recovery system or support staff with more than two working neurons.

And Steam? Shame on you for enabling this. You happily sell their games but take zero responsibility when your customers get locked out. You partner with a company that treats paying users like disposable trash, and pretend it’s none of your business.

At this point, the only thing more broken than Rockstar's support is their sense of responsibility.

And honestly, I’m just waiting for Rockstar and Valve to update the terms of service again – months or years after purchase – so players must agree to another “anti-cheat” spyware package that scans their entire PC, bank statements included… all to stop modding in a singleplayer game.

These two ego-fueled giants seem oddly comfortable with that setup. Almost like it benefits them.

10/10 game, 0/10 company. Buy with caution – and maybe keep a pirated backup handy, just in case the "official version" becomes inaccessible and no one cares.

[h1]A tale of three men who need group therapy more than they need another heist.[/h1]
Remember when GTA V first dropped? Life was easy, your PC could actually run games, and stealing a jet from a military base felt like a reasonable evening plan.
Now it’s almost 12 years, 3 console generations, and 47 re-releases later... and guess what?
It still slaps harder than Trevor in a cutscene.

[i][h2]It’s not just open-world. It’s open chaos with GPS and so detailed, even the pedestrians have better lives than me. [/h2][/i]

[h2]The Story: Dysfunction, Heists, and Midlife Crises [/h2]
The story of Grand Theft Auto V is like a three-headed beast powered by crime, chaos, and an unholy amount of sarcasm. You’ve got:
[list][*][b]Michael [/b]– retired bank robber turned Vinewood dad, trying to enjoy the quiet life… while accidentally reigniting every bridge he ever burned. His hobbies include yoga, yelling at his kids, and pulling off cinematic heists like it's 1999.
[*][b]Franklin[/b] – stuck in the middle, trying to climb out of the street hustle and into the big leagues. He’s the only one who seems like he actually wants a career and not just carnage. Buys a house in Vinewood Hills, but still drives like the cops are chasing him. [i][b]Because they are.[/b][/i]
[*][b]Trevor[/b] – a walking war crime in a tank top, who answers every problem with violence, yelling, or both. His entire character arc is: [i]I regret nothing.[/i] Runs a criminal empire in his underwear. [b]Respect.[/b][/list]
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3122380232

Together, they pull off heists, insult each other endlessly, destroy the city economy, and occasionally bond, usually over felonies.
It’s not a story about good vs evil. It’s about bad vs worse,  and somehow, you end up rooting for all of them.

[h2]Combat & Gunplay[/h2]

Shooting is punchy and smooth, with solid cover mechanics and a huge arsenal.
Each character has a special ability, Michael slows time in gunfights, Franklin slows time while driving (bless him), and Trevor? Trevor just becomes more violent.

[h2]Driving & Vehicles[/h2]
Driving feels responsive and arcade-style ,perfect for weaving through traffic at 120 mph with five cop cars and a helicopter behind you.
[b]Bonus:[/b] Franklin’s slow-mo driving basically makes him a street-racing Jedi.

[h2]Character Switching[/h2]
The game’s biggest gameplay twist: you control three protagonists.
You can switch mid-mission or mid-mayhem.

Whether you’re doing serious heists or spending three hours obeying traffic laws for no reason, the gameplay never stops being fun.
Even a Decade later, it still holds up better than half the games released last week.
Whether you're in it for the heists, the story, the flying motorcycles (thanks, Online), or just to cause legally questionable mischief you’ll find yourself saying, 'Just one more mission' right before sunrise.

[h2] Final verdict: [/h2]
Do I even need to include something like 'Final Verdict' in a review?
[b]No[/b]- it's not required at all.

GTA Online is a true standout in the multiplayer world—few games offer such a sprawling, unpredictable playground where you can chase a luxury lifestyle one moment and dive into a high-stakes heist the next. The sheer range of activities, vehicles, missions, and customization options makes every session feel like your own personal blockbuster. Whether you’re teaming up for a daring casino robbery or simply cruising through Los Santos at sunset, there’s always something unexpected around the corner.
That said, the experience isn’t always flawless—cheaters and disruptive modders can seriously dampen the fun. While mods in single-player can be wildly creative, in the online world, unfair mods can crash lobbies, ruin missions, or give certain players invincible advantages. It’s frustrating when hard-earned progress or fun gameplay is compromised by exploits. Thankfully, Rockstar has stepped up enforcement and security in recent years, but it’s still a cat-and-mouse game.
Still, for most players, the chaotic joy and open-ended freedom of GTA Online outweigh those rough edges. Got a favorite car or mission you keep going back to?

Rating: ★★★★★ (5/5)

GTA V is a masterpiece that blends open-world exploration, gripping storytelling, and endless gameplay variety. The massive, detailed world of Los Santos is alive with activities, from heists and car chases to golf and skydiving, making every moment in the game exciting. The narrative is top-notch, with three distinct protagonists whose stories intertwine in unpredictable ways. The driving, shooting, and general mechanics are tight, offering a truly polished experience. Online, GTA V offers even more with GTA Online, where players can dive into a variety of missions, races, and activities with friends or strangers, keeping the game fresh for years.

Pros:

Massive, vibrant open world with endless activities.

Engaging story and memorable characters.

Tight controls and varied gameplay.

GTA Online offers continuous content and multiplayer fun.

Cons:

Some minor bugs and glitches.

The humor and mature content may not appeal to all.

Verdict:
GTA V is a genre-defining experience, offering unmatched freedom, fun, and replayability. It’s a game that keeps giving, making it an essential for any gamer.

This game isn’t just a checkbox RPG — it’s a world. A beautiful, brutal, morally gray, emotionally rich world. Every side quest feels like it matters. Every character feels real. Even the goats have backstories.

What makes it legendary:
✔️ Geralt. Just… Geralt.
✔️ Writing that punches you in the gut (and sometimes the heart)
✔️ Gwent is dangerously addictive
✔️ Stunning world — from Skellige’s icy cliffs to Novigrad’s seedy alleys
✔️ Soundtrack? Goosebumps.
✔️ Combat is fluid and fun once you get the hang of potions, signs, and dodging like a ballet dancer with a sword

Minor flaws (but who cares):
➖ Inventory management can be a little clunky
➖ Roach has a PhD in rooftop parkour

Verdict:
If you’ve never played it — I envy you. You get to experience it for the first time.
If you have — you already know it’s one of the greatest games ever made.
If you love playing open world games, you'll love this one. Get it on a Summer sale (with all the DLCs) or any other good sale (always get the DLCs pack).

"Love the game – hate the controller support on PC (PS5 controller)"

I played Witcher 3 on PS4 and absolutely loved it, but on PC with a PS5 controller, the experience is incredibly frustrating.

In just two hours, I ran into multiple issues:

I can’t dismount Roach properly.

Button inputs (like moving left/right in menus or Gwent) double up.

There’s no option to remap buttons on controller, which is insane for a modern PC game.

Tried fixing it with Steam controller settings, no luck so far.
For a game this polished in every other aspect, this controller mess is extremely disappointing.

Unless you're using mouse + keyboard or Xbox controller, expect a bad controller experience on PC.

Quite simply if you're an open world action RPG fan, this is the greatest game of all time. What CDPR managed to achieve in 2015 with their ambition being this high is nothing short of miraculous. All western open world RPG's will be compared to Witcher 3 for all time as the benchmark for storytelling, compelling side quests, player agency, non condescending scripts and themes, masculinity, grittiness, art design, music composition, and world building. 

The game is grim dark, it is shades of grey and forlorn despair for the most part just like our world. Very few choices you will make in this game are cut and dry, you will agonise over what decision to make even in side quests because they are so morally ambiguous. Every single decision you make in this game has repercussions and affects the world around you, someone you handed over to the guards you may find hanging from a tree a week later as you ride through the countryside, or being burned alive to jeering crowds (and this is only if by chance you happen upon the place where these consequences play out, you may never see them or know what outcome some decisions you made had, it is organic and beautiful this way), what seems like the altruistic decision at the time during a quest may lead to many innocents being slaughtered later. The player agency in this game cannot be understated, it is phenomenal and the game genuinely stirred up my human empathy and compassion, regret at times. Honestly, I don't know how CDPR made a game of this calibre and ten years later nothing has come even halfway near to what they achieved. 

It's 2025 and playing this in native 4K using the next gen graphics update settings I am constantly in absolute awe of this world, it is a monument of game art and a testament to a team of developers who clearly put their hearts and souls into this game. I am currently 113 hours in and by my estimates I have another 50 hours before I finish this play through and that doesn't include mopping up the last points of interest on the map. I know I will be returning to this game again, like I have now since I first played this MASTERPIECE (yes, this actually is a masterpiece, no exaggeration) in 2015. Playing through Witcher 2 and 3, and being part of Geralt's story is something I will carry with me the rest of my days, I feel like I know the characters and countries in this world.
Best game of all time for me.

The best game I've ever played! While the Witcher drew me into this game world, and is outstanding in it's own right, this is the gem of the three. The Witcher 2, was sadly simply horrible. What drew me to the game was while the mechanics, which are good for me since I can only use one hand and pausing is an absolute necessity were great for someone that is handicapped, the hidden gems are the main and side stories within this series. Simply impossible for me to put down until I could hardly keep my eyes open. About as emotionally realistic as I have ever come across.While I prefer the ending where Ciri becomes a witcher like her father, I realize the developers preferred her returning to her heritage. Fortunately, I could decide their fate, many games deny that option.  5 ***** is too low a score for this game.

After 9 hours i still do not know how any of the main game mechanics work. I think you need to have played games like this, or previous versions of this game. There are just way too many things that are assumed to be understood.

I have not reached a point in this game where i feel i know what i am doing, or what i am supposed to do. Most of it has been playing along with the "script", going to markers and accidentally stumbling on side quests.

I have not made any weapons up to this point, because i do not know how to find the ingredients needed, or how to get the coins needed. I do not know what weapons to make if i could, or how i can see if they were worth it if i could make any. I ended up just doing quests, hoping to get coins to craft something.

The combat system is like flipping a coin. Attack sometimes works, sometimes doesn't. Jumping out of the way sometimes works, sometimes doesn't.

I don't know if, when or how i should be using which sign. The q button does not work consistently for me, so even though the game says i can use signs in combat, i cannot. I am probably missing something here, but i can't tell.

I found out i can have bombs because a quest told me i needed some kind of bomb. I have no idea how to get bombs, or if they are better than melee weapons. If i had a bomb, i would probably not be able to find it in the menu, or be able to figure out how to equip it or use it.

I am currently in a quest with the basic weapons, where i am instantly killed by a wraith. It could be i need some protection against his one shot kill, but i do not know what that would be. I also don't know how to get out of the location where this wraith is.

Googling questions and watching other people play the game in order to make me be able to play the game is too much hassle, and not enjoyable at all.

I assume this game is great if you are familiar with the mechanics.

The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt is a masterpiece of storytelling and open world design. its a living world filled with complex characters and morally challenging choices. Geralt of Rivia feels real and compelling, and every quest main or side offers depth and meaning. The vast, detailed world of Velen, Novigrad, and beyond is immersive, with dynamic weather and day night cycles that impact gameplay. Combat balances skill and strategy, while RPG elements allow meaningful customization. Even years later, the visuals and sound remain stunning, with excellent voice acting and an evocative soundtrack that bring the fantasy world to life. This game is a must-play classic that sets the standard for RPGs.

Got this game on sale and enjoy the graphics and story, except I do not enjoy the combat. Since Buying this game I have been wondering why I never felt like I had control of combat situations, and suddenly I realized that it's because I have zero control over the animation Geralt chooses to attack with. Will it be a short, easy-to-hit animation that will net me the attack that I want? Or will Geralt decide to do a weird spinny move first and make it take longer, thus getting hit in the process? It feels like guesswork most of the time and that shit is not cool.

Like I am literally trying to light attack and jab enemies, but Geralt wants to add a little spin around before swinging the blade resulting in getting hit before your attack lands, that shit is fucking annoying. All in all attacking feels slow, even when using "light" attacks they can still take AGES to land, resulting in you getting hit by a REAL light attack from an enemy, super fucking annoying.

The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt is an outstanding open-world role-playing game developed by CD Projekt Red. From the very first moments, the game captivates with its rich storytelling, immersive world, and deep character development.

You play as Geralt of Rivia, a monster hunter searching for his adopted daughter while navigating a war-torn world full of political intrigue, moral dilemmas, and dangerous beasts. The narrative is mature, branching, and full of emotional depth. Every choice you make has consequences, making each playthrough feel unique.

The graphics are breathtaking — from dense forests and bustling cities to stormy seas and eerie ruins. The soundtrack complements the world beautifully, and the voice acting, especially Geralt’s, adds life and authenticity to the characters.

Combat is fluid and strategic, blending swordplay, magic (signs), alchemy, and monster hunting tactics. The game also includes an expansive crafting and upgrade system, as well as the addictive card game Gwent.

With its massive world, gripping storyline, and attention to detail, The Witcher 3 sets a high standard for RPGs. It’s a must-play for any fan of fantasy or immersive storytelling.

Rating: 10/10
