An extraordinary experience elevated by the loveliest fantasy universe I've had the honor of discovering.

The Witcher 3 is an abundant source of amazement with its gorgeous explorable worlds as well as its long list of intricate characters ; some loved, some begging for a silver sword through the thorax. 
Break free from the expected political neutrality as you delve into the labyrinth of dilemmas left & right. (I swear that pun wasn't intended.) 
Your sword won't be the only thing getting wet, as all the sorceresses in your viscinity will. Geralt has a knack for such things. Mixing monster hunting with pleasure never actually hurt anyone, right? So does having sex with at least 50% of the female roster.

Jest aside, I've never had more fun with an RPG ever before in my life. This is a masterpiece, and I doubt many will argue with that. The side quests either add additional layers to the characters' already complex personalities, or make you die of laughter. There are rare exceptions I can think of off the top of my head, but hey, no game's perfect ; however the positive overwhelmingly outweighs the negative.

This entry has gotten me into the franchise, as I'm playing the 2007 and 2011 entries. When you encounter a world as rich as this one is, you can't help but seek more in the source material : Sapkowski's The Last Wish, Time of Contempt and so on.

You will not regret this. This has been a crucial gaming experience that has affected me so positively that i'll forever smile at the mention of it.

I'm not really into medieval games, but since the reviews were so positive, I decided to give it a try.
First of all, the game is overwhelming. Sometimes it fails to properly explain things. I hate doing it, but I had to search the web to understand some aspects.
Secondly, the game sometimes fails to load a save file. For example, when I die, it suggests reloading the most recent save, but then it gets stuck on a black screen and I have to Alt+F4.
Other times, when I Alt+Tab, the audio mutes and I have to quit the game entirely. That gets annoying pretty quickly.
That said, I’m finding it somewhat interesting. I'm not a huge fan (at least for now), but for some reason, the game makes me want to keep playing. I might update this review later.

Whether you're exploring the wilds or diving into gripping side stories, The Witcher 3 is truly a game that stands the test of time.

My thoughts after completing 100% of the game

This game is nothing short of a masterpiece. I've played it ever since it came out and lost count of how many times I've finished it. From the very first quest, the atmosphere and story pulls you into the world where you'll sink countless hours over and over again, each time discovering something new. 

The story writing in this game is nothing short of miraculous. A subtle secondary quest about a certain man trying to help another man on the street may lead you to rehearsing a play involving a falling of an Elven king (won't spoil too much there :D). It's perfect, so perfect in fact that this very game inspired me to read the complete Witcher book saga. Rarely does one encounter a game that invokes such an emotion within a player where you could literally sob (not exaggerating) for an event in a game, or get you so hyped up, emotional and completely invested in a quest that may even not be the main one. Not to mention, Gwent is a hella of a lot of fun to play :D 

Graphics are astounding. For a game that came a decade+ ago, this game set a high standard (in my opinon) on how graphics should be handled. The game runs beautifully on a 3080, 5800X3D on a 1440p 165Hz panel, with a constant 120+ frames. Stunning sceneries, accompanied with yet another incredible point about this game, the music, are unmatched. There's just one feeling one can feel when visiting the fields of Ard Skellig or listening to a certain trobairitz in Novigrad.

Combat is solid. Nothing special, nothing extreme, just polished with a lot of room for experimentation to make your build synced with your playstyle and gear. Want a sign build? Poison? Heavy attack? Glass cannon? All of them are well balanced and fun to play.

The DLCs could've been the games by themselves. Their stories are incredibly well written and give you access to new areas, expanding on what is already a gigantic map. I'd dare say that the Duchy of Toussaint is one of the most beautiful places in gaming to this date.

This is one of the best games ever made. There are some bugs (Roach having fun uphill/downhill, downright glorious), Act 3 of the main campaign feels a bit rushed, but nothing even remotely detracts from me giving this hearty recommendation to anyone that hadn't had a chance to experience this world for the first time.

Wow. This game is truly astounding. I went into playing this game not really knowing what to expect, although I had heard good things about it. I have never played any of the first two Witcher games either. I have to admit, it was a weird transition from Bloodborne to the Witcher 3 because of the significant difference in pacing. However, they're two completely different games and the Witcher certainly proved itself to me. From the amazing sceneries to the engaging story, this game is definitely praiseworthy. However, the most compelling part of the story for me was definitely the characters. The character development in this game is amazing, and I truly began to feel a sense of comfort and love for nearly all of the characters. I loved the characters and lore of this game so much, in fact, that I actually played through the game multiple times, covering the main story and various side quests. It is very easy to put in over 150 hours into this game, as I have put in at least 500. Furthermore, I bought all of the books that the game series was based on and I am currently reading them with delight. If buying the entire book series simply because the game was incredible doesn't convince you that this is definitely a worthy buy, then I don't know what will. This game does not fail to impress and I can't wait for the upcoming DLCs. Hopefully you give it a shot, because it is definitely worth your time and money. Congrats to CD Projekt Red for creating such a magnificent experience with the Witcher 3.

10/10 game. Truly a masterpiece, especially the NG version. What can be said about this game? It has everything:

+ A compelling story
+ The action, twists and plots
+ Interesting characters, especially the beautiful females
+ Great RPG elements
+ Good and straight forward combat system
+ Great graphics even for my taste in 2025
+ The bond with Ciri was so incredible

There is so much to write about this game, a lot to tell but this game is just one of those that you must've played once in a lifetime like Super Mario back then. It's simply part of gaming history. I'm saying this as a person who is not really a fan of medieval fantasy action. Medieval stuff is already growing out of my ears after spending my life over 30 years in Europe. 

A few negatives about the game:
- Some guiding paths showing you where to go or find things can be misleading, depending on the mission
- While the combat system is very straight forward and simple, it lacks some "modern touch". Like fluidity, adaptive combos and fighting techniques
- More diverse weapon types would be highly appreciative 
- Hands down, the Netflix version of Geralds armor is one of the best but I was so astonished by the lack of creativity when it comes to providing more top tier outfits that could be an extended expression for players. I've used various mods to give Gerald a mix of armor sets. PC mods are the best!

You absolutely don’t need to know a thing about the franchise to start here, either. 10/10, would give up my first born to experience this for the first time again.

Almost all of the characters behave and sound like juvenile teenagers doing their impression of what they think to be cool. Including your character, V and Johnny (who you will hear plenty of). Especially jarring when juxtaposed against a dystopian world dealing with (even if superficially) heavy themes like hypercapitalism, oppression, hedonism, body horror etc. Almost nothing feels believable, sensible or consequential. 

Speaking of Johnny, Keanu Reeves' performance is awful. 

There are also still tons of graphical glitches like characters and cars clipping through the environment etc.

Got to Act 3 and put in a few hours in the DLC, but can't bring myself to finish. It'll be too soon if I hear another slang like 'preem', 'choom', 'sitch', 'delta' and 'gonk'.

A solid and amazing game.

The game has grown to be one-of-a-kind for many reasons. Graphics, obviously, becoming the new "can I run it?" game. Chances are that the answer is "Not at over 60fps without DLSS." In my experience, the game runs well and is optimised enough to run smoothly without crashes, stuttering, or sudden frame-rate drops.

The story is brilliant, easily the highlight of the game for me. It has a lot of replay value thanks to the well thought-out perk system, and the combat (or alternatives to direct combat) keep the whole experience fresh and fun.

It's one of those games that you can have a blast playing by taking it easy, running side quests, or 100% focusing on the main story. It's well-made to be open to player choices.

The character designs in appearance and personality are fleshed-out and well-invested in. You see where some people live, work, and where they like to regular. It feels like a lived-in world.

It's worth a go.

It's unfinished, and was released as such. Over the years, though, the patches and DLC have really flushed out the game. Core mechanics like using MaxDocs to get health have been changed. Before updates, I would say it's worth a try but can get really frustrating with all the bugs and crashes. I put many hours in when Cyberpunk was in it's more janky state. In 2025 with Phantom Liberty, I still experience bugs and crashes, but they aren't game breaking, and due to the autosave feature the crashes don't set me back too far. Overall I have a really fun time with Cyberpunk, and there are plenty of mods out there to explore as well. Calling Cyberpunk 2077 a "bad game" feels ignorant. What, it isn't fun to zero some gonks with a katana using a slow-mo body mod? Come on, choom. Pick up some iron and make some eddies by playing Cyberpunk today.

One of my favorite games of all time.

From the very first day — bugs and all — I loved Cyberpunk 2077.

The storyline is unforgettable, the quests feel deep and emotional, and the entire world of Night City is both tragic and beautiful in its own broken way.

The music? Phenomenal. The gameplay? Addictive. The atmosphere? Unlike anything else.

I’ve bought this game on more than one platform because it truly stole my heart.

If I had to say something negative, it’s only this: I wish there was more. The story felt short, and while the city is stunning, I sometimes wished it felt more alive, with more things to interact with.

Still, Cyberpunk 2077 is a masterpiece — flawed, yes, but beautiful. One of the most memorable gaming experiences I've ever had.

Rust is not about survival, it's about people. People think that Rust is about survival, about campfires, food, tools, and stone. No. Rust is about people, and people are worse than beasts. You meet a person, and he shouts to you: "friendly, friendly," throws you food, smiles, and ten minutes later you wake up without a sleeping bag, without loot, and without a home. And the scariest thing, you know what? That you are not even angry anymore, you expected it. In this game, you can't trust anyone, but for some reason, you still sometimes do. Rust is about betrayal, revenge, paranoia. It's not just a survival game, it's a real social experiment. And at some point, you become the one you used to hate. You raid newcomers, take the last cloth from homeless people, and set traps in the bushes. You just hated door campers, and five minutes later you are sitting with a shotgun at someone's house. Rust first breaks you, and then rebuilds you, but as a different person. In Minecraft, you build, in Alchemy, you follow, in The Forest, you defend, and in Rust, you learn to be a beast. And not because you want to, but because otherwise you simply won't survive. Yes, Rust gives you a sense of trust, but only to break it. There are no neutrals here, only enemies and not-yet-enemies. At first, you defend yourself, and then you learn to take revenge. Rust re-educates you, your morals adapt to a new world where kindness is a weakness. And gradually, you turn into the person you complained about in the first hours of the game.

"It’s like my ex: toxic, unpredictable… but I keep coming back."

You spawn naked on a beach, didn’t ask for it, not even cold, already starving.
You meet a guy with a rock → he kills you.
You respawn → die to radiation.
You respawn again → get adopted by a clan, start to feel hope… then they betray you and steal your burlap underwear.

And still, I come back.
Like that toxic ex who ghosts you for a week then texts “hey” at 3AM.
You know you shouldn’t. But you do.

One day, you build a dream base.
Next morning: offline raided at 4:12 AM by some dude with 7 monitors and 12,000 hours.
And you’re left crying in your underwear, watching your campfire burn out.

But damn… when you win a fight…
When you loot that AK…
When you place the code lock… and you do the raiding…

You forgive everything.
Just like her.
It’s unhealthy. But it’s so good.

10/10 – Highly recommended. Play at your own risk.
C’est comme mon ex : toxique, imprévisible… mais j’y retourne quand même."

Tu spawn à poil sur la plage, t’as rien demandé, t’as même pas froid et pourtant t’as déjà faim.
Tu croises un mec avec une pierre → il te tue.
Tu respawn → tu meurs de radiation.
Tu respawn → tu te fais apprivoiser par un clan, t’y crois… puis ils te trahissent et te volent ton slip en tissu.

Et pourtant, j’y retourne.
Comme un ex toxique qui te ghost une semaine puis t’écrit "coucou" à 3h du mat.
Tu sais que tu devrais fuir, mais non. T’y replonges.

Un jour tu construis une base de rêve.
Le lendemain matin : raidé à 4h12 par un mec qui vit dans sa cave avec 7 moniteurs et 12 000 heures de jeu.
Et toi tu pleures en slip devant les braises de ta fonderie.

Mais putain… quand tu gagnes un fight…
Quand tu loot un AK…
Quand tu poses CE code lock et que c’est TOI qui raid…

Tu pardonnes tout.
Comme avec elle.
C’est malsain, mais c’est bon.

Rust has something for everyone regardless if you're new or returning after a few years. You get to play the ULTIMATE hunter/ gatherer simulator but that's not all. Love music? You can start a band or roam the lands with a guitar...or even a sousaphone! Not into violence? Cozy up in your base and paint on in game canvases! Want to make your neighbors protect you instead of sending bullets your way? Bake them some pies! Don't want to do all the work but want some action? Hop in a raid server where everything is setup for you already! Seriously...something for EVERYONE. Then you have Rust+, a free yet VALUABLE app you can download onto your IRL phone. Go outside and let the sun touch your skin without worry. You'll be notified if you die in game, if someone is snooping around your base, and you can even study your server's map.

Also, this game is beautiful with a 4080 & was STILL beautiful when I had a 1080. Every time I open the game and catch a sunset, I cry a single tear.

tl;dr DOWNLOAD THIS GAME

awesome game, lots of fun updates, the vehicles are finally here and the game is 10000x better as a result. devs obviously give a shit, constantly pushing updates, expanding the team, and have patched so many issues. i always wonder what the game will seem like in a year, 5 years, 10 years time. so many fun times that i've had. i've never left a review because i had too much too say, but this pretty much sums up the most important things.

i will say i'm really upset the screaming wounded sound is not in the game though. i have my critiques, but with proper modding, they can simply be added back in. so many games lack proper modding nowadays... this part of the game is very much underlooked from an outsider perspective. the modding community is dope, and everybody seems to have a different take on the game that can be satiated through searching servers for their beloved niche. 

i've watched this game grow up from infancy, and i can firmly say (with prior bugs and all) that the game has always been fun. it's a great time to play. i'll likely edit this review with more comments to say in the future, but it SHOULD always be a huge recommend from me.

Rust is brutal. It throws you into the wild with nothing but a rock, a torch, and the will to survive — and yet, that’s exactly what makes it amazing.

This is not your typical survival game. Every encounter matters. Every decision counts. One moment you’re gathering wood under a peaceful sunset, the next you're running naked from a guy in full metal armor screaming “friendly!” (he’s not).

Why it’s worth it:

🏹 Deep survival mechanics — hunger, weather, crafting, base-building

🔫 Intense PvP where your gear and your pride are on the line

🏰 Build massive bases with traps, turrets, and clever defenses

🤝 Unpredictable player interactions — betrayal, alliances, revenge

🔥 Regular updates and a huge, active community

Rust is tough on new players — you’ll die (a lot). But every failure teaches you something. And that first time you win a fight, build a base, or raid someone else’s? Pure adrenaline.

If you enjoy survival, chaos, and the thrill of starting from nothing — Rust will hook you.

Just… trust no one. 😉

⭐ Rating: 9/10

Ready for a hilarious take on your Rust experience? Here's a review that will make you laugh!
-------------------------------------
**Rust: A Love Letter to the Grind (and the Occasional Rage Quit)**

147 hours. That's how long I've spent in Rust, and honestly? It's been a wild ride.  Think of it as a digital version of the "Groundhog Day" movie, except instead of reliving the same day, I'm reliving the same cycle: spawn, kill (or be killed), farm, build, die, repeat.  Rinse and repeat.  It's like a beautifully crafted digital hamster wheel of frustration and fleeting moments of glory.

The graphics?  Pretty good for a game where I spend 90% of my time staring at the back of someone's head before they promptly end my existence with a rock. The building mechanics?  Incredibly satisfying, until some Chad with a rocket launcher decides my meticulously crafted wooden shack is now his personal bonfire.  The community?  Let's just say it's a diverse group of people, ranging from incredibly skilled builders to those who apparently think "teamwork" is a four-letter word.

My favorite moment?  Probably the time I spent three hours building a massive base, only to have it raided by a naked guy with a bow and arrow.  It's the little things, right?

Overall, would I recommend Rust?  Absolutely.  If you enjoy the feeling of your heart rate skyrocketing, the taste of pure, unadulterated rage, and the satisfying crunch of virtual wood being destroyed, then this game is for you.  Just be prepared to accept that your life will be defined by the endless cycle of spawn, kill, farm, build, die, repeat. And maybe invest in a good therapist.

Title: “Warlord of Wipe Day”

Wipe day. The sweet chaos. The bitter cold of the beach spawn. And you, just a naked with a rock and a dream.

Your name was whispered on the server—TundraKing69—but this wipe, you'd become a legend.

Day 1: From Beach to Beast
You spawned near Launch Site. Lucky. Within minutes, you clubbed a boar with your rock (twice, because it bugged and ran in circles), crafted a bow, and started sniping nakeds from the shadows. Your kill feed lit up like a Christmas tree.

Before nightfall, you'd solo’d a decayed 2x2, grabbed some scrap, and cranked that tier 1 workbench. By midnight, you had a crossbow, nailgun, and enough cloth to build a small empire—or at least a base with a double door.

Day 2: The Rise
You raided the neighbors with handmade shells and sheer spite. Took their furnace. Took their pride.

By sunrise, you were rocking road sign armor, a custom SMG, and a base shaped like a tank. You knew all the tricks—honeycombing, dropboxes for loot, hidden stashes under foundation twigs. You weren’t playing Rust; you were playing chess.

People started forming zergs just to try and take you down. You'd log in and get messages like:

“Bro chill.”
“TP me? I bring loot.”
“You’re cracked, how many hours you got?”
“ADMIN THIS GUY’S CHEATING.”

But you weren’t cheating. You were just him.

Day 3: Dominance
You owned Oil Rig. Not ran it—owned it. You built a minicopter base on a cliff, set up turrets around it, and ran Cargo solo with an AK and four stacks of meds. You dodged L96 shots like Neo, sniped headshots with iron sights, and wiped zergs like they were tutorial bots.

People logged off when they saw your name in kill feed. Clans offered you tribute—sulfur, guns, even blue cards—just to leave them alone.

You didn’t join them.

You became the server boss.

Day 5: The Raid
They came at dawn. 8 deep. Rockets, C4, LRs. It was a full-blown siege. But you knew they’d come. You set up traps. Hidden bunkers. Loot stashed across half the map. You held the roof with an M2, sent one last message in global chat:

“Come get your offline, rats.”

But you weren’t offline.

You were waiting.

The rockets hit, but you clutched it—twice—then countered with fire arrows and an army of shotgun traps. The kill feed glitched from your killstreak. By the time the smoke cleared, their bags were on timers, and you were dancing on their corpses with their own gear.

Day 7: Server Wipe
They say your base stood until the last minute. That the cargo ship never left the waters without your name on the leaderboard. That the server died when you logged off.

You left a note in a wooden sign near Outpost:

“I was here. TundraKing69. See you next wipe.”

And just like that, you vanished with the wind.
The server wiped.
The legend remained.

I do not recommend buying or playing this game until they fix the rampant cheater issue. 

For years the game has been plagued by cheaters in almost every server (yes, even the premium ones that require you to buy $15 worth of skins in order to play). For years the community has been asking for a resolution to this problem, and after literal YEARS of asking, we finally got them to institute a limit of $15 in order to pay on premium servers (this is what they took years to come up with). Facepunch, the game maker, has only prioritized profit by choosing to pump out new skins, or paid DLC, what feels like weekly.

The cheater issue is rampant and something that is not prioritized by the game maker. To add to this, Facepunch has recently announced they would UNBAN CHEATERS after only 8 MONTHS. Guess what they have to do? Just buy the game again...

After well over 5k hours of legitimate playtime, I won't be playing until Facepunch starts to prioritize the players who made this game great, instead of profit.

I am updating this as I have resolved the issue. The game is not crashing my computer is overheating and shutting down. I reduced the frame limiter from 240 down to 60 and cannot tell a difference but no more overheating. [bold]That having been said, going to the menu and adjusting the fps limit does not work. The option is there but when changed it doesn't save and just reverts to 240.[/bold]

You can resolve this when the game is not loaded, go to your game directory, open cfg folder, open client.cfg in notepad. Then find the line fps.limit and change the value in quotes. I really should not need to do this workaround but it worked. [bold]Notably this bug still exist even in staging branch. Please fix this.[/bold]

[strike]I like the game; however, crashing and stability issues are making it unplayable.[/strike]

"Rust made me the man I am today."

Before Rust, I was soft. I trusted people. I believed the world was fair.

Then I spawned naked on a beach.

I punched trees. I ate raw chicken. I died of cold. I died of wolves. I died to a man in a wolf headdress screaming "friendly" while beating me with a rock. I built a shack—I lost a shack. I made allies—I betrayed allies. I crafted guns—I got outgunned. I logged off—I got offline raided. I learned... never trust anyone with a torch and a smile.

But through the fire, the betrayal, the madness—I evolved.

Rust taught me resilience. Taught me how to grind, how to think ahead, how to adapt. It taught me to accept loss, and savor revenge. Rust isn't just a game. It's a life simulator with no safety net. And if you can survive here? You can survive anything.

Still not sure if I have PTSD or just miss the old wipe.

10/10 would scream at a naked running off with my loot again.

I downloaded Rust on a rainy night. I remember that part clearly — because it was the last time I felt warmth.

At first, it was just a game. Chop a tree. Build a base. Die. Respawn. Repeat. Simple. But it sank its claws in slowly. I stopped noticing the world around me. The sunlight faded behind curtains I never opened. I didn’t hear my wife when she said she missed me. I didn’t look at her when she cried. I told myself I’d make it up to her… after one more wipe.

She left a note by the keyboard. I never read it. I was farming sulfur. She walked out the door and didn’t say goodbye. I didn’t follow. I was crafting explosives.

The kids were quiet after she left. I thought that was good — it meant I could focus. But they were quiet because they were hungry. Because I forgot to buy groceries. Because I wasn’t there. They waited for me, day after day, as I roamed the coastline of a digital island looking for scrap. They cried themselves to sleep while I screamed into my headset about getting roof camped.

One day, the knocking came — but it wasn’t them. It was CPS. They said I was unfit. They said the house smelled like rot. They took them. I didn’t fight. I barely looked up. I just whispered “Hold on, I’m almost at oil rig.”

My job was next. Fired via email. I didn’t even check it until three days later. The electricity was already cut. I pawned my phone for one more day of internet. One more raid. One more chance to feel like I was winning something.

But Rust doesn’t let you win. It pretends it might. Then it strips you bare and leaves you screaming on a beach with nothing but a rock and broken dreams.

I took the last of my money to Bandit Camp. This was it — my final spin. Everything on black. The wheel turned. My hands trembled.

And then...

Black stole my money.

No fanfare. No tragedy. Just silence. Like the game was laughing. Like the universe had already moved on.

Now I live under a bridge, haunted by gunfire that isn’t real. Sometimes I press my fingers to my temples, pretending to loot my own body. At night, I whisper my old base codes to myself just to feel something. Just to pretend I’m still inside. Where it was safe. Where I mattered.

Rust didn’t destroy me.

I logged in.
And never logged out.

At the time of posting this review, Elden Ring is hands-down the best game to have been released.

Unlike some bosses in previous FromSoft games, no boss feels ridiculously out of place, pointless, or comically easy.
Long and frustrating run-backs? Not on this game.

FromSoft giving a Souls-like this kind of open world is breath-taking. Everything has lore. This game has inspired countless hours of player-made content covering everything. As always, there's the perfect balance of buried answers and unanswered or lost secrets.
It's unreal. Create a character, pick a new build, experience this incredible world, and do it again. Do it again, and again, and again.

This is the most accessible Souls-like game ever released. Near endless ways to stack the odds in your favour.
This has the potential to be the hardest Souls-like game ever released. Stack the odds against yourself.

It's all down to your choices. It's a masterpiece.
It's Dark Souls 2 but it's bigger and better and you can seamless coop.

is an unforgettable journey through a hauntingly beautiful world where exploration is rewarded, and every battle feels earned. The freedom to forge your own path, combined with deep combat mechanics and mysterious lore, makes it more than just a game—it’s an experience. Brutal, brilliant, and endlessly fascinating.

More of the same that you know and love from previous titles like Dark Souls & Bloodborne. Awesome gameplay, beautiful scenes, and a very challenging experience. I especially love the many different weapons you can choose from.

Where Elden Ring differs most from it's predecessors is the open world, and it does it better than many other open-world games. Every corner has something new to discover. It could be a weapon, a skill, some lore, or even a path to a completely new part of the map. Maybe even a part of the map you're not really ready for just yet. But you can go there if you want. There is very little hand holding. And if you feel like you are not up for that part just yet, there is always some other place you can go to.

The story is like that too. There is no quest journal with lists to follow up on. You either figure out what you need to do, or you just go about your own way. It's tied into the open world experience nicely where sometimes you just happen to run into a familiar face in the middle of a field.

The downside to the open world is apparent though. Assets tend to be reused. There are a lot of bosses that you face many times, and many smaller dungeons that you've seen before. Several times I found some cave somewhere that I was hesitant to explore because I already knew what it was going to be like.

On the multiplayer side, I was happy to learn that you can play on online mode now without the hassle of being invaded! A very welcome change. The online features like the messages and 'ghosts' really add something to the overall experience. Unfortunately, invaders can still appear if you are co-operating with other people, and it's still an unbalanced mess. On the topic of co-operating, there still is no real coop mode. Which really is a missed opportunity. 

If you are looking for a great single player experience though, then Elden Ring delivers like no other.

master piece as expected from Fromsoft, but it might not be for everyone.

An unforgettable achievement in open world map design. Extremely purposeful in it's layout, the lay of the land always feels intentional. Striking vistas are always presented as such, with clever gating often allowing the player multiple paths to arrive at these moments. The game struggles to keep it's momentum, and much of the optional content feels like a chore upon a second play through. Due to the nature of builds, much of your obtained items will not be usable or have very low impact on your character. This issue becomes more glaring when the prospect of replaying is so daunting. All in all one of the greatest modern RPG's for a first time playthrough, but falls off dramatically after it's secrets are plumbed.

Coop is extremely tedious in vanilla, and runs into the same issues of replayability as mentioned above, even when using mods like Seamless Coop.

PvP is extremely corny in vanilla, and only slightly less so using mods, with many mechanics not being implemented well (netcode is also atrocious).

Clearly this game is a masterpiece...

The music, the visuals are gorgeous. The Lore deep and fascinating.

But if you are new to the Soulslike Genre, it makes it very clear that it hates you and doesn't want you here. Fromsofts PC port is garbage. They wanted the PC money but couldn't care enough to adjust the interface to PC controls. In order to make everything gamepad compatible you have to suffer through ridiculous impractible button settings that, for some reason, do not allow to have an action placed on more then 1 keyboard and 1 mouse button. Who in the hell thought that running/dodging should be on the same button? Has to be so gamepad works? I do not care. It is a PC we don't need gamepads you want our PC money make keyboard and mouse work.

Another frustrating thing is the constant constant CONSTANT loosing of runes due to traps or insanely badly balanced enemy difficulty in the same region and no you cannot always revover them. Sometimes you are too far away from the last respawn point and you will not get back to them.

The first forced boss Margit, The Fell is hard but fair and well placed behind a respawn point. But good luck on your sry soul if you start exploring the castle that takes you deeper and deeper and it never stops and somewhere deep in there you die to an idiotic anime combo of a wind guard that feels more chaotic and unfair to evade then the actual boss you fought before. It took you 30 min with close calls to get there and now your runes lie there on the ground and you cannot muster the energy to fight back through all the trash to retrieve them. Another equivalent of 2 levels down the drain.

The bad camera movement if you are locked on randomly and repeatedly screws you over, there you are dead again kiss your runes godd bye again potentially.

This is indeed a misery simulator, the difficulty is not the problem.

I guess I'm way late to this realization but I don't care. FromSoftware may be leaders in some of the most amazing graphical imagery and story telling through video games. But It's lost on me and I've been gaming for over 30 years. These games are for the clinically insane and the gluttonous for punishment. FromSoftware should change their name to GasLight. I was never into Souls games before, but Elden Ring completely changed that. From the moment I entered the Lands Between, I was hooked. The world feels alive—massive, mysterious, and full of secrets waiting to be found. There’s no cluttered UI or forced direction—just pure, organic exploration. Every castle in the distance, every strange statue or ruin, pulls you in. It’s a game that respects your curiosity and rewards your instincts. I didn’t just play it—I got lost in it.
Just play it!

If the Lands Between had a Steam page, I’d give it a fistful of Runes and a resounding 10/10! I’ve plunged into Elden Ring’s vast, hauntingly beautiful world several times with different builds—each playthrough a fresh dance with death and glory. From nimble dexterity rogues to hulking strength colossi, every character felt like a new legend forged in fire.

This game isn’t just a game; it’s a lore-filled, boss-smashing, horse-riding masterpiece that stole my heart faster than a Radagon’s Greatsword swing. The thrill of finally beating a boss after countless deaths? Pure Elden ecstasy. And let’s be honest, who doesn’t love the satisfying “You Died” screen that quickly turns into “I’m coming back stronger!”?

The world design is breathtaking, the soundtrack epic, and the freedom to explore is unmatched. Whether you’re summoning spirits or dodging a dragon’s fiery breath, every moment feels legendary. Elden Ring isn’t just my favorite game of all time—it’s a way of life.

If you haven’t yet, grab your Flask of Crimson Tears, mount your trusty Torrent, and prepare to become the Elden Lord. Just beware: you might lose weeks of sleep, but hey, that’s the price of greatness!

Praise the Sun! 🌞

TLDR: 6.5/10. It's too convoluted and complex to be enjoyable at first, but once you watch enough YouTube content, you can begin playing this game without wanting to shoot your face off.

Breakdown:

Plot: 4/10

While I do like the noir method of how the main character finds out the plot of this game, as with everything else, it's not clearly explained unless you watch a 4 hour video on YouTube. I just finished the game and have a very rudimentary understanding of what the hell is going on and the mysteries raised at the start of the game don't get answered in the slightest.

Graphics: 10/10

One of the most gorgeous games I have ever played, especially playing off the Gothic Horror setting! From the various, sweeping landscapes to the intricate designs of the bosses, this game is an undeniable visual treat!

Combat: 8/10

The sheer versatility and approach to different styles of combat is greatly appreciated. I would've given this a 10 if it wasn't for the fact that most of Elden Ring's combat is a combination of rolling forever until you can hit, using pots when you get hit and rinse and repeating until you kill people. For all of its variation in combat playstyles, the general approach is the same.

Characters: 3/10

The main character is mute but all the surrounding NPCs and bosses all have enough personality to offset this, creating an immersive world where you get a glimpse of their story before the fight. However, because the plot doesn't tell every part of the story by the time you finish the game, I have no idea who these characters are from the previous previews I get, without watching those 2 hour YouTube videos.

Voice Acting: 9/10

Excellent voice acting, nothing really to add here tbh.

Music: 8/10

This one is a given, the music in this game is an absolute banger! Some of the boss fights feel like some sort of anime showdown with the kind of orchestral playing in the background!

Open World: 20/10

I had 2 ways I could rate this. I could've given this category a 10/10 and gone back to change all the Open World scores for every other game I've played, or I could simply give this a 20 and move on with my life. I went with the second route. The scale of this game is so unprecedented that it feels like it should've been in development for 10 years! There's simply not enough things to do in this game and it's easy to sink hundreds of hours exploring every nook and cranny. Unfortunately, the scale of this open world does contribute to a major downside which I will talk about in the bonus section.

Progression: 7/10

A very smooth progression scheme... after you get through the early game. The early game is a fucking nightmare, especially for someone who's new to Souls-game but after I grinded through the guides and what to do, it become very easy to move on from there. Actually, it gets to the point where if you follow enough guides and to things in order, you'll generally outscale the bosses you're fighting as the story develops.

Grindiness: 3/10

That being said, it looses the points it was earned due to the sheer grindiness of this game. Let's make this very clear; without online guides this game is straight up impossible. It's too vast and intuitive and you constantly need to swap back and forth between different videos in order to progress in this game to any appreciable degree.

Enjoyability: 3/10

While I definitely enjoyed the game after I found all the guides that I needed, I was actually quite depressed playing this game for the first 15 hours. Everything was unintuitive and I actually quit gaming for awhile simply because of how hard and weird it was.

BONUS

Quest Lines: -10

This is one the game's biggest downfalls. The questing system in this kind of completely fucked up the ass; without a very specific guide series from Its Shatter on YouTube, I don't think I would've ever finished this game, let alone advance the main story. FromSoft is too pretentious with how they want their players to interact with the game and they create very unintuitive play patterns which suck the fun out of the game and make it a chore, which I do not appreciate.


TOTAL: 65 [ABOVE AVERAGE]

Overall, it's an above average game. It easily is one of the greatest games of all time, if not the greatest, but its unintuitive storytelling make it an absolute nightmare to play without YouTube assistance.

For me, the story pulling you in and exploration has already been ruined by the controls and movement. 

Player movement is too direct and instant, but the attacks are very slow and gradual. 
You always instantly face the way you move, so avoiding enemy attacks, and attacking is confusing. You also have to manually focus on enemies, which makes more than one at a time ridiculous. 

I don't often play third person games like this, but the closest I can compare to is the Witcher 3, which was an actually balanced game most of the time, with combat dotted around the world with an emphasis on story. This like that, but everything is made more difficult on purpose and the story is dotted around the crappy combat.
Even the menus are confusing and have weird navigation buttons.

About 30mins in I got invaded by a level 56 and killed instantly, what is the point in that feature? especially since i'd just started playing and had no clue what was happening.

I had to avoid almost all enemies, without knowing where to go or finding anything of value in what seems like a vast map. Enemies every 30 seconds are used as filler rather than content. Lack of progress and stupid difficulty instead of entertainment took away from it's incredible visuals and atmosphere.

The environment and dialogue is quite interesting, and I really like the visual style. However, the game-play isn't for anyone who likes to be immersed in story and rpg-like features. It's aimed towards those who like hard games so they can boast about completing them. 
Wished they'd focused on the atmosphere and story, the actual art in the game. 
The combat and crap controls are truly awful and completely unavoidable.

my opinion: You will just get annoyed, which isn't an enjoyable experience, and isn't worth spending time on.

The biggest disappointment of my playing career. It is full of mistakes and the management is terrible. It's beyond me how such a pile of bugs could win game of the year. CP 2077 was never in such a shit state on PC as this after all these years. After the distracting texture bugs and the terrible mouse control, what finally blew my fuse was that after I disconnected the controller to continue with keyboard and mouse instead, the game still thought I was playing with a controller even after restarting. When entering the keybindings menu the game only shows the controller layout, it does not respond to escape. After a bit of struggle I found that right-clicking brings up a menu where I can select back but there again only the controller layouts are shown next to the captions. If the first 2 hours have this and so many problems what should I expect from the rest? Is this a bad joke ? :D Even at a discount it was a waste to buy it, there goes the refund.

[h1] One step forward and two steps back. [/h1] 

[b] The good: [/b] 

    * The visuals are fantastic.
    * Good music and sound
    * The world is massive
    * Cool weapons
    
[b] The bad: [/b] 

    * The combat is a step down from Sekiro.
    * The bosses are unfun. There are 9 unique bosses. The rest are recycled with minor variations.
    * End/late-game balance is awful. Ordinary enemies can kill you in 2 hits when you have over 50 vigor.
    * Input reading. Certain enemies or bosses will react inhumanly fast. It kills the immersion.
    * A quest log or an NPC log would be useful
    * Endless amount of copy-and-pasted enemies
    * Tons of recycled assets
    * There is almost no story
    * The camera does not work for large bosses

Just as the shadow tree is the secret of the Golden Law that cannot be revealed, the intertwining of Queen Marika's love and sin, divinity and humanity shapes the blood and conspiracy of the boundaries, bringing both destruction and new hope to this land. As the point of origin, it has shaped an entirely new chapter in history. The Golden Tree does not exist solely in a fantastical realm; it and its hidden shadows reflect the secrets of human history and the alternations of civilization. Queen Marika symbolizes the long journey of human civilization from barbarism to civilization, from divine rule to human governance. The Golden Tree is human civilization itself, while the Elden Ring is the epic of human civilization.

I often think about things each day, sometimes to a point that some have told me I think too much. That started with Elden Ring. When I first played this game in 2022, I thought about the details of the game like most players have done and still do. From the most clear and obvious parts of the game and how they've affected Lands Between, and especially the most vague and unexplored areas such as the land of Eochaid. Playing this game has slowly pushed to want to try out different things, primarily practicing creative skills. 

Above all else however, I want to see the world. The curiosity of seeing all the grandest details of the Lands Between, primarily landscapes; has inspired me to want to leave no stone of life unturned. Seeing the world, for each small part that it is. That's what I want most from life. If not for this game, I'd probably not be as curious as I am now. 

Thank you, Miyazaki. For all that you've created. For all those you have inspired.

Whoever may be reading this, stay curious. You can only see the world for yourself. Others can't see it for you.

Piranha killed my dino-bot.

That was the thatch that broke the brontosaurus's back. Everything in The Islands "easy" starting area #1 has eaten my face off at least twice. Dilophosaurs won't even do you the courtesy of waiting until you're dead, to begin feasting on your entrails. You're generally blinded by their poison, so you can't see it. But that's not as reassuring as it sounds. I made friends with them. I learned how to use a pack of dilos as a meat and hide harvesting machine. Remorseless and efficient, if a bit messy.

But to kill and eat my beloved dino-bot, saddle and all? Oh HECK no!  I might not have a mission in-game, per se. But I am a cro-magnon man on a mission. There is no achievement for vengeance, friends. Only surly satisfaction. They'll all pay for what they did to Mr. Roboto.  

Soon, I had cleared the shallow lagoon in the starting area. I built a raft. Time to take this fight to the high seas!  I built a cooking pot, storage, a bed and several torches for light and warmth. I would be a mobile, one man seafood processing facility. Making kibble, and never tiring of the taste of justice. I learned to keep to the shallows. I became a ghost. 

But I got lost. I keep away from land now. Getting off my raft would mean instant death. It's getting dark. I have only enough fuel to keep one torch lit. I can't stop without being attacked. I'm running out of food.

On all sides, I can hear monsters I don't have names for screaming as they tear each other apart. 

I'm scared.

I have no idea what I'm doing, but I get to ride dinosaurs.  Still mourning my first tamed dinosaur Berry, the Lystrosaurus who was mauled to death by a Rex.  RIP Berry.

----

The good thing about coming into a game late is the fact that there's a lot of fairly nice mods.  The bad thing about coming into a game late is that there's really no further development of the game, so what there is in the game is what you get, which is why mods are a great helping hand to improve your enjoyment of the game if you're not too happy with what the base game (and all its DLCs) has to offer.

Have played on almost all the maps starting with The Island - haven't fully explored the storyline DLC maps yet, but the free DLC maps were very fun.  Lost Island was nice - very big map with much to explore.  Ragnarok, Valguero, and Fjordur were the best of them IMO, and Crystal Isles was the worst (which is to say, I'll be revisiting it at some point to give it another chance).

Playing Ark solo has been a challenge, as I have seen it was built to definitely be a multiplayer experience just from gameplay alone.  Single player isn't impossible, as I'm sure with enough time and a robust enough herd (and a willingness to lose a few dinos in the effort), one can manage to conquer most anything.  Perseverance is key in any game that's challenging, such as when a Rex comes around to kill your beloved Lystrosaurus named Berry and then decides it wants to hang around your house and body for 2 in game days while you watch from a hiding spot across the river until it finally runs off chasing an unfortunate Parasaurolophus.

Get Ark: Survival Evolved and ride some dinos.

Ark: Survival evolved is a good game with terrible optimization, at a astounding 260GB FOR THE BASE GAME WITH NO DLC this game is a rescource hog and just having it installed wipes out a huge chunk of your hard drive. If they had the option to remove DLC content until you bought it this game could justifiably be worth the purchase but in it's current state it is hard to recommend unless you have an ungodly amount of space on your pc. The game itself is good, a very well paced survival crafting experience with lots to uncover and is playable with friends. However official servers have shut down since the release of survival ascended so you will have to deal with third party servers, playing solo, or playing tethered to your friends. 4/10

Dear Sunday, you are the love of my life, the bearer of my seed, the target of my binoculars. Not a day goes by when I don’t reject the throbbing masses of men, ever so desperate for a piece of my soul. “BUT NO” I shout at them! BEGONE, TH❤️T! ONLY SUNDAY!  They understand. They could never compare to you. They aren’t as pretty, as touchy, as tasty.   We have been playing a most undignified game. For the last eternity, we have sat, peas in a pod, our eyes yelled S❤️X but our mouths whispered patience. Such a charade we must do to protect the sacred idea of v❤️rgin innocence. But at what cost? We lie, incomplete, desperate, childless and dry. Our hearts yearning for a mate that hasn’t yet come.   But Sunday! You are my one! When I bought this game on the Steam Summer Sale a few years ago, I was at a bit of a low point in my life and through it, I was able to connect with a bunch of people who also enjoyed the game. Even though I don't talk with many of them anymore, the memories I made on this game are irreplaceable.

Besides my personal experience with the game, this game has proven time and time again to be not only one of the best zombie games out there, but also one of the best co-op games as well. Unlike a lot of zombie games that seem to play the same way, Left 4 Dead provides a unique experience that focuses on teamwork and is still fun to play even today, despite the game having released all the way back in 2008. I was never a fan of tactical games like Counter Strike or R6S due to the mechanical skills needed to keep up with your team and Left 4 Dead provided a fun experience that leaned further on team coordination rather than how fast a survivor could shoot an enemy or how fast their reaction time is while turning a corner. Along with this, Left 4 Dead has a colorful cast of characters who are all vibrant and stand out from each other. The story is also unique compared to other zombie apocalypse stories and allows you to take in the details as quickly or slowly as you'd like with Valve's mastery in environmental storytelling and dialog.

The other aspect I love about this game is the workshop and how much mod support the game has. Of course things can get janky with how stretched the engine is on this game, but the amount of custom campaigns, survivor swaps, weapon skins, custom mutations, and so much more never ceases to amaze me. My favorite custom campaign has to be the Crash Bandicoot campaign and is also the very first custom campaign I played. I can't even count how many times I've played this campaign and it's become an unforgettable part of my experience in Left 4 Dead 2.

While I've had a falling out with a few of the friends I've played this with over the years, I still find myself coming back to this game either to experience the fun I had back then again, or make new memories. This game, along with Valve's other titles stand as a testament to how far a game with a good set of developers and a loyal community can go. As of writing this, I hope to get more out of this game with each time I press play. I've played games for almost my whole life, and I've come to learn that games are art and should be experienced that way. Left 4 Dead 2 only reinforces that idea in me and I hope to make new memories on this game, wherever life takes me next.

Ahoy, Swoonds here.
Today, we’re talking about a game so iconic, so timeless, that even your dad with 3 DUIs and a missing pancreas has probably yelled “PILLS HERE!” in his sleep.
This is Left 4 Dead 2 — a game where the zombies are faster than your internet,
the bots are dumber than a plastic spoon,
and every mod replaces something with Shrek.

WHAT IS LEFT 4 DEAD 2?
Left 4 Dead 2 is the only co-op game where friendship dies faster than the survivors.
You and three teammates — which could be your friends, strangers, or clinically depressed AI — must survive through 5-stage campaigns full of:

Zombies,

More zombies,

Special zombies,

Zombies on meth,

And a finale that will reduce your soul to ash.

It’s built on Valve’s Source engine, which means everything is made of pure jank and duct tape.
And I love it.

The goal is simple:

Go from point A to point B without dying.
That's it.
That’s the game.
But in practice?

It’s a test of willpower, a hellish gauntlet, and a psychological experiment to see how fast a human being can scream “WHY DID YOU SHOOT THE CAR ALARM?!”

THE SURVIVORS
You get four playable characters, none of whom asked for this:

Coach – your friendly local diabetic gym teacher with a heart of gold and cholesterol of steel.

Nick – a con artist in a white suit. He is sleaze incarnate.

Rochelle – the most underappreciated and overmodded survivor on Nexus.

Ellis – a southern himbo whose brain has been replaced with NASCAR trivia and stories about Keith.

By the way, you can mod any of them to be Master Chief, Hatsune Miku, or 12-foot anime dommies — and you will.

THE ZOMBIES
The zombies come in two flavors:

Regular zombies, also known as "expendable XP drops."

Special Infected, also known as:

Boomer – a fat man who throws up on you and then explodes.

Hunter – edgy parkour boy who hates you specifically.

Smoker – stealthy smoker who ropes you like it’s a hentai.

Jockey – tiny gremlin that mounts your skull and rides you into the nearest death pit.

Spitter – spits radioactive gender fluid.

Charger – legally classified as a war crime.

Tank – a muscle-bound gorilla that throws concrete and has the HP of a small country.

Witch – a crying one-shot boss fight that you will startle every time despite being warned.

The AI Director controls everything dynamically.
Have too much ammo? Spawns a Tank.
Got too many medkits? Here’s a Witch.
Doing too well? Here’s all of them at once in a hallway the size of a prison toilet.

GAME MODES
Campaign – Classic co-op. Get in, survive, get out.

Versus – Human players control zombies. Betray your friends. Laugh as you body them with a single Charger.

Survival – How long can you survive endless waves? Answer: 13 seconds.

Scavenge – Team deathmatch, but with gas cans. Pure chaos.

Realism – No HUD. No outlines. No mercy. Like being born in the woods and told to read Nietzsche.

And then there’s Mutation Modes, including:

Chainsaw Massacre (self-explanatory),

Gib Fest (M60s for everyone),

Confogl (competitive tryhard simulator),

And my personal favorite: Hard Eight, where the game spawns twice the infected and none of the hope.

MODDING COMMUNITY
The real game isn’t in the gameplay — it’s in the workshop.
You haven’t truly played Left 4 Dead 2 until you’ve replaced:

The Tank with Shrek,

The music with "All Star,"

The Jockey with a toddler riding a Roomba,

The pistol sounds with anime moaning,

And the survivors with every combination of Doomguy, Thomas the Tank Engine, and a 2B swimsuit mod.

You can install 100GB of mods, crash your RAM, and still run it better than CS2.

SOUND DESIGN
The sounds are iconic:

The Witch’s sobbing is actual psychological warfare.

The Tank’s music triggers the fight-or-flight response in war veterans.

And every time you hear “Grabbing pills!” your brain releases serotonin.

Also:

Molotovs explode like Zeus himself took offense to your existence.
Pipe bombs make a beeping sound that attracts zombies and gives me war flashbacks.
The Charger sounds like he’s running through drywall and masculinity.

WHY IS IT STILL ALIVE?
Left 4 Dead 2 is 14 years old.
It runs on a toaster.
It still has an active player base.
People host tournaments.
People mod it daily.
And Valve keeps patching it, which is more effort than they’ve put into Half-Life 3.

There is no progression.
No battle pass.
No cosmetics.
Just skill. Violence. And a deep-seated hatred for Boomers.

FINAL THOUGHTS
Left 4 Dead 2 is:

The most fun you’ll ever have yelling at your friends.

A perfect co-op game that still has zero competition.

A love letter to the genre that somehow still has the best zombie AI in gaming.

A showcase of how modding = immortality.

This isn’t just a game.
This is a stress test for your friendships and a religious experience for anyone who’s ever thrown a bile bomb into a funnel of undead.
I give Left 4 Dead 2:

10 out of 10 adrenaline shots.
One panicked scream when someone startles the Witch.
And a slow clap for Coach, who still hasn’t stopped running.

As always, more content to come.
So stay tuned.

Witam, prawda!

Tu Krwawy Joe i dziś opowiem wam o grze, która nie tylko przetrwała próbę czasu, ale wręcz rozkwita wśród zgliszczy współczesnych shooterów – Left 4 Dead 2. Tak, moi mili, ta perełka od Valve wciąż żyje, kopie i rozwala nieumarłych z gracją, której nie powstydziłby się sam Bruce Campbell.

Zacznijmy od tego, że L4D2 to esencja kooperacyjnego grania. Czterech ocalałych, hordy zarażonych, napięcie jak przy rozbrajaniu bomby i ta nieustanna potrzeba trzymania się razem – tu nie ma miejsca dla samotnych wilków. Gra nagradza współpracę i karze egoizm, a każda sesja to inna historia, dzięki niesamowitemu systemowi AI Director, który dostosowuje tempo i poziom trudności w czasie rzeczywistym.

Broń? Miodzio. Od klasycznych shotgunów po katanę, patelnię i piłę mechaniczną – każda zabawka ma swój ciężar i feeling. A jak walniesz z molotova w środek hordy i zobaczysz te jęzory ognia... Poezja!

Tryby? Jest kampania, tryb przetrwania, versus, mutacje – każdy znajdzie coś dla siebie. A modderska scena to złoto – nowe mapy, skiny, tryby... Można grać bez końca.

A klimat? Ten brudny, amerykański południowy posmak apokalipsy zombie. Muzyka, dialogi, głosy postaci – wszystko pasuje idealnie, jak celny headshot z magnuma.

Podsumowując: Left 4 Dead 2 to nie tylko klasyk. To gra, która dalej kopie tyłki i pokazuje, jak robić kooperacyjne shootery z duszą. Jeśli jeszcze nie grałeś – nadrób to natychmiast. Jeśli grałeś – wróć. Bo zombie same się nie odstrzelą, prawda?

Z pozdrowieniami – Krwawy Joe.

I’m a 26 year old guy who has played an unbelievable amount of single player and multiplayer games of any and every genre. Like even the really boring genres that no one really likes. I’ve played this game more than any other in my life, thousands of hours on the same maps over and over again. (All on Xbox 360 so my hours here don’t compare now that I’m a dad) Every single day after school from 6th grade to 8th grade my best friend would come over and we would play for at least a couple hours then I would play for a couple more when he wasn’t over. 

I know every map,  every room, every closet, and every place I’ve somehow gotten over run that seemed safe at first. I remember so many close calls of almost being saved and having victory snatched from our grasp, and so many times of somehow surviving when I thought there was no chance. I remember barely limping away with one hp after killing the last tank in the stadium finale with my last grenade launcher round. I remember shooting my friend playing as Ellis, and the 2 computers Rochelle and Nick as they tried to get on the hard rain boats but they were taking too long and I had to think of me first. I remember getting through all of the Parish campaign everyone around me died and I am low health about to walk into the helicopter and the tank is in there waiting for me to ruin my day! 

So many memories of every possible situation I could imagine and even now coming back 15 years later and finally being able to play again I am still finding situations or moments I haven’t felt before. This game is what all games should be, fun, simple enough, and polished like crazy. Amazing physics, rag doll, death animations, progressive dismemberment and gore, audio, pacing, comedy, fear, terror, and the overwhelming satisfaction of survival against the greatest of odds will keep left 4 dead 2 as the best game I’ve ever played for as long as I’m lucky enough to play it.

The feeling of being overrun by the horde over and over while you are just trying to move down a couple hallways makes it feel like it’s an endless amount of enemies coming from everywhere. The enemy ai and movement is so terrifying and unpredictable at times it feels desperate and violent like a zombie should and like they almost never do in games. When you finally find moments of quiet you finally look around to realize the walls are covered with the pleas and cries of the ones left behind who knew they were doomed, begging for help using their own blood as their only ink. The feelings you get when no one is around to save you and a Smoker has its slimey tongue wrapped around your neck and your character is struggling to get away and you know this is it for you….. the atmosphere, gameplay, ai, music, scenery, visual effects, and pace of the game all wrap into something never seen before and something that will probably never happen again. There is literally 0% filler  or fluff and this level of pure gaming is almost impossible to replicate in today’s massive studio world with bloated budgets, micro transactions, no creativity, and no love.

Then you add on that it was released in 2008 they are still updating it, the servers are still up, and now I can play it with amazing graphics in a view I could’ve never imagined on my 1 second delay big ass box tv I started playing this on. I love this game with all of my heart and hope that the next generations continue to give it a chance and really immerse themselves as a survivor trying their best with 3 random people in the apocalypse. 

The only bad thing I can say about the entire game is that your ai companions are unbelievably stupid and bad at saving you when you go down so either play with friends or download one of the many mods to fix their AI because everything else in my opinion is perfect. 

10/10 steam make Left 4 Dead 3 and it will be the #1 wish listed and #1 anticipated game as soon as you announce

Suppose I should do a review...
Okay, so this is one of those games where you don't need any level of experience beyond just standard PvP FPS stuff to get into it. However,
-paid content includes having fun, in-game chat*, storing more than a handful of items
-lots and lotsa toxic players, they don't normally interact with people beyond dominating lobbies though
-source(TM)  jank©
Jank includes anything from the unintended demoknight, battle medic and Pootis sub-classes all the way to backstab flings, that one window on pl_frontier, and a lot of weird reasons for getting stuck on things. The game traces its roots back to a HL2 mod and as such has matured over a long time. There's a grand old well of user generated content you can get into for free on a lot of community servers, which is a great way to have fun or play warioware if you don't want to pay for it. Seriously, check out the custom maps people make, it's incredible. 

Game culture you might want to know about: 
-Friendlies: usually seen dancing in groups, crouching with melee weapons or doing other funny shit. Killing them is normally rude, unless the whole server is dancing. At that point, I'd consider it okay to re-queue for something else or start using your tauntkills.
-Pootis: a quasi-friendly species, the Pootis is found in ctf_2Fort and many other gardens of slow gameplay. Though some are un-adorned heavy players, one can easily tell a pootis by their behaviour and colourful, often whimsical plumage. They most typically sport a beanie with tassels and a sandvich in hand, with other colourful garments seen often. They are typically friendlies. If you attack them, they may stop at nothing to kill you in a demeaning way. They may attack first, in which case the winner is whoever tauntkills the other first.
-If someone dies suddenly, with no attacks made, they have used a 'killbind'. It is a common joke. To make your own:
     1- open settings from within the game. From the popup for changing controls, select [Advanced...] -> [enable developer console]
     2- with the console enabled, hit `~ key (top left of keyboard)
     3- don't worry about the code, you're not going to hack anything (probably)
     4- enter this phrase without the quotes: 'bind k kill' and press enter
                         (you can select another key to bind but k is easy to remember and not used by default)
     5- disable the developer console, it's really annoying mid-game. 

*this is a counter-measure to some serious bot issues that have, thankfully, been resolved at the time of writing. Thank you, valve

Team Fortress 2 - what firstly started as a nostalgic dive into a game of my childhood quickly turned into an appreciation post about how a game soon turning 20 years old can still be relevant and most balanced hero shooter out there.

Seriously, the game's balance is amazing, except sniper, its always sniper. That aside you can put any 2 classes against each other and both of them have a chance to win. Don't get me wrong there are types of soft and hard counters amongst the classes but depending on the positioning you take and how you decide to play with your strengths and weaknesses you have a chance to win even against hard counters of your class or at least to regroup with your team. On top of that there is variety of subclasses and interesting sidegrades of different weapons.

The problems the game had in the past e.g. Meet the Match update that removed quickplay, the whole botting thing that made casual unplayable etc. are long gone and I can proudly say casual is great. Player numbers might not be as high as they used to be, but if you fiddle with the map settings you will never notice any difference. The maps that used to be popular back when i started (2013) are still popular nowadays.

Oh did I mention that in tf2 you can mod almost anything ? Ranging from custom huds and crosshairs to custom models and hit sounds tf2 mods are on another level. I would definetly recommend using one of the huds made by the community - most famous probably being [b] budhud [/b].

Only downside that seems glaring to me is that if you are brand new player you might have harder time playing as the player base skill level has risen over the years, to which I can assure you that this game suprisingly so, has hidden MMR for casual and you will not meet them in every match. 

9/10 just because the devs don't treat it as they should - as a gem.

This will always be the best "hero" shooter, casual fun environment + comedic in voice acting and game design that are alien to modern games.
No stoic military heros; no heros that couldn't bear ill will against a mosquito; no evil heros of tragic backstory that might be just misunderstood, but instead a bunch of human psycopaths bearing a cartoony levels of hate and love towards each other.
No ultimates to cause a "Q" kitchen sink standoff; only cooldown is running out of loaded ammo; no hero sharing a role with each other; no role-locking yourself; 9 heros with sidegrades will always be more insteresting and balanced than 40+ hero rosters even when there is no real update in a decade.
Not to mention how mechanically deep some tricks can be.
It is a very old game, and still the best in the genre.

BUT it has been neglected by valve to a extent that for a good time casual was unplayable because of the aimbots and when the community was tired of valves neglect the got of their butt and actually did something with TF2 and fixed the bot crisis for now. Chaotic, Timeless, and Somehow Still Alive

Review:

Team Fortress 2 is a masterpiece of class-based multiplayer mayhem. Released in 2007, and somehow still kicking all these years later, it remains one of the most fun, creative, and personality-filled shooters out there.

With 9 completely different classes — from the sneaky Spy to the explosive Demoman to the sandwich-loving Heavy — every round is a unique blend of strategy, chaos, and comedy. The cartoonish art style never gets old, and the gameplay is fast, fluid, and endlessly entertaining.

Want to snipe from the shadows? Burn everything as a psychotic Pyro? Build teleporters and sentry nests as an Engineer? TF2 has you covered — and lets you do it all with hats. So many hats.

Yes, the game has its issues: bots can ruin casual matches, updates are slow, and Valve hasn’t shown it much love lately. But the community is still going strong, the custom content is wild, and there’s nothing else quite like a full-on payload push with a team of screaming Medics and rocket-jumping Soldiers.

Pros:

Unique, well-balanced class system

Fast-paced, team-focused gameplay

Tons of weapons, cosmetics, and maps

Vibrant community and custom servers

It's fun. Pure, chaotic fun.

Cons:
– Bot problems in public servers
– Rare updates and little developer communication
– Steep learning curve for some classes
– Aging engine and occasional bugs

Verdict:
TF2 is like that weird, loud friend from high school — a bit broken, kinda chaotic, but always down for a good time. It’s not perfect, but it’s still one of the most iconic and enjoyable multiplayer shooters ever made. Free-to-play and full of personality.

Rating: ★★★★☆ (4.5/5 — +1 if you wear the Ghastly Gibus unironically)

DayZ Standalone: The Ultimate Test of Patience, Anxiety, and "What Was I Thinking?"

⭐⭐⭐⭐⭐ (Out of 5, somehow)

Ah, DayZ Standalone. The game that gives you hope, only to rip it away faster than you can say “Zombies aren’t that scary, right?”

Let’s start with the positives: The game world is stunning. There’s a vast, open expanse where you can wander for hours, thinking you’re doing something productive… and then realizing you’ve just been chasing a chicken for the last 30 minutes. The beautiful forests and dilapidated towns are like nature's cruel joke. You will feel the tension in your chest as you creep through a dark, abandoned house, knowing that somewhere, just beyond the window, is a player with an AK-47 who will shoot you on sight for a can of beans.

Speaking of beans… food. You will spend 90% of your time in DayZ doing one of three things:

Searching for food (preferably something not expired and in a can you can't open with your bare hands).

Trying to drink water from a contaminated well (because apparently, your character isn’t immune to dysentery).

Running away from other players who look like they’re about to kill you for a can of beans.

Now, the combat. Oh, sweet, sweet combat. You think you’re prepared. You’ve got a pristine AK, a tactical vest, and a feeling of invincibility. Then you see a zombie. You shoot at it… miss. You shoot again… miss. Your aim is like a toddler trying to play darts after too much sugar. But hey, maybe you’ll hit the next zombie… or maybe you’ll spend 10 minutes crouched behind a tree, praying that the player with the crossbow doesn’t spot you while you fumble with your inventory, trying to find that one bandage. Spoiler: You won't find it in time.

And let’s not forget the joy of the game's infamously buggy physics. One minute you're sprinting through the woods, feeling unstoppable. The next, you're getting launched into orbit because you accidentally tripped on a twig. You think you’ve found a nice little shelter in a building, only to have the door decide it’s not going to open for you. That’s okay though. You didn’t need to escape anyway. You’ll just sit in your tiny, claustrophobic room as the screen fades to black from the starvation you’ve been dealing with for the past 45 minutes.

The true magic of DayZ is the community. There’s nothing quite like the experience of having a perfectly normal, peaceful encounter with a player, only for them to go full “savage cannibal” and try to stab you with a pitchfork five seconds later. Because who doesn't want to see the true nature of humanity when there's a chance to steal some duct tape?

DayZ is basically a 50/50 mix of triumph and despair. One moment you’re securing a helicopter, living the dream. The next, you’ve been killed by a guy with a flashlight because you forgot to double-tap "alt" to check your surroundings. Pro tip: Don't trust anyone. And if you do, you better be ready to get stabbed in the back… literally.

In summary, DayZ is the game you play when you want to test your nerves, your patience, and your ability to forgive bugs and glitches. But when it all comes together, when you find that one sweet moment of victory (like getting a car started or finding a pristine rifle), you feel like you’ve won the apocalypse. Until you get sniped from a hill five seconds later, of course.

10/10, would stress myself out again.

PEAK MALE EXPERIENCE

This is one of the hardest survival games I’ve ever played.

There’s a massive learning curve — it can take at least 20 hours just to get somewhat used to the game.

The game feels like living a whole different life. If you only have about 30 minutes a day, I wouldn’t recommend it.

The people you meet won’t always be friendly — true. But when they are, it can be a wonderful experience, whether they’re teaching you the basics, you’re teaching them, or you’re just playing together.

9.5/10. Would definitely recommend.

*This review is mostly based on DZSA modded servers since Vanilla DayZ is pure dehydration, starvation, disease, and death*

No other game scratches the *hardcore-survival-looter-shooter-prox-chat itch* like this game. The contrast of ultra realistic firearms ballistics, but with the jankiest world collision hitboxes & zombies, will either make you love or hate the game... for the DayZ veterans maybe a bit of both. It feels like a glitchy retro game but also modern sim at the same time.

Takes a while to get up and started with a base, pvp encounters are few and far between until you venture into cities/towns, but when you do encounter someone its pure adrenaline. One moment you're just running through the forest or looting a building, and the next thing you know you're in a gunfight holding 12 hours of loot and everything to lose, all while zombies are rushing towards you from a 100m away. No other game has made me more paranoid about losing my loot than DayZ although it gets better when you've established a base with storage. 

The sound of distant 1km away gunfire will give you a rush. The players are either the solo ghillie sniper, or the team who just rushes and flanks you on contact. If you're new, a lot of the times you won't know how you died (to that sniper) since it just cuts to black screen with no sound (can't hear the gunshot that killed you). Be prepared to use real world tactics & mechanics in this game to come out on top, eg. fire and maneuver, flanking, ambushing, concealment & cover, travelling in a spread out column formation with your group. Never sit still in the open in town. Even firearms mechanics like ballistics, zeroing, height over bore, etc. That or just rush in close range to spray and pray with an auto rifle. But seriously you'll save 100's of hours of pain, If you don't get the mechanics down in this game you're at a huge disadvantage.

p.s. Play modded servers on DZSA launcher and bring a friend.

Still a noob, but I've put plenty of time with friends on the Xbox version and I can safely say this game is something everyone should play.

The first shots rang out somewhere to the south — sharp, distant, but close enough to draw me in.

I crept up the hill slow, rifle ready, stomach growling from starvation. I had barely anything left — my canteen was empty, my stomach hollow, and in my hand, a sniper rifle with one single bullet.

When I reached the top, I went prone and scanned the valley below.

A town — broken, quiet, crawling with infected. And there he was.

A survivor.

He moved cautiously through the town, checking each house. His gear looked solid. Backpack. Vest. Rifle slung over his shoulder. He was looting, calm but quick. I stayed flat in the hill, watching him through my scope for what felt like forever.

Seven minutes.

I followed his every move. House to house. No panic. No return fire. Just methodical scavenging. He had no idea he was being stalked.

Then he stopped — stepped behind a tree on the edge of town. Probably sorting his inventory. Vulnerable.

I adjusted my aim.

One bullet. One chance.

I took a breath, held it, and squeezed the trigger.

Crack.

He dropped instantly — like a puppet with its strings cut.

No hesitation. I leapt up and sprinted down the hill.

The infected would’ve heard that shot. Other players too. I didn’t have time to check.

I reached the body, snatched what I could — food, water, ammo, meds — then vanished back into the treeline before the echoes even died out.

That day, it all came down to patience and precision.

In DayZ, survival isn’t always about having more.

Sometimes, one bullet is enough.

I have over 2k hours in this game just on this account on Steam, I've played this since 2013 on friends' PCs before I owned a PC. I played over 6k hours of DayZ on Playstation when that came out. I have purchased copies of this game for friends 5+ times over across different platforms. I think I'd probably recommend this to anyone who enjoys these 3 principle things in survival games: 
1. A hardcore survival or a completely customizable difficulty to your survival preference (with community modded servers). This game will push you to engage and learn on a curve that is very steep and sometimes makes you more thoughtful on your choices than you normally are on any other survival game. 
2. You have no UI (on a vanilla/lightly modded server) telling you to "get food" "get drink". Your story or character's "life" is up to you. You choose on what you want to accomplish and get no direction besides your character needs. 
3. You will die. A. LOT. and will be killed in the most ridiculous, stressful, and hilarious ways. But it makes you work to understand the game knowledge and how to survive longer. 

I love this game beyond measure, it's given me thousands of hours of entertainment and challenges. My favorite thing about this game, is that every character "life" is never the same. You can team up with people and become the biggest group on the server, you can team with other fresh spawns share food and water and get betrayed later on. You can become the bandit that you were killed by, You can steal peoples' shoes and amass a collection. You can do whatever you feel up to that minute and it'll feel different every time. I cannot speak higher of this games praises, legacy, and the love this community has. And hope everyone finds this review helpful and enjoys it half as much as I have. <3
