Fun until you get shot. Then it's fun again, until you get shot. Repeat until nothing is fun. Pretty much any good game could gain the same entertainment value of sudden inevitable death by setting a macro to randomly Alt+F4 for you and delete your save file. This one is not really optimized for Rogue-lite progress either; it's pretty much just Rogue-like FPS. That's common enough in PvP FPS, but you start with (basically) nothing every time, which leads into the enjoyable-enough survival crafting angle, but then randomly trashes all time invested, and it's generally enough time going into each life that it hurts. However, when you do manage to survive, or just play a community server without PvP or whatever, then it also becomes evident that the survival crafting angle doesn't actually go THAT deep anyway. Live or die, you're gonna be doing a lot of the same shit for as long as you have the appetite.

There are reasons to do it anyway, but those reasons are also too finite to justify all the mundane gripes of how actually unrealistic it is. E.g.: starving to death -- faster than you'd dehydrate -- in something like 2 hours of real time or maybe 2 days of game time -- and much faster if you're freezing, because...? Can't build a base or even drop a tent you're carrying because the ground isn't flat enough anywhere in sight? Chop down a tree of any size with a hatchet in 10 seconds, but you'll break all your hatchets, axes, sledgehammers, and maybe even your guns before you'll dent the wooden wall some jerk made out of the same kind of tree just to block off the water supply in the spawn towns, because fuck you.

And a big Fuck You Too to the playerbase. In 1212 hours, I've never had a 2-minute conversation with any of you psychos. The few of you willing to talk instead of shooting first are clearly too afraid that I'm going to kill you, and that's justified (mostly by others' baseline behavior). This game could've had all kinds of better social dynamics if you douchebags weren't wasting your lives preying on fresh spawns for some of the most pathetically invalid ego tripping PvP shooters have to offer, and that's saying something. May you all continue playing for tens and hundreds of thousands of hours until you're too physically infirm and cognitively rigid to do your harm anywhere else. DayZ can keep you.

If you want to play a game that is simultaneously challenging and ridiculously immersive...you've found it. 

The crafting system is deep but not overly complex. The survival mechanics feel intuitive without being too obvious. Your life actually matters, and players act more like how I imagine people would actually act in a zombie apocalypse -- sometimes friendly, but mostly not. 

Even with over one hundred hours in (counting experimental), i still learn something new every single time i play. 

You know that Call-of-Duty feeling of getting first shots on target -- then getting turned on and dying to an aim-assisted controller child? This ain't that game. This is a sandbox that rewards patience, planning, observation, and experience. 

Jump in. Die allot. Learn the map. Celebrate the wins. 

Welcome to DAYZ

"I installed DayZ as a joke. The joke is now my life."

I thought I was just going to try it for an hour, but oh boy, did it get into more:

I haven't replied to a single family group chat.

My girlfriend left me because I kept whispering "I hear footsteps" in my sleep.

I got fired after trying to explain to my boss that I missed work because I was held hostage in a church by three guys in tracksuits speaking only Russian.

I haven't eaten a warm meal since 2022. Everything is canned now. I even bought beans IRL.

My friends staged an intervention, but I just kept asking if they had duct tape.

And despite all that...

I can’t stop. The tension, the stories, the betrayals, the weird roleplay encounters, the panic when someone says "friendly?" but you're already aiming — it's too good.

DayZ hasn’t just ruined my life. It’s replaced it.
10/10, would lose everything again.

Good game imo if you like survival games.
There's a large social element to it as well, if you wanna chat with people then you gotta be careful. Everybody's intention in this game is to survive, and they'll do it at the cost of your life in a heartbeat, but they'll appear friendly. They'll give you food, they'll give you shelter, a home. Then in a heartbeat they'll kill you and you'll have to restart your hours of progress. Some people are well meaning though, my favorite part about this game is you can spend hours bonding with and playing with a complete stranger, and then when they die you never see them again. It adds a lot of weight to the game and makes you genuinely want to protect your buddies.

Certainly not a game for everybody, I will say though that it's a really complex survival game, there is a lot. It's the kind of game where you can spend 200 hours playing it and still be a beginner. There's so much to do, learn, and experience, and every new character is a new adventure. I have about 130 hours though, and I can already see myself getting into a rhythm on the maps I understand, but I'm still a complete beginner and have a lot to learn. 

This is one of the most unique games I have ever played, there really isn't anything quite like it.

Happy gaming!

Vanilla DayZ is intense but modded DayZ is where it truly shines.

With PvE servers, traders, missions, custom zombies, banking, and base-building mods, the survival experience becomes deeper and way more rewarding. You can actually live in Chernarus, not just survive it.

Still janky in places, but the modding communty turns this game into a sandbox of chaos, creativity, and unforgettable stories.

Must-Play Mods: Expansion, Banking, mutants, BBP, Paragon&Renegade.

Verdict: Survive, thrive, mod it till it breaks. Then reinstall 😂

Tried to play with a friend. Spent an entire hour just trying to land in the same damn server. Not join a match, not play the game, just find the same server.

This isn’t early access anymore, but it still feels like a half finished mod. The server browser is borderline useless. Same game, same filters, and we get two completely different lists. No way to refresh properly, no real fix unless you do some voodoo by joining random servers.

And yet somehow, it’s still priced like a premium title. For a game this old, it’s shocking how broken the basics still are. You’d think after a decade they’d fix the most essential part of a multiplayer game: playing with friends.

If you're thinking of buying DayZ in 2025, don’t. Spend your money on something that actually works.

🎮 DayZ: Um jogo de sobrevivência imersivo e desafiador 🧟‍♂️🌍

✅ Imersão Total – O ambiente pós-apocalíptico é super realista 🌫️🌲, com clima dinâmico, ciclo dia/noite e sons que te colocam dentro da experiência 🔊🎧.

✅ Sobrevivência de Verdade – Você não luta só contra zumbis 🧟, mas também contra fome 🍞, sede 💧, doenças 🤢 e o clima 🌧️. Isso faz cada escolha importar!

✅ Exploração e Liberdade – O mapa é gigantesco 🌍, cheio de cidades abandonadas 🏚️, florestas densas 🌳 e locais secretos 🗺️. A sensação de explorar e achar loot raro 🎒⚙️ é recompensadora.

✅ Interações Únicas com Jogadores – A tensão ao encontrar outro jogador 😳🔫 pode virar tanto uma amizade 🤝 quanto uma emboscada 😈. As histórias emergentes tornam cada sessão única.

✅ Gráficos e Atmosfera – O visual do jogo é incrível 🌄, especialmente com as melhorias recentes. A atmosfera é densa e passa a sensação real de perigo e solidão 🕯️.

✅ Constantes Atualizações – A equipe da Bohemia continua melhorando o game com correções e conteúdos novos 🔧📦, mantendo a comunidade ativa.

💬 Conclusão:
DayZ é uma experiência intensa e realista de sobrevivência. Se você curte jogos onde cada decisão importa, esse é pra você! Prepare-se para emoções fortes e histórias que só um verdadeiro sobrevivente pode contar. 🧢🔪🔥

🎯 Nota Pessoal: 9,9/10 – viciante, imprevisível e cheio de adrenalina! 💯

I rarely enjoy survivals as they get dull fast and usually no one wants to play but I have been having fun. I do play modded servers only even with minimal mods that let you enjoy the vanilla experience but add interesting stuff like more types of enemies like zombie bear in the bunkers or toxic gas bombardments. If you play modded servers avoid vanilla launcher and use DZSA which will fix most of the issues you have trying to access community servers. If you are a PvE lover and do not want to deal with having your base raided or killed by other players there are plenty of PvE dedicated servers that offer decent experiences. Some servers are made for those folks who work 40 hours a week and just wanna come home and enjoy socializing while doing minimal effort to survive (like what we call the Call of Duty servers), while others offer more challenging experiences while not making you deal with player kill from others. Just be aware that not all PvE servers have the mod for the friendly fire enabled, some you need to be careful to where you shoot. 
If you like more eccentric stuff you have servers with Jurassic mods or The Predator, Mutants, Stalker like scenarios. Tho I do have to give a good advice, avoid RP (role playing) servers, they have admins with the emotional capacity of a toddler and they will rant with you for things that shouldn't even be a discussion like you accidentally falling off a higher place...because "it is not realistic"...In sum if you play the community servers you will enjoy the game quite a lot and it won't feel like simply a walking simulator. There is a server for everyone.

DayZ My Beloved <3

If it wasnt for FRANKIEonPCin1080p I might never have fallen in love with this game as much as I did Ive been watching since 2012 and seeing how much this game evolved and changed is honestly beautiful. He captivated everything great about it and showed the crazy adventures and intense gun fights and interactions that can take place. Which I've now experienced aswell and let me just say.

Nothing and I mean nothing will bring out the pure caveman paranoia/sweat that this game can bring when it comes to trying to survive. This game genuinely does something to your brain and in a good-way it keeps you hyper alert. I've probably played 100s-1000s of games over my lifetime but nothing comes close to the feeling of pure survival and death that DayZ brings. Getting into gunfights inst always the answer but neither is trusting the person opposite you.

Its just my opinion but if you really want to experience this game in its absolute truest form then I highly recommend staying away from heavily modded servers. I think all new players should experience official vanilla or atleast lightly modded Id recommend Spaggies Or Karmacrew/Basically Vanilla. On official If you have a friend you can spawn beside eachother now, just die and spawn at the same time to be in a bubble, this is fantastic for new players IMO and doesnt involve potentially hrs for some players of trying to find each other due to zero map knowledge when they just want to play the game. My one grievance with official is that there is a problem with cheaters. I have had a couple of deaths with friends where we found it extremely suspicious and its a known issue. however do not let this put you off they are not rampant.

Get rid of any gear fear its not needed here it will only hold you back. Make your characters life as long and as crazy as possible.

And please If possible use your mic in game. most players will KOS (Kill On Sight) if you dont speak to them. Usually when people dont speak they could be up to anything (which is usually the case). If you're good at reading people this game is for you, you would be surprised what you can figure out are a players intentions by the tone of their voice and how they are acting if they will be friendly or not or potentially stab you in the back down the road most people are a dead giveaway.

Ive had some crazy journeys on this game with my closest friends and complete strangers become friends and everyone of them memorable with clips and screenshots. Theres truly nothing like this game but thats just my opinion. its a true masterpiece in survival instincts. If your looking for game that will have you on edge and have your adrenaline pumping then this is it.

Its probably been close to ten years since I last played DayZ. But I remember back then all the friends, and experiences I got to be a part of, and share with. I've been watching various Twitch streamers play this game for years, and to see how much this game has gone from what it was to what it is now, is absolutely mind boggling. I am very nervous to pick this game up again after so long, but I have been searching for a game where when I play, I have no idea the encounters, or what is going to happen. To develop a game, and put so much hard work into it to make it a new experience every single time, how could anyone get tired of a game like this!? I am excited to experience this game all over again, and learn more about all its creators, and people working so hard to make this game what it is today. And to all the future players I will come across, because the players is what ultimately shapes the experience and excitement. Much love to everyone, and happy hunting!

Man... what can I say about DayZ. 

This game has me eating tinned fish in real life just to boost immersion. I spend my morning commute scanning treelines for snipers. I literally dream in DayZ. I've racked up 550 hours over the last few months—this review might be more of a cry for help than a recommendation.

I’ve sprinted across the entirety of a fictional country with an empty double-barrel and a mag-less rifle on my back, all for a single box of .380 ACP. My most recent run ended after 30 minutes of desperate hunting and cooking, only to die of starvation because the rabbit leg was still "too hot to eat." I perished next to a perfectly good meal—peak DayZ.

The game truly shines when you stop shooting on sight and start talking to people. I recently met a stranger, fixed up a car together, and hit the road—laughing, dreaming of adventures ahead. Five minutes later, he got sniped through the back windshield.
(If you're reading this, DJ—I made it out. I found your killer. I avenged you. Miss you, brother.)

This isn’t just a game. It’s a lifestyle. A traumatic, beautiful, chaotic lifestyle where I don’t trust anyone, yet I desperately hope to find a friend. Every death is a story. Every life is a gamble. And every can of food is sacred.

DayZ is the best worst game I’ve ever played. Would I recommend it?

After 1300 hours; 

Sure, it's been a while since DayZ first dropped, and yeah, it’s a little rough around the edges. But despite being dated, it still rocks. There’s something about the atmosphere and sheer intensity that makes this game stand out, even years after its release.

PvP is as brutal as ever. Whether you're getting ambushed in the woods or having an all-out firefight in a small town, the stakes always feel high. The unpredictability of player behavior—some will kill on sight, others might team up—keeps you on your toes. And the tension of encountering another player is still unmatched in this genre.

Zombies, while not the central focus, still play a major role. They’re not the biggest threat anymore, but they can definitely mess with your plans. You’ll find yourself managing scarce resources, making tough decisions about when to fight or when to just run. That balance between dealing with the undead and surviving against other players is still very much alive.

The world itself is massive, and exploring it never gets old. The game has its quirks, sure—bugs, server issues, and some clunky mechanics that might make you question your sanity at times—but if you’re patient and willing to dive deep into the survival experience, you’ll find plenty of satisfaction here. Plus, the modding community is still going strong, which means you can find custom servers with unique rulesets to keep things fresh.

So yeah, it’s not perfect. But if you’re into intense survival, heart-pounding PvP, and the constant threat of zombies lurking around, DayZ is still a game that can hold your attention for hours on end.

Pros:

Heart-pounding PvP with unpredictable encounters

Immersive open world and survival mechanics

Zombies still add a solid challenge to survival

Active modding community keeps things interesting

Cons:

Dated graphics and clunky mechanics

Can be buggy at times

Not everyone’s cup of tea if you're looking for a polished experience

If you're after a true survival experience, DayZ has stood the test of time. It’s not flawless, but it’s still one of the best when it comes to creating tension and drama.

“10/10 — Accepted dinner in Kamyshovo. Realized too late I was the main course.”

Spawned in with a flashlight and a dream. Heard laughter near the church. Followed it. Found five people in matching raincoats singing Ring Around the Rosie around a fire.

One offered me steak. Said it was “locally sourced.” I thanked him. He wept. Another named MilkSteve asked if I wanted to “join the family.” I said yes. They cheered.

They dressed me in burlap and gave me a new name: Nibbles.

I spent the next two hours clapping to sea shanties and eating “mystery meat.” Then someone passed me a human skull and whispered, “It's tradition.” That’s when I knew.

I ran. Tripped over a goat. Woke up on the beach again. Heart full. Pants gone.

DayZ is the kind of game that makes you question your life choices. Not just in-game—all of them.
You start off cold, hungry, and lost. Much like me at every family reunion. Within 10 minutes you’re drinking questionable pond water and chasing chickens barefoot through a ghost town while a man in a clown mask sings “Country Roads” from behind a bush.
One time, I spent two hours looting, eating berries, and crafting a beautiful life for myself. Then I accidentally pressed the wrong key, vaulted off a roof, broke my leg, and spent 30 minutes crawling toward a stranger yelling “I HAVE CANNED TUNA PLEASE HELP.” They shot me. And stole the tuna.
Zombies are the side dish. The main course is paranoia. Every rustling bush might be the wind… or Chad with a Mosin who hasn’t blinked since 2019.
If you’re looking for fast action and instant gratification, run far away. But if you enjoy existential dread, inventory Tetris, and screaming “IS THIS WATER CLEAN???” at 2 a.m.—congrats, this is your new home.
DayZ doesn’t care about your plans. You are not the hero. You are a starving gremlin with a frying pan and trust issues.

10/10. Would get betrayed again.

Stardew Valley isn’t just a game—it’s a cozy chapter of my life. I’ve farmed alongside strangers who became friends, and once with someone special who made every harvest sweeter. Even after drifting in and out over the years, the steady stream of updates kept the valley alive, always waiting with something new.

For a casual gamer like me, it’s a treasure. The gameplay is intuitive yet deep, offering endless things to do—from mining and crafting to befriending villagers. Oddly enough, I even enjoyed the fishing mini-game that frustrated so many others.

Someday, I’ll return to finally hit that 100% completion. Until then, Stardew Valley remains a warm, pixelated memory of teamwork, simple joys, and countless peaceful gaming days and nights.

I just saw that Stardew Valley overtook Portal 2 and Terraria as the top rated game on Steam. So here's my negative review. Stardew is incredibly slow. Your character moves about as fast as your poor dead in-game grandpa. Time is constantly ticking which is hugely stressful. The idea that this is cozy or relaxing is delusional. It's an efficiency simulator and if you're doing well at the arcade game and it hits 11pm you'll get kicked out of the bar and lose all your progress. The relationship sim aspects of the game are terrible. You have to love bomb someone with gifted items on a daily basis. It feels like such a waste of time and offers nothing in return like interesting dialogue or decent roleplay. The mine is the best part of the game which is sad because there's nothing much to it. Compare it to, e.g., Terraria, where you can explore a variety of biomes, fight diverse monsters and bosses, and build a home using hundreds if not thousands of different block, furniture and wall sets. Stardew Valley borrowed its only good concepts from Harvest Moon, and tbh I'd rather play that, it's way cuter.

A Heartwarming Escape into a Peaceful Pixel Paradise

Stardew Valley is nothing short of a masterpiece in the world of indie gaming. Created by a single developer, ConcernedApe, this charming farming simulator offers far more than just planting crops and raising animals—it delivers a deeply rewarding, peaceful, and emotionally rich experience that players can sink into for hours on end.

From the moment you arrive in Pelican Town, you're welcomed by a vibrant world full of character, mystery, and possibility. The pixel art is gorgeous and nostalgic, paired beautifully with a calming soundtrack that evolves with the seasons. Whether you're tilling the soil, mining deep within the caverns, fishing by the river, or forming bonds with quirky townsfolk, there’s always something meaningful to do.

What truly sets Stardew Valley apart is its depth. Beneath its cozy surface lies a thoughtful game full of choices, consequences, and hidden stories. Each character has a distinct personality and background, with relationships that evolve in heartfelt ways. You can even get married, start a family, and help restore the town to its former glory—all at your own pace.

Stardew Valley is a perfect blend of relaxation and engaging gameplay. It respects your time, rewards your curiosity, and encourages creativity. Whether you’re a casual player looking to unwind or a completionist aiming to perfect your farm, the game offers something special for everyone.

Rating: ★★★★★ (5/5)
A timeless gem that proves games don't need high-end graphics to deliver unforgettable experiences.

Honestly I can't describe the feeling I had after reaching perfection on my save file with the Stardew Valley Very Expanded mod pack...it was an unforgettable experience. First year is spend just kinda setting up getting back into the groove after a couple of abandoned save files. Second year I started getting to know the towns folk, and starting the third year I slowly began the journey towards perfection...and what a journey that was. Honestly I wouldn't do the game justice if I tried to describe it....Play it. Get a feel for the unmodded version and if you feel that you need more content than this mod pack is beyond amazing. Biggest of bows towards Eric and the whole modding community

[h1]🛸 Among Us – Review[/h1]

[b]Among Us[/b] is the kind of game that snuck into the party wearing a spacesuit and took over the entire evening. Originally released in 2018 with barely a blip, it exploded in 2020 thanks to streamers, memes, and the perfect storm of global lockdown boredom. And let’s be honest—it’s [i]still[/i] fun to ruin friendships in zero gravity.

[hr][/hr]

[h2]Strengths[/h2]

[list]
[*][b]Brilliant social gameplay[/b] – The core concept is simple and perfect: complete tasks… unless you're the imposter, in which case, sabotage everything and lie through your teeth. It's Mafia in space, and it works like a charm.

[*][b]Anyone can play[/b] – The controls are minimal, the rules easy to grasp, and the games short enough for casuals yet intense enough for hardcore bluffers. It’s endlessly accessible.

[*][b]Chaos = comedy[/b] – No matter how serious people try to be, the result is always hilarious. Accusing your best friend with zero evidence? Classic. Getting voted out for [i]walking weird[/i]? Peak gameplay.

[*][b]Cross-platform and free options[/b] – You can play on PC, console, and mobile together. And on mobile, it’s free—with optional cosmetics. That’s a low barrier to entry for hours of entertainment.

[*][b]Constant updates[/b] – Roles like Engineer, Scientist, Guardian Angel, and Shapeshifter add variety. The addition of new maps and modes (like Hide and Seek) has kept the game fresh long after the meme peak.
[/list]

[hr][/hr]

[h2]Weaknesses[/h2]

[list]
[*][b]Not fun with the wrong group[/b] – The game lives and dies by the players. A quiet or overly serious lobby? Dead. Randoms who quit mid-match? Rage-inducing. It's best enjoyed with friends or a Discord crew.

[*][b]Trolls and toxicity[/b] – Public lobbies can be messy. Accusations fly, people rage-quit, or just spam nonsense. When it’s bad, it’s [i]real bad[/i].

[*][b]Task gameplay is forgettable[/b] – Let’s be real: doing the tasks isn’t fun. It’s just a reason to move around the map. You’re not here to calibrate wires—you’re here to throw shade and gaslight strangers.

[*][b]Repetitiveness[/b] – Even with updates, the core loop doesn’t evolve much. After a few matches (or a few dozen), the novelty can wear off—unless your group keeps things spicy.
[/list]

[hr][/hr]

[h2]Overall Impression[/h2]

[b]Among Us[/b] is lightning in a bottle: simple, chaotic, and pure social dynamite. It thrives on group energy, hilarious misunderstandings, and the universal joy of yelling “[u]It wasn’t me![/u]” with a dead body right next to you.

It’s not a deep game, and it’s not meant to be. It’s a digital party game with just enough deception to spark both laughter and rage. And sometimes, that’s exactly what you want.

[hr][/hr]

[h3]Score: [b]8.0 / 10[/b][/h3]

A wildly fun social experiment with a short shelf life—unless you’ve got the right crew. [i]Among Us[/i] isn’t always “game of the year” material, but it’s a classic in the “chaotic fun with friends” category.

Among Us is a fun and engaging multiplayer action/strategy game that's consistently updated with new content and collaborations. In this game, crewmates work together to complete tasks while trying to figure out who the impostors are (who could be 1, 2, or even 3 players). Meanwhile, the impostors try to sabotage and eliminate the crewmates before they finish all their tasks.

One thing to note: on free chat servers (which are the most commonly used), swearing is often prevalent, but there's a chat filter available that censors offensive words. That said, some servers may have undesirable or disruptive players, so it's worth being cautious.

Overall, I mostly recommend this game—just be aware of the occasional chaos that can happen online.

The game itself has managed to entertain for the time it has been around. Game still has some bugs kicking around. However the real issue right now is actually trying to join an English chat lobby with actual English talking players, They pretty much do not exist right now. I think for the next update the devs should consider finding a way to segregate other languages, Not being able to speak the language in a lobby in a social deduction game is not fun at all.

On another note I think devs should add something that shows you if your friends are online and maybe a join friends game option. I still love this game but right now I will have to give it 3/10 due to chat filters being useless and the game being unplayable. Maybe when this changes I will change this review or maybe even just remove it. But until then I would not recommend this game for English speaking players.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

Storymode is perfect and there's nothing I would ask that needs to be changed. Graphics are beautiful, there are tons of detail in everything including the NPC interactions, even footprints and tracks you or your horse leave behind in the different elements. The story is unlike any I've ever come across and I love it so much. The only issue I have is with Red Dead Online mode.

The graphics are the same as storymode but it's the currency and leveling system which ruin it for me. It takes hours just to get 100 bucks and that's only if your wandering around looking for missions or hunting and selling all of the time. All of the things you'd want to buy; clothes, outfits, accessories & weapons are at INSANE prices and some you can't even buy without having GOLD which by the way is given out to you in decimals. If that isn't bad enough you can only unlock some clothes when you're at a certain level, some are easily lvl 40-60. That's with everything including the weapons and horses as well. Don't even get me started with the horses and weapons. You get stuck with a horrible horse when you first log in which while you can say that's fair, like I said with the money being so hard to get, some horses are easily 1000 dollars and some of them aren't even that good for a price like that. You would have to be spending many in real life days on the game just to buy a horse. You can try find some wild horses but they are just as bad as the one you log in with. If you want to do bounty's get money quick you'd need to pay 15-20 gold just to get a license to do it. WHAT? Arthur Morgan could do bounty's in storymode yet he didn't need a license. I get if its to make it so you have to work a bit harder online but hell.

The players are also an issue. Most of the players you find on there either try to kill you or your horse and your lucky they ignore you. You could just shoot back at them if it weren't for the fact the guns just don't work the same as they do in storymode. You have to shoot players twice as much and animals are worse, especially if your new to online and have the default guns that they give you. There are also so many mod menu users it's mad. Almost every session there's at least one that messes with me or my horse. I've had moments where I was walking my horse and randomly blew up. Not to mention my horse can get de-spawned randomly and at times I would get teleported off the saddle. I don't know if that last one was a modder doing that to me or if it was just a glitch but it was still very annoying nonetheless.

Anyways, those are my thoughts and opinions on RDR2. Hope you all the best.

This game truly is one of, if not the most immersive open-world games I’ve ever played. The story it tells will hold you so tight and refuses to let you go. Arthur Morgan is an amazing example of what every game developer should aim for when creating their protagonist. His views on the world are always evolving and his growth is so tangible that the player feels it with every mission and choice made in the game. It’s a rollercoaster that you never want to get off of. You can experience it at any pace that you wish. You can get absolutely lost in the world of RDR2 in the most amazing way possible. The side stories you encounter along the way reach out and grab you and you never want to say no. The environment is stunning and you’ll find yourself wanting to explore it until you leave no stone unturned. There are truly no words to describe how amazing every aspect of this game is. As someone else said here, the only down side of RDR2 is that you can only play it for the first time one time.

It's a good game. I don't think it's quite as great as most seem to, but it kept my attention for a while. The story was pretty good, but I got so sick of Dutch that I didn't finish. I liked the world, but it was open world more like Ubisoft than something like KCD or Fallout. The gameplay loop is decent, but the travel times are extremely long for every little thing. It's frustrating to go way out and only carry one large item back, then make the trip again.

I experienced far more glitches here than in Cyberpunk. The sky does this flicker thing where a big chunk repeatedly goes black. I haven't experienced this in any other game. I have read that it's a common occurrence on PC only (see: "horseshoe in the sky").

I don't think this is the GOAT by any stretch, but I think it's worth a buy when on sale.

Skip this company if you ever lose access to your old email.
Rockstar offers no real customer support when it comes to recovering your account. There’s no phone number to talk to a person, and all support relies on having access to your original email — even if you've spent money on games. If you lose that email, you’re basically locked out forever. I’m extremely disappointed in their support system and how little they help loyal customers. Be warned before buying any future games from them.

My first attempt at playing this game was rough. I got to chapter 4, said damn this is dull, and gave it up. That was 4 years ago, now, and decided to give it another go.

Off the rip, I'll say the game mechanics and controls are rough, at best, and horrible if I'm being fair. If you're someone who cannot handle really tedious, and often mind-boggling, mechanics in a game, you likely won't make it past the first couple of chapters. Gunfighting is not really fun, slow-walking through buildings and opening every single drawer or cabinet to look for loot that you grab individually (if the game will even focus on the item to grab it) is goofy, and don't even get me started on the Karma/Law systems because I probably won't stop complaining for hours.

If you are someone who has enough patience to look past these short-comings, and see the game as less of a game and more of an interactive HBO series, then you may find the appreciation that I did for the story, the characters, and the world at-large. This is not a good game, it is, however, one of the finest pieces of story-telling I've ever experienced outside of a book or show/movie. The tale of Arthur Morgan is the masterpiece, not the game.

The story of Arthur Morgan and the company he keeps made me laugh, made me cry, and made me angry. Sometimes, I experienced all of that in one mission. I have never grown so attached to fictional characters in my entire life, and that includes my horse (R.I.P. Bullet, you were a finer stallion than any outlaw deserved). By the end, I cared about these misfits, and where their lives would lead. 

Arthur Morgan's internal conflict is ultimately decided by you, and whichever dog you decide to feed, so you may not have the same journey that I did, but you will be provoked to consider your actions and the consequences they bring throughout the journey you lead. Good or bad, some choices may not be so easy to make. You decide the kind of man Arthur Morgan was, and what legacy he leaves behind. You may even find sometimes it's not about what is necessarily "good" or "bad," but what is right and what is wrong, and sometimes those lines aren't as clear as you may think. It may be the right thing to stop and help some poor woman lost in the wilderness, but that decision may cost you more than you bargained for.

Is the game perfect like so many make it out to be? Hell no, partner -- I've already stated the game itself is not really great -- but, is the story one you are likely to carry with you for years to come? Absolutely, friend -- you will never forget the bonds you forge with the fictitious and eccentric goons you meet throughout your journey in the boots of Arthur Morgan. I hope you are prepared to question your own morale compass, friend. Don't make it about where you're going, make it about how you get there.

I bought this game thinking it was Cowboy Skyrim. IT IS NOT. I also thought it would be a lil silly pow pow rootin' tootin' cowboy time. It kind of is, but it is a HEAVY and somewhat serious shooter game. But don't be intimidated if you suck at those. I was utter dogcrap at shooter games when I bought this a week ago, but this game is SO forgiving. No spoilers here, but I impressed myself at some of the stuff I've pulled off since I started, holy crap. Just learn about guns and which ones are appropriate for each activity. 

Keep in mind this game has some frustrating bugs that are either relatively inconsequential or easy to work around, and be prepared for a surprising emotional journey. I am in love and am grateful I stuck it out.

Hire more people, fix your own problem. If you are a small company with a lot of clout, you clearly are having an issue keeping up with demand. If you are not going to push your team, you need to hire more people. I will not change my review until I see significant change behind the scenes, because as it stands your "State of the Game" updates are not only misleading and often full of BADLY WRITTEN FLUFF, often written in a way to get your hopes up greedily for cash grabs that miss the whole point of why people like Terraria in the first place. We don't want your board games, we don't want your manga, we don't want "Terraria" plushies. As it stands, since you haven't done an actual update in years, I couldn't see myself ever doing something like that to support a company I hate because of how they actively "string me along" and "get my hopes up" for zero reason. I feel like the devs have been on autopilot for a very long time and need a wake up call.

I used to love this game.

Now I can honestly say I wouldn't recommend it to anyone. I think they are lying, and even if they aren't -- there will be a lot of people who will die of old age before seeing them actually update this thing. They lie and lie and lie all along they way, setting a standard of lack of transparency that many games in the genre now have standardized. 

I dislike the lack of transparency about development. It has gotten ridiculous for this game I used to love, and in kind you have gained an actual, honest-to-Gods enemy.

Ahoy, Swoonds here.
Have you ever wanted to beat God to death with a yoyo while wearing a wizard hat made of bee parts?
Do you enjoy deforestation, dynamite-based mining, and using a fishing rod as an interdimensional weapon of mass destruction?
Then I’ve got just the game for you:
Terraria – aka “2D Minecraft for people with trust issues and 800 mods.”

🎮 THE PREMISE
Terraria is a sandbox survival nonlinear roguelite boss rush RNG simulator capitalist time sink, where the goal is simple:
Turn the natural world into a theme park of violence and industry.
You start with nothing — not even pants. Just a copper shortsword, a dream, and a man named “Guide” who will later be ritualistically sacrificed to open the gates of Hell.

It’s charming.
It’s simple.
And it spirals into absolute cosmic insanity within five hours.

🔨 GAMEPLAY
Dig.
Fight.
Build.
Suffer.

Repeat.

At first, you’re punching slimes with a stick.
By the end, you’re curb-stomping Lovecraftian horrors in a minecart while blasting EDM and firing lasers out of your ass.

Terraria has progression — but it’s not linear.
It’s prehistoric cave drawings to sci-fi nuclear power level escalation.
One minute you’re farming pumpkins, next minute you’re fighting the Moon Lord, a kaleidoscope of eldritch eyeballs that turns your screen into an acid trip sponsored by Satan.

🔥 COMBAT
Every weapon in Terraria is someone’s fetish:

Boomerangs? Check.

Yo-yos? Absolutely.

Bee guns? Mandatory.

Guns that shoot swords? Yes.

Swords that shoot guns that shoot bees? Getting warmer.

You want melee? Ranged? Summoner? Mage?
Play your way — or pick all of them and become a war crime on legs.

Enemies scale from “annoying slime” to “sentient solar eclipse” to “why is there a tree trying to kill me with its face?”

🌎 WORLD
Terraria’s world is procedurally generated, which means you will never find your house again.
Expect:

Biomes like Corruption, Crimson, Jungle, and the Post-Apocalyptic Mushroom Cult

Weather events like acid rain and goblin invasions

And seasonal holidays where everything tries to kill you, but festively

You thought spelunking would be fun?
Enjoy falling face-first into a spider den, or a trap that turns your internal organs into external ornaments.

😇 BOSSES
Each boss is a milestone.
A moment.
A deeply traumatic, screen-shaking memory.

Eye of Cthulhu: Eyeball with rabies

Skeletron: Angry IKEA chair with PTSD

Wall of Flesh: Summoned by throwing your only friend into Hell. Cool mechanic.

The Twins: Because one Cthulhu eyeball wasn’t enough

Plantera: Killer weed

Moon Lord: Galactic slap fight with a god

Every boss drops loot. Every loot drop unlocks more power. Power that lets you fight even worse things.
This is called game design. Or addiction. Possibly both.

🏠 BUILDING
You can build:

A village

A floating castle

A giant phallus made of obsidian

A functioning lava-powered squirrel trap
Terraria’s building system is so deep you can create pixel art, contraptions, or a murder dungeon that violates the Geneva Convention.

Also, don’t forget to build housing for your 37 NPCs, who will sell you bombs and lore, and then immediately die in a Blood Moon while screaming about prices.

🧪 MULTIPLAYER
Play alone? Sane experience.
Play with friends? Full anarcho-industrial clown fiesta.

Expect:

3 dudes nuking the world to “farm faster”

1 guy building a museum no one asked for

Someone summoning the Moon Lord at 3 AM while everyone’s AFK

Trust no one.
Especially the guy who insists "I know how to do this boss solo." He doesn't.

"Are video games art" is a question that's been debated since the dawn of the medium. Some people say that video games are definitely art, as they can portray a story, a message, a feeling, just as well as (if not better than) other mediums. Other people say that video games are simply a waste of time, more of an indulgence than an experience. While I definitely fall in the former camp, I will admit that sometimes I use video games as the waste of time that some people say they are.

I got Terraria around four years ago, for a price that I'll disclose later. It was more of a "yeah I have money left in my wallet" kind of purchase, being bought after I already spent money on another game (I think Hollow Knight, but I might be misremembering). I tried playing it around a month later, and, while I could definitely see why I had heard such great things about the game, I dropped it for a while because it was too hard for me. Said while passed by, and I picked it back up again. It took a lot of blood, sweat, blood, tears, and blood, but I finally got a handle on the gameplay, and I finally fully grasped how good of a game this was (and still is). Then I dropped it for a while. Then I picked it up again. Then I dropped it for a while again. Then I picked it up again again. All of this revisiting added up to the amount of hours that it says I've played, which, at the time of me typing this review, is 1534.9 hours. That's the most amount of time played out of all of my Steam library. That's more time than I've played Rain World, my favorite game of all time. It's more time than I've played Stardew Valley, a game that's famous for its absurd amount of quality content. Hell, if not for Palworld being my Pokemon detox because damn those dex cuts hit me embarrassingly hard, then my playtime with all non-indie games in my library doesn't put a dent in Terraria's number, and even with Palworld, it's pretty damn close. And the kicker is, I got it for 2 bucks in a Black Friday sale (or 3, I may just be remembering the first digit of $2.99, but I'm pretty sure it was 2)! That's about 7.5 hours (or 5 hours, if I'm misremembering) per CENT that I paid, which is absolutely ludicrous, and at full price, it'd still be ludicrous at 1.5 hours per cent!

This is, by far, the most value you can get for your money out of any video game I've played. It's not perfect, but it doesn't matter that it's flawed. Sure, its difficulty curve is kind of wack. Sure, the developers sometimes choose really weird cliffs to die on. Sure, some items have a drop chance that's twenty times less likely than the chance of flipping 2000 coins and getting neither heads nor tails on any of them. But none of that matters, because, despite all of it's flaws, it's still a quality experience that lasts you a long-ass time. So, if video games truly are a waste of time, then this is the best video game of all time. There is truly no reason to not buy it.

tl;dr: I'm puzzled by the popularity of this game and would've refunded after 30 minutes. Since I was playing with a friend, we tried and even had a bit of fun. This game could be great but feels like beginning of Early Access. If you want to craft/survive together, play Minecraft or Grounded.

Long version: I'm happy for everyone who can enjoy this game. For me, the interface was the absolute worst I have seen since the beginning of (videogame-)time. After one hour, we watched some videos because we were 100% sure we're doing it wrong. Alas, we weren't.
Even if I could get around this, I still don't understand the progress in this game. After 2 hours, we had the double jump and platinum gear. After 7 hours, we had double jump, platinum gear and the same gear made from 7 other metals which were all inferior.
I won't even start about the combat... Minecraft in 2D is a great idea but to me it seems like the clunky frame of the game was never fixed, instead the content was just continuously expanded and ppl were used to how it plays. Otherwise I cannot fathom the positive reception of the game.

Terraria provides an excellent adventure both solo and with friends. With an incredibly deep world with a large amount of unique boss fights to encounter and dungeons to delve in Terraria is what many people hoped that the survival genre would become. Sticking to a 2D plane has provided Terraria with a unique atmosphere and a new way to build and explore a world compared to the hundreds of 3D survival clones. From the deep NPC systems to the iconic sound track combined with the low price it is hard to not encourage someone to try this game. 9.5/10

A Timeless Adventure Packed with Endless Possibilities

Terraria is much more than just a 2D sandbox game — it’s a sprawling adventure that combines exploration, crafting, building, and combat in a beautifully pixelated world that constantly surprises you. From the moment you start chopping trees and mining ores, you quickly realize this game has incredible depth and complexity hidden beneath its charming retro aesthetic.

The world feels truly alive, filled with unique biomes, dangerous enemies, and epic bosses that provide a rewarding challenge without ever feeling unfair. The progression system is incredibly satisfying; each new weapon, armor set, or tool unlocks fresh ways to play and explore. Whether you enjoy constructing sprawling bases, diving into treacherous caverns, or battling terrifying bosses, Terraria offers it all with an ease and polish that keeps you hooked for hours on end.

The multiplayer experience shines, too. Playing with friends turns the game into a shared journey filled with cooperation, strategy, and plenty of laughs. Plus, the community mods and frequent updates add even more content and polish, extending the life of the game well beyond its initial release.

The soundtrack and pixel art are delightful and timeless, perfectly complementing the gameplay and enhancing the overall atmosphere. Terraria strikes a rare balance — it’s accessible for newcomers but has enough depth and secrets to satisfy hardcore players.

If you love games that reward curiosity, creativity, and persistence, Terraria is an absolute must-have. It’s a true indie masterpiece that continues to evolve and captivate years after its release.

10/10 – Endless hours of joy and discovery.

If anyone told you before that Terraria is "2D Minecraft" than they've got no clue what they're talking about.

While there are undoubtedly many similarities, Terraria's gameplay focuses much more on the rpg gearing, crafting and fighting side. You can obviously build a nice house and just chill but that's just one part of what this game offers.

For me and many others, Terraria is a game where you farm gear, fight bosses with it, get better gear from those bosses or unlock new ways (NPC's, ores, mobs...) to farm and then kill stronger bosses to unlock even stronger gear.

The game offers a large variety of unique enemies and events that get more complex the further you progress.
There are often many possible ways to progress at any given time, which the player must choose themselves. Or not, It's up to them.

Different milestones, usually bosses, change the entire world and make it more dangerous over time (But you also get more valueable stuff).

For people who like to build great structures there are a ton of tools and blocks for that aswell. So your builds are (almost) only limited by your creativity. But for people who don't enjoy building and would rather just grind and fight, there is no requirement to build anything besides maybe small houses so you can have NPC's move into your world. Those are useful after all.

Terraria has great modding support (Look up t-modloader on the store page) which adds countless hours to it's already more or less endless amount. A vast variety of content mods exist given this game's long lifespan and add incredible content to an already incredible game. There is really a mod for anyone, no matter what you want to add to the game.

I'd personally recommend "finishing" the game in vanilla once before you jump into mods but I'm not your mom. Do whatever you want.

Overall a 10/10 that I happily come back to every few months and it never gets old for me.

Fitting in with the sea of blue here, but Terraria deserves all the praise it gets, and I'm not particularly knowledgeable on it. I treated the game at first as 2D Minecraft, because I didn't know any better, and to a degree still treat it like that (just interrupted at times by boss fights to shred). The music, visuals, and gameplay all fit, all contiguous parts that bring you into the world, which can be as relaxing or as stressful as you choose to make it.

Plenty of people I know will beeline for the next boss or milestone, immediately grind for the next big armour set for their class, and continue. I barely know what comes after Skeletron, I've spent a number of hours just making a cool house in the middle of a snowy biome with weapons that are just enough to fight off the slimes and zombies prowling around. And I enjoyed it that way, as can you if you aren't a fan of the breakneck pace that veterans tend to play this game at.

But there's plenty of content in that regard too, you build yourself up until you fight a giga boss called the 'Wall of Flesh' and then unlock Hard Mode where you unlock better movement options and pretty much start the process again to build up to a far more impressive final boss. I've only done this whole loop once, because I got carried, but it's fun.

And besides vanilla, there's a very active modding scene. People have their opinions on expansions like Calamity and Thorium, but I don't have enough investment in the game despite my hours (which are dwarfed by anyone who actually got into Terraria) to mind any of the problems they may or may not introduce. Pick some that look cool if you find vanilla dragging on a bit, as always.

For the price, it offers plenty for anyone interested, but still goes on sale every so often if you feel you're still reluctant to fork over the cash. I recommend.

Terraria is only $10, however the Gameplay, the Unlimited Hours of Time you'll be Blessed with Playing this Game; not just in Single-Player but in Multi-Player too? The Soundtrack for this Game? Absolutely Moving too, Everything Truly does just Fall into Place so Wonderfully and you'd simply be a Fool to not Play this Game!

I, Way More than Just Highly Recommend this Game, You'll make some Incredible and Unforgettable Memories playing this Game, whether by Yourself or with Others.. The refund request and downvote reasons are:

[list]
[*] The Interface is far too small, barely readable text, icons are almost invisible and the UI cannot be scaled up. Very frustrating

[*] No early success as in e.g. Minecraft: Even the first tool to craft is a pain (dig a mile in hope there's iron - I had to google what do I need for that to realize it's not just wood + dirt + some crafting)

[*] The crafting menu is very weak - should be Minecraft-like to be a nice something

[*] It really IS Minecraft in 2D (was only an impression, but read up the opinion of those who played the game much longer than I did and they confirmed the suspicion), and if I want to play Minecraft... you know... I do play Minecraft...
[/list]


All in all, not a bad little thing, so try it yourself: Give it a go and I wish you all the best in hope you'll enjoy the game, it's just not my piece of cake.

Terraria is a chaotic, creative adventure where every decision matters.
It constantly makes you think—what to build, where to explore, how to survive—and rewards that thinking with epic weapons, wild boss fights, and satisfying progression. The magic system and gear variety are amazing, and it all exists without needing mods. If you love planning, battling, and discovering cool gear, this game is a dream.

10/10 – It made me fall in love with everything it has to offer!

If you like decorating: Try Terraria!
If you like challenging bosses: Try Terraria!
If you like exploration: Try Terraria!
If you like suffering: Try Terraria! With some mods (TModLoader)!
If you don't like any of the above: Try Terraria anyway, you might enjoy something else along the way.

Gameplay-wise, definitely my favorite game out there. There's something for everybody in this game. Whether it be lots of interesting areas to explore, difficult bosses, or building, you'll find something. There's also a lot of different potential play-styles and difficulties for everybody. There's also lots of space for socialization if you play mulitplayer. With what's in the vanilla game, you could find hundreds, or even thousands of hours worth of content. Mods, however, are a whole other story. With mods, you can get practically unlimited content for free. If you decide to get Terraria I'd highly recommend going in with minimal spoilers. I find it very enjoyable to explore the world, finding all the fun little features. Avoid searching anything up online unless you're really stuck, to the point where you're not progressing at all. The achievements guide near your inventory and the Guide NPC can both be useful tools for figuring out what to do next. (Tip: Give the Guide NPC an item and it'll show you everything you can craft with it. Might seem obvious, but I didn't find this out for a while and I wish I knew earlier.)

“40+ hours in… still not done, but I love this game .”

Terraria is one of those games that looks simple at first glance… and then suddenly you’re 40 hours in, surrounded by chests full of weird loot, and trying to solo Duke Fishron at 3AM.

The game just doesn’t let you go. Every boss fight feels like a mini adrenaline rush, and the sheer amount of gear, biomes, secrets, and progression systems is overwhelming in the best way possible. There’s always something new to build, mine, discover, or get destroyed by.

Some highlights for me:
	•	Boss fights are actually fun, not just difficult for the sake of it.
	•	Weapons are creative and satisfying — from yo-yos to laser rifles.
	•	Constant sense of progression and discovery.
	•	Great for solo, but next level with friends.

That being said… I’m still not done. Empress of Light and Duke Fishron absolutely wrecked me — not gonna lie, those fights are way beyond what I expected.

I really wanted to finish the game solo, but I think I’ve hit my limit. Maybe it’s a skill issue (lol), or maybe it’s Terraria gently reminding me that this world is better conquered with friends.

Minor downside:
	•	Not everyone will vibe with the 2D pixel style or the open-ended progression. If you need your hand held constantly, Terraria might throw you into the deep end.

But for me? It’s been an unforgettable ride so far, and I’m nowhere near done.

10/10 would get stomped by Empress again. Bring friends.

terraria is a really good game, with great bosses and a good gameplay loop. Even after you beat the game, you can still do things like build a house or kill sidebosses or main bosses for specific loot. It is also fun to play with friends, although i can hardly do that since i have no friends. I would like console crossplatform, or for consoles to be able to add servers, but otherwise it is a great game. Also, to anyone who says its "2d minecraft" i dare you to find half the animals in this game in minecraft. Oh, you cant, because being 2d allows this game to have way more features than minecraft without it being quite as difficult to code (i think, i actually dont know but im pretty sure). So please, try Terraria, and give it more than a few minutes before you say its boring, because it can be a little boring at the start.

Payday 2 is an absolute blast to play—a chaotic, fast-paced 4-player co-op shooter where the goal is simple: get rich or die trying. You and your crew pull off all kinds of high-stakes heists, from robbing banks, jewelry stores, and casinos to infiltrating art galleries, nightclubs, and even top-secret military facilities. You’ll be stealing everything from cash and gold to drugs, priceless art... and yes, even nuclear warheads (not joking). You can try to go stealthy or go in guns blazing (though let’s be honest, we all know which one is more fun). The soundtrack is pure adrenaline. There’s a ton of customization too, with a huge variety of weapons, attachments, skins, and unique masks to collect as you progress. The gunplay is tight, the gameplay loop is addictive, and there’s always another score to plan. One downside: a lot of the content is locked behind DLC. If you want the full experience with all the best heists, you’ll likely want to grab the Legacy Collection, which bundles most of it together. All in all, Payday 2 is a fun, chaotic ride that I highly recommend to fans of FPS games and co-op mayhem. So gear up, don’t act dumb, and enjoy the music.

💰 "Get In. Grab the Loot. Get Out—If You Can!"
🌟 Rating: 8,8/10

PAYDAY 2 isn’t just a shooter—it’s the ultimate heist simulator, packed with adrenaline, chaos, and endless tactical choices. Whether you're going loud or stealthy, solo or with friends, every mission feels like a Hollywood crime blockbuster gone off the rails (in the best way possible).

🔫 Gameplay:
Robbing banks, stealing art, cooking meth, or hacking servers—every job offers a unique experience. The gameplay is deep and addictive, with skill trees, customizable loadouts, weapon mods, and perks to suit any role. Want to be a silent infiltrator? A walking tank? A tech wizard? The choice is yours.

🎭 Freedom & Teamwork:
No two heists are ever the same. You can ghost your way through with suppressed pistols and hacking tools—or kick the door down and unleash mayhem with LMGs and explosives. But be warned: teamwork is essential. One wrong move and you’ll be swarmed by SWAT in seconds.

🎨 Style & Content:
With over 100 missions and years of updates and DLC, PAYDAY 2 is bursting with content. The visual style may not be ultra-realistic, but it nails that gritty, high-stakes underground crime vibe perfectly.

🎧 Soundtrack & Atmosphere:
The soundtrack absolutely slaps. Tracks like “Razormind” or “Break the Rules” pump through your speakers while alarms blare and bullets fly. Combine that with intense voice lines and ambient chaos, and you’re right in the heart of the action.

💡 Conclusion:
PAYDAY 2 is the go-to game for anyone who wants high-octane action, smart planning, and beautiful chaos. Whether you're running perfect stealth jobs or laughing through a botched escape, every moment is unforgettable.

🎭 Put on the mask. Make your mark. Become a legend of the criminal underworld.

Payday 2 is the ultimate co-op heist game that delivers nonstop action, strategy, and adrenaline-fueled chaos. Whether you're stealthily sneaking into a bank or going in guns blazing, every mission feels intense and rewarding. The game gives you tons of freedom in how you approach each job, and the variety of heists — from bank robberies and art thefts to armored truck hits — keeps things fresh. There's a massive selection of weapons, gear, and skills to customize your loadout and playstyle, and the progression system is deep and satisfying. Playing with friends makes the experience even better, as communication and teamwork are key to pulling off perfect jobs. With years of content updates, DLCs, and community support, Payday 2 has grown into a feature-rich, highly replayable game that still holds up incredibly well. If you've ever wanted to live out your Hollywood-style heist fantasies, this is the game to do it in.

Many designs are malicious and are made to be difficult for the sake of being difficult.

For example, to carry a corpse, you need to wrap it in a body bag before you can carry it, which is just like taking off your pants to fart.

Did you ever play games like "Hidden&Dangerous" and "Hitman47" series? Are these classic mission behind-the-enemy-line and assassination games designed like this?

In addition, the player cannot close the door after opening it, which is also deliberately designed by the designer to increase the risk of being discovered by the enemy when sneaking in, but is it reasonable? Not at all. I would like to ask all the players who have played so many FPS games, which one can't close the door after opening it?

Speaking of rationality, it is illogical to have only a bunch of monitors in some stages but no control room at all. It is also unreasonable to say that the designer forgot to arrange the control room, because not all stages are like this, which seems quite malicious, and it seems that the game difficulty and uncontrollable randomness are increased through the mission content generated by this random number.

Moreover, as long as the guard is killed, someone in the control room will definitely use the radio to ask about the situation, which is also very deliberate. I just want to ask all the players in which movie or TV series have you seen such a sneak plot?

Can you imagine that the monitor screen monitored by the security personnel in the control room actually includes the monitoring equipment for each security personnel? This is an unimaginable and exaggerated design. In my opinion, the control room will only ask the patrolling guards for details unless the guards show an abnormality that cannot be judged within the line of sight of the monitor. Who would have such a coincidence that the control room would call to ask about the situation every time the player kills a guard?

Moreover, the act of supervising every patrolling guard is a serious violation of human rights and privacy. Which security company's guards have to be supervised by the control room even when going to the restroom? Because of this, the design team deliberately made an unreasonable design that the control room would identify the player as being invaded and sound the alarm if the player killed the guard more than 4 times.

Even if the mission of this game is to invade the enemy gang organization, as long as the stealth process turns into a full-scale battle, the police will definitely intervene, but this is also a very unreasonable design.

I would like to ask all players, in which gang fight movie have you ever seen the gang call the police after the gang was attacked by the enemy? Even if it is the ordinary people outside, they will be very happy when they see these gang members who usually show off their power and bully men and women being beaten and killed, so how could they call the police to help them? Isn't this a joke? Similarly, in my opinion, this design is made to be difficult for the sake of being difficult, there is no other reason.

The design of ECM Jammer is also unreasonable in this game, because using this thing to interfere with the surveillance screen in the control room is exactly the same as the player directly smashing the monitor with a stick. Since the game designer believes that the guard will send someone to check the situation when the monitor screen disappears, why don’t they want to investigate the situation when they see the screen is interfered with?

In fact, in modern society, in many movies and TV plots, as long as they sneak into places with these monitors, the intruders will use hacking technology to remotely control the surveillance screen of the control room directly, and implant fake surveillance screens so that the guards can’t see the real screen, so that the intruders can freely enter and exit the area monitored by these monitors. If you use a jammer here, isn’t it the same as telling the enemy that you are invading?

This game is actually just a re-skinned L4D, except that the zombies are replaced by armed policemen.

Unlimited police force = unlimited zombies; the zombies charge horn every once in a while = the interval between each assault; various special zombies = various SWAT special units.

Why is stealth so difficult in this game? Because stealth is too easy, players can't play the gunfight escape part similar to L4D.

If you think I'm wrong, you can continue to give me some clown badges, it's okay, because to me it just shows how ridiculous you are.


In order to increase the difficulty of the game, the designer deliberately made the robbery settings more realistic; but at the same time, in order to increase the difficulty of the game, many details are deliberately ignored.

Maybe many players like this style, but at least I would rather play GTA's robbery than "authentic" robbery games like Payday.
Although GTA's robbery is simplified in many places, it is more reasonable in other designs.

For example, except for The Cayo Perico Heist which was changed by the Indian studio, other robberies in GTA are relatively reasonable.
For example, The Heists(apartment), the police will not break into the bank and attack directly during the robbery.

It seems unreasonable, but in fact, this design is more reasonable.
Because there are always civilians in the bank, and there will definitely be hostages inside during the robbery.
Then what about Payday? The police just forced the attack without saying anything. In which movie or TV series have you seen the police treat human life so carelessly?

Indeed, when the police in GTA attack the players, they also don’t care whether they will accidentally hurt civilians. There is nothing wrong with the design that kills the players as the first priority, but Payday obviously raised this unreasonableness infinitely in the design of the robbery. No wonder some players pointed out in the thump down reviews of Payday that the game is actually just a L4D shooting game with zombies replaced by SWAT.

Moreover, in the Payday series, there is no part about how the player escapes from the police, because the player only needs to put the money bag in the car to pass the mission.
In GTA, the player has to drive to escape the police's 4~5 star wanted to pass the heist mission.

Payday adds unnecessary stealth elements and details the process of suppressing or assassinating guards, crippling surveillance systems, etc. during the robbery process, which is actually just unnecessary trouble for the players. 

After all, in the real world, which country's robbers would play such a stealth game when robbing a bank? They just put on a hood and go into the bank to pull out a gun and start robbing.

Stealth elements are only found in some movies or TV series such as "Ocean's Eleven", "Phantom Thief", and "007", because that is stealing, not robbery. Robbery is done openly, while stealing is done secretly.

Unfortunately, Crime Boss is just like what the thump down giver said, a second-rate copy of Payday, a work made by slightly simplifying Payday's heists, and most of the details and settings can be seen in Payday's elements.

Moreover, many detailed preparations for GTA's Heists also require players to participate in actual activities, rather than skipping them directly like Payday or Crime Boss. Even the weapons and equipment used in The Diamond Casino heist can only be unmarked. The design of Payday and Crime Boss's heists seems to be completely ignoring whether the police will find out who did those work later by those trails.

Payday 2 is a thrilling, cooperative heist experience where you and your crew execute bank robberies, heists, and other criminal activities with friends or strangers. The game’s mechanics are solid, and the variety of heists, weapons, and customization options provide plenty of replay value. The intense action, strategic planning, and teamwork make every mission feel rewarding, especially when everything goes according to plan.

However, the game does feel a bit dated at this point. The AI can be frustrating at times, and while there are tons of DLCs, some of them feel like essential content that should have been included in the base game. The grind can also feel repetitive after a while, and newer players might feel overwhelmed by the sheer amount of content and unlockables.

Overall, Payday 2 is still a lot of fun, especially if you enjoy heist games and have a good crew to play with, but it does show its age and requires patience to fully enjoy.

Verdict: 7.5/10
A thrilling heist game that still delivers fun, but it could use more polish and accessibility for newer players.

PAYDAY 2 puts you in the shoes of a professional criminal mastermind, teaming up with friends to pull off daring heists ranging from bank robberies to high-stakes hostage situations. It’s a thrilling mix of tactical planning, fast-paced action, and teamwork that keeps players coming back for more.

The heart of PAYDAY 2 lies in its cooperative multiplayer gameplay. Each heist can be approached with stealth or all-out gunfire, allowing teams to coordinate and adapt to changing situations. The game offers a deep skill tree and extensive weapon customization, letting players tailor their roles—from stealthy infiltrator to heavy firepower specialist.

Missions are varied and dynamic, featuring objectives like hacking, bagging loot, and escaping under pressure. The AI is challenging, requiring players to communicate and strategize to succeed.

While the graphics aren’t cutting-edge, the gritty urban environments and detailed character models create an immersive atmosphere. The sound design is outstanding—every gunshot, alarm, and shouted command adds tension and excitement to the chaos of a heist.

Pros:
-Intense, cooperative gameplay with great team dynamics
-Deep customization of skills and weapons
-Variety of heists and multiple approaches to objectives
-Strong community support and regular updates

Cons:
-Graphics and animations feel dated
-Steep difficulty spike in some missions
-Solo play can be challenging without teamwork

PAYDAY 2 is a gripping and highly replayable co-op shooter that shines brightest when played with friends. Its blend of tactical planning, explosive action, and rewarding customization makes it a standout in the heist genre. If you love intense multiplayer experiences with strategic depth, PAYDAY 2 is well worth the time.

Heist, teamwork, and chaos—PAYDAY 2 delivers adrenaline-fueled criminal fun.

I will recommend this game a million times over. It has got to be one of my favorite games and I've probably sunk more time into this one than any other. Now you may be thinking, "115 hours being the most?" well you see, I originally had the game on Ps4 and had dumped loads of time in that shit-ass version, it is obsolete in every single way. I believe 7 years behind on updates, leveling is EXTREMELY slow and I won't add more just because that's not what this is about. But the point is even on a far inferior version I have been able to spend an extensive amount of time on that version and now that I've had access to more recent content, and many improvements overall, it's just far better. The game is obviously way better with friends as with any game but Payday 2 is really not bad to play solo, I usually play solo and find the AI teammates to be above competent and can really take a lot of damage and carry bags for me. The game for sure feels clunky given that it's over a decade old and was developed on a game engine FOR RACING GAMES those maniacs. But if you are somehow questioning whether or not to buy it, buy it anyways. It goes on sale for 3 dollars last time I checked and I believe that the entire DLC collection is about 10 or 15 dollars on sale with the game as opposed to over 100 dollars.

Very, very fun, and there's plenty of content IF YOU HAVE ALL OF THE DLCs. It's kind of comical how little the main game is compared to the 74 things you can buy besides it? Almost every gun is going to be hidden behind something. There are of course, *other* ways to acquire these, but I'm not going to mention them. Not that they're difficult to find.

Let's then, for the sake of this review, assume you have all of those. The game runs like a dream, owing to its age and ability for newer hardware to pretty much brute force anything, though harder modes still get crazy enough that you should probably set a corpse limit or risk dropping to the 50s even on something like my 4060.
The content of years and years of those paid DLCs is here, such that if you start now, you won't be running out of things to do for some time (though you might not have many or any people willing to accept a completely fresh character). I personally run this game with a group of friends, but Steamcharts reports 33-34k concurrent players as of writing this review, so it's not dead by any means.

You go into missions which have the same objectives every time, though certain elements of the objectives may be randomised, as well as the enemies that drop in being constant barrages of different groupings and special enemy types. You know what this formula is, you have a thing you want to do and you have a bunch of trash mobs, tough guys, specialists which incapacitate you, and specialist annoyances to deal with while you do it. Every objective and side objective completed is extra cash for you, multiplied by whatever difficulty you're running on. I tend to enjoy the general gameplay loop of mowing down the hordes so much I'll full clear almost every heist I run, and on the bigger heists, the optional stuff often pays  far more than the contract itself, so it's incentivised.

The main gimmicks come from your skill and perk decks. Perk decks are fixed 'this is what your playstyle is' lines of upgrades which take eons to grind up but define your build at its bones. Stuff like getting Dodge (percentage chance to ignore getting shot) or turning all your armour into health and almost all damage into a DOT you can chug alcohol to ignore, stuff like that. There's tons of builds like this, some are better than others (hi Stoic, my beloved), but as long as you aren't sweating at the highest level of difficulty, you're gonna be just fine with whatever build you want to run. Again, do try to have friends along so that the people who still are playing (who likely are those sweats) don't want to kick you instantaneously. Skills, on the other hand, is a much more freeform system that are all small upgrades that escalate into some really insane ones. Like a small buff to your armour turning into functionally infinite ammo for yourself, or the ability to turn a police officer into a friend turning into a functionally immortal health fountain. Go nuts.

Now, I have 54 hours in this game. I skipped some of the grind via mods (you can allow cheaters in your lobby if you want, it's kinda all over the place and very easy) because by the 50 hour mark I did not have my first Infamy yet. That's the prestige system for getting to level 100. I had like 70% of one perk deck completed and I was level 74 or something? I just wanted to start having fun with a full build, so I skipped all the way there, but if you don't do that, expect to have this grinding going on until probably the 80 hour mark.

Payday 2 is inherently silly with a number of its guns and melee weapons, the crap you're doing in the first place (raiding the White House to get a bunch of pardons and retire scott-free?) and you can lean into or out of that as far as you want. You could be a full on actual criminal mastermind with some reasonable choices of weapon, small bits of armour and trying to scout out the place first, do everything quiet. Or you do what I did.

My team was the following:
Me - Immortal drunk with a flamethrower, minigun, and greatsword. My weapons were blue and red, and I had no regard for civilian casualties.
Friend 1 - Leech or Tag Team or something, swapped builds every round, most times a semi-mobile fella with two shotguns in his slots. Leech made his ability to somehow get hit by everything beneficial for the whole team, and he stacked Doctor Bags enough to never go to jail on top of being able to revive himself almost every time. Tag Team meant he just pointed at me and an exit and I mowed down 48 officers to heal us both to max.
Friend 2  - Akimbo explosive shotguns and a fucking bow? He erased Bulldozers, which were the primary issue for either of our other builds,  since I had to focus on the helmet point blank with a minigun to get them down.

This was one of the first M-rated games I was actually allowed to play growing up (it came out when I was 12). Legendary game, legendary heists, legendary community. Probably the least toxic multiplayer experience out there. Randoms are usually great about coordinating and working together, chat is usually active enough for people to consistently communicate.

Weapons feel consistently fantastic, ammo management feels hectic on Mayhem or higher difficulty but you never end up in the Killing Floor situation where you're totally out and have to sprint 3 miles to find an ammo box. Progression feels consistent and rewarding - you're always unlocking new swag.

Get your life together and buy this game if you haven't yet.
