Here is a very good ham sandwich recipe if you are looking to zest up your day.

Bread – I recommend seeded bread for maximum flavor and some added texture too.
Honey Mustard Mayo – Wondering what condiment goes on a ham sandwich? Some people do mayo, some do mustard, but I like mixing them both and adding a dash of honey too!
Red Onion – Very thinly sliced. This adds a nice crunch and a punch of flavour.
Tomato – Some nice juicy tomatoes to prevent a dry sandwich.
Cheese – Here I use a slice of smoked cheddar (Applewood).
Ham – Good quality deli-style ham. I use two large slices, just to keep it the star of the show!
Watercress – This goes perfectly with pork. I have used rocket/arugula in the past though which works well too.
Seasoning – A good pinch of salt for the tomatoes, and a pinch of black pepper on the ham.

PAYDAY 2 is the kind of game that’s just fun to jump into when you feel like causing some chaos with a crew. It’s got that satisfying “just one more heist” loop, loads of weapons, gadgets, masks, and enough missions to keep you busy for hours. Coordinating with friends, pulling off a stealthy bank job, or going full loud and messy – it delivers those classic heist movie vibes.

That said, it does feel kinda dated. The graphics are showing their age, the UI can be a mess, and some of the systems are unnecessarily complex or grindy. There's a TON of DLC, which makes the whole package feel a bit bloated unless you’re all-in. Still, the devs have supported it for years, and credit where credit's due – the game’s still getting love.

Not a masterpiece, but a solid, enjoyable experience – especially with friends. If you’re into co-op shooters and don’t mind a bit of jank, PAYDAY 2 still holds its ground.

Game is generally pretty good... Except for the fact that they decided to "patch" the game a year or so ago and COMPLETELY BROKE HOLDOUT AND CRIME SPREE. Good luck getting every achievement when entire modes crash quite literally 95%+ of the time. 

It WAS perfectly fine. So WHY did we need to change it? Why did we need to 'fix' it? Development was halted years ago and yet the team felt the need to 'fix' the game all of the sudden when Payday 3 reviews were terrible? Coincidence? Personally, really doubting it.

All in all, I'd love to recommend the game. I love the game. It's great. But with devs deciding to still put patches in the game that 'fix' certain builds they think are too overpowered or 'fix' game-modes by making them unplayable..? 

Just go back to the way things were. Sure it was a buggy mess but it was a PLAYABLE buggy mess. Now, a large portion of the game is so unstable that it frequently crashes and completely locks your mouse requiring you to literally create a new desktop and task manager the game without using your mouse in order to get it back or to just restart your entire pc. 

These are FREQUENT issues. I have not had a single play session in YEARS that didn't have multiple people crashing multiple times in just a few hours. All of this was without mods too. In fact, we even installed mods for the sole purpose of trying to make the game crash less. 

Revert to the way things were a few years ago and it's great. But don't stop development of a game and then give half-assed patches that completely break the game and then say you don't have the resources to fix what you broke because they're all focused on the other game.

If you’re looking for the ultimate co-op heist experience, Payday 2 is where it’s at. I’ve put hundreds and hundreds of hours into this game, and even now I find new builds, new strategies, and new ways to make the cops’ lives miserable. There’s just nothing else like it — and that includes Payday 3.

This game is loaded with content. Dozens of heists, hundreds of weapons, perks, mods, masks, and playstyles. Want to go in loud with LMGs and full armor? Do it. Want to sneak through a bank without anyone knowing you were ever there? Good luck — but yes, you can. The freedom is wild, and every mission feels different depending on your crew and your loadout.

The progression system is incredibly rewarding. You’re constantly unlocking stuff — new gear, skill trees, infamy levels — and every change you make actually affects how you play. Combine that with a deep modding community and endless build variety, and you’ve got a game you can play for years.

Now… about Payday 3.
I wanted to love it. We all did. But let’s be real: it launched with a fraction of the content, way fewer features, and somehow removed a bunch of things that made Payday 2 great. No real offline play, basic matchmaking, shallow customization — it just felt half-baked. Meanwhile, Payday 2 is sitting here with 10 years of updates, polish, and chaos that still holds up incredibly well.

Sure, it has its rough edges — the engine’s old, and some stuff can be janky — but it works, it’s fun, and it’s been supported like crazy. Even now, it gets love from both the devs and the community.

If you’re new to the series, don’t start with 3. Start with 2. It’s cheaper, deeper, and just straight-up more fun.

Payday 2 is a great co-op shooter with tons of replay value. The action is intense, the variety of missions is impressive, and working together with friends to pull off a loud heist is a blast. There’s a lot of depth with the weapons, skills, and gear customization, and it’s really satisfying to build your character around a certain playstyle.

That said, the stealth missions are bad. Not just tricky - they’re frustrating. The detection system is inconsistent, guard paths are unpredictable, and the margin for error is way too small. It feels out of place compared to how fun and flexible the rest of the game is.

If you stick to loud heists, Payday 2 is absolutely worth playing. Just be ready to either skip or suffer through the stealth parts.

PAYDAY 2 is a classic that everyone should play a least once. It supports a lot of different play styles, you like some stealth? This game has you covered, you like to go guns blazing? Yep, you can, do you wanna beat cops up with a giant spoon, a minigun and a multi-shot 4 rounds rocket launcher? YES YOU CAN. and don’t even get me started with the mods.

The problems:

This game has some weird things that don’t make any sense, you can’t close doors(its not a problem but it’s just….weird), the AI is really random(especially civies), playing solo is really annoying if there is a lot of bags to move etc and the biggest problem im my opinion is that the game is HEAVILY DLC DEPENDENT, you can’t play 70% of the game if you don’t have the DLCs(and there are a lot of them).

Overall, PAYDAY 2 is an incredible game even if you don’t like heist games, its pretty fun and it’s almost perfect, also don’t play PAYDAY 3.

There's no other way to put it: This game is simply legendary. Over 20k concurrent players 12 years post release is all the proof you need that this is a one of a kind experience. Be it with friends or randoms, I had hundreds of hours of fun with this game as a kid. Just looking at the menus already floods me with nostalgia. 

It was impossible to deliver a proper sequel to this game considering the sheer amount of content built up for well over a decade, and yet Payday 3 is so much worse than anyone could've imagined. Honestly, there's no reason for it to exist at all. This game is all you need. If millions can still enjoy WoW with its potato graphics, there's no reason why this game can't continue living on and on. Just look at Payday 3's player numbers compared to this game and try not to laugh. 

This is the definitive Payday game.

[h1]Colossus[/h1]
[b]Key features[/b]
[list]
[*]Lots of missions (heists),
[*]RNG is not your friend,
[*]Paradise for achievement hunters
[/list]
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2174496323
[b]Hundreds of hours[/b]
There's like 80+ missions set in most various places: warehouses, crowded shops and gigs, multiple banks (naturally!), military structures, open streets, trains and even hospitals. Finishing them alone takes many-many hours, now double that amount because you can complete them either stealth (masterpiece music is not included) or painful gun blazing (loud).

PayDay2 offers huuuge selection of weapons. Lots of pistols, rifles, throwable ninja stars, spears, rocket launchers and even bbq forks, flags, electric gloves and so many more. And the best (hilarious) part is - they are quite usable and not just for lulz. 

Pair the above with impressive skill tree (classic alike more damage, more ammo, extra speed, health, blah-blah-blah) and sprinkle with perk system - you got yourself extremely flexible and working build (replay value STONKS!) 
Now you can run w/o armour, dodge bullet storm and forget about ammo. Or let turrets do all the work for you. Or stun all cops around you and carry on with objectives. 
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3049363551
[b]Better with friends[/b]
Playing PD2 in 2025 might be stressful. Public lobbies aren't cooperative and chaotic. Grab a friend (or three!) and enter dark offices with loud whispers "guaaard!!1". 

PD2 might feel unpleasant. Its characters do not have facial animation. Driving feels extremely repelling and that with several missions relying on car escapes. Hostages can clip through walls and then guards spot them afar, alerting everyone and quickly ruining your session. PD2 also punishes you for being greedy - picking up and tossing loot bags isn't fun. 
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2632906617
[b]Let's talk about RNG. It doesn't cooperate either. [/b]
Say, you start a mission, need to find a password. You search everywhere, crouch behind cops, find it eventually, on your way to enter... uh, you've been seen and hello mission restart. Now you head straight to the door and enter the password thinking it's the same. Heh, it's not! Because you entered wrong password, security is alerted and the mission is failed again. You start it anew, going to the room where you found the password note earlier... and it's not there. Search again!

RNG in PD2 plays enormous part. Objective items change locations and so do cameras. Passwords vary and god damn drill keeps breaking... Happens in those 80+ mission, embrace yourself!

But! Even with all these "tiny" drawbacks PD2 is superb. It is a feast for achievement hunters - difficulty related trophies stack, there are many creative ones, lots based on weapons and solving secrets (serotonin is real), as well as some speedrun completions. 
These days PD2 goes on sale so often and so low, it's genuinely worth to play.

If Tim Burton directed a survival reality show and let the contestants slowly go insane, you'd get Don't Starve Together. This game doesn’t hold your hand—it slaps it, steals your food, and leaves you arguing with a talking flower while freezing to death.

I’ve spent 300+ hours trying (and hilariously failing) to survive. Whether it’s starving in winter because we forgot to plant enough carrots, or accidentally summoning Deerclops on Day 28 and watching our base turn into charcoal, every session is chaotic brilliance.

The hand-drawn art is timelessly eerie, the sound design is haunting yet whimsical, and the co-op experience… pure gold. But beware: it’s not for the faint of heart. If you rage-quit over burnt toast, this might not be your jam.

🪓 Pros: 
+ Rich, punishing survival mechanics
+ Unique characters with real personality
+ Mods add infinite variety
+ Every death is a story

💀 Cons: 
- Learning curve steeper than Wilson’s sanity drop
- Some updates leave old bugs kicking around like unwanted guests

Final verdict? DST is a beautiful, brutal fever dream—and I can’t stop waking up in it. 9/10, would eat monster lasagna again.

I usually love hard games to be clear. But I prefer them with a goal and end sight as a personal preference.

'Get experienced friends they make it fun' but I played with three of them and they went off doing whatever while I gathered wood and rock because, well, what else am I supposed to do? I can't spend time learning more in-depth mechanics because I'm getting attacked non-stop when I dare. I can't craft because the other's were prepping for fights and farming etc.. When I do dare and do get creative I am immediately slapped down for  the audacity, and not in a fun way that makes me want to repeat it. More a grumbling that I have to get everything I can before it's consumed by the wilderness. Without any tutorial that isn't me just flat out reading things online I don't actually know what anything is, or does.  Not a bad mechanic in theory but there's not much breathing room for a new player to engage and learn things, so I don't feel there's any other option available in-game. Combine that with some awful pathing, enemies movement being so quick they can't be clicked on in time, accidentally inspecting teammates because they came to help me causing even more deaths, and I wasn't really having a good time.

Hate the sound design playing the same cues over and over and over again. Thirty seconds pass? My strongman is weak again with the same sound cue. Have a small companion trailing you? Hope you LOVE Footsteps Audio playing nonstop in your ear at a oddly loud volume for not messing with any audio. That said all other music(ambient tracks and enemy cries, when not ganging up on me eight to one so it's overlapping sound bytes) are nice. The animations when they fire off are very fluid and the stylized art has a lot of love put into it.

The skill trees are nice but seem a little bloated in design.

Playing with others meant my internet, which is usually fine and yes I did check it, magically hit the rocks and did nothing. Constantly stuttering and randomly retreading ground. Slow animations constantly causing death, stuttered loops that made me re-click over and over frustrated out of my mind. Regular crashes and non-responsive in my whopping three hours of play. Call it a skill issue/clown award moment but it did pile on for me.

I did get experienced players to carry me after a bit that didn't click either. Doing busy work while they slowly got bored too, knowing the game and quickly overcoming early challenge with our base, then goofing around trying to hatch a bird egg just to see if they could before bouncing. I don't blame them. Other people love the game, and good for them! But I did not and won't recommend it.

Tips and tricks for the interested:

-If you're new just read online, get experienced friends to play with, or go on the easiest mode possible to wander and explore while you can

-Flower crowns are lovely for sanity

-Gather Flint immediately. Make an Axe, and Pickaxe. 

-Berries regrow so if you have the option, save any vegetables for emergencies and go for berries

-Crock Pot is great

SORROWFUL BE THE STARVING

If ur belly gnaws with the void of hunger
If ur sanity crumbles like stale breadcrumbs
If ur graveyard of worlds lies littered with the bones of Wilsons
Don’t Starve Together shall claim u, whispering: "Just one more night"

I, too, was once well-fed.
I, too, planted seeds with hope, danced with Beefalo,
and dared believe the darkness was my friend.
Yet here I kneel—a husk draped in Rabbit Ears,
my pockets full of Rot,
weirdly proud of my 17th demise-by-Goose.

🌑 THE UNHOLY TRINITY
Hunger

    A gnawing abyss.
    Berries mock you. Rabbits laugh as they dart.
    Your Crock Pot—a cursed altar—demands sacrifice:
    "Three twigs and a nightmare… for Meatballs?"
    This isn’t sustenance. It’s edible despair.

Darkness

    Charlie’s velvet claws.
    Shadows breathe. Fingers brush your neck.
    The lantern flickers—always as sanity snaps.
    You’ll huddle by the fire. You’ll weep for daylight.

Chaos

    The true deity.
    Deerclops at Day 29. Your base? Splinters.
    A "friendly" firefly ignites the forest.
    Your friend, starving, eats your last Pierogi.
    All is ash. All is beautiful.

☠️ SACRED SUFFERINGS (Highlights)

    *Permadeath: Watching your corpse decay as a ghost while friends ignore your woeful moans.

    *Winter: When hope freezes solid. (Also your toes.)

    *The Hounds: Hell’s doorbell. Always ringing when you’re naked and afraid.

    *Wortox: “I ate your soul. For healing. SORRYNOTSORRY.”

    *Caves: Where sanity goes to die… and depth worms throw the funeral.

⚰️ VERDICT

    10/10 WOULD STARVE AGAIN.
    This game didn’t just break me.
    It taught me the sacred geometry of panic-farming.
    It made me cherish the Goose that crushed my skull twelve times.
    It gifted me resilience (dubious), ingenuity (desperate),
    and an eternal craving for Monster Lasagna.

Now pardon me, Forsaken Ones.
The Nightmare Cycle approaches.
My Beefalo horn thirsts for another charge into oblivion.

Sorrowful be the stomach. Heavy be the log stack.
So Mote It Be. 🔥🪓

This is the LAN party game.

It is a fun game, though it can be frustrating at times. I like how it's one of those games that is somewhat accessible to a new player, even someone who isn't really good at games. Make your world really easy and simple, play around in it, get your feet wet, then put it back on normal settings and get killed over and over again. And then when you get a feel for that, check out the content of this game, which is fairly extensive, or go and play as one of the other dozens of options for a player which brings in unique challenges and abilities.

Just make sure you get some friends, because while you can certainly play this game solo... it's truly meant to be enjoyed among friends. While by no means is it a requirement, some quality of life mods can make for a good experience too.
if you like playing hard games with your friends, this game is perfect for you.

I've been playing this game since I was 15 years old, nearly half my life including all the iterations of the dont starve series. Just one of my favorite games of all time. I played a bunch of the amazing special events they had like into the forge and into the gorge. Just have had a blast revisiting it time and time again. They constantly update the game and continue working on it. 

I remember when each character came out and I got to try them. I've pretty much convinced every friend I've had to try the game and play it lol. Really love the art style and all the music. I've always appreciated the world gen/sandbox options since you can make a fresh experience by changing the spawn rates in an already procedurally generated world. I have also always appreciated the ability to change your environment such as permanently chopping down trees and the aspect of certain non-renewable resources.

I love the design of the bosses and how special it is to discover how to encounter the bosses. Every action has a consequence has always been a feature.

Truly just one of the most badass games of all time. Love yall <3

Don't Starve Together is one of the most unique survival games out there. The Tim Burton-like art style, eerie atmosphere, and wide variety of characters and creatures make every playthrough feel different.

Playing with friends adds a lot of fun (and chaos), but the game doesn’t go easy on you. There’s a steep learning curve, and the lack of tutorials can be overwhelming at first. Still, once you get the hang of it, surviving each season feels incredibly rewarding.

The devs are still actively updating the game, adding new content and improving balance. If you enjoy challenging survival games and don’t mind a bit of trial and error, this is definitely worth picking up.

🚫 Not Recommended (unless you're a masochist such as myself who thrives on pain, suffering, and emotional devastation)

I’m going to say this once, loudly and with the emotional stability of a starving raccoon: I do not recommend this game. Unless, and hear me out; you are the kind of person who puts hot sauce in your eyes for fun, considers taxes a hobby, and thinks "emotional damage" is just spicy seasoning for your soul.

“Don’t Starve Together” is not a survival game. No. It is a slow-motion breakup with reality, served on a beautifully hand-drawn plate of despair and bees. So. Many. Bees.

🌲 MY JOURNEY INTO MADNESS:
Day 1:
"Gather twigs," they said. "Pick some flowers," they said.
It’s cute. It’s whimsical. I named a frog. I was doing great.

Day 3:
My campfire went out while I was crafting a hat made of grass. A shadow demon shanked me in the dark while whispering eldritch riddles. I respawned next to a spider orgy.

Day 7:
I made a meat effigy. I don’t know why. I think it was to prepare for the inevitable, which came 20 minutes later when my friend, whom I trusted, lit our base on fire trying to cook a carrot.

Day 12:
A tree came to life and chased me halfway across the map. I asked it to stop politely. It did not.

Day 16:
Winter arrived. My thermal stone turned cold. My soul turned colder. I fashioned a coat out of beefalo fur and my friend’s broken trust.

Day 20:
We were attacked by dogs. Why are there dogs?! What do they want?! I died again, but spiritually this time.

💀 THINGS THAT HAVE KILLED ME IN THIS GAME:
Darkness

Spiders

Tree monsters

Freezing to death

Overheating

Starvation (ironic, I know)

Bees

Frogs

My own friends

A sentient penguin horde

A moose-goose. Yeah. That’s real.

🧠 MY MENTAL STATE:
You know that meme with the guy in the burning house saying "this is fine"? That’s me. Except the house is made of twigs, the fire was started by my teammate trying to cook a berry, and the guy is now haunted by hallucinations of Charlie whispering Latin backwards.

👥 MULTIPLAYER? LOL.
You think playing with friends will make this easier. Wrong. It just means you’ll have someone to blame when they pick all the flowers and summon a forest god to annihilate your camp because they wanted to "make a pretty wreath."
Teamwork makes the dream work... unless that dream is a fever nightmare about starvation and pig people.

📢 FINAL THOUGHT:
This game will test your patience, your friendships, and your sanity. It's beautiful. It's cruel. It’s a handcrafted sandbox of torment wrapped in Tim Burton’s art style and sprinkled with goose trauma.
If you want a fun, relaxing, cozy survival game, go play Stardew Valley.
If you want to feel like a raccoon in a burning dumpster trying to juggle flaming meatballs while hallucinating shadow wolves, then Don’t Starve Together is for you.

Don’t Starve Together takes the uncompromising survival experience of Don’t Starve and turns it into a shared adventure. You and your friends are dropped into a dark, whimsical wilderness where every day is a fight against hunger, monsters, and the creeping madness that threatens to consume you.

The game masterfully blends resource management, exploration, and crafting with a relentless challenge. You must gather food, build shelter, craft weapons, and fend off terrifying creatures—all while managing your sanity in a beautifully eerie world.

Playing solo is tough, but the multiplayer twist elevates the experience: cooperation is vital, but so is planning and adapting. Whether splitting tasks or banding together for a boss fight, teamwork is what keeps you alive.

The depth of the crafting system and the unpredictable, procedurally generated world means no two playthroughs feel the same. Seasons, biomes, and random events keep you constantly on your toes.

The game’s hand-drawn, Tim Burton-esque art style is striking—dark and quirky, with a unique charm that perfectly fits its unsettling yet whimsical tone. The soundtrack is haunting and minimal, enhancing the tension and isolation you feel in the wilderness.

Pros:
-Deep, rewarding survival mechanics
-Rich crafting and exploration systems
-Unique, memorable art and atmosphere
-Multiplayer adds layers of fun and strategy

Cons:
-Steep learning curve for newcomers
-Can be punishing and sometimes frustrating
-Occasional connectivity issues in multiplayer

Don’t Starve Together is a brutally beautiful survival game that demands creativity, cooperation, and perseverance. It’s perfect for players who crave challenge wrapped in a darkly whimsical world. With friends by your side, every narrow escape feels like a triumph.

Survival has never been so eerie, engaging, or downright fun—especially with friends.

Game has morphed a thousand times since I bought it, in order to stay alive (and, for now, succeeding). This includes the addition of mandatory crossplay for PC users, which means you get people playing with controllers. While I'd rather not have that, it is not as unbearable as I thought it would become - just a little frustrating at times.

Absolute realism is not the core of the game anymore, as creativity starts to fail under the restrictions of the real world, so now we have some absurd outfits for the operators, which make them difficult to identify, especially if you stay away from the game for a while.

I'm not a gun expert, but I am satisfied with the behaviour of guns in the game. Reloading can be interrupted, leaving one bullet in the chamber. The game no longer has different fire modes.

Toxicity has been toned down immensely with so many restrictions and the "karma" system. Repeated teamkilling is no longer an issue, which is great. In my opinion, the chat filter and some decisions they made to keep the game politically correct are ridiculous.

Finally, it would be great if the devs managed to balance the game without nerfing some ops to the point where they are unplayable (I remember being a twitch main up until when she was nerfed and her gun became uncontrollable).

As of July 2025, I would still recommend getting the game. It's very much alive and taken care of, has more gamemodes then ever, and you have enough content to keep busy for a long time. However, it is showing some problems like the grinding to get renown (currency) becoming more tiresome.

Rainbow Six Siege is the most tactical and skill based first person shooter I have ever played while succeeding to maintain the fun aspect of what makes games great and not feel like jobs. With continued support going strong in 2025 it changes the meta consistently enough to make it a fresh experience every time you hop in after a break. It can get frustrating at times and you will frequently find toxic players but support cracks down on those abusing TOS and cheating well enough to know when you might just be having a bad game. I would recommend this game to anyone looking for a new type of shooter which is less chaotic yet still fun with friends. 8.5/10

I've never played the game until Siege X, so I'm coming into this very fresh to the mechanics. As a new player, the game is very fun. It plays as slow as you're comfortable playing, but there is quite a bit of strategy and tech to understand before taking it too seriously. I'd recommend watching some videos and understanding how the game works, because there is a learning curve. Having said that, I've really been enjoying it! I'm a former COD fanatic and FPS lover, and genuinely miss how slow the old COD games played. This game scratches that itch. If you're into learning a new way to play FPS games then I'd definitely recommend checking out Siege X. If you're expecting a fast-paced arcade shooter, then I'd look elsewhere. Unless you have great map knowledge, it is really impossible to provide value to your team by playing this game fast. Just my opinion!

I played this game since Beta on console (xbox) and it was genuinely fun and interesting. I took a break sometime after Zero came out, the start of less maps and less operators being produced. Game was starting to feel dry and repetitive so I took a long break. I'm now p[laying on PC after some years seeing the launch of siege X (grand re-opening kind of vibe) and it is fun again playing with friends, but at the same time, it feels more like cod with strategy than original siege felt. The ranked system is wack and the operator reworks to give objectively worse operators buffs like ACOGs and deployable shields to give them love instead of just reworking their gadgets properly or buffing what was bad about them. I get some ops will be better than others and thats fine in a strategy FPS like this, but it just doesn't feel like the answer. Will i continue to put in countless hours? Yes, until i move on and then come back in another multi year cycle. It's just  not what i had envisioned when they announced their 10 year plan back in Opeation Health (still worst season to date)

Overall it is an alright game with quite a few flaws. The main thing that is enjoyable, unlike many battle royals, is that it is more strategy based, as well as requiring more skill to get a kill, as I enjoy that style of gameplay. As well the operators add a strategic element to the game, which prioritizes teamwork. This is all in vain as at its current state, it is a dumpster fire. Although the new update brought a few new needed features to modernize the game, Ubisoft fails at the most simple task. Currently there are multiple game breaking glitches which force you to lose the game, which have yet to be fixed in the newest patch. As well much of the ranked gameplay is filled with people blatantly cheating. On top of that, the visible ranking system does not even matter, as the true matchmaking for ranked is based on a hidden rank, only the devs can see.

Siege saved my life

Rainbow Six Siege X was supposed to be a rework—a fresh take on the classic Siege experience we all loved. Instead, it’s a catastrophic step backwards that has alienated the community and destroyed what made the original game great.

What Went Wrong?

Instead of refining the tactical, tight gameplay Siege was known for, Siege X throws out everything good and replaces it with clunky, unpolished mechanics that feel like a cheap knockoff. The gunplay feels completely off—aiming is inconsistent, recoil is a joke, and hit registration is so unreliable it makes you question if you even hit your target.

The “Reworked” Mechanics:
The rework introduced new movement and gadget systems that break the tactical pacing. Operators no longer feel unique or balanced; many have been turned into overpowered or completely useless caricatures. Instead of strategic play and teamwork, the game pushes spammy, chaotic playstyles that make every round feel like a mess.

Performance and Bugs:
Siege X is buggy beyond belief. Expect to encounter frequent crashes, weird clipping through walls, and teleporting enemies due to horrible netcode and desync. Matchmaking is a disaster—long wait times paired with uneven matches where you either get steamrolled or completely dominate due to blatant balance issues.

Microtransactions and Monetization:
Ubisoft seems to have taken this opportunity to shove even more overpriced skins, battle passes, and loot boxes down players’ throats. The cosmetic overload and aggressive monetization make Siege X feel less like a rework and more like a blatant cash grab.

Community Reaction:
The community was ready for improvements, but Siege X feels like a slap in the face. The developers’ silence and slow patch cycle only add to the frustration. The game’s official forums and social media are flooded with complaints that have yet to see meaningful responses or fixes.

Final Thoughts:
Rainbow Six Siege X isn’t a rework—it’s a regression. It strips away the core tactical gameplay, introduces sloppy mechanics, and ruins the balance that made Siege unique. If you’re a Siege fan, stay far away until Ubisoft fixes this mess—if they even bother.

Rating: 1/10 — Avoid at all costs.

One of the best Cosmic fantasy games i've ever played

This game had a rough start and though on principle i disagree with companies releasing before it's ready, they did some COOKING over the years and in it's current state now, they just recently added settlement management into the game in June as an interesting side project you can do to net more money and items, it's amazing. Visually it's incredible and captures the scale of it all beautifully, the gameplay is is a pretty straight forward collectathon with some decent variety that ties into the resource management system. The OST is incredible and i've added 65 days of static to my vinyl collection because of it. The story itself is a mixed bag, i personally liked it since the lesson and mystery in what was being conveyed interested me enough to overlook the lack of cutscenes and voice acting, but i know that a completely dialogue driven adventure might turn people off, fortunately i think this game is very compitent in not really having to care and just playing the core game if you want. 

The game suffers from a handful of technical issues which honestly pale in comparison to the avalanche amount there was on launch. To list a few, menu interaction can be dumb at times and kick you out, the game tests your graphics card a lot when you start making a base or fighting sentinels, some resource harvesting units bug out and don't harvest the right materials, but these are really few and not something i think people will be bothered about in the longrun, small flaws in a gigantic constantly generating game.

8/10 - a really well rounded space exploration game that finally achieved what it set out to do
Immersive and beautiful. Truly a love letter to the open-world space exploration genre. Can play all day. Can't wait to discover all the things this game has.

No Man’s Sky is the gift that keeps on giving. What started as a bold vision has grown into an ever-expanding universe thanks to Hello Games' unwavering commitment to free updates and passionate development. Years after release, they’re still adding new features, refining gameplay, and surprising players with deep, meaningful content—all without charging a dime.

Every update feels like a thank-you letter to the community. From massive multiplayer overhauls to base-building enhancements, visual upgrades, and new storylines, the game's evolution is nothing short of remarkable. It’s rare to see such dedication and humility from a dev team—they’ve transformed early criticism into one of the most inspiring comeback stories in gaming.

Whether you're a veteran explorer or a curious newcomer, there's always something new to discover among the stars. This isn't just a game—it's a living universe crafted with love and imagination.

Judging this game from the state it is in currently,
Its fun but i abhor the story and the setting.
The content is a bit... shallow and sometimes buggy. Im thinking back to them scrambling to get every promised feature in and while they do have the feature its kind of shallow in its implimentation to the point that when you complete one content questline your just kind of done with it.
For example i wanted to get into pet companions and got attached to a little bipedal turtle creature who i adopted as a infant after i watched its fellow infants get eaten alive by giant bugs and wolves.
But the stuff i can do with this companion pet is extremely limited and doesnt really intersect with any of the other features of the game. Once in a blue moon Somyazi the turtle will give me a goo covered clump of minerals that they mined but other than that they dont do much. In combat they seem to be poorly planned out with their ability to fight sentinals being completely removed due to pets having a instant kill attack intended for when they massacre ecosystems around the player. Its weird.

Im 160 hours in and have been playing kind of addictively while keeping freighter dungeon raids for when i play with my friends. So my experience might be a bit skewed. 
The thing that bothers me about the tone of the world is that it feels very... child friendly. I know that the story involves existentialism and species wide genocide but it still feels like its been softened on the edges. [spoiler] Especially when you learn that the entire world could have been created last tuesday and that species wide genocide was just flavor text. Theres evidence of the species killers civilization but those who had been exterminated are entirely gone, likely put in the recycle bin for space or something. I used to think that travellers were individuals of those exterminated species but apparently they are just stuff running on a seperate USB. [/spoiler]

I also have a issue with the Space Anomaly and how it makes the game feel like the town center for a Final Fantasy MMO due to all its neon colors and cosmetic merchants.

Amazing game with many different paths to explore. If I had to give criticism to one thing, it would be that each path has very limited depth, but at the same time, development and free updates continue for this game, and I can only imagine how much more depth will be added in the future. For example, you can farm plants! I love a good farming simulator. But the number of plants you can farm is limited, and specific structures are required. You can't just create a field of plants on any planet (you'd think it'd be allowed at least on planets where that plant is native). Additionally, the limited amount of plants you can farm exist all across the universe. For all the diversity that exists in the other types of planet life, you'd think the farmable plants might get some of that too. That said, I still love the current ability to set up a new base, throw up a few green house domes, and have a new farm to take care of. A bit more depth would make it much better, but that's how the whole game is. You can do some awesome stuff, many different awesome things. But nothing really goes super, super deep on mechanics, techniques, and abilities. I have faith that it may go deeper though! I really hope so! However, if you, like many people these days, find yourself on the ADHD spectrum, you'll never run out of things to do. You can switch from farming, to space battles, to architecture and interior design, to settlements, to underwater bases, to quests, to faction reputation, to trading, to exploring lore... There's so many different things to do! Making the game itself have plenty of depth in general, just not in any specific direction. Holding out hope that every direction becomes increasingly deep over time!!

Additional note for Steam Deck players: The game works beautifully on Steam Deck! But beware, if you're not plugged in and charging at the right voltage, the Steam Deck will crash within minutes of gameplay. While it's great to be able to play handheld near any outlet, it's not truly portable given how quickly it depletes the Steam Deck's battery life.

A potentially great game, ruined by half-baked systems and game-breaking bugs.

This game has an amazing core idea, but it's plagued by issues that make it hard to recommend in its current state.

The UI is clunky, unintuitive, and badly needs a redesign.

The HUD is minimal to the point of being unhelpful.

Stability and polish are sorely lacking—this feels more like an early access title than a finished product.

Major Bug (still not fixed):
Put items in a refiner, save your game, then go do anything else—build, explore, whatever.
Come back and… your items are gone.
No warning, no logs, nothing.
This happens almost every single time, and it’s infuriating.

🛠 Workaround: The only way to avoid losing items is to wait for refining to fully finish before doing anything else or saving.

Base Building:
Base building is a core part of the game, and yes—it’s better than Starfield’s.
But compared to other games that do base building well, it’s still clunky, frustrating, and underdeveloped.
(This isn’t about automation—just basic construction and management.)

When this game was initially released, it ran like drek because of all the bugs.  Then, after YEARS, the bugs mostly got sorted, and the game actually ran pretty well.  Then, the devs just kept working, which was cool, but then they started making things prettier, more animated, fancier, and just generally more graphically COMPLICATED, so that now it runs like drek again on the original platforms that folks BOUGHT it for.  In fact, it runs like drek on just about any rig that costs less than a grand.  What kind of dev INCREASES the minimum system requirements of their own game, AFTER people spent real money on it?  Yeah, there are some in game tweaks--more on the PC than on the PS4, but still not enough.  Used to run great on the PS4, too, now it stutters and tears and flashes and just runs like drek.  But look, the explosions are so detailed while they're flickering!  Sigh.  

Otherwise, yeah, decent game.  XD

Phenomenal game that keeps getting better. Fun progression and the initial grind was not overly annoying, probably about 5 or so hours before I was deep in space and on my own accord. From there the game is truly a sandbox 'choose your own style' type game where you are certainly given solid direction towards progressing the main story if you so choose but you can also completely ignore that and just hustle recovered ships or explore til your hearts content.

All that being said, I would encourage you to get through at least the primary quest line that helps get your primary base and buildables catalogue going as I found that I had wasted some tech credits manually unlocking some base items that the storyline eventually would have allowed me to unlock for free, nothing major but slightly annoying. That is part of a truly freestyle game though, youre going to learn some things the hard way and that is part of the fun and depth of the game.

More and more expansions keep coming and the fact that they have never charged for anything beyond the initial cost of the game is freakin' amazing! After almost 10 years the game truly is a special work of art that all gamers should play.

Why can’t I use items in the freighter storage pods without constantly pulling things out into my main inventory and having to do this annoying reorganizing everywhere I go? Why is the Teleport Receiver so useless and why can’t it just let me use the ship inventory anywhere on the planet we’re on? Why do I need to summon the freighter everywhere I go? This is close to the perfect space exploration/survival/base building game and with each new update, it gets better and better. I'm a latecomer to NMS but I've sunk almost 200 hours into it and every time I get "bored" or distracted, I come back and sink another 20-30 hours easily in a week or so.

It's beautiful, it's expansive, it feels ALIVE, and the options to explore and do stuff or just... be... in the game feel endless. Don't try to cram it all in at once and you'll find a universe that's rewarding and timeless.

I'd like ship combat to be a bit more nuanced, sure, and maybe adding in some co-op abilities for base building with specific friends/allies would be very cool. I'd love planets where bases need to be fortresses against attacking creatures or pirates or whatnot. I dunno - I think adding in elements I love about other games might dilute the overall experience, though.

As is, it's extremely worth your time at full price. Hello Games should be a shining example of post-launch support and I hope everyone who worked/works on this game is very wealthy because of it!

For the context:
I played EVE online a lot and I played Valheim.

Compared to those games this one is a shallow sandbox, lots of bugs and glitches.

Co-op is effectively pointless and unplayable:
- You might be in the same system, one suddenly gets an event to fight someone, another just stare at their friend flying randomly like they are high or something
- on a planet: one is building something, another has a storm and has to sit this one out.
- Bases are often not in sync so while one is using the base equipment, another stares at a half unfinished based with walls hanging in the air.

Missions are boring and pointless. Also, there are so many glitches in this procedurally generated world. My storyline mission with a translation quest got NPC spawned somewhere in the ground below the point where I can dig them up lol.

Game loop is also pointless. 
You mine and grind resources just to make slightly different resources to learn that you can only sell them to NPCs at the station. No player market, no real economy.

Half of the resources are in general useless as well.

You can't gift a ship to your groupie either. Nor trade directly with other players.

Bases: totally pointless, the only reason for their existence is to build a medium (or higher) refiner, that's about it. 

Also, interface is probably there to make console players happier, I don't know. To me it is the worst game interface I've ever seen. I really can't see how one could make it worse.

So all in all, it is a glitchy singleplayer game and full of empty promises.

Best to skip.

Love this game and what it's become. My only problem, which is becoming larger everyday, is that once I started playing VR, I can't really go back to playing standard. That's not a cheeky joke, the VR controls are atrocious, clunky, uncomfortable(at the best of times) and the only benefit you get from them is when on foot. All vehicle interaction in VR is the worst possible gaming experience, purely from the controls aspect. They use very novel concepts, but the worst execution. Mostly the hand break loose from controls all the time, or are simply unresponsive, despite me nearly breaking my wrist back. Hopping in a mech in first person and holding out your hands to control it sounds dope, until you realize a blind autistic pig designed the VR portion of all vehicle controls. Cars are fine, literally never use them though, flying makes me want to jump out of my window.

I love that there is so much attention still paid to this game from the devs, but y'all NEED to fix VR, asap.

One of gaming’s best redemption arcs.
No Man’s Sky launched rough, but Hello Games never gave up. Years of massive free updates turned it into one of the best sci-fi sandboxes out there.
There’s always something to do — whether you’re building, exploring, fighting, or just getting lost in the universe, solo or with friends. One minute I’m fending off pirates from a freighter. The next, I’m hunting for elusive living starships. Every session delivers new, memorable moments I still talk about.
Few games earn a permanent spot in my favorites. This one did.
9/10 becomes tedious late game. But otherwise so fun to explore in.

There aren't enough words that could describe this game and my emotions towards it.

Hello Games have proven that they adore this game, and have made a truly unforgettable game here. Though there was the launch that will remain unforgettable, this game has made a definitive mark on gaming history instead for a very different reason: They didn't give up, and came back with the most jaw-dropping achievement in gaming history by redeeming the game and themselves.

EVERY, and I mean EVERY update contains something wholly unique with even more insane depth and fun. You have a legitimate universe to explore, with 256 GALAXIES that you will find your way to, even though many of you like me will probably never leave Euclid as we have not explored the galaxy yet, all of us playing. And there's still billions of planets and star systems that players haven't found in the galaxy, which is all tracked. You will know if this is first contact in a galaxy or if another player has found it before.

If the sheer amount of free updates and content that would put every live service gaming company COMBINED to shame isn't enough for you, there are also brand new "expeditions" every month that promise new or returning ships, decoration items, equipment, mods, and beyond.

Because this game truly is beyond anything you have ever played, and you'll realize that, the second you begin interstellar travel, and start zooming out, and out... and out... and out...

And beyond.

And it keeps going.

And it's still not fully explored.

AND THERE'S HUNDREDS OF GALAXIES OUT THERE THAN JUST THE ONE?!

Over 245 Hours In – Still Blown Away

No Man’s Sky is hands-down one of the most immersive and rewarding games I’ve ever played. With over 250 hours logged, I’m still discovering new worlds, building bases, and losing myself in its beautiful, ever-expanding universe. The updates are incredible, the freedom is unmatched, and the sense of wonder never fades. A must-play for any explorer at heart.

Even 9 years later the game is still a buggy mess. Its still possible to get softlocked in the base building Tutorial where the solution was on some obscure reddit threat. And the base building overall is so scuffed that there realy isnt a point trying to make anything look nice architecturely. The combat on ground is fine but when you try to fight with your ship the controls are so bad that its impossible to actualy lock on and shoot a ship for the majority of the fire fight. Its a decently fun game if you have a ton of credits and are able to do whatever you want, but actually making progress through the story is difficult. This games difficulty comes entirely from being tedious and sending you to random places to get stuff. There's no automation, so you have to collect everything by hand. While the story is interesting progressing through it isn't. multiple times the game breaks your ship and its up to you to fix all the broken parts. For those segments my solution was just to make everything free in the settings, but I shouldn't have to cheat just to fly my ship after a story segment. Again, building and flying between systems is plenty fun and the game looks good. things like the dreadnaughts and gas giants look incredible. The loop of completing a single objective just to be sent to get more stuff just isn't very fun. the game is overall fine, it can be really fun sometimes. just be aware that progression can get very bland.

This review is only about the VR portion of the game. The base game itself is enjoyable.

I don't recommend this game for VR players. It is a terrible implementation of virtual reality and makes what could be a relaxing game infuriating. The visuals and ground movement are not the issue, they are acceptable. What isn't is the world interaction, the HUD and the air combat movement.

If you have any experience with VR you will be used to using natural movements to interact with the world. Like reaching out and gripping something to pick it up. There is none of that here. You have to stand in just the right place and move you hand in the air until you get the item you want to interact with in range, then grip and pull to pick up or start objects. It is frustrating to try and do, and even more so when you have many objects around that can be interacted with. An even bigger problem is when you interact with something and the game moves you to "face" the something, only you are not facing it. You could just be looking at the sky now, disoriented because the game suddenly changed your view (a really good way to get sick).

Worse than that is the HUD, which gets my award for worse VR HUD ever. It isn't in view unless you stand in the perfect spot! You move around the HUD, the HUD doesn't move for you. It is crazy. You can be picking up items and not know what you got until you crane your head around to see where the HUD decided to be at that time. Want to know how much health or jetpack you have? You won't, because it is probably displayed behind where you are looking. Pulling up an in air menu will usually have it clipping though the world so you can't read it.

Space combat was so bad I gave up on it without downing one ship. The issue here is that the controls for the throttle and directional input for the starship are way too vague. This isn't an issue only with this game, other flight games are too difficult for me to play when you are trying to hold a joystick and throttle that don't exist. If you were going to play this, you would almost need to have a HOTAS to switch to to make it bearable. Maybe this game can be remapped so the thumbsticks can control the spaceship instead?

A Galactic Redemption Story – No Man's Sky Soars Beyond Expectations

No Man’s Sky is one of the greatest comeback stories in gaming history. What began as a rocky launch in 2016 has transformed into an expansive, engaging, and genuinely awe-inspiring universe that rewards exploration, creativity, and discovery like few other games can.

From the moment you step out of your first crashed starship onto a procedurally generated planet, the sense of scale and possibility is overwhelming in the best way. The game boasts a staggering number of unique worlds, each with its own ecosystems, climates, and terrain. You’re free to explore, build, trade, fight, or simply wander — and every path you take feels meaningful and self-directed.

What truly makes No Man’s Sky shine is the dedication of Hello Games. Through a steady stream of free updates, they've added base building, multiplayer, VR support, space combat improvements, living ships, new biomes, narrative depth, expeditions, and much more. It’s a constantly evolving experience, and every major update brings exciting reasons to return.

Graphically, the game is stunning, especially with recent visual overhauls. From alien sunsets to atmospheric space stations, there’s always something breathtaking to see. The music and ambient sounds complement the sense of wonder, creating a meditative and immersive experience.

Whether you’re a solo explorer, a builder of sprawling planetary bases, or a traveler who loves cooperative missions with friends, No Man’s Sky offers something for everyone. It’s a testament to vision, perseverance, and the power of community feedback.

Final Thoughts:
No Man’s Sky went from underdog to essential. It’s a must-play for any fan of science fiction, exploration, or open-ended gaming. The universe is vast — and in No Man’s Sky, it truly feels alive.

The developers have delivered on their promise and they made a truly beautiful game. :)

Fun alone. 

For me there was nothing more engaging and immersive than finding a beautiful planet with perfect weather and resources, and building a permanent home there. :)

That said there are some Cons. 
I loved the limited story that the main game had. But it ended too soon. 
This game would do well with actual quests... Elder Scrolls style quests. 

Different Star Systems should have their own politics and characters and local situations.

Maybe introduce a framework for building quests? Allow complex base design and triggering events?

Melee, jumping and flipping? 
How do we NOT have lightsabers and psionics yet? lol

No Man’s Sky has had one of the most impressive evolutions in recent years. At launch, it disappointed a lot of people by promising more than it delivered. But over time, Hello Games showed a rare level of commitment — they listened to the community, released dozens of free updates, and completely transformed the experience.

That said, the game still has some bugs that need fixing, which can be frustrating at times. I hope the team keeps paying attention to player feedback, just as they’ve done so far. Even so, it’s undeniable how much the game has grown and become an engaging experience — especially for those who enjoy exploration and science fiction, like I do.

To say this game is a turnaround success is probably redundant at this point, so I'll stick to my thoughts on the game as it is now. A bit of a throw-everything-and-see-what-sticks design, with a mysterious and melancholy story running through it. The procedural generation is generally quite good and I've encountered very few bugs (excluding the giant glowy ones roaming around my first base). I've somehow managed to rack up over 90 hours in about a week, but that's probably because I don't have a great deal else going on so don't expect to do the same (if you do, that's a bonus). If I had a quibble some of the later additions are spread slightly thin, if that makes sense. The most recent update (BEACON) built on one of them, though, and the devs are self-evidently dedicated to the game (good on them, incidentally, I think it's going great).
TLDR: Good game now, simple but effective story, procedural generation's good, side activities can be fun but sometimes seem just a bit spread thin.

I keep coming back to this for no good reason. The actual cause is a gaming addiction. My brain doesn't enjoy other activities and just sitting by myself brings pain. NMS is not doing anything particularly well, but it's the only game that provides interstellar spaceship travel with some meaningful amount of freedom. Somewhat relaxing, when that's an activity you crave.  Sadly, though, the content is still puddle-deep. Nothing makes sense and there's hardly any purpose to flying, building, fighting or whatever else you can do. Pointless activities, like building a sandcastle in a sandbox.

It's important to note, at this point, that "good" games don't have that problem. When good game design is applied, you'll be given a motivating make-believe purpose that'll drive your actions. Of course, regardless of how well that purpose was designed, it won't last forever. The difference here is that Hello Games never even tried to come up with a remotely good idea for a purpose. Just the most pretentious and thinly weaved plot of "Reach the center of the universe", horribly written and lacking anything interesting to do, other than traveling. 

The lackluster world generation is certainly the worst part. All surfaces look about the same, lacking anything worthwhile to point at, other than how odd (but not exciting) some of the plants or creatures might look. 
Building a base could maybe be tempting, if they ever managed to generate a planet that doesn't bore me after 5 minutes. So, moving on is in some way motivating, if just due to the flimsy hope that maybe the next star system will have the improved generation that some updates kept promising.

I'll probably keep coming back, time and again, traveling around for an hour or five until boredom becomes overwhelming and my brain sends me on to get disappointed by other games.

This Game Is NOT VR Ready – False Advertising, Broken Performance, Refund Requested

I have spent 8 goddamn hours—yes, a full-ass workday—trying to get No Man’s Sky to run in VR. Let me make something absolutely clear:

My setup is a beast.

Laptop: ASUS ROG Strix G16

CPU: Intel Core i9-14900HX (24 cores, 32 threads)

RAM: 32GB

GPU: NVIDIA RTX (top-tier)

Headset: Meta Quest 3

Connection: Link Cable

Platform: Steam

This rig could probably run a simulation of Earth collapsing into a black hole—but it can’t run your game without looking like I’m watching a PowerPoint slideshow underwater, through a cracked window, on acid.

I’ve tried:

AirLink (trash)

Link Cable (still trash)

Shader wipes

Graphics tweaks

OpenComposite bullshit

SteamVR configs

Launch options

Sacrificing a goat under a full moon

Nothing. Fixes. It.

The game either:

Won’t launch

Crashes my system

Runs at 2 FPS

Looks like a glittery seizure-inducing mess

Until you fix this game’s VR mode, you owe every VR user a refund, an apology, and maybe a hand job for the trauma.

No Man’s Sky: The Game That Never Stops Growing

When I bought No Man’s Sky in 2016, my friends laughed. “You paid full price for a glorified screensaver,” they said. But little did they know, I was investing in the Neverending Space Game. Seven years later, I logged in to find out I now own a freighter, a settlement, a farm, a fleet, a pet blob, a kitchen, and—somehow—a working Xbox 360 inside my ship.

Every time I blink, Hello Games has patched in three new galaxies, underwater banjo duels, and 47 ways to turn space rocks into soup. I don’t even bother reading patch notes anymore. I just boot up the game and wait for Sean Murray to appear in my living room, personally explaining the new features.

Honestly, at this rate, I’m convinced if I stop playing for a week, I’ll come back to find No Man’s Sky running my taxes and babysitting my kids.

Buy this game if you love surprises, exploring the universe, and never having a clue what you’re supposed to be doing. By the time you finish reading this review, Hello Games will probably have added the option to play as a toaster.

10/10, would get lost in patch notes again.

You are breathing MY oxygen here buddy. I own everything from the stars, the planets all the way to the many specks of dust on your door handle leading outside. I am the all seeing, slightly crimson, eye. I know everything. I know what this is, it isn't a world at your fingertips waiting for you, it is a game. A game made to hide your insecurities, to escape reality, and it does a wonderful job at that. Enjoy the game, Traveller-Friend.

Do yourself a favor and don't try to look up guides for the things you can figure out on your own with this game. When I was a new player each new experience in the game felt like unwrapping an even better present every time and thinking to myself, "This is great, there's no way they can top that." Then they did, over and over.

My most awe inspiring moment was being positioned nearby to a planet while in space and docking on the outside of a ship in my fleet. I had landed there because that particular ship had sustained damages on the excursion I had sent it out on and needed repaired before I could send it out again. I step outside of my ship and am suited up on a strip of walkway in outer space. My view from the rail is an entire planet. I explored the exterior of the ship and jumped from section to section with the black void of space between the gaps. One misstep and I would drift off into cold eternity. The feeling of distance and the way it made me disoriented and stunned in a video game made my heart ache. The developers had pulled me through the screen into an immersive experience that no game has ever done before and may never do again. 

Breathe this game in deeply and prepare for Light No Fire.

From a total disaster to one of the best survival games in history. Wow, just wow. And all that with just FREE updates almost 10 years after release. That's truly incredible. But really, I don't think players will mind at least one paid DLC. How do you even make money to maintain the game?!

I've seen a lot of reviews alleging the rehabilitation of No Man's Sky from the overpromise and underdelivery from whatever. I don't know, I didn't follow it closely. I bought it recently, and attempted to play it on its own terms. Let's cut right to the chase:

This janky game is a mess. Resources are all over the place, you'll burn huge amounts of time trying to put anything together, all in the name of procedurally generated wasteland that doesn't actually get better with any of their patches, it just adds more jank that I can only assume "sunk cost fallacy" has players feeling like their nonsense is suddenly good, when actually, it's just a lot.

Enable the free build - infinite resources, easy tech, etc - and try building a base. Plug in things. Just go for something simple. Whatever strikes your fancy. It'll be an exercise in pointlessly difficult frustration that should not have survived one year in development. It's horrible.

Let's go more fundamental - all the UX is reinventing the wheel pointlessly, in counterintuitive and counter"principle of least surprise" ways, so whatever it is you want to do, you've had to re-master (this is a bit of psychological trickery, so you feel clever once you master the idioms, even though their very existence should be damning to rational thinkers). Hold to click everything. Right click doesn't context. Sometimes it's "out." Sometimes it isn't. Completely random. Letters are just kind of randomly used based on WASD proximity, but overmapped on a whim.

Also, there are a bunch of systems - bases, freighters, exploration - that have interchangable currencies so they appear to interact, but actually are almost completely orthagonal to each other.

It isn't a fun space game. It isn't a fun base building game. It isn't a fun trading game. There's nothing fun about this. It just is an application draped with the trappings of a game but not to be confused with one, with many systems and soaks your time.

My main issue with this game is not with the content. I actually really like this game and all of the content that is in it. The problem I have is with the performance of the game. I have a ryzen 7 5700x, a radeon 6600 with 8gb of vram, 32gb of 3200 mhz ram, and I run the game off of an M.2 SSD. I am way over the minimum specs, yet fps drops are frequent when playing. I have tried literally everything outside of buying new hardware to get the game to run better. This includes trying to run the game on Linux instead of Windows. It is my opinion that the performance is subpar for a game that came out in 2016.

It is important to note that the frame drops and stutters I have been struggling with in this game may not bother other people, and outside of the poor frame timings, the game is playable. It just isn't playable to me.

There are some fun elements, but it's super twitchy and the interstellar map is often confusing. The story is impossible to get into because the devs made every space alien race genderless and refers to each individual alien with plural "they" pronouns. I always have to figure out if the alien being referred to is an individual or an entire group. It's super distracting and (of course) political programming which takes me out of the story. Yawn.  I got it for 60% off, but it still felt overpriced.

No Man’s Sky: A Universe of Possibilities

From its humble and somewhat rocky launch to its evolution into one of the most captivating space exploration games out there, No Man's Sky has truly earned its place among the stars. What was once criticized for not meeting the lofty expectations set by its ambitious trailers has now become a triumph of development, community support, and limitless imagination.

At its core, No Man’s Sky offers players an unparalleled sense of freedom and discovery. Imagine an entire galaxy—18 quintillion planets—each with its own unique flora, fauna, terrain, and weather systems. The sheer scale is mind-blowing, and while no one can explore every corner of it, the excitement of stumbling across something previously unseen or unexpected never fades. Whether you’re trekking across a planet’s surface, scanning alien wildlife, or building sprawling bases on distant moons, No Man’s Sky always makes you feel like a true explorer.

One of the standout features is the game’s visual artistry. The planets themselves are stunningly beautiful, from the serene beauty of lush, vibrant forests to the stark, desolate landscapes of harsh desert worlds. The lighting and atmospheric effects are breathtaking, and the way the game handles day/night cycles, weather, and even the stars in the sky is a testament to the incredible world-building done by the developers at Hello Games.

But what truly elevates No Man’s Sky is the constant stream of updates and improvements. The team at Hello Games has consistently rolled out new content, features, and enhancements, proving their commitment to evolving the game. The Atlas Rises, NEXT, and Origins updates all added layers of depth, new ways to play, and expanded multiplayer options, each one improving on the previous. The addition of the Expeditions mode and the ability to team up with friends or random explorers has made the experience even richer. The game's shift from a solo exploration experience to one with multiplayer elements brings it into the realm of community, making every journey more social and dynamic.

The sense of progression is another key element that makes No Man’s Sky so satisfying. From mining precious resources to crafting exotic upgrades, every action you take feels meaningful. You’re not just floating through space—you're working toward building a home, whether that’s by upgrading your ship, setting up an intergalactic base, or unlocking new star systems to explore. The crafting system has a nice balance, allowing players to tailor their experience while maintaining the wonder of discovery.

The audio design is equally stellar. The ambient sounds of alien worlds, the hum of your starship’s engine, and the subtle but atmospheric soundtrack all combine to create a fully immersive experience. Whether you’re in the cockpit of your starship or exploring the surface of a planet, the audio cues pull you deeper into this vast, living universe.

At its best, No Man’s Sky is about the journey. It’s about the sense of awe that comes from discovering a new world or simply drifting in space, staring at the stars. It’s about the joy of exploration, not knowing what you’ll find, and the peace that comes from knowing that the universe is always just a little bit bigger than you imagined. Whether you’re a lone traveler or embarking on a journey with friends, this game reminds us that the greatest adventure lies in the unknown.

In a world where games often get lost in the race for quick updates and flashy new content, No Man’s Sky is a testament to what dedication and passion can achieve. It has become more than just a game—it’s a living, breathing universe that evolves alongside its players. If you haven’t taken the time to explore it yet, now is the perfect moment to dive in.

Pros:

Stunning, procedurally generated universe with nearly endless exploration

Constant updates, improving the game with new features and content

A deep sense of progression and meaningful discovery

Gorgeous visuals and immersive audio design

Robust multiplayer elements for cooperative play

Cons:

The sheer scale of the game can sometimes feel overwhelming

Occasional performance hiccups on older hardware

No Man’s Sky has evolved into something truly magical—a game where the universe is at your fingertips, ready to be explored. It’s not just a space sim; it’s a testament to the power of imagination and perseverance. Whether you’re soaring through the stars or building your own intergalactic empire, this game invites you to dream beyond the horizon. And for that, it deserves to be celebrated.

The game itself is good, but the bugs are frustrating and completely shatter the immersion. Although the visuals can be impressive, not even the famed planet entry and exit transitions are tolerable without giving you a headache. Landscapes look like a strange, jittery mishmash of overlapping water and landmasses, and the water appears as a grid when viewed from a distance. Occasionally, a surface storm can disguise these flaws tho. 

Base building is equally disappointing. You can’t change the wood textures from the “weathered” look, and many materials are blurry. Pieces won’t snap together properly, leaving odd, shaky lines between walls and floors. Terraforming frequently reverts only partially and deforms your structures, displacing interiors. 

And the list really just goes on...

It’s infuriating that a game this long in development, with such a high price tag, still struggles with these basic issues. Although there’s a solid foundation here, the problems of its sometimes, but often enough, bad development are just too pervasive. I can’t recommend it unless you’re heavily prepared

Nearly a decade after its turbulent launch, No Man’s Sky in 2025 stands as one of the most remarkable redemption arcs in gaming history. What was once the poster child for overhype and underdelivery has transformed into a genre-defining space exploration experience that rivals the very best in both ambition and execution.

Pros:
    Vast, ever-expanding universe
    Deep base-building and fleet mechanics
    Regular updates
    No (!) microtransactions

Cons:
    Learning curve can be steep for new players

🌌 575+ Hours In and Still Loving It! 🚀

No Man's Sky has been an incredible journey. After over 575 hours of playtime, I can confidently say this is one of the most rewarding and immersive games I've ever experienced.

What truly amazes me is how the developers continue to support the game with amazing updates—years after its original release. They’ve listened to the community, improved the game in countless ways, and keep adding new features that make exploring the universe feel fresh and exciting every time I return.

Whether you're building a base, discovering strange planets, trading, fighting space pirates, or just relaxing and enjoying the beauty of the cosmos, there's always something to do. And with each update, it just keeps getting better.

Thank you, Hello Games, for not giving up and turning this into something truly special. 💙

Highly recommend to anyone who loves space, adventure, and creativity!

While the "procedural generation" nature of this game is quite repetitious, so is Bethesda's 'Starfield'.  Starfield has a better story line and combat, but "No Man's Sky" is more fun.  Both games kinda fail in the exploration of planets because of the repetition.  I find myself continuing to play NMS because it's a casual, relaxing experience.  I can turn my brain off and just march through the galaxy exploring, collecting resources from mines and farms, or otherwise just building bases.  Hello Games continues to update NMS with periodic content drops that keep me wanting to grind just a little bit more.  I know that eventually I'll get bored and just stop.  ...like I did with Starfield.  Until then though, I recommend NMS for anyone who wants to wander landscapes and build ever increasingly more complex bases.

Game is taking off to a really slow ass start, pun intended. While I am happy with the successful turnaround story Sean and his team were able to achieve with No Man's Sky, I still have some criticisms of the game after playing it for myself when I got it on sale for $20.

The game, even in its much better state currently, still has a boring gameplay loop. Fetch this, fetch that, replenish your life support, hazard support, refuel your starship's launcher, refuel your multi-tool, harvest that, mine this, get x y z materials for x y z craftables. There is barely any fun or intensity. Gunplay is incredibly underwhelming, even if the game's main selling point is exploration. Even the starship battles were a let down. All you have to fight are these robots called "sentinels" that are brain-dead easy.

Granted, I am still pretty new to the game and I'm still going through the story. But it is off to an incredibly bad impression with a miserable slow-burn to it. Some if not all of the story missions act as the tutorial for the game, and boy oh boy will you spend hours just going through the tutorial alone, because like I said the game's missions consist of long ass fetch quests which even for an exploration game is mind numbingly boring. From a story narrative standpoint all you will be doing is talking/interacting with non-VA machines and npc's. With the story having you chase down unknown signals that were left by unknown entities, so there is a little mystique to it but in my opinion its nothing to write home about or even classify as "decent" or "good". None of it is hooking me at all as a new player.

The game's graphics are really beautiful especially if you happen to find a naturally pretty planet with cool weathers that are really atmospheric like dust storms or mild rain. It's really nice how the wind interacts with certain wardrobes like capes or robes, there are some really nice physics that add a lot to the immersion. But its still.. not.. enough, unfortunately. While it is cool and interesting that the game is heavily RNG which makes every planet you visit unique, it quickly wears down its novelty because there just isn't much to everything else especially the gameplay. Animals/creatures are cool to look at but there really isn't anything to write home about them either. Maybe I'm too early into the game but most of the animals in this game don't attack you and are just kind of there.. There's little incentive to hunt them or do really anything with them.

There are extensive customization options for your player which I can appreciate, and they are free and aren't locked behind any micro-transactions which is also something I can appreciate. As far as the ship customization and building, I am just not there yet as a new player so I can't speak much on that yet.

The game's trade economy is what it is and I don't really have any complaints or compliments for it. I think it's serviceable and it offers a motivation for going to planets and harvesting mineral deposits or undigging lost artifacts of technology. Even as a new player you can get rich pretty fast just by digging for shit or collecting things. I once found a single item that was worth 600,000 units. 

All this to just say that I'm really confused on what people mean when they say this game made a turnaround or maybe this game simply just isn't for me. I don't know. I will continue to keep playing after this review is made to see if my mind changes and maybe I'll change the review from negative to positive.

I'm only a few hours in so far, so I can't say much.  I'll update this when I've got about 25-30 hours into it.  Steam insisted that I write something, so that was it.

While I only have around 50 hours in the game I still feel I have completed most of the fun content. 
I am frustrated by the fact that it just feels like a massive loop of fetch quests when the gameplay could be a lot more involved and interesting. They demonstrate this with some of the abandoned freighter missions you can do but ultimately they get boring. 

I love a lot of the mechanics of the game but it really gets frustrating when they are utilised to their full potential. If you are going to have random interceptions while warping in space create a fun side mission out of it. If you are going to give us frigates to control perhaps create a more interesting levelling system that gives us harder missions or perhaps we could tag along in our own frigate as a captain to run the mission. 

The credit system is just eh. I find that too often I am wondering around in space and I have 100m credits with nothing to spend it on. Yes I could buy a 50m ship or something but like eh what really will that get me. It feels like there isn't much need to actually grind for credits because most of the items in the game you just craft them because actually having anything in a galactic terminal that you need is rare. 

I would love to actually see a reason to level up your connection with a given race as I see no benefits from becoming a friend or companion and therefore no losses to being an enemy. you don't seem to be treated any differently when you enter a system of that race and it doesn't affect you going to use any of the terminals there. 

I want to love this game with some of its incredible mechanics and somewhat fun gameplay. BUT these issues just make it really frustrating for me to enjoy it when I am constantly doing fetch quests or have run out of things to actually explore on planets... 

and sure settlement updates is kinda interesting but ultimately this game still needs a lot of work to be played from me. Thanks for 20hrs of fun
