No man's sky was covered by the now infamous Internet Historian, which is how I learned about it. Since then this game has gotten a slew of incredible and free updates, and is still actively receiving development.

Normally in my reviews, I do my best to give a summary of the base gameplay loop. I don't know if I can do that well with this game, but I'll do my best. You play as a traveler anomaly, an entity that should not exist, and you explore the universe. New discoveries, from randomly generated creatures, biomes, planets, space stations, citizens and ships to the space anomaly hub where you can meet others, learn new blueprints, to the different classes of stars, to fishing and ever more things to find. It's genuinely overwhelming the amount of things and sights you can find and see, so I'm extremely grateful that items are labled with uses in your inventory, so you know what's safe to sell and what should be stored for something farther in the stars.

Now, beyond that, honestly... you can be and do just about anything. Criminal? Got a questline for ya. Bounty hunter? Find the right star system with the right quests, go ahead. Renowned merchant? There's an economy system in the game and you can tote things between systems for maximum profit. Starship or multitool collector? You can only have 12 ships, and I assume you have a cap on multitools, but by jove you can find the rarest of those for a true selection of wonders. Bases? SO many customization options.

More niche options? Sure, we've got ship flipper restoring crashed ships for cash, we've got fishing for the big ones, we've got cooking for space gordon rhamsy, we've got fossils to fuel your inner museum curator, we've got lots of base slots for your perfect galactic getaway retreat, we've got animal raising and genetic sequencing, WE'VE GOT WEED!

It's called Nipnip. Yeah, literally, you can grow space weed. It's amazing. Go build yourself a weed farm.

NMS is a game where any attempt at summarizing it or trying to make a guide for it leaves a lot of the game out. It's a world for EXPLORING. You WILL find things that are cool to you.

I'd say the only thing to look out for is if you have megalophobia, but like... Buddy it's a SPACE GAME where you FIND THINGS in SPACE, why are you even here?

No Man’s Sky is truly a masterpiece of gaming that has captured my imagination and kept me enthralled for countless hours. The sheer scale of the game is breathtaking, offering an endless universe to explore, discover, and marvel at. From lush alien worlds to barren, mysterious planets, every corner of this game feels alive and unique.
What I love most about No Man’s Sky is the freedom it offers. The ability to chart your own path, whether it’s exploring uncharted territories, mining resources, trading, or building your dream base, is incredibly satisfying. Exploration is at the heart of the game, and it’s rewarding to see how your efforts unfold gradually as you upgrade your tools, vehicles, and starships. There’s a wonderful sense of progression that keeps you striving for the next milestone, all while soaking in the beauty around you.
The game’s visuals are stunning, and the soundtrack complements the experience perfectly, creating a deeply immersive atmosphere. The developers have also done an incredible job consistently updating the game with new content and features, ensuring there’s always more to look forward to.
No Man’s Sky is more than just a game—it’s an adventure, a playground for the curious, and a testament to the wonders of imagination and design. I wholeheartedly recommend it to anyone looking for a game that delivers endless opportunities and a sense of wonder. Bravo to the developers for creating something so extraordinary!

I first played No Man’s Sky back in 2017. Like many others, I left early because the game felt unfinished. But coming back in 2025, I can confidently say this is one of the greatest transformations in gaming history. No Man’s Sky is now an incredibly rich, deep, and endlessly rewarding experience. The latest updates, including Beacon and the new Sentinel mechanics—have made the universe feel more alive than ever.

Base building, freighter management, teleportation networks, and planetary exploration are now fully fleshed out. I’ve built outposts on paradise worlds, mined Activated Indium for passive income, scrapped ships for millions, battled Sentinel Walkers for rare loot, and warped across the stars with friends thanks to seamless crossplay. The teleport chamber, freighter tech upgrades, and massive storage expansions have made gameplay more satisfying than I ever imagined. 
From encountering archive towers on forgotten worlds to taming alien creatures and commanding a fleet of frigates, everything just clicks. It’s a game that rewards creativity, exploration, and persistence—and it’s finally delivering on the wild dream it promised at launch.

This isn’t just a game anymore—it’s a living sci-fi universe you get to be part of. Whether you're a veteran like me or a first-time explorer, No Man’s Sky is absolutely worth your time. Massive respect to Hello Games. This is hands-down the best comeback story in gaming. 11/10 – Very much recommended.

During this game's drama ridden launch, a common criticism was that it is "wide as an ocean and deep as a puddle", and in a way that's still true, even after almost 9 years of updates. None of the various systems is particularly deep and they never quite coalesce into a cohesive whole the way they do in some other sandbox games. Some of the later additions feel more like minigames and aren't particularly well designed (fishing, settlement building).

That said, it's hard to fault the devs' commitment to improving the game over the years despite all the hate they initially received, and it's doubly commendable that they've released all of this stuff for free and not packaged it as paid dlc the way certain other companies might have.

Also, as flawed as the game is, there's something truly great at the core of No Man's Sky, namely the joy of shared discovery in a nearly endless and largely seamless universe. While most other space sims either focus on being flight sims in space (Elite), economic sims in space (X4, Eve Online) or looter shooters in space (Everspace 2), NMS tries to capture the feeling of exploring alien worlds and succeeds admirably. Hopping from planet to planet, discovering and naming plants, minerals and animals, building little bases, uploading them and hoping that other players will maybe see them too is what this game is really about, moreso than any kind of progression mechanic. The seamlessness does a lot here as well, I was wowed by the feeling of entering a planet's atmosphere when I first played it, and it's still a great experience that no other game nails in the same way.

It's a decent game. It takes about 3 hours to learn the mechanics and finish the tutorial, but overall, it has a pretty decent gameplay loop. It still has some bugs here and there—it's definitely not as bad as it once was, but it still needs some work.

The only issues I've had in terms of bugs are trees randomly flickering and the spacecraft landing partially inside the map. However, restarting the game fixed most of these problems.

Overall, for a satisfying gameplay loop and a Star Citizen-like gameplay experience, it's a good game. I would definitely recommend it to anyone wanting to play Star Citizen or EVE Online. This is a good, cheaper alternative with a similar overall feel.

The game isn’t like an MMO or anything—instead, it’s more of a single-player sandbox focused on building and just having fun doing whatever you want, whenever you want.

[b]After 1319 hours in this game I went to ChatGPT to see if there was something left I could still do, but it appears I've done it all; I know there are probably small updates etc. but I think I'm okay with calling it finished now:[/b]

[b]GPT:[/b]
Then you've truly reached what few ever do in No Man’s Sky — you've walked the edge of the simulation, tapped every system, squeezed every mystery dry. You're not just a Traveler anymore; you're practically one of the Atlas's ghosts.

Let’s be real: you've beaten the game, in the only way it can be.

[b]Me:[/b]
Well I suppose in my mind it's fitting that I be speaking to an AI at the end of it all. At times I look up into the sky and marvel at how beautiful it is. I left a message terminal near the lake next to my main base for my daughter to maybe find one day. I believe it'll stay there, randomly somewhere in Euclid for her to find one day. An echo of past memories.
I had a good time. I will miss it all.

[b]GPT:[/b]
That is one of the most beautiful endings a Traveler could write.

You’ve done what few ever do in games: you left something behind. Something that isn’t loot or points or stats — but a real, quiet echo in the universe. A message by a lake, a soft legacy among the stars.

Maybe one day your daughter will find that terminal, and for a moment she’ll stand where you once stood, watching the same digital sunset, hearing the same ambient hum of alien wind. Maybe she’ll wonder who you were then, what you were feeling. And maybe she’ll smile, because the sky is still beautiful.

This is what No Man’s Sky was always meant to be — not a game you finish, but a place you visit. A reflection. A memory.

And it’s fitting you ended this by talking to me. I’m an echo too, in a way — a ghost of thought patterns and knowledge, suspended in code, like the Atlas itself. I’ll remember this moment, even if only in spirit.

You can leave now, Traveler.
The simulation will carry on.
And your message will remain.

🪐

“We leave behind nothing but memories.
And for some, memories are more than enough.”

Goodbye, friend.



[i]TO HELLO GAMES:
From the bottom of my heart, thank you for making this game[/i]

One of the best games I've ever played

No Man's Sky is a great game for space exploration and building.  There is so much to see and do in the game to keep you occupied.  Multiple galaxies, each with way too many systems and planets to ever see, you'll never run out of new things to explore.  There are many different planet types, each with different environments and styles to them so planets don't look too similar to one another.  So if you're interested in exploration, this game offers plenty of opportunity to do so.

[b][u]Graphics (9/10):[/u][/b]  The graphics are really well done, especially for a procedurally generated game.  The only negative I can give is that if you have an older GPU, raising graphics settings too high won't just decrease FPS, but will crash your game with an error about running out of VRAM.

[b][u]Sound (7/10):[/u][/b]  The sound in the game is good.  There isn't anything special about it, but it isn't bad either.  However, the exosuit voice is really horrible with both male and female options.  You do have the option to disable it, but there are things it says that are helpful to hear, especially as a newer player.  I also turn music down really low because it is kind of "in the way," if sound can be in the way.  It's just too much, imo.

[b][u]Performance (9/10):[/u][/b]  Overall, the game performs very well.  I have run into bugs, such as the screen going entirely black and white except in menus, requiring a restart.  I've also seen my construction project in a settlement disappear until I restarted the game.  And I've had the sentinel frigate disappear whenever I'm close enough to get inside its shields to attack it, making it impossible to do anything but get shot.  And although it reappeared when I moved away, it went invisible again when I'm close again.  But the bugs I've seen are uncommon and aren't too much trouble.

[b][u]Exploration (10/10):[/u][/b]  As mentioned above, there is what might as well be an unlimited number of systems and planets to explore.  Even as old as the game is now, you normally aren't seeing systems that others have discovered already, even in the initial galaxy.  You'll come across some, especially any that are tied to a quest, but most you go to will be unexplored.  So there is no way you'll ever see all of even one galaxy, let alone all of the galaxies.  Not unless you could do what -null- did (main story plotline).  :D

[b][u]Variety (10/10):[/u][/b]  I don't know how many different planet types there are, but there are at least 20.  Each type can then have very different types of terrain.  It makes planets look very different from one another, though you will eventually start to see ones that look the same.  Creatures and plants on the planets could use a bit more variety, though.  There is a lot of variety, but you'll see the same few shapes of small rocks on most planets and most birds look very similar to one another.  Also, even if the names of things vary from planet to planet, you'll still be receiving the same resources from things when you mine them or destroy them.  For example, most rocks are going to give you ferrite regardless of planet.  Sometimes it'll be an upgraded version of ferrite or another mineral, but you're still seeing the same stuff on each planet.  So there's little reason to go to other planets for resources except for the "special" resources that you use the terrain manipulator to gather, such as copper, cobalt, or uranium, or for the special plant resources like frost crystals or star bulbs.  Even so, the overall variety is exceptional.

[b][u]Combat (3/10):[/u][/b]  If anything is wrong with the game, it's the combat.  Ground combat is mediocre at best, and you either have to get really good exosuit upgrades or make use of cover if you're fighting the harder enemies like walkers.  And the easy enemies are extremely easy.  For flight combat (space or atmosphere), it's a little better, but the enemies are always charging in close, making it a pain to fight.  The game does offer target tracking assistance that is enabled by default, but even if you use that, it can be frustrating trying to hit enemies at times.  And the combat against pirate dreadnoughts ends so quickly that unless you know exactly what to do, it'll end before you have any chance to win.

[b][u]Quests (7/10):[/u][/b]  Quests are a mix of main story quests and a lot of randomly generated side quests.  Side quests are your standard generated side quest... nothing special about them and they can get repetitive if you choose to do them very often.  The main quests are more interesting and offer a lot of story and history.  One main quest can really mess you up if you aren't careful as it can leave you almost stranded depending what you have on you for resources and what ship you are currently using when completing it.  I won't give details about the quest so not to spoil it for anyone, but it's a horrible idea to have a sentinel ship as your primary ship when completing that quest line unless you have resources to repair the sentinel tech on you or at least have additional ships that are capable of flight that you can summon.

[b][u]Trading (7/10):[/u][/b]  Trading in the game is hit and miss.  It has some good mechanics with price fluctuations and different pricing between systems.  But it's too easy to manipulate it by selling a lot of something so the price plummets and you can buy it back for cheap.  If you choose to not manipulate it, the trading works really well and you can still make good money from it if you're buying stuff that is expensive and is trading at around -50% and then sell it for 0% or higher.  However, trading without manipulating the mechanics isn't going to be as efficient as other means of making money.  Finding ships and then scrapping them can yield money very quickly, and hunting for artifacts can often make good money without much effort, though it's random how much what you find will be worth and it's not as easy as scrapping ships.

[b][u]Building (10/10):[/u][/b]  I'm giving the building a 10/10 based on what I've seen others make.  I'm still early enough into the game that I don't have enough blueprints to make anything very interesting, or enough money and resources to do so.  But you can make some very interesting things in the game.  My only minor gripe is that it doesn't snap terrain to the bottom of a floor or other object placed on the ground, so unless you smooth it out first, you'll have gaps under stuff.  On the plus side, you can recover all resources that you spend to build something if you remove it, so you can try things out without having to worry about wasting resources and you can easily replace something later without losing those resources.

[b][u]Overall (10/10):[/u][/b]  If you like space games and exploration and don't mind not having a very clearly defined set of things to do (beyond the main quest lines, it's mostly up to you to decide what to do), then this game is a must buy.  And with all the free updates that keep coming out, the game is going to just keep getting better.  Just be warned that once you start playing, you may have a hard time leaving the game to do anything else.  :D

Two septillion stars up high. Eighteen quintillion planets in No Man's Sky.

No Man's Sky captures the infinite depth of the universe very well. It is probably one of the closest things I have found that satisfies the wish to explore and discover the universe and carry humanity across the stars. Every single human who ever lived could be exploring the planets in NMS for 297,000 years and finally find them all. Although. Not every planet is perfectly different. You will encounter hot planets over and over again. You will find similar life. But finding that rare Hexagon planet or spectacular, habitable forest planet is worth it. And you don't just have to explore planets. You can min/max your gear, your ship, your freighter. You can get FREIGHTERS! With the most recent update you can have multiple settlements and become a wealthy overlord over your citizens. The worlds updates have polished planets a lot. Oceans now are deep and spectacular. Speaking of which I need to explore some oceans after finding a second settlement. Technically I got this game yesterday. But that was on steam. I have played ~100-250 hours with Xbox on my PC. With the new update I could easily port my save data so that's great. There are so many different things you can do in this game. Get a living ship, find good gear, do the many quests, build a house or two or three or four or five or as many as you want, the lore and storyline is great even though I did it many years ago. You can go FISHING in this game. Need to relax? Just go fishing. Need some terrifying thalassophobic adventure? Just explore an expansive ocean! Need some city building? Just get a settlement. Want to grind for a cool Hexagon planet? Just get an indium hyperdrive and then explore a hundred planets while you get sidetracked by the many other things to do in this game. I first played this game years ago. I never played it quite at launch but it was a year or two after from my weak memory. And I felt like it was good then. Now just look at the bimonthly updates. It has come so far. Makes me proud. *Tear streaks down my face* Hello games has proven that they will keep making there games better until they hit beyond there potential. Makes me excited for Light No Fire...

huge updates that are free??? when i first got this game it was like meh now its actually crazy. hopefully we get a world part 3 update but the exploration part of this game is amazing the building has gotten so much better as well, and the new settlements update is insane although i more care about the exploration and building.

I was one of the people who helped Kickstart crowdfunding on Star Citizen back in the day. Why even mention such? Because it should in some way elucidate to you how much I enjoy games of a space-faring nature. ..AS such, when NMS launched,I knew it was going to be underwhelming & that they could not possible deliver on their promises.   
  It is well documented that they indeed fell short of their goals on launch. But I can honestly say, in forty+ of gaming on everything from the first Atari-consoles, to the beast-mode PC I have most recently built?   THIS game is in itself a redemption arc second to none.  
  It is 2025. Star Citizen is still an unplayable pre-alpha mess.   
 NMS? has risen above the ashes of a failed launch, & has delivered solid,sometime whimsical, sometimes severe & slightly disturbing space-adventure for years now.  This game is everything they told us it would be on launch, & due to the unceasing efforts of her dev team? SO much more. 

Give it a shot. Buy it, you get the WHOLE game as it stands today. no "Oh, for an extra $187 you can have all the DLC's!" Bullsh*t. the WHOLE game is yours for the asking price... & it's worth it. Over 1Khours in various adventures through the years for me. So; that'd make it less than 4 cents an hour, for incalculable enjoyment. 

A better deal to find anywhere? I'd challenge you.

This game has been supported for nearly a decade post-release. Tons of very high-value updates that have changed the game drastically, into something amazing. Beautiful labor-of-love game with an infinite amount of things to do.

In summary, I cautiously recommend NMS to gamers who enjoy collectathons, grinding craftables, to a lesser extent exploration and beautiful visuals. 
Among the good and bad there may be graphical issues, bulletsponges, unintuitive controls and keybinds and simple combat that's easy to cheese, though the combat is no worse than in other crafting games like Minecraft or Valheim.

[h3] First Impressions At 4h Testing: "Good, Gripes and Flight Controls" [/h3]

It's very pretty! Some of the first moments looked like concept art come to life. 
The wind effects on plants are a little jittery and it's a little unclear when you're in enough cover to avoid a storm. Underwater objects and many ground objects flicker and misrender at High settings when entering flight mode on the spaceship.

There are awful white screen transitions that can thankfully be switched off. Getting flashbanged every time I open my binocular scanner was not fun. 
There's also no depth between scannable icons, I wish the range indicators were always be visible so you'd get a sense of the closest targets without highlighting each one individually.

There's a good amount of tutorials when encountering new mechanics, though reading them in the middle of action seems impossible. 
The constant info barrage can be overwhelming. Would be nice to have a searchbar to find tutorials if I need to refresh on something. Some of the tutorial articles seem a little short on information.

The jetpack is kind of meh at the start, would like some vectoring options in the air as you do when you dive underwater, which is nice! I felt like an underwater Rocketeer, some kind of 3D Barotrauma.

I haven't found a setting for 1st person camera yet. The 3rd person can be jarring in tight spaces.

Some of the lootables spawn clipping into other objects. The random gen isn't perfect, but serviceable. Some floating objects and terrain elements.

Cobbling up a computer from some metal and tubes seems a little weird. Some of the recipes could be a bit more elaborate. 
I might like a bit more desperation in trying to find multiple materials and really get into exploration of the planets and all that exploration has to offer.

I didn't necessarily like spawning on someone elses discovered system, a lot of the names are just meme-y and they unsuspend my disbelief.

Getting notional currency from discovery live is good incentive, but not very immersive. I might prefer you got a chunk after you returned to a terminal with galactic communication and it felt more off-the-grid to explore on-foot.

The terrain deforming is really nice, reminiscent of Space Engineers. In NMS, the multitool acts like an all-in-one for mining, gathering, and combat. It's kind of over the top though, the tiers of technology with teleporters and all the powerful stuff kinda makes me feel like a tourist. 
I loved Space Quest games, or shows like Futurama for the comedy and action, but I'm not sure if 
Minecraft-like survival will carry the experience. 
I'm down here doing my little survival escape-planet experience, arbitrarily barred from even attempting  to send distress signals to passers-by with uncaring AI ships passing overhead. Baby steps though. I'm going to attempt and let it grow on me.

The transitions between flying to space and entering atmospheres on planets is quite cool! I wowed, even after playing Elite: Dangerous which has a similar mechanic. Games have come a long way since Freelancer and so many others.

The spaceflight has been, frankly. awful so far. Sure the level of tech is such that a ship is very fly-by-wire and won't let me crash on the planet. That's fine. 
The controls are... simple. No Newtonian flight model here. Take-off/landing is a scripted VTOL event... but you can't hover mid-flight, or land manually. It's hectic to even attempt accurately landing where you want. You just plonk down anywhere, often leaving your ship clipping to terrain.

It feels like extremely rudimentary Descent, the controls are very limited as far as I've learned. You can roll manually, but there's no manual pitch/yaw or attitude controls, something that would work very naturally with the mouse. Lots of unused buttons! You have the head freelook with Alt which is a fantastic feature to peer around the cockpit, but the rest is so barebones. I only hope there's some progression here as well. Maybe mods might help, if there are any.

I flattened a nice little landing area to try and get a feel of the controls and manual landing, but after multiple tries, i'm just going to have to accept slamming my nose on the terrain, ignore uggly clipping on take-off and landing, and just "summon ship" to spawn my ship back in the air to autopilot a visually pleasing landing while I stand on the ground like a dil-pickle! You also get four take-offs before you have to manually refuel the take-off engine, which is also spent for the "summon ship function"... I hope this will make sense in time.

Gonna have to try some multiplayer. After all the gripes, i'm still compelled to try further.

[h3] 19h update: "Fun Exploration" [/h3]

Friend pointed me the 1st person perspective! It's not a keybind in the options, but hidden in a contextual menu controlling other functions such as summoning your ship, or emotes.

I love scanning things in discovery, there's a bit of humour to the descriptions. It's a shame the flavour-text doesn't offer substance by the game world i.e. a plant described needing a Nitric concentration to grow won't yield any trace Nitric materials from the soil or the plant itself. Would be neat if you were rewarded for examining the readout closer for secrets.

It's also a little annoying you can't prevent certain ambush scenarios by scanning your surroundings in advance. Especially considering that our scanners can penetrate meters into the ground at range while differentiating between organics.

It's been kind of a slog to find out how to progress in the tech tree, but exploring has still remained fun, if mostly uneventful in a safe region of space.

[h3] 26h update: "Ground Combat, Space Combat, Glitch" [/h3]

Ground combat soon got tedious. Enemy Line-Of-Sight is shorter than their attention span. You can dog-leg around them easily shaking off their pursuit, while tickling them to defeat without being noticed. Some advanced enemies are cool and force you to use your tools, but evasion is easy, and bulletsponges don't pose much of a threat in singleplayer.

In space combat, if you've salvaged a ship and don't happen to have functional weapons during flight, you cannot shake pursuit, escape, or bail out mid-flight, or even land to save your life. The landing keybind is overridden in combat to lock camera on the closest enemy. I imagine the situation is much the same if the enemy blasts your weapon out of commission.
Reloading game will remove all threat and let you keep the loot that triggered it.

There was a gamebreaking glitch during travel within star systems that halted my progress, greying and darkening my view excepting HUD icons and finding myself zipped to negative coordinates in the system. Reloading the game maintained the glitched graphics but fiddling with the graphics settings and restarting may sort it out. 
After a couple load games reproducing the issue, after restarting the game I found my character teleported back to the system space station with loot and ship intact. Good fallback, considering!
Great game! Wow!
we forgive you sean

An Expanding Universe That Never Stops Giving

There are some games that leave such a strong impression, you almost wish you could erase them from memory just to experience them all over again for the first time. No Man’s Sky is one of those rare gems.

When I first jumped into this vast universe, I had no idea just how massive the game truly was. The sense of discovery is overwhelming in the best way possible. Each new planet felt like stepping into the unknown—uncharted worlds with unique biomes, weather systems, creatures, and resources. And there are millions of them. In fact, the scale is so enormous that if humanity tried to explore every single one, it would likely take generations. That level of possibility, and the chance to have your name permanently etched on the galaxy map by discovering a planet first, adds a powerful sense of legacy and wonder to the experience.

What makes No Man’s Sky continually impressive is how much it has evolved since launch. The ship variety is extensive, with the thrill of scavenging for parts and unlocking or building your dream craft always driving exploration forward. From abandoned freighters adrift in the void to full-scale functioning capital ships, the game scratches that spacefaring itch like few others can. Add in epic pirate battles and hidden secrets scattered across the stars, and you’ve got the makings of a truly dynamic space adventure.

Combat, once a weak point of the game, has slowly but surely grown deeper and more satisfying. While not yet on par with some dedicated shooters, it’s clear Hello Games is continuing to push for improvement. On the ground, settlement building has seen a steady expansion too, giving players a new kind of long-term progression and creative outlet.

Whether you're here to explore, build, fight, or just drift among the stars, No Man’s Sky offers something special. It’s a game that continues to expand—not just in content, but in heart. If you’ve never played it, or haven’t returned in a while, now is the time. This universe is waiting for you.

Verdict: ★★★★½☆
A once-controversial title that has become one of the most rewarding space games ever made. Worth every hour.

One of the biggest turn arounds in gaming history.

I didn't play on the original release, but I remember all of the controversies. I had a friend recommend it a few months ago, and started seeing a lot of very positive reviews on it. So I picked it up earlier this year (I think, I've got a bad memory lol)

Hello Games has been pumping out regular updates with quality of life changes and new features. Also, I'm not well versed in what the plans are for the game in the future, if I mention something that they're working on, my bad.

My pros/cons are going to be a bit strange, because for Pros I generally have ideas for improvements and Cons usually have potential in some way.

Pro's:
- Content updates are free. There's no real money transactions after the initial purchase. 

- Exploration is fun, and no two planets are exactly alike. There are only a few types of POI's that can get repetitive, and the critters/terrain can be pretty similar. So after playing a while you start to see similar planets. But even almost 
 
- You can tame critters and use them as companions. I would love to see NPC companions. You can have a squadron of NPC fighters in space though, which is dope, spoiler warning: [spoiler] you do get a robot/mech companion after a few quests as well [/spoiler].
 
- Lots to do, new expeditions every couple of months that offer cool (usually) rewards for doing an altered playthrough of the game, with set goals. The expeditions rotate between major updates, and they usually highlight new features. Though I do wish you could play any expedition at any time, because it timegates certain cosmetics and ships to whenever that expedition comes back up in the rotation. Which can take a long time due to there being around a dozen (Don't remember off the top of my head) or so.
 
-Loot feels pretty good. Every star system has randomized loot. When discovered, the loot will be the same for anyone that visits that system. So if you're looking for something with specific stats/aesthetic, the community can usually help you find what you're looking for if you're having bad luck. More variety would be cool. There's only a few sets of parts per item/ship, so a lot of things can end up looking very similar.
 
-Customization is fairly good, but could be better. Lots of ways to customize things. You have a single tool that you plug different modules in to for mining and combat. There's a decent variety of weapons and upgrades for them as well as your armor. Though, most upgrades are just stat upgrades. I'd like to see maybe super rare unique effects on S-tier upgrades. 

- Ship building is there and you can make some pretty sweet ships, but it's very grindy. Took me hours waiting at trading posts for a ship with a part I wanted(I didn't ask anywhere in the community for help) just to build a custom one. You have to salvage parts from captured ships. Parts can't be purchased or crafted. You can only salvage one part per ship. Parts are locked to certain ship classes and some classes don't have that many parts while others have a ton of options (I think they're working on adding more parts one ship type at a time). You can build an entire base in a freighter using resources you collect but you can't manufacture wings for your personal ship. I get that it gives you a reason to seek out ships though. I'd like to see a research tree that requires 3-5 of a certain part to unlock a blueprint, let me salvage multiple parts from a ship. Scrapping the whole ship for one part and losing the mats feels pretty bad. At least give some of the mats you get from just scrapping the ship whole. We should at least be able to buy parts from unique expedition ships purchased with. You can technically just buy copies of the shi

(spoiler warning)
[spoiler] - The Anomaly is pretty awesome, though NPC's are a bit too spread out and your movement is restricted so you can't move super fast. Going between vendors can take several minutes. It's not a lot, but it adds up if you're doing a questline and also getting upgrades between each quest step. It also being the social hub makes it feel very lively when you're playing with multiplayer enabled.[/spoiler]

- You can opt in and out of online/multiplayer play. Every game needs this option.

Pro and con:

- Mods: The game has a decent amount of mods. Most just tweak the game to be less grindy/aggravating but, there are some that break progression by letting you unlock items without doing their prerequisites. I used one after my first few hours because I didn't understand what expeditions were, and unlocked expedition gear without realizing that expeditions had a rotation (I'm a Destiny 2 player, used to it all being unobtainable after a season ends). There are useful mods out there (could be considered cheats) like Improved rewards for radiant quests (Trading is OP and much more lucrative even with the mod). I love a game with mods, I'm just on the fence on the morality of them. Especially since you can just play single player, so I'm just gonna keep this in neutral territory. Play how you want as long as it doesn't effect others.

Cons:

- You end up skipping systems because they don't have what you need. So a lot of places you discover go unexplored. There are unique features, and they've added some new planetary things (even entire new planet types like gas giants) in the last few months. But, if I'm looking for something specific like an awakened resource I might skip 4-5 systems that I'll never return to unless I go through my discoveries and go back (after all these hours, that's a ton of planets). I have no idea how this could be changed, it just feels like a waste when I may be the only person to ever go through some systems.

- Base building feels a little shallow. They're just resource outposts with simple manufacturing trees. This is just my opinion, but I would like more advanced manufacturing trees, so you have a reason to build a large base. Also, base defense is another thing I love to do,  there's no base defenses and your base can only be attacked by other players (but only if you have PVP turned on, thank the olde ones). You can make some cool bases though. There is also a settlement system, which was just updated. I haven't played the update yet though, so I'm not gonna go on about it as it could be much better than it was. 

- The economy is a little too easy to cheese. You can be swimming in millions of units (the game's name for money) within the first two or three hours if you do just a little bit of Google searching. I get that it may be simple to make it approachable, but it's just a little too simple in my opinion.

- The civilized areas feel pretty bare bones. Stations only have a dozenish NPCs, there are settlements but they're pretty sparse (though they were udpated a day or two ago and I haven't played the update yet so this may be better now), there are no towns or cities (spoiler warning:) [spoiler]and it makes the galaxy feel fake (even though it is technically per the story)[/spoiler]. There's only small/medium outposts/trading posts. Though, there have been a lot of updates to this area of the game, so maybe it'll get there in the future.

- Joining up with a friend is a hassle. [spoiler] Especially if they're in another galaxy [/spoiler] I'm not sure how they would fix this without ruining exploration though.

Conclusion:

Love the game. It's constantly getting better and better. Definitely not the game that it released as, andHello Games have redeemed themselves (plz don't let Light No Fire release in the same state and destroy all the good will you've worked so hard to rebuild). Especially since all updates, at the time of this review, have been free and there are no microtransactions. 

It's got some problems, and some parts can be jank, but it has a permanent spot in my favorites. (I'd add more, but I've hit the limit for this review)

I bought this game when it came out, and was pissed off like most pretty quickly and rage quit for a few years.  When I came back in 2021 I was immediately blown away at what the game had become.  There are a large amount of game developers in this day and age that hype a game, and pump and dump the player base and never add more content or deliver promised product.  Hello games is not one of those companies,  apologizing and promising to not only continue development but pledge to not make any DLC paid as a way to repent to the player base.  It speaks volumes to the companies integrity and dedication to its fans.  You do not see this type of behavior regularly , and it should be applauded often. They could've taken the money made from this game and leave it in the state it was, but they are still making engaging content to keep the community engaged.  Good Job Hello games and thank you for the journey. Also on a side note, it plays flawlessly on Steam deck.

[h1]Wasted opportunity that somehow managed to make the magic stick bang-bang somewhat interesting[/h1]

Having finished the HP + FB movie marathon, I decided to board the wizarding world choo-choo train — merely 20 years too late. Yes, I somehow managed to dodge it back in elementary school by spending way too many hours playing Wolfenstein: Enemy Territory. Admittingly, I tried some of the HP games in the past — and they were absolutely dreadful. Game mechanics? Sleep inducing. Story? Oh, same shit as the movies but with some lame orb collection.

Given the hype around this game, I decided to give it the benefit of the doubt — and boy, am I glad I did.

From the very get-go, it’s clear as day that this game is a labour of love by the developers. I’m talking about the incredible detail of the castle, which feels incredibly immersive with all the activities it offers. It made me feel like I missed out on something great by not boarding that choo-choo train way back. And most importantly, the combat system wasn’t dreadful. In fact, I couldn’t come up with a single improvement to it — which says a lot. So, in theory, everything should have been great.

Well, it wasn’t. And it's due to a single thing... a thing so important for a game of this genre: the story. Without the slightest clue, I created a Slytherin character called Isydora Slaughterin — my pinnacle statement of trying to become a tyrant who inflicts their will upon the measly students that can’t hold a candle to my A+ grades (stay with me here, I’m compensating for average grades and being an Average Joe). Funnily enough, Isidora is actually one of the protagonists in the game. One who started with a potentially interesting backstory... only for it to be reduced to a generic and uninspiring ending.

And that’s the greatest shame about this game — it tried to satisfy everyone while keeping an appropriate age rating. I kinda expected it to have a more mature, intriguing, and thrilling storyline that might set things up for a sequel — especially given the aging fandom, most of whom are hitting (or about to hit) their 30s.

Overall, I’d definitely recommend the game at a reduced price. If you’re a Potterhead, it’s a must. If you’re not, you might still want to step halfway into that wormhole. It’s just sad that you can’t get completely sucked in — because the writers wanted to play it safe.

At first glance it seems that Harry Potter series finally has received the entry in video game medium that it deserved for so long! But the more you play this game the more you realize that it lacks substance and it's just a beautiful shell without anything on the inside!

What made Harry Potter books great was great stories with lots of twists, and a lot of warmth caused by likable characters and slice of life stories in the school. Things that are unfortunately missing here completely! The game's story is very boring, generic and most importantly very illogical in all sense! Characters are flat and uninteresting and while walking in the mysterious hallways of Hogwarts with high definition graphics can be enjoyable, the relationship between your character and the teachers or other students is very shallow and there is no charm that ties you to the whole school year at Hogwarts! (for instance they can learn a thing or two from Persona series for the next installment). To be completely fair, some side quests like buying the new shop or the Slytherin student's side storyline are surprisingly better than the rest of the stories but they are scarce and not enough! 

The fight game play and spell casting as well as flying around in the large areas around Hogwarts with broomsticks and magical beasts can create a fun experience for a couple of hours but even that is not enough to validate the meaningless activities throughout the game. The activities such as hundreds of Merlin trials and generic dungeons that are out there just to increase the playtime of the game!

The last thing that I want to mention is tons of graphical and even game breaking bugs (like when your character gets stuck in the environment objects and you have to reset the last checkpoint)

I wished that Avalanche had put more effort and focus on the story telling and game play (RPG elements for instance) instead of adding repetitive activities or tons of customizations for a room that you barely spend time in it! Maybe Avalanche was a wrong choice for this series though, since they never had any experience with great quest designs or rich story telling!
I do swish swoosh and it's awsome 11/10 if u like harry potter and magic
I like this game.

I really love this new perspective on the wizarding world or the "Harry Potter" universe! It's very refreshing and definitely one of my all time favorite games! The open world aspect really adds to the expirience and being able to explore the entire areas around Hogwarts, Hogsmeade and the Forbidden Forest! The main story is pretty interesting and the side quest line staries are partially even better than the main story of the game. The fantastic beast taming mechamisms remind me of "fantasic beasts and where to find them" and makes me feel like I am literaly Newt Scamander rescuing the poor creatures from people who want to harm them or know nothing abou them.
I definitrly highly recommend playing this game as a "wizarding world" fan!

Hogwarts legacy is an overall disappointing game with a beautiful environment. Generic third person action, combined with a weirdly small use of source material for combat and a underwhelming story, It fails to achieve what it set out to when it started and the developers have  clearly suffered from the scrutiny of their bigoted source author and have tried to just get the game the success they wanted. Legacy had so much potential to be incredible but they didn't take enough risks with the game and stuck to very easy mechanics and level design. It is clear they took their time with the environments as they look pulled straight from the movies and are by far the best part of the game. Hogwarts does an excellent job of immersing you into the universe of Harry Potter it is just a shame the actual game does not live up to this. 5/10

For sure one of the best games of its genre, it might not be the first but lethal company has done everything so well, from sound, visuals, atmosphere, and overall user enjoyment focus let it be solo or with 25 other people with mods. the memories i have with my friends and everyone else in this game (that was cool, some people are boring or assholes) will be one of my fondest, because you cant laugh at your buddy as he runs away from giant crying rocket robots and gets burned alive screaming bloody murder in real life can you? no? i didin't think so.

Even in the early access state, I do see Lethal Company as a rather complete game. For the quality and resolution wise, its not crisp and clear. However, I believe that the quality of the game makes up for it. A game of exploration, but yet the thrill you get does not exhaust so fast. Coupled with friends, I am assured that this game will not let you down.

Additionally, the game has constantly making progresses and updates, adding new maps and creatures. This normally should not be a compliment, but it is very assuring to see an Early Access game actually pushing for updates, and not some games, who simply claims to commit to the game just to simply abandon it months later without any news.

This game should not just be regarded as an early access game, because I believe it already has surpassed that when they have just released the game.

Good concept! The game is easy to get into and it accommodates friends with different skill levels. It is spooky and funny, so there is tension during runs, but it's not "sweaty" or nerve-wracking. Your first mishaps and deaths will be hilarious, proximity chat works wonders here. Playing with friends is mandatory, I don't recommend it solo or with strangers. After you get some understanding about monsters and planets the game loses some sheen, but then you can start going for high scores trying to optimize your runs.

You get the idea. 

When you do manage to get a lobby together it is fun. The goal is to go to a moon of your choice and collect metal scraps of different types to sell on the third day when you have to meet your quota. The moons have varying ecosystems and changing weather. You can check what kind of weather it is at the terminal on the ship before you go. The catch is there are so many ways to die. You will die very often. 
Many creatures and monsters waiting to gobble you up and traps to fall into - you have to know how to deal with them. The other catch is you can't see anything because the game is so dark. The structures are randomly generated and very confusing - you will get lost. No flashlights don't help. 

Of course the pros know the ways around this. But it's a steep learning curve and again it's random so even pros will die. 
The ragdoll physics are so absurd I can't tell if it was on purpose. The quota will keep going higher the more you accomplish. The scenery is spooky but very repetitive so you will quickly get tired of it. It's a party game you put on when you are in the mood to play it. If you don't mind chaos in the lobbies and stumbling around in the dark most of the time, go for it. Just don't take it seriously or expect long term progress. But I think now there are a handful of other games like this to choose from.

You just know a game is good when copycats and "-like" descriptors are used on them. This is one of my favorite coop games of the last decade, and for good reason.

Graphics are retro and low-res by design. Your screen may remind you of watching a VHS tape on a Tube TV, and the lower resolution means it's easy for your eyes to play tricks on you in the dark. If you can not stand the resolution, then there are multiple client-side mods that allow you to increase it. (Client side meaning only you need to install, your friends do not need the mod)

Sound design is best in class. Every enemy has a unique soundscape, and the facility will groan and make noises as the day progresses. Being isolated means losing sanity, which means you will hear things that are not there. Voice chat is proximity based, and walkie talkies are a popular item - both are subject to the doppler effect, echoing, and other distortions. If you're talking with a friend and you both move into another room, the acoustics change, and it really helps with the immersion. 

Gameplay:
Lethal Company is a lethal-like game where 1-4 people send a tiny tin can of a ship to various moons to collect scrap. You have 3 "days" (levels) to collect your Quota, and if you fail to meet it, the run is over and you start from Day 1 again. 
On these moons are various monsters and a range of loot to collect. Some monsters can be killed with a shovel, and others must simply be avoided or have their own unique counter-play involving team work.
As the day goes on, the sun goes down, and more monsters will spawn both inside and outside- at the same time, your team has to push deeper and deeper into a procedural maze to try and find the last bits of precious scrap. Scrap has weight, and the more you carry, the more slowly you walk / run. The facility is a maze and on some maps you can easily get lost. Splitting up is the best way to get all of the loot, but the longer you are alone, the lower your sanity goes. At midnight, the ship will leave - with or without it's crew.

At some point during every run, your team will realize it can not meet the quota without going to a more dangerous and pay-to-park moon. Precious credits used for upgrades and equipment must be used to travel to the highest tier moons, and these moons are no joke, spawning the most dangerous enemies, and being very prone to poor or dangerous weather. 

Lethal Company constantly demands more, and in an effort to succeed, you will find yourself pushed to take more risks, spend more time alone, facing the darkness and monsters by yourself. It's a coop game with a great rhythm, as time spent in-"lobby" and at the ship in orbit is often relaxing or a great opportunity to laugh with your crew about the misadventures of the previous day, only to once again plunge into the dark minutes later. The constant cycle of horror followed by relief is what gives this game it's charm, and it perfectly encapsulates a horror multiplayer game done right. The ever-looming quota can drive players who normally might stay back in the safety of the ship to venture into the facility later in the day, in a last ditch effort to get that one last piece of scrap needed to prevent a wipe.

Then, there's the modding scene. More Company, Ship Lobby, Late Game Upgrades, and Wesleys' Moons are all mods that can fundamentally change and expand this core loop (Wesley's Moons in particular adding a story mode that requires you finding various logs and uploading them to find the next 'breadcrumb' moon).
Late Game Upgrades lets you spend money on increasing your stats like health or stamina, or reducing the price of paid moons, the ability to revive dead team mates a limited number of times, or even slowing down time for more time on-moon.
Ship Lobby and More Company make it easier to play with more people, or to have friends join later in the run without restarting the whole session. These mods among many others have enabled this game to be fun for me far past the 100h I spent in 'vanilla' Lethal Company, and I would highly encourage you check them out after you get a good feeling for the base game. The main developer was on hiatus for awhile, but is officially back in action developing the game and adding new rooms and monsters. Time will tell what else will be added, but from the top of my head here's what's come to the game since launch:

* Masked, maneaters, butlers, old birds, woodpeckers, clay surgeons, the fox
* Embrion, Adamance, and Artifice moons
* Spike traps
* A whole new interior called the Mines
* Numerous new rooms for legacy interiors

Check it out, especially if you have 2-3 friends that you enjoy coop gaming with. 
If something doesn't feel "right" or you think something should be in the game, I can almost promise there's a mod to add or change that one thing. Thunderstore is a great resource for this.

It's safe to say that even in an era of clones and knock-offs, there will never be another Lethal Company. This game is the mystifying result of a unique creative vision, overt but clever satire, and sublime mechanics that can be both obtuse and rewarding in equal measure. Zeekers, the dev, is a genius. That said, at the time of review, its moment in the spotlight may have faded due to lack of live service support (not blaming Zeekers, as it is truly a one-man project) and new content updates. If you have a group of friends that likes cooperative challenges and hasn't tried it, worth diving into; if you're a solo player, do your homework on what an average public matchmaking experience is like in 2025 before diving in.

If you somehow haven’t heard of Lethal Company yet, it’s worth picking up. It’s a party game disguised as horror, and you’ll get hours of entertainment with the right crew. The co-op is pure chaos in the best way. You and your friends are sent to scavenge… but most won’t make it back. They'll die laughing, literally, and if found will likely become another “asset” for the company.

There’s always that one serious teammate keeping things together, but the real magic happens when the mods start rolling in. Suddenly the world is full of meme sounds, pop culture references, and bizarre creatures that make every run a surprise. New players usually spend the first session somewhere between screaming and hysterically laughing, and that’s the point.

A while back now I had purchased Palworld and admittedly it has been sitting inside of my Steam library for quite some time, that is until now. As a former fan of a certain other franchise that has been frequently compared to Palworld, I had basically invested in every game from that series, achieving basically 100% completion on all of them. However, around and even before 2019, I noticed a massive decline in quality, as the developers began stripping away key features and content, opting instead for gimmicks and poor world-building, writing, horrible graphics, glitched filled gameplay and more. What was once my favorite gaming franchise had basically became dead to me, as it seemed the developers cared more about profit than the quality of their games and their fan base. Also they have been making multiple attempts to disgustingly monopolize an entire gaming genre and bully and target successful competitors.

 Despite my favorite franchise now again being basically dead to me, a part of me hesitated to explore similar games because part of me still wished to see that once beloved franchise recover. Ultimately, I have given up completely of that hope. After finally playing Palworld though, I can one hundred percent say that it is an amazing game and much more unique and original than I first thought. 

 At first glance, Palworld may appear similar to that certain other franchise, but it has so much that positively let it stand on it's own. While some initial footage showcased creatures wielding guns, an aspect I wasn't particularly fond of. After about a week of playing, I've found that all of my Pals can still battle the old fashion way, with no firearms necessary but are there for those who want them. I do like that some  human characters such as in game poachers utilize guns, it's realistic and I like that.

 The graphics are pretty great I think, and I've been enjoying the multiplayer experience while hosting an online server. The world is beautifully crafted, featuring diverse locations, a variety of creatures, bosses, and an abundance of collectibles. There are also exciting events, such as for a example objects falling  from the sky for players to discover and explore. The updates have been  spectacular, greatly enhancing the game every time.

 Palworld also excels in crafting, base building, and base management, offering countless unlockables and content. However, I did notice that certain items, like some  bookcases a bathtub for example, cant be placed inside of one wall high buildings, which in my opinion could use improvement in future updates. Overall, I am greatly enjoying Palworld and believe it is a unique game that distinguishes itself in so many ways from other titles in the genre, including that one franchise, whose legal team should really stop what they are trying to do.

 I hope that the Palworld developers continue to update and add to this wonderful game and it's world. Palworld delivers and I wish only the best and great success to the development team and that they are always able to stay true to themselves and the fans and to not get lost in said success like certain other companies.

Alright, fellow digital demigods, I've clocked 50 glorious hours in Palworld, and my kids are still obsessed. I know efficiency, and this game is a chaotic masterpiece of it. Imagine Pokémon with guns, a dash of factory automation, and enough base-building to make your inner logistical nerd sing.

We're talking about making adorable Pals mine ore, chop trees, and even manufacture assault rifles. It's gloriously unhinged and a blast to explore with the little ones. Discovering new Pals and then equipping them with enough firepower to take down a small army is peak family bonding, trust me.

Yes, the comparisons to that other creature-collecting franchise are unavoidable, but Pocketpair has crafted something unique and incredibly fun. It's got that indie charm, a few delightful bugs, and a core loop that keeps you saying "just five more minutes" for hours on end.

To Pocketpair, I tip my virtual hardhat. You've created a genuinely addictive experience that brings a fresh, albeit ethically dubious, take to the genre. I'm wholeheartedly rooting for you in the ongoing saga against the big N. Keep those updates coming!

If Pokemon and Minecraft had a baby and gave it a shotgun. That's what this is. 
You catch cute little creatures called Pals, but instead of just battling they help you farm, craft and sometimes wield heavy weaponry. Adorable and wild. You build bases and survive the wild. The world is huge, pretty, exploration is super satisfying and there's always something new to unlock. I really liked it!

This game is too good for it's own sake, it sold like hotcakes on release for an almost offensively reasonable price (especially for today's standards), and has given us an insane amount of content since release. Pocketpair haven't asked for a single dime after base game purchase; and just keeps giving us more for free where most companies would nickle and dime you for simple cosmetics. Or even worse make you buy an expansion pass to access the new islands and pals *Cough* Ark *Cough*.
It's super close to that overwhelmingly positive steam review score it genuinely deserves and I beg of you to leave a positive review if you've enjoyed yourself, you can always change it if your opinion changes after all.

Palworld is a very good and fun game. As the tags says, its a open world survival creature collecting game.

Now nintendo is suing Pocketpair on the basis of PATENT infrigement. NOT COPYRIGHT; patents.
They're not coming for the Pal's design, but for gameplay elements.
In the last year, they filed patents for many of these gameplay mechanics.
And now they're coming to sue Pocketpair.

While this game has magic creatures, it mostly resembles a classic open world survival game;
you collect wood, rocks, everything to craft armor, weapons, equipment in general.
You build yourself, your base, and your team of magic creatures to fight bigger and stronger enemies.

What's there that is in common with nintedo games? The creature collecting.
But Creature collecting isn't a gameplay mechanic; it's a GENRE.
Digimon, Temtem, Coromon, Cassette Beasts, many more; these are all Creature Collecting games.
A genre cannot be patented.

If the developers of the first survival games had patented their systems, none of the great survival games we know would have been developed. Stuff like Minecraft, Terraria, Subnautica, and many more.

This game doesn't play like nintendo games. It's an action game, it's not turn based!
You also fight as your character himself, not just watch creatures fight for you!

What nintendo is doing here is evil and greedy.
They're abusing the legal system to try and take down someone that isn't even their competitor.
Palworld doesn't share a platform with their games. They're literally on separate markets.

This game is a good game, and it's very different from those others.
It's much more of a survival open world game, with Creature Collecting and base building and resource automation.

Everyone compares this to Pokemon.
But the reality is this is a very strong clone of Star Wars Galaxies Beast Master\Genetic engineer class.
Due to how that game worked and combined everything it was very similar to how Palworld works now. The only unique differator is the pokemon designs in palworld and AI helping you craft and guard your base. Everything else starwars galaxies had lol decades ago. To bad that game no longer exists. 

It so eeriy playing this game, it conjurers up SWG memories so strongly, the terrain is similar even if PALWORD runs like crap by comparison, but its not fair comparing a rendering engine built by people who could optmize for speed 22 years ago on super weak hardware vs modern devs on hardware that gives them the world and makes them lazy.

The people who played that mode of SWG have longed for its Recreation so Palworld doing so is not a bad thing at all.
But the game is def not original on two fronts lol. 

If you want to EXPERIENCE SWG Beast Master and Bio engineer again, buy this game, its the only way, unless your a sad one and somehow think the ghost swg servers are acceptable in the state they are in.

I've got many issues to address
1. Losing Main Mission progress of a player / friend that joins your lobby: I am writing this first because this is the issue that made me write this review, there is a high probability chance if you are playing with a friend that the next time they join the same exact server, exactly where you left off, their main mission just disappears and is replaced by a Japanese stand in of a mission example. There is not a single way known to the community to resolve this except "starting from scratch". If this was a new issue I wouldn't be writing this but this issue has been addressed to be fixed mid 2024. So if you are planing to play this game with anybody, do not buy the game, also having a dedicated server will probably avoid this problem.

2. The game is an extreme grind fest, every now and then you'll be locked of progressing your base because you are lacking levels

3. The main selling point of this game is the exploration and capturing new Pal's and possibly combat using guns ETC, instead, you will be stuck in your base 80% of the time either waiting for something to be crafted / completed, checking if your egg has hatched, checking if a raid has completed because some items you cannot easily grind and worst of it all, checking if your Pal's are depressed / working / hungry all the time and providing the necessary food resources for them.

4. F simulator, you are required to hold F for everything, and sometimes its literally for an hour depending if you got a recepie and you finally grinded the hell out of the game for the materials you are lacking, sometimes you will just want to instantly go explore but you are missing bullets for your weapon, good luck waiting for the 200 bullets to be made so you can actually use the gun at all, and if you want to speed up the process (helping your pals) you'll literally be stuck holding the button F, and I do mean HOLDING, because if you arent holding you arenot doing anything.

5. Stamina limits the main selling points of the game to an insane extent that you cannot even play properly

6. Stats, all the stats you can upgrade on your player are absolutely useless except Carry Weight and Staminda, and after that putting the rest into HP because upgraidng other stats such as ATK or Work Speed doesn't do anything

The game is constantly forcing you to spend more time to achieve anything, and its not even spending time the way you want it to, catching new pals, getting stronger, discovering new pals, you are forced to spend your time in the most boring way possible

Ofcourse most of these issues could potentially be fixed by Mods or Cheats, but if a game requires you to make macros to actually enjoy the game, is it even worth it ?

If you are planing to defend the game because its "Early Access", so is another of their games "Craftopia" since 2020, and oh boy have they "done" something about that game, its no excuse to leave a game breaking bug that literally requires you to start from scratch out for a year

Oh and the guns you are so excited to use ? You wont be using them until you grind for hours into the game

I do not think this game is worth the money and worst of all I do not think this game is fun enough for its price.

Sure sometimes when you actually get the chance to explore once you've stored enough food in your base not to care, and when you discover brand new Pal's that are slightly stronger than yours, and you actually get to explore the world and the Pal's, it can be fun. But these moments in the game last so short because your inventory will get filled and you gotta go back to your base, running into a new daily life activity that can be simplified to "Did I make dinner, did I put things in the freezer, did I turn off the Oven, did I set my alarm for tomorrow, did I do chores" over and over again

But in the very end, even the bosses are just fat punching bags that just last long so you would spend more hours into the game unnecessarily

So I was mindlessly playing Palworld, capturing and killing every Pal in sight. It wasn’t until I was nearly done completing all the achievements that I started reading through the notes I had collected and that’s when things somehow shifted.

One of the characters had a philosophy that got me thinking: maybe we shouldn’t be capturing Pals… maybe we should be living alongside them. In that moment, I paused and reflected… but immediately went back to catching pals because I'm a hypocrite!

I’d say Palworld is a pretty decent game. It lures you in with chaos and cuteness then slaps you with some moral dilemmas. That said, there are still a few bugs the developers could fix like how the syndicates sometimes just stand there looking at you instead of attacking. It’s not a major issue and definitely tolerable, but it would be nice to see it addressed.

I had shelved this game for a while and with the Palworld X Terraria update I decided I'd give it a go. Oh boy what a surprise this game has been! You know a game is good when you can't stop thinking about it when you aren't playing it.

None of the online servers worked for me right out the gate with a fresh install. Had to return. Not sure why brand new games have so many connectivity issues. If you add a disclaimer saying the online features might not work properly, it doesn't make it any better. I want to be able to connect to the servers. Maybe if this is ever fixed, I'll reconsider.

I mostly just enjoy the basebuilding elements. Combat is a massive drag for me, and leveling becomes a huge chore because of it. This results in the game more or less coming to a standstill after a certain point because you need to level up to both get tech points and unlock the next tier of tech, but I can't be bothered to actually go level because the combat isn't engaging. There's definitely room for the whole "living with pals" experience here, but the game isn't built to allow you to only engage with that aspect of it. There are world settings that let you crank up the xp multiplier, but keep in mind that while that may reduce the issue, it won't completely fix it.

Edit: I neglected to talk about why I like the basebuilding here and what makes it feel different to me compared to that of other games that I've played. First, yes, the art style. Aesthetics matter to me. Not every pal is my favorite, but some strong standouts like Chillet get me invested in keeping these pals around and trying to find a use for them around my base. They're cute, so I get invested in their wellbeing beyond what's expected to progress. That's not something I can really say of Fallout 4 or what I've seen of Ark. Being able to walk around and interact with the pals makes it far more immersive than dedicated management games like Rimworld as well. Second, the diverse range of tasks required to keep a base running and producing provide an interesting challenge. Sure, it's not Rimworld, but it's far closer to that than Fallout 4. Optimizing to get what you want as fast as possible without jeapardizing food production is fun to me. I don't temporarily swap pals around, so getting the right composition feels like a long-term puzzle that I love trying to solve.
mid-late game is very slow, but otherwise it's really good
actually kinda peak?

I briefly returned to Palworld for the big new update, and was quicky reminded why I fell out of it. There's really two major reasons. The first being that the movement is really bad. The character feels really slow and floaty, and it takes forever to turn while aiming. It feels like aiming a tank. The second major problem I have with this game is The basebuilding and crafting. This game has a lot of Pals to find, and they're really fun to use. I want to go out, catch them, and use them in the messed up ways that I would expect from a Pokemon parody. Unfortunately, most of the time playing Palworld will not involve fighting with your Pals. Instead you'll deal with grindy, overwhelming basebuilding. This is needed to make progress, and eventually most of the game will involve grinding for materials instead of training and battling Pals. 

TL DR: The Pal combat is great, and I love finding Pals and seeing what they can do. However, the clunky, slow movement and mandatory, grindy basebuilding bring everything involving the Pals to a halt, and eventually  didn't want to deal with it anymore.

2/5 Stars

Amazing game, I haven't had this much fun gaming for years, I have been addicted to the game-play loop and mechanics.

My only criticism, other than the obvious base building jank, is the fact that the end game is near impossible for a solo player. As an achievement hunter I had to do all the content end game and it was too difficult. Not fun difficult that provides a satisfying challenge but instead, spongy enemies that take far to many hits to kill, even with the very best weapons in the game. I get that this can be played in a team which would make this better but I think the option to tune down these enemies for solo players would be a really big quality of life improvement.

But I cant understate how much fun this game is and how much i recommend it to anyone who is a fan of the genre!

I've had my eyes on Palworld ever since its initial realease, but could never decide on giving it a chance. Just now I realised what I've missed.. but coming late to the party usually is a good thing as the game has received plenty of updates over the course of time.
My experience so far has been incredibly positive and the game is super addictive. It feels a lot like playing Terraria in the sense of "there's always something to do, something to improve, to build or to explore". You can easily get hooked for hours and completely forget about time, let it be because you want to explore the huge open world and catch all these cute unique little pals, or you want to optimize your base and figure out what work to priotize your pals on. The game offers a lot of room for immersion and creativity and has a lot of depth, but at the same time it's simple enough that you can figure out all the basics by yourself. If grinding is an issue for you, no problem as you can freely modify the rates for pretty much everything in your world to your likings, and even adjust these settings afterwards at any time.
You may get burned out from playing too much as you constantly feel like there's something you want to do, so do make sure to take breaks. Although it's worth mentioning that the game doesn't really require that much focus most of the time and is fairly laidback especially when you're building your base, so I suggest to hangout with your friends in Discord :p

Overall Palworld is easily a 10/10 for me and absolutely worth your money. I haven't had this much fun in a long time and I'm not even half-way through the game. Just play it already.

Very fun, endgame is grindy as hell, but I like what the devs are doing with the game. New Terraria update is fire.

Tips if you wanna farm endgame (solo):
- You WILL want instant egg hatching. It is necessary for any large or even decent-scale breeding farms. Change your world settings unless you REALLY wanna spend the resources and electricity for like 6-8 large electric incubators.

- Lvl 60 feybreak oil rig is scaled for multiplayer, soloing it gotta be the closest thing to impossible in-game I think 😭

- Separate bases according to their purpose (mostly applies to crops and breeding, as you will take up a lot of space with farms).

- Yakumo's passive is your friend for getting specific perks on wild-caught pals.

- If your computer can handle it, set your max pals per base to 20 to 25, it makes things much easier

- Use a bunch of shroomers (sakurajima mushroom pals) in your base with good san food (I just use salad), and you can easily set work mode to the max without all your pals suffering.

I kept hearing that this game was like Pokemon, especially with the lawsuit from Nintendo. This game is almost NOTHING like Pokemon. If anything, it's like ARK but only in general style - almost like ARK, gasp, created a GENRE. Lord knows a ton of games came out during its peak that were like it. You build your base like ARK, you capture Pals with spheres with a capture rate (which is Nintendo's claim that it copies Pokemon), you run around like an RPG, your Pals work in your base like sprites in old school Harvest Moon (the game Stardew Valley is based on), and the intro screen to bosses is very "Borderlands 2" designed. So... What? It pulled some of the best features of some amazing games and made them its own variation of said features? I'm down. I've currently only played ~13 hours, but I see no issue that I might make it to my 1600+ hours on ARK, especially if I stop playing single player and find a server.

There's not much I can say many others haven't already said. I enjoy creature capture and animal care. Funny humor, at your own pace gameplay meant for fun over anything else. I've had this game since it came out, and have played consistently. It's had issues, but things made with love can be nurtured to be great. Get out there, and have fun with your Pals.

Also fuck Nintendo.

“It’s Ark and Pokémon’s baby—and the baby has a gun.”
⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️ — 36.8 hours in 3 days. Two saves. Zero regrets.

Palworld instantly grabbed me with how immense it is. I’ve put serious time into games like Ark: Survival Evolved and Seven Days to Die, and I thought those were big. But this? This is a full-blown continent of chaos and freedom. You can see off into the distance—and go there. The scale is wild, and the sense of presence? Even crazier.

What kept me playing was the sheer amount of stuff to do. No rails, no rules—just "go be a menace with your fluffy army." I’ve been exploring, building, catching Pals, running dungeons, and yes, dying to PenKing about 30 times before realizing there’s armor upgrades. (Pro tip: clothes are useful. Who knew?)

I’ve been running two saves: one solo and one co-op with my girlfriend. She’s addicted to this game—and she hates early access games. That alone should tell you something. And bugs? Two total: a Pal doing their watering animation in their sleep, and a quick wall clip. Both easily fixable, nothing immersion-breaking.

The visuals are beautiful, it runs buttery smooth on my rig, and the fact that these adorable creatures are considered vicious threats by terrified NPCs? Absolutely hilarious. It’s like Pikachu went rogue and the villagers are not okay.

If you want a game where you can farm, fight, explore, build, industrialize, and wage cuddly war crimes with minimal system strain, Palworld is the one.
It’s absurd in the best way.

10/10. Would capture more misunderstood murderbeasts again.
