I've played a lot of early access games, I'm used to bugs and don't mind the unfinished feel so long as the core gameplay loop is present and enjoyable. In Palworld it is. That's all.

I've also played enough early access games to tell you that this game in particular will never feel finished. This game reeks of the dev cycle that games like Bannerlord have, no real intent to fix broken features that are actually holding the game back but instead a desire to drown the game with half baked new ideas that will inevitably add their own roster of bugs that need patching. All in the hopes of maintaining a lagging playerbase that only came here off streamerbait, instead of the core playerbase actually here for the game. I am neither, I saw it on sale and wanted to give it a shot. Of all my crafting games, it is probably the most mid; but since my switch broke it gets the Pokemon fix in alright I guess.

Your pals will never not clip through walls, the PIDF will never not TP to your forehead, your fixed work assignments will never not randomly reset when pals sleep. If you can accept that bugs or just awkward design choices like these are permanent, you'd probably have some fun here. If you want polish, wait until Game Freak tries the same thing.

pokemon with guns, more like The Israeli-Palestinian crisis is a deeply entrenched conflict rooted in over a century of political, territorial, and religious tensions between Jewish and Arab populations over the land historically known as Palestine, now including Israel, the West Bank, and Gaza. The origins of the dispute date back to the early 20th century, as both Jews—many fleeing persecution in Europe—and Palestinian Arabs laid claim to the same territory under the declining Ottoman Empire and later British colonial rule. In 1948, the State of Israel was declared following a controversial United Nations partition plan, triggering a war with neighboring Arab states. As a result, Israel gained control over more land than the original UN plan had designated, and over 700,000 Palestinians were forcibly displaced in what they call the *Nakba*, or catastrophe. The conflict deepened in 1967 when Israel captured the West Bank, Gaza Strip, and East Jerusalem during the Six-Day War, placing millions of Palestinians under military occupation. Since then, the region has seen numerous failed peace attempts, ongoing settlement expansion, periodic violent uprisings known as *intifadas*, and repeated clashes between Israel and Palestinian factions such as Hamas, which currently controls Gaza. The humanitarian situation—particularly in Gaza—is dire, with shortages of clean water, electricity, and medical care exacerbated by Israeli blockades and internal Palestinian divisions.

Despite the seriousness of the crisis, it has at times intersected with global pop culture and sports, revealing how interconnected the world has become. For instance, NBA superstar LeBron James, while not directly involved in Middle Eastern politics, represents the kind of global influence that athletes now wield. With millions of followers worldwide and a reputation for speaking out on social justice issues—from police brutality in the U.S. to voting rights—LeBron’s voice has power beyond basketball. Although he has not made public statements on the Israeli-Palestinian conflict specifically, the way figures like him influence discourse on race, oppression, and human rights shows how even distant crises can be shaped by or draw attention from prominent cultural figures. In a world where public opinion is often swayed through platforms like Twitter and Instagram, the silence or engagement of global icons like LeBron can significantly impact how international conflicts are perceived, especially among younger audiences. Ultimately, while the Israeli-Palestinian conflict remains a bitter and unresolved geopolitical struggle, its human impact and symbolic weight ripple far beyond the Middle East—touching everything from international diplomacy to celebrity activism, and even the global conversation on justice and freedom.

This review is overdue and since I love the game so much, I'll give it my all in putting down my honest feelings about this game, especially after the Terraria collab update. I would also like to say that I have not been to school in many years and my word knowledge took a toll. 

First of, I would like to thank Pocketpair for creating this amazing gem. It's rare for me to sink hundreds of hours in a singleplayer (I play solo) game. Steam and Xbox combined I'm up to over 1,000 hours.  


With the Terraria update I noticed small tweaks in the towns and Pals are more involved. You'll see them working side by side with human NPC's and gave the game more life. The enemy bases gave me more ideas for improving or building another base and I was shocked by the amount of detail in each of them and I wonder if it's normal players that built them, since I've seen amazing base tutorials on Youtube that matched the quality ingame. 

When I saw Fishing achievements I was annoyed "Oh boy, more Fishing!!!!". Boy was I wrong. Fishing not only gives you access to Pals with rare abilities, but can rack up some solid cash on the side and valuable loot like books to improve your favourite Pals. I noticed that the Pals on Xbox are more responsive and gets baited easily compared to Steam. Unless I just gud, who knows but I got 50 fish super quickly, just make sure you aim center mass at the glow spots. I also don't think the Large ponds are worth building, the whole point of Fishing is to do it yourself (lol). As for the actual Fishing minigame, definitely grab the Advanced Fishing rod at level 45 with the best bait you can afford.  

I actually have not played Terraria, but I can tell there's references to the game while I explored the dungeons. Also, new Pals to get can't complain. New books that boost affinities for Watering and Kindling especially makes baby Pals or any Pal that you like viable to use in your base. Those that prefer smaller pals due to spacing issue for indoor bases probably love this update.

Zoe was #1 in the popularity poll (not surprised) and is now recruitable (takes a Pal slot). I admit I did the glitch on Xbox and I already had them, but makes you think if they thought ahead and they were meant to be recruitable.

Anyways, PalWorld is still evolving and there is more to come. I just touched on the topics that matters more to me and the quality of life that'll make me come back time and time again!

Maybe I'll come back when it gets out of Early Access, but honestly this has soured the whole experience.

The game is also graphics-hungry, and I had to lower the settings after a while because I got a black screen and my graphics card couldn't handle it. However, you can also play it very well on the lowest settings.

The mobs sometimes get stuck on pixels or can't find their way back correctly after a raid, but you can carry your friends back to the base.

The base, honestly, is the stupidest thing I've seen in a survival game. First, the area is round (who comes up with that nonsense), then you have to build extremely precisely, as some buildings require so much space that it's ridiculous, since you can't enlarge the "round"; that absolutely has to be changed.

The construction of buildings itself... wow, that needs to be completely reworked. For example: a sloping roof has to be attached to the ceiling, otherwise it won't "snap," so you build a house, build the ceiling, then the sloping roofs, then remove the ceiling again (luckily, the programmers aren't real bricklayers, the houses wouldn't be habitable).

You become early a Sancturie quest (with lvl17-18), but it is a lvl 50 quest, also absolutely stupid. I can't stop telling what's shit in this game. Campfire for doing food, you change that later to a cooking pot, but then the warmth of the night is gone, so there always has to be a campfire or a burning barrel (we're rapping about it).
All nonsense that takes up building space in the "base-round"

Overall, it's playable, but a lot (no the most of things in this game) of things still need to be improved. And as I said, it's just a time thief, save your money, there are better things you can do to spend your time and money.

I downloaded Palworld thinking it was a wholesome monster-collecting adventure. Ten minutes in, my adorable Pal was helping me build a sweatshop to mass-produce ammo while another mined rocks 24/7 with tears in its eyes. I named that one "Steve."

At one point, I gave my sheep a rocket launcher and watched it obliterate a bandit camp while I sat back and questioned my life choices. Then I lassoed a fire-breathing duck and forced it to power my base’s generator like some dystopian Dr. Seuss villain.

The game really teaches you important lessons:

Trust no one.

Capitalism is eternal.

And cute creatures can and will betray you mid-battle if their union demands aren't met.

10/10. I sleep in shifts now, just in case Steve tries to rebel.

It's just fun survival with silly creatures. Overall just a fun time sinker if you like survival games. If I had a slight criticism, the creature designs and art style can feel inconsistent at times (surprisingly, the weaponry is not part of that sense), yet there's still some good creativity and great designs in here

Palworld is what I like to call the better pokemon. Catching pals, fighting with them, having them farm items at your base, breeding/hatching eggs all very good.
The tower bosses, oil rigs and summoned bosses makes grinding worth it I'd say.
Weapons include guns, grenades, swords, even have laser guns in newer updates. Same goes for armor and shields, usually get some new additions in the updates.
Updates also often add new build materials for the bases
New pals and locations are added with some of the larger updates
The most recent update adding fishing and having the terraria realm being part of the update was certainly a great choice for the game with new islands to explore and new pals to catch.
The game is updated often either for bug fixes or new content which is always good. So far all the new content updates since palworlds release have been good, I enjoy returning to the game for updated things and can play for hours easily. Much like with other games I do take breaks once I feel a bit of burnout and may not return to it for months, even then I still find the game enjoyable.
Of course always keep in mind updates could come with issues you may experience crashes (especially if you're using mods that may have not been updated yet to line up with new content) but even then I have only had a few crashes myself and usually can get back into the game no problem (I use mods sometimes so I know why my game crashes)
I look forward to even more updates with this game. 10/10 would recommend.

This may get long. I want to preface this by saying I do love this game, however; This game is filled with bugs that don't seem to get as much attention as they could be. The amount of time that passes between updates is absurd, and with each new content drop they do, the bugs either don't get fixed, or get worse.

Now, the biggest issue for me - The new update.

I have never played Terraria, and while I don't mind the crossover/colab, it did absolutely nothing for the end game. The main piece of content is a level 45 dungeon, where the level cap was just increased to 65. Why was the level cap increased to 65? The new raid boss is level 50, with no ultra variant, we cannot invest the 5 new stat points if we've already used elixers to max everything when we were level 60, the new armor and weapons are, realistically, sub par compared to the level 55/60 armor (Hexolite) that was already in the game. In essence, there is basically nothing to do for those added 5 levels to be meaningful. 

Now, this would not have been a problem in and of itself. The issue lies in the fact that it took 6+ months to release this bit of mid game content, which I will say fleshes out the game quite a bit. The hype around this update was WAY over the top for what was delivered. Pocketpair released basically no information on what we should expect, so the let down was absolutely huge after spending the past 2 months after a fresh start to reach the end game, only to have no new end game content. Which, again, would not be as much of an issue if the updates were more frequent and I didn't have to wait (most likely) another 6-8 months for another real content update like Feybreak or Sakurajima. 

All in all, this is a good game and has a lot of potential, but not if this is what we can expect for the next 2-5 years of updates. Pocketpair, you guys need to kick it into gear with the bug fixes and the content updates. And please don't extend the level cap again if there's no new end game content with the update, it's just ridiculous. 

TL:DR - Update is lackluster for existing saves, too hyped up for what was delivered, bugs suck, Pocketpair needs to do better.

Imagine que alguém jogou Pokémon, achou que eles precisavam de armas automáticas e que a indústria de trabalho escravo estava pouco representada nos jogos. Aí pensaram: “E se os Pals fabricassem minhas metralhadoras ENQUANTO cultivam batatas?” — e nasceu Palworld.

🔫 Ponto positivo: Posso dar uma AK-47 para um coelho gigante e sair numa raid contra um chefão montado numa galinha elétrica.
🥲 Ponto negativo: Fico com peso na consciência quando coloco meus Pals pra trabalhar 24h sem férias. Mas aí lembro que eles não têm sindicato. Vida que segue.

💥 Combate? Caótico.
🍳 Craft? Viciantemente inútil até que você perceba que precisa de 93 ligas de metal pra fazer uma panela.
📦 Gestão de base? É tipo The Sims, mas com greves inexistentes e um dragão chamado Menasting fazendo tijolos enquanto pega fogo.

🧠 Lições que aprendi jogando:

Se algo se move, pode ser capturado.

Se algo é fofo, provavelmente vai virar operário em tempo integral.

Se um Pal tá doente... bom, ainda dá pra ele cortar madeira. A tosse passa.

E se você pensa que está jogando errado, na verdade tá jogando certo. Só não pense demais.

🏆 Resumo final:
Palworld é o jogo que começa com “olha que fofo esse bicho” e termina com “tenho um império movido por Pals e não vejo mais a luz do sol”.
Altamente recomendado para quem sempre quis misturar Animal Crossing, Ark e um leve toque de tráfico de criaturas fofas.

🔨 10/10 – Meus Pals estão cansados, mas meu coração está feliz.

better than anything gamefreak has put out in the last decade, and that's saying something because if this game weren't based around catching creatures it would be fairly mediocre. The pal mechanics are what turn this from a generic survival game to an engaging base management/creature collector.

Palworld is like Pokémon’s rebellious brother who prefers doing things his own way instead of following the path laid out by Nintendo.

Nintendo runs on pure nostalgia, slaps a full-price tag on it, and serves the same reheated dish over and over again. I mean, how many times can we hear the same tune?
Then along comes Pocketpair saying:
“You want cool Pokémon, but with a touch of survival? Come with me — we listen to the community here, because the bond with fans actually matters.”

Nintendo had the chance to do something fresh, like combining Zelda with Pokémon.
The money was lying on the sidewalk... but Nintendo just walked past it, off into their own corporate sunset.

Pocketpair picks up that idea, mixes it with survival mechanics and monster-catching — and now the big N is crying “Plagiarism!”

Fun game. People who haven't played it will tell you it's a pokemon clone, but the gameplay couldn't be more different really. Highly recommend if you like survival games. Most fun with friends or on a server. If you're playing solo I recommend raising the EXP rate a tiny bit and maybe the gatherable resources multiplier. The game can be a grind on normal settings. I usually put EXP rate to 1.2 and gatherable resources multiplier to 2x, so that the game isn't too easy, but also is slightly less of a grind. I also change the item weight multiplier to 0.8 to slightly adjust for the extra resources I get from the multiplier. You can change your world settings at any time, so don't ever feel bad about changing them in the start.

I can honestly say Palworld is one of the most fun games I have played in a LONG time. I don’t play games much but the number of hours I have poured into this game easily beats out all the other games I have in my library. 
I love the Pal designs! At launch people called them Pokémon rip offs, but after each update they have shown they certainly are NOT Pokémon rip offs. I honestly like some of the Pal designs more than most Pokémon designs. Some Pals are cute and cuddly, while others badass.
Base building is another part of the game that absolutely hooked me. Being able to build a base where ever you want is fun and gives you plenty of freedom. It’s also cool to look back and see how much your base evolves as you level up and unlock new technologies. Watching your home grow from a simple outpost into a fully functioning base with resource production, crafting stations, and Pals working together is deeply satisfying. 
The exploration and survival side of the game is something I am typically not a fan of in most games but Palworld is different. The world is huge, and it’s only gotten bigger with each update. There are so many biomes and regions to explore, each with their own unique feel and regional Pals. 

One of the best parts is that the dev team actually listens and delivers. In just 18 months, we’ve seen three major updates, each one packed with new content, new Pals, quality of life improvements, and balancing tweaks. I love coming back to what was added because they haven’t disappointed me yet. You can feel the heart and effort they’ve put into it and it shows. While the endgame can sometimes feel like a grind, the devs have made solid improvements to breeding, and trait hunting is more accessible now. Rarer materials aren’t as painful to collect as they used to be. It's a great sign that they’re committed to improving the game for the long haul.
And let’s be real the constant Pokémon comparisons just don’t hold up. This isn’t some lazy nostalgia cash grab. Palworld is its own thing and it’s better for it. It’s a game made by people who clearly care, not just about their product but about the community playing it.

Very disappointed with this game from both a visual and gameplay perspective.

This game has an issue with visual whiplash. The characters have a very stylized visual style, while the environment is much closer to realism with a very bland, uninteresting style. While it's important to differentiate your characters and environment, this game does it in an unappealing way.

Gameplay leaves a lot to be desired here. The building mechanics are incredibly janky, making it sometimes impossible to lay buildings out in any formation that isn't just a standard box.  The game also advertises pal automation of base operations, but this functionality is incredibly limiting. Pals can be set to automatically complete a job for you, and gather resources; however, more advanced multi-step recipes can't be preplanned for automation. This becomes a huge problem in the late game when you need better balls to catch strong pals to level up. Crafting high level balls is an enormous chore, and makes the end game grind unbearable.

Pal customization is also a chore and a bore that doesn't pay off. Since every Pal can learn every move/trait in the game, and Pals not having their own unique base stats, different Pals are effectively just a skin. The only two unique aspects of a Pal are their underwhelming passive abilities and their typing.  The meaning of a Pal's stats is even further diminished by Level heavily influencing Pal damage output. If I create a level 40 Pal with all their stats superior to a level 50 Pal, I will still lose the fight because of level alone.

Speaking of the fights, combat in this game is awful. There is very little agency to battle. Pals use moves on their own, with only some Pals having a special attack you can activate with almost no feedback to the user as to whether you successfully activated the skill or not. The most "strategic" way to play I've seen is being able to recall a Pal before they get hit then resummoning them since there appears to be no cooldown on summoning. You can also run around shooting things yourself, but player damage seems greatly inferior to Pal damage, and isn't particularly engaging on its own either. For a game advertising itself so heavily on its monster taming aspects, I would expect far more engaging combat involving the monsters.

One of the best survival games on the market, and that's not hyperbole.

Active dev support, a growing modding scene, and unlike other survival games like it, the grind won't kill you or consume your life. With even a little bit of effort you can see and do most content in this game without much problem. Unlike say, ARK, where you'd need to no life grind for ascendant gear and min-max breeding to even complete the standard boss fight, you don't need to do that here.

You can though, if you enjoy minmaxing, optimizing, and grinding that's all here for you if you want to hit the upper echelons of palworld, wiping bosses out in seconds. 

The new terraria update has made it so with the trust mechanic, even pals with lower stat IVs are still viable for use! 

If you enjoy fun, whimsy, and supporting what nintendon't, buy it.

This game scratch a spot that itched me for so long as a pokemon fan.

New rules same concept, I felt like a child rediscovering pokemon for the first time. Cool places to be, cool creatures to get, strategies to adopt, with proper difficulty.

Above all, ironically for a game where the goal is pretty much enslaves creatures to do your bidding, I've been far more attached to my creatures than in any pokemon game. There is something inherently special to come back to your base and see your pals not only work for you, but help you and being happy to do so when creating a new building. And don't get me started, being able to play with my friends, it feels so weird yet so right. 

The quality of the game has been astounding so far, and seeing the grow with the years is an honor. I actually feel respected as a consumer.

tl;dr interesting premise, tedious execution.

This game is really designed around multiplayer. It probably won't interesting to play for long as single player as there's no real structure to hang everything on. I liked the premise and it had a promising start, but the grind and lack of an overarching plot wore that away. Also, as a personal gripe, I hate spoilage mechanics. 

Issues found with the game (in no particular order);

1: The UI is poor. The UI is clearly designed to be cross-compatible with consoles, but this creates real challenges when dealing with this level of complexity. A user should be able to;

Hot-button consumables & gear.
Auto-craft (i.e. not have to physically hold down the craft button to complete).
Search pal lists by the name of the pal.
Sort the expedition pal selection screen by combat power level.
See an indicator of gear wear level outside of the inventory.
See passive/partner skill definitions on any screen where the skills are visible (there are a lot of skills).
See pal habitat from pal management screens.
Etc.

2: The game is kind of samey. Hour 30 is pretty much just like hour 2, just with more pals/buildings. In a way, the pals work against the game as they are better than the player at almost everything, leaving the player with not a lot to do beyond capture more pals and play manager. Additionally, the huge number of pals & skills adds complexity without adding depth.

3: Can't pause single-player games.

4: Game is pretty grindy. For a max star pal, you'll have to capture/breed over 100 of that pal. You'll probably want to make sure it has skills you want and a good stat growth pattern, which can require a lot of pals (and time) to acquire. As noted above, all building/crafting takes time to complete, so you'll likely spend a considerable amount of time just holding down the craft button.

Palworld is an excellent survival crafting game that just so happens to have a growing library of monsters that you can catch and put to work. The developers are releasing updates at a solid pace, adding to every stage of the game and bringing in quality of life features that just seem so fitting and natural in hindsight. I can easily recommend Palworld in its current state, but it becomes even easier to do when you realize that the game is just going to keep getting better over time. 

Even though the game is focused on resource collection and application, the Pals steal the show. There are many fun designs, and the monsters often have their own adorable animations that bring them to life wonderfully. Everyone has their own favorites, and I have enough that listing them all here would be longer than the rest of this review. In the end, I am very satisfied with the Pals, and putting them to work like a benevolent slave driver never gets old.

Palworld is an easy recommend from me, and I am interested in seeing what the future holds for it. Incineram is the best.

The game is fantastic, and shows how good D&D as a franchise can be if it's free of corporate meddling and willing to approach sensitive topics with nuance and care. I sincerely believe that Larian Studios is one of the best developers when it comes to both plot and mechanics (particularly when it comes to RPGs), and their design choices and expression of those two elements has only improved over the past decade.

While it is a shame that we're unlikely to see Larian's brush paint a masterpiece upon the canvas of the Forgotten Realms again, I have faith that whatever they make next will be great.

I actually borrowed this game from a friend before securing a copy for myself, because I just couldn't wait until I had the funds to spare. When I tell you that I easily poured 200 hours into this grand love-letter to Dungeons & Dragons before it ever touched my Steam account, I'm being 100% truthful. 

The complete package this game provides cannot be overstated. There's a character creator that can be used by fellow tabletop addicts to create as many characters as you'd like; a strong, moving, elegant story, which branches into so many different paths that you can discover new paths just by choosing a new line of dialogue, or moving a rock aside in the overworld; the music, which never fails to raise the hair on my arms even while I'm just sitting on the title screen or idling in camp; the options for companionship and romance with your party members, who feel, in the best way possible, like real human beings, people who can strive towards heroic greatness or follow you down a dark path to villainous ruin; the countless non-playable characters that bring the world to life; the ability to start a playthrough from the perspective of ALL the major companions rather than making a character of your own; and, last but certainly not least, the addition of a SECOND main storyline via the Dark Urge origin option, which deviates from the default story just enough to give you a brand new experience. This game eclipses its market price several times over. It's simply astonishing.

Oh, and there's cross-platform multiplayer now, in case you've ever wanted to throw your friend's lovingly-crafted D&D character into a chasm.

Buy this game. Play it, love it, share it with your friends. Send love to the voice actors, the scenario writers, artists, and programmers - everyone at Larian, really. Baldur's Gate 3 is a one-of-a-kind masterpiece that everyone should try at least once.

"Shining star of mine, hold tight,
Don't fight the power."

PS: ROMANCE KARLACH.

The game itself was great. Lots of choices, varied and differing paths depending on character choices. 
The game is an utter memory and power hog though. 
I just had a technical situation taht seemed like no one was going to address or fix. 
Occasionally, the graphics card just stops and the monitor goes black with no data input. 
I see that this is a known issue in the forums. I've been doing the recommended clearing the cache and lowering the screen resolution. Which Sucks, because that was one of the selling points of the game. 
But this would only stop the Black Screen for a little bit. 
Multiple times a week, I have to hard shut down and restart. Sometimes I even have to switch monitor ports and reinstall the drivers. 
And NO ONE has offered a fix. 
Now, this black screen thing has started outside of playing BG3, So I have had to stop playing it and remove it from my computer. 
Great job guys.

Am only about 17 hours into playing so far, it has been a learning experience, but am enjoying it. You can tell a lot of love and effort has gone into making this game.

For reference, I am not an D&D nerd, and am not very experienced with CRPG's, I have played them, but never knew about the underlying DND and dice stuff. With this game the dice rolls are central to a lot of the game, so you have to learn about it to play effectively.

Only cons I had come across are some janky bugs (like a central party member not appearing where she should near the start, a reload fixed that, but I only knew she wasn't there as someone who knows the game was watching me play and told me!). 

Overall very good game, it is turn based (which normally isn't my thing) and has a lot of dialogue, so you need to be prepared to slow your gameplay down and use your brain to progress.

9.9/10

Absolute...ly love this game. Truly amazing game. I am a huge fan of BG1 and 2 and this game just brings those amazing adventures into the modern age.

My only complain is the sheer amount of romance. I understand that the devs wanted to create an open world where there is romance options for basically anything and anyone. The issue is that it is CONSTANTLY thrown at you. You will be trying to get to know any character in a good way and then all of a sudden they want to go diving in YOUR dungeon... or show you their Dragon. Or the characters will randomly bring up sex while you are just walking around (the companions will start engaging in conversation with each other as you wonder around the world. The issue is you will be going into a crypt where there are spooky scary skeletons and stuff, and then one of the characters will start talking about gender roles in the underdark and how relations with men is for baby making and relations with women is for pleasure. It just is really out of place. The NPCs and companions will just immediately talk about romance in really weird times and not even player provoked. My first real time speaking to Karlach she was talking about her desires for Jaheira. I am fine with romance in video games, but this game feels almost like a dating simulator or what I would imagine one of those weird Japanese harem games is like. Sometimes I just want to go out with my companions in a completely platonic way and save the world from evil. But even if I always turn down my companions, they will still bring it up and again even when I the player isnt even talking to them, again the characters will still bring it up.


Now all of this said, THAT IS MY ONLY COMPLAINT. This game is an absolute masterpiece. I have never had this much fun playing an RPG. This game makes me feel like I am playing a table top RPG but without the struggle of scheduling everyone. The story is truly captivating. I am 130 hours into the game now and I still have not completed the game on my first play through. Also I have noticed that there is opportunity to replay this game over and over. 

If you like tabletop wargames, rpg, the Faerun setting, D&D, or anything fantasy, then this is the game for you. 9.9/10 (would be 10 if there was an option at the beginning to tone down the overall amount of romance stuff. That is literally my only complaint)

Games like this have always been my favorites: Dragon Age, Diablo, Fallout, etc., etc. I really don't have much to say that's different from other players - I have dedicated HUNDREDS of hours to this game between two runs, one Origin run and one Dark Urge run. Probably a first for a majorly single player game. Different romances, different play styles between a lawful good Cleric of Selune and a chaotic good bard. I definitely did end up discovering things in my second run that I didn't my first run, despite said first run being 150+ hours long, and I'm sure that I'll discover something new when going into my third run. I get attached to the characters, I love the story line, and when you do co-op it genuinely just feels like you're playing D&D at times. I've stayed up all night multiple times just to play this game.

As someone who enjoys D&D outside of BG3, it's been fun creating my PCs from campaigns and throwing them into this world, especially my Descent into Avernus character, which really forces me to play different styles because of my love for role playing. I enjoy seeing what Larian had provided their dedicated audience since BG3's release, from added story lines to bug fixes to just genuine interest in what the fandom gives. It's been such a fun, wild ride that I've even considered getting into Divinity: Original Sin just because I believe Larian Studios produces good games AND going back to see what the other Baldur's Gate games have in store.

What I loved: The freedom to really be whoever I wanted. The characters are messy in the best way, and the story had me hooked from the start. I got to make big choices that actually changed things, and the romance options?? Whew. Let’s just say I made some decisions I’m still emotionally unpacking.
Combat was fun once I got the hang of it, even though turn-based isn’t usually my vibe. It made me think but still let me be wild and creative with it.
If I had to pick something I didn’t love, it’s that the game can get a little overwhelming if you’re not used to these types of RPGs  but honestly, once you settle in, it’s a wrap.
Would I recommend it? Absolutely. Especially if you love story-heavy games, emotional chaos, and being a little dramatic with your choices. This one’s for the storytellers, the schemers, and the softies with a sword.

[h1]🧙 Baldur’s Gate 3 – Review[/h1]

[b]Baldur’s Gate 3[/b] isn’t just a return to one of RPG’s most sacred franchises—it’s a love letter to Dungeons & Dragons, turned into a sprawling, reactive, and emotionally gripping adventure. Developed by Larian Studios (the minds behind Divinity: Original Sin 2), it’s one of those rare RPGs that actually earns the word "epic."

This isn’t just a game. It’s a [i]campaign[/i]. And you're going to be talking about your playthrough for years.

[hr][/hr]

[h2]Strengths[/h2]

[list]
[*][b]Incredible narrative freedom[/b] – Every decision matters. Whether you talk, fight, seduce, or betray your way through the world, the game adapts. Your actions ripple through the story in meaningful and sometimes [i]hilarious[/i] ways.

[*][b]Unforgettable characters[/b] – From the vampiric snark of Astarion to the gentle ferocity of Karlach, every companion is deeply written, well-voiced, and worthy of obsession. Romanceable, too—if you're into that. (And you will be.)

[*][b]Turn-based combat done right[/b] – Based on D&D 5e rules, the combat is tactical, creative, and often wildly chaotic. Shove people off cliffs. Set oil on fire. Summon magical chickens. It's pure sandbox joy—especially on higher difficulties.

[*][b]Drop-dead gorgeous[/b] – Visually, it’s stunning. From gothic cathedrals to fungal underworlds, every location is dripping with atmosphere. Facial animations and cinematic camera work bring conversations to life like no CRPG has before.

[*][b]Replayability through the roof[/b] – Different races, classes, moral alignments, and origin characters completely change how the world responds to you. It practically begs for multiple playthroughs.

[*][b]Co-op is a blast[/b] – Like a real D&D campaign, you can play with friends. Arguments over loot, accidental fireballs, and roleplaying chaos are part of the fun.
[/list]

[hr][/hr]

[h2]Weaknesses[/h2]

[list]
[*][b]Bugs and jank (still)[/b] – While polished for such a massive game, you’ll still hit occasional bugs, pathfinding weirdness, or save/load hiccups—especially in co-op or late-game.

[*][b]Inventory management hell[/b] – The UI isn’t bad, but between all the gear, keys, quest items, and alchemy junk, your backpack becomes a black hole fast. Hope you like organizing.

[*][b]Can be overwhelming[/b] – For players new to CRPGs or D&D, the sheer amount of systems, stats, and dialog options can be intimidating. There’s a learning curve, and it’s steep at times.

[*][b]Act 3 performance issues[/b] – The final act is dense and impressive, but on some systems, it can tank performance and introduce lag or long load times.
[/list]

[hr][/hr]

[h2]Overall Impression[/h2]

[b]Baldur’s Gate 3[/b] is a towering achievement in RPG design. It combines deep player choice, thrilling combat, unforgettable storytelling, and a true sense of adventure that few games ever manage. It’s not just one of the best D&D games ever—it’s one of the best [i]RPGs[/i] ever made, period.

It demands your time, your brain, and your heart. And it gives back an experience that’s funny, tragic, epic, and uniquely yours.

[hr][/hr]

[h3]Score: [b]9.6 / 10[/b][/h3]

A new gold standard for fantasy RPGs. [i]Baldur’s Gate 3[/i] doesn’t just roll a natural 20—it brings the whole party to the table and makes you care about every single dice roll.

Absolutely damn spectacular, that's the least one can say.
The story i'd say rivals Divinity 2's, not way better, not worse, however, BG3 beats D2 in every other aspect too, Cinematics, world building, lore, random tidbits. Everything is superb <3

The pro's i'll keep short, you all know about the high's of BG3 after all;

The Cinematics.
One problem with D2 was with every important moment, it'd just be a topdown slightly emotionless angle, but in BG3, you have way more expression and heartfelt moments, one of the best decisions.

Graphics.
Yes, the graphics are good, but the important thing is the optimisation. Only a few times i stuttered, and thats only when i was ambushed so the game tried to load a bunch of enemies at once, not a problem for me however, stunning needs a few sacrifices however, and this is on the higher graphics <3

Characters.
Each character has wonderful chances to change and show themselves, i appreciate that you can truly be a "hero" in this, i liked seeing them all become better people and what their stories shape them into, way, WAY more indepth than D2 and i loved every moment.

The cons imo, were little and not even a problem, just mostly UI and glitches;

The Sounds: Great, wonderful, clear. However, a couple times a VA just sounded different, like they're in a new location or swapped entirely. Not immersion breaking, but very noticeable when it happens however, but i like to think the character just had a cold during the moment heh.

But the worst? Was occasionally a persistent "scratchy" noise in a few areas, rare, and only in a few moments. But these would make me want to leave an area ASAP. They weren't my headset, settings, seems to be a bug with the game, but not worth knocking points off atleast.

Camera limits and UI.
The camera is good most of the time, but then there lies the problem i mostly dealt with. Often times i try clicking something, but my character will talk to someone because the hitbox is massive compared to their body, making it so many times my characters would ignore important valuables, ignore mines, etc. While i desperately clicked on them :')

Sometimes an angle is just... godawful, doors WILL NOT let you pass them because the hitbox just doesnt let you click past them, you have to manually move the camera past doors into the fog just to get past. And occasionally, you CANNOT see above you even in tactical camera, because the camera is just too low down, and i have to put the camera on the side of a frame (like on rocks) JUST to see high enough for an enemy or item i'm actively trying to get to. 

Both a con and a pro. The "random people";
In D2, usually i could help random strangers, talk to them about certain topics, donate, etc. But in BG3, there were waaaay less moments i could just straight up help someone. This isn't a "con" as much as a sacrifice. The people you DO get to talk to often have more fun dialogue or do have meaningful moments, so you get less worthwhile dialogue, but it's more impactful. :D

In the end, i'd give this game a 9.5/10. Most of it is just damn wonderful, with the aforementioned cons being the only thing i can think of being "bad". I'd definitely say Larian has lost alot of their older negatives in D1 and D2, (I have not played BG1-2, my apologies), some called this "being woke", but i'm glad they got more friendly and less weird, often times just being plain uncomfortable playing D1 due to just how weirdly extreme the writing choices were, but in BG3, i was really enjoying every moment, and even the darker parts didn't sour the game, a genuinely well thought out experience. I hope you guys and gals at Larian are proud <3

Baldur’s Gate was one of the very first games I ever played as a child. I didn’t fully understand what was going on back then, but I knew it was something special. That world, those characters, that sense of adventure – it planted a seed that would grow into a lifelong love for RPGs. Now, all these years later, Baldur’s Gate 3 comes along and somehow manages to capture all of that magic… and crank it up to eleven.

I’ve only played 50 hours so far, but I could easily play thousands more. I catch myself smiling like an idiot during dialogues, taking way too long to make decisions because I care that much, and reloading saves just to see how a different choice might play out. I’ve laughed, I’ve gasped, I’ve sat in silence after big moments. It made me feel like a kid again – like I’m discovering gaming for the first time.

The writing, the characters (Karlach, you chaotic cinnamon roll, I love you), the music, the worldbuilding – it’s just... on another level. Every corner of this game oozes love, effort, and an almost insane level of detail. It's a game, yes, but it’s also a storybook, a theatre stage, a sandbox, and sometimes even a therapy session (thanks Withers).

To Larian: thank you. You didn’t just make a great game – you made something that people will remember years from now, with that warm little glow in their chest. Take a bow, you've created magic.

P.S. I only had the chance to play it in the summer of 2025 because I became a father – now that my son sleeps through the night, I finally have some time. And I’m using every second of it in Faerûn!

Simply put: I am OBSESSED. And I know I'm not alone in this feeling!

I have been wanting to dive into DnD style games for awhile. Been slowly absorbing and learning about DnD for many years but have been too intimidated by this self-inflicted feeling that I need to know everything about how it works. BG3 lays it out perfectly and there are plenty of tutorials both in-game for certain features and online to help if you want to deepen your knowledge. 

I am no stranger to Role-Playing games. From character creation to the engaging story and opportunities with companions - This is the perfect game for me and exactly what I was looking for without even knowing how to articulate what I wanted!

If you're new to DnD (like me) or want something you can play alone (or with friends): This is a GREAT game for that. 

*side note: as someone who likes modding for cosmetics or non-game-breaking features they make it so easy

Baldur's Gate 3 is one of the best games I have ever played.

I recently finished Fallout New Vegas and was floored by how vast, complex, and deep the characters and the world was. I was honestly disappointed since there would be very few games that would allow me to immerse myself in it's world. Baldur's Gate 3 did that in spades.

This game is so interactive to where every small decision creates ripple effects in how you interact with the world. I have spent over 100 hours in one campaign and I still feel as though I have not explored every option to this universe. 

At first, I did not like this game because of it's camera and turn-based gameplay, but I began to love the strategy and focus I had for getting past puzzles and fighting larger and tougher enemies. 

I'd easily recommend everyone to play this game. This is a world which will have you enthralled from the moment you escape the nautiloid ship to arriving in Baldur's Gate.

[b]Short Answer:[/b]
[b][i]Worth every penny you will buy it for. 1000000/10[/i][/b]

[hr][/hr]
[b]Long Answer:[/b]
[b]More than 80 hours in, and guess what? I still haven’t finished Act 1.[/b]
The [i]possibilities[/i] in this game are endless, and the fun never stops.

[h2]Why You Should Play It[/h2]

[b]Looking for a game to enjoy with friends?[/b]
One where you can argue about strategies, sneak through enemy camps, or just soak in an amazing story solo?

Want to take breathtaking screenshots, do tons of activities, or just vibe in gorgeous scenes?
[b]Baldur's Gate 3[/b] gives you [u]all that and more[/u].

[h2]My Experience[/h2]

I discovered this game after playing [i]Divinity: Original Sin[/i]. Even though I’m not familiar with D&D, I was super excited to try BG3.
What immediately hooked me was the [b]soundtrack[/b] — it [i]melts your heart[/i] and builds atmosphere like few games can.

You start by creating your character: pick a race, class, and later a subclass (I’m a [b]Necro Monk[/b] xD).
Then the story begins, and no — it’s not a slow start. It [b]grabs your attention right away[/b] and makes you want to explore everything.

[h2]Choices Matter[/h2]

Every decision you make can change something — even things you wouldn’t expect.
You’ll meet [b]deep companions[/b] with their own personalities and moral views.
Exploring every corner might reward you with a secret weapon… or drop you into a deadly trap.
[b]Be smart. Be curious. It pays off.[/b]

[h2]Multiplayer Mayhem[/h2]

[b]Up to 4 players. Tons of chaos. Endless laughs.[/b]
Play co-op with friends, argue over tactics, or accidentally throw someone off a cliff because you “misclicked.”
It’s the kind of fun you’ll remember.

[h2]Final Thoughts[/h2]

[quote=Larian Studios]We don’t just make games. We craft worlds.[/quote]

[b]BG3 is a huge leap forward from Divinity: Original Sin[/b] — better storytelling, more emotional connections, deeper systems, and just more fun.

[b][i]It’s worth every penny at full price. And if it’s on sale? That’s a steal.[/i][/b]

[hr][/hr]

[i]Well done, Larian. You absolutely nailed it.[/i]

With enough friends and mods, it's a good time.

Other than that though, Larian Studios were so concerned with whether they could make a digital version of D&D, they didn't stop to question whether they should. D&D is still a turd, and this game is an impressive attempt to polish that turd to the point of playability.

Pros:
* Automating much of the crunchy mechanics from D&D speeds things up a bit
* Unlike typical D&D, the items in BG3 actually do something, and can contribute to a decent number of distinct builds
* Animations are generally pretty good, and add some gravitas to the actions of your character
* As mentioned, multiplayer support and mods help a LOT
* Some decent characters, some decent music, some cool environments

Cons:
* The core gameplay is still D&D, an awful system in its own right that was never meant for the digital medium
* The core gameplay is still D&D, an awful system in its own right that will frequently have you wait 10 minutes for your turn
* The core gameplay is still D&D, an awful system in its own right that has pitiful amounts of customization when it comes to your character class and levelup choices
* The core gameplay is still D&D, an awful system in its own right that fails to make most classes/subclasses viable or fun to play
* The core gameplay is still D&D, an awful system in its own right that uses "Miss!" to describe your sword bouncing off of a heavily armored enemy the size of a building (by the way, have fun waiting 10 more minutes for your next opportunity to impact the battle)
* BG3 has by far the worst UI of any game I have ever played
* Confusing, convoluted controls, you genuinely need a PHD to even just play this game
* Lack of an undo button means that a single misclick, 1 pixel away from the enemy you wanted to attack, wastes your turn
The creative and technical masterpiece everybody says it is. If you're a fan of RPGs in any form, worth your money and more.

I’m not a fan of rouge-likes. I get frustrated when I have to bang my head against the same brick wall over and over again without any meaningful progress. Though somehow I still ended up putting close to 50 hours into Hades on switch and another dozen or so on PC.

Why? Because Hades has something most other rouge-likes lack : a sense of progression. Every time you enter the first chamber of the Underworld, you know you are going to end up coming back stronger. You may leave with a handful of chthonic keys that unlock new weapons and abilities, or darkness to buy extra lives. You might end up fulfilling one of the many prophecies, or pick up some jewels to add new layouts and bonuses to the dungeons. You might even make some new friends out there, or find some delicious nectar to trade for keepsakes. Or perhaps you just end up doing a bit of fishing.

Whatever you end up doing, you are moving both the game and the story forwards. Every return to the antechamber adds a host of new conversations and character interactions, including, occasionally, the reappearance of new rooms and mechanics. Nothing feels useless, and you never feel like wasting your time.

It helps that I’m a history buff, and Hades’ take on Ancient Greece is both outlandish, amusing and, occasionally, surprisingly tragic. As the story goes on, we learn not only why we are trying to escape, but also the depressing events that have led to our fellow denizens being trapped down there with us.

It took me about twenty runs to make it through the Underworld for the first time, and I’m nowhere close to the end. Hades must be thwarted a total of ten times before the story draws to a close, and even then there are plenty more secrets to unlock, including a special kind of keepsake that can only be gained after completing a series of side quests for each character.

So yes, Hades is a rouge-like. But it’s also a role-playing game with a finally tuned dopamine drip of upgrades and story that is perfectly tuned to keep us coming back for just one more run.
AMAZING GAME

The hype is warranted. I generally don't like action roguelikes, but Hades pulls it off well. A few thoughts:

-It is a bit fast-paced, as movement important in Hades. 
-I really like the boon system. You are often given a choice to pursue a boon from a given god. Then, that god will offer you a choice of 3 options from their pool of boons. Each god's boons tend to have a theme (Athena's defensive boons, Hermes' speed related boons, etc). So you get a sense of what god you want, even if you don't know exactly what you'll get. From there, you can start to combine the abilities for your given run.
-Like other rougelikes, once you beat the game you can replay on higher difficulties. Unlike most examples of this where each higher difficulty adds another debuff/challenge that stack incrementally, Hades has a list of these that have a challenge value assigned to them. You can set these yourself, which dictate what the overall difficulty level is.

Hades is one of the best rogue-lites out there, using a vast field of source material it succeeds in making an immersive and enjoyable story with fresh gameplay which will keep you entertained for a very long time. Where many in the same genre use procedurally generated environments which look basic and simple to make them easy to implement Hades has a beautiful environment and maintains a consistent art style with the 2D sprites which represent the characters. Hades also has much more replayability than expected as the journey to 100% adds new challenges and extreme difficulties if you want to push yourself. I highly recommend Hades to anyone wanting to try rogue-likes but is intimidated by the full reset on death as Hades allows you to maintain upgrades and has a "God mode" for those struggling to beat it too. 9/10

Hades – A Quick Review (26 Hours In)

Hades delivers a unique and satisfying gameplay loop that never feels stale, thanks to its roguelike design where no two runs are ever the same. Even though the structure is repetitive by nature, each attempt feels fresh with its own evolving narrative and choices.

While I’ve yet to finish the main story, what I’ve experienced so far is charming and cleverly intertwined with Greek mythology. The characters are memorable, and the writing has a lot of heart.

Visually, Hades is stunning. The art style is vibrant and distinctive, and the soundtrack complements the atmosphere perfectly, enhancing every encounter.

Replayability is one of the game’s strongest points, I’ve clocked in 26 hours (at the time of writing) and still find myself eager for "just one more run." It's a fully polished experience; I haven’t encountered any bugs or performance issues. That said, there is a learning curve, especially if you're new to the genre. I struggled at first, but once the mechanics click, the game becomes incredibly fun.

Final Verdict: 10/10

Great game

Quite possibly the roguelite of all time. There's lots of different playstyles with all the weapons and their aspects, lots of variety in the boons that you get from the gods, most significantly this game has an insane amount of dialogue. You can keep getting new story and character bits between runs for a loong time, so you're going to constantly see new dialogue even deep into the game. 

Hades has one of the best Roguelite post-games out there too. There's still plenty story to uncover even after beating the game, and the Heat system lets you choose modifiers to make later runs more challenging in exchange for letting you earn more upgrade materials. This keeps the game interesting even after winning runs, and there's so many options to choose from that it can keep you hooked for a long time while setting an extremely high skill ceiling.

If I'm being completely honest it's not my personal favorite roguelite, since the beat em up type of combat feels a little spammy to me, and I prefer a bit more viable randomness and chaos in runs, where a big part of the skill in Hades is just learning how to build your loadout through a run. I'm also not a huge fan of the progression between runs where you need to invest in yourself to power up your baseline, since I prefer games where your growth is completely tied to learning the game. I still like it though, and it's probably the most widely well receiver roguelite out there

The Drunken Epic of Zagreus, Who Would Not Stay Dead

Sing, O busted lyre, of Zagreus the rebellious,
Whose sandals were swift and whose dad was hella jealous.
He sprang from the Underworld, brimming with sass,
Flipping off shades as he sprinted past.

"Stuff it, Father!" the lad declared,
Dodging lava while extremely underprepared.
Yet with sword, with shield, with fists of flame,
He died a lot—but always blamed the game.

From Tartarus’ depths to Asphodel's fire,
Through Elysium fields and the Hydra’s ire,
He brawled with a fury who just wanted love,
And a skeletal bro who shouted, “GET SOME, MY DOVE!”

The Olympians chimed in with heavenly flair:
Zeus brought the thunder (and incredible hair),
Aphrodite flirted, Dionysus poured wine,
And Ares said, “Kid, you’ll kill just fine.”

Each chamber a gauntlet, each run a grind,
But the controls? Divine—like ambrosia to mind.
The Boons stacked high, the builds insane,
"Look, Mom, I’m a bloodthirsty hurricane!"

Yet flaws there are, like all Greek tales—
Repeat too much and the magic pales.
You'll fight the Bone Hydra thrice a day,
And wish the Minotaur would go away.

Still! The dialogue sings, the sprites have class,
Cerberus is Good Boy, 10/10 would pet his three-ass.
The music? Euphonic! The pacing? Just right!
Even Hades himself gets a redemption arc light.

So raise your goblet to Supergiant’s might,
Who’ve made roguelikes sexy, and dying feel right.
A half-star lost, but do not grieve—
It’s Hades, my friend. You’ll never want to leave.

Hades is honestly really great. Great story elements, and fun gameplay. I really love the heat system for the endgame challenge. It is the sort of system that grips a player like me who likes to push themselves to the limits

My biggest gripe is 'Hell mode'. Hell mode is the final endgame challenge you unlock after beating the game. To unlock it you must start a new game. I don't mind NG+ playthroughs in other games, but my issue with how it's implemented here is that it takes a REALLLLYYY long time to 100% the game anyway. It's also really hard to speed up how quickly you unlock everything. So what this means is the game is asking you to go through another tediously slow playthrough, of the stuff you've already done. When the story elements are fresh, it's fine, but once I've done it once, it just becomes so... tedious. I put the game down at this point. I truly wanted to max out the game and grind the heat ladder on hell mode, but I was not going to waste another 40hr of my life 100%ing the game again.

I hope they don't bring it back for Hades 2.

Firstly, even if this is a negative review, it is for petty reasons along with actual technical concerns. Hopefully among the few negative reviews, this will convince somebody on the fence to purchase over being yet another praise filled opinion. I'll organize this into negative and positive with reasons why below each. I will open with the caveat I am about halfway through the main story, and have cleared on heat level 2, nearly finished 3 now. My first clear was rather early at about 6.7 hours and no, not using god mode.

Negatives:
- Progression has very frustrating requirements for some items
- Enemy animations can be very unclear at times
- I only enjoy a single weapon from the roaster
- Heat system feels too punishing at times for a smooth difficulty curve (related to the most annoying item to get)
- Sometimes the environment can block enemies
- Final boss scales way too high for a normal, non heat playthrough
- Romances are not very fleshed out

The majority of my complaints come from the small, technical aspects and personal preferences. Only the gauntlets are any enjoyable for me to use, and the upgrade system for weapons often relies on utilizing the punishing heat system. The option for increased difficulty is nice, but scales too rapidly especially with no way to refund resources. Don't like the weapon you are using? Too bad you're stuck with that choice and have to either hard save your money each run for the chance to get more, or have to keep beating the boss at higher difficulty modifiers while the bosses keep increasing their difficulty natively.

Other small issues like some enemy animations being a wiggle into a next frame hit, and the cursed witches circle make runs feel more like hit enemy, dash out, dash in, and repeat. At the worst of times you'll have an enemy hidden from view and chunk your HP because they were out of sight. Then the final boss continues to progressively become more difficult, and if you chose poorly for your titan blood, you're forced into using weapons you might not want to use for more, or have to take part in the heat system for upgrades. This was a non issue for me, because I simply looked up what was the "best" upgrade for me, but being encouraged to use external sources to save you precious early titan blood is a negative.
Positives:
- Exceptional art
- Exceptional details to the world
- Exceptional voice acting
- A large amount of dialogue
- Extensive story
- Lots of progression 
- Very replayable
- Lots of rewards for long term playj
- Boons offer a variety of gameplay options, while not completely changing every single run
- Romances still exist

What Hades does right, it does very right. Despite the above, I find myself wanting to continue playing for the story and characters. Every character brings great design and voice acting to a memorable cast. While there are annoyances in some items for progression for me, having a GREAT number of cosmetic options and for those who desire it, a -very- lengthy heat system for difficulty modifers will make roguelike fans who want a very replayable game happy. The boon system and run progression both are enjoyable, except for when you get a cursed start.

While this is a negative review, it is as I said at the start, for petty reasons. For the years of praise I hear for Hades, I went into it with overly high expectations and my singular review among nearly 300,000 at the time won't be tipping any kind of balance.

Would I recommend this game? Yes. For the pure story enjoyers or those who are intimidated by roguelikes, there is a "god mode" option in the settings that will significantly reduce difficulty with enough deaths. For those who want a long term game to die in repeatedly, and have a HUGE amount of difficulty modifiers, you'll love this game too. Being only halfway through the story, I can't say I wasted my eight dollars for this on sale. But I can say that anyone picking this up should relax their expectations and understand while it is not perfect, the good outweighs the bad. Just don't let the hype tell you only praises. Go into it with the knowledge that even though there are some frustrations, this is a well done game from what is still an indie company, with it's handful of troubles.

Hades – Mid-Game Review (After ~6 Hours of Play)

After spending around six hours in Hades, it's easy to see why it’s one of the most celebrated roguelikes of recent years. The gameplay is fast, fluid, and incredibly satisfying, with each run offering a unique blend of boons, weapons, and upgrades that keep things fresh. Even after dozens of attempts, the combat feels tight and rewarding.

At around 50–60% completion, the game begins to reveal more of its depth—not just in mechanics, but in story. The way Hades ties narrative progression to repeated failures is brilliant; each run feels meaningful, with new dialogue, character development, and lore that build a strong connection with the overall characters .
 Pros:
Tight, responsive combat
Excellent voice acting and character writing
Deep, evolving narrative
Tons of replay value
Cons:
Early frustration from some steep difficulty spikes
RNG can occasionally create unbalanced runs
Overall : very polished as a game and i would defenitely recommend it!

This game has a perfectly addicting and tight combat loop, with several weapons, upgrades, and playstyles available to the player. This game is ultimately one of the most amazing games ever made (IMO), and I will probably be begging for more time with Zag until the end of my days, and I descend under the cement myself.

This was the first rouge-like game I've ever played. I've never really been attracted to these types of games but Hades... Oh boy Hades is just perfect. From the voice acting to the art style, Hades captures the player from the very beginning. Add to that the repetitiveness and it's uniqueness... it instantly becomes a VERY addictive game. U may think "Oh, it'll be way to repetitive, must be boring", well let me tell you that you are insanely mistaken. Yes, as a rogue-like game it is repetitive, you kill, level up, die, repeat and you keep going until you reach the end, but... every time you go through everything again, it feels equally as amazing as the past hundreds of times you went through it. The variety of weapons and the fact that enemies change the more you advance make it so that the game keeps on being refreshing. Overall, Hades is a must grab game, very fun to play and worth the try.

Don't let my playtime fool you, it's closer to 400 hours if you count my time clocked on the Switch version.

I won't waste too many words: This game is perfect. Perfect difficulty curve and limitless playstyle potential. The art style is instantly iconic and Darren Korb's soundtrack is so good it actually feels unearthly. The ever-expanding world rewards you for every death with deeper relationships, new powers, and new challenges. Every run pulls you deeper into the story, and the story drives you toward attempt after attempt in a gameplay loop as ruthlessly efficient as the God of the Dead himself. And you just hate that guy, right?

Play this as soon as possible and prepare to lose track of time fighting your way to the Surface. Just remember: There Is No Escape.

This game is on another level of immersion, balance and complexity. I played this game 5 hours straight before realising that I was playing 5 hours straight! The constant dialogue interactions with all the characters is insanely complex and refreshing. The weapons, charms, and ability upgrades (temp or permanent) actually show little to major improvement each time you enter Hades. My partner is a Greek and Roman mythology geek and she's been telling me all the actual stories of every god character in the game. If you're with someone who likes stories and not much of a gamer, this game is it.

Hades is a breath of fresh air. It is the mighty vessel that has sailed the seven seas to come home with stories of conquest. It is the large rock on the edge of the cliff of originality. I'd love to pour more love into this game, but then I won't be able to play this game if I do. 

Ps. Dev team, you rock!

I have 400 hours on Switch, I literally bought this again just to sync my save file and write this review. This alone should tell you a lot about the game. It is absolutely perfect in every aspect, one of my favorite games ever. Might replay it or at least do all achievements on Steam Deck, this game is VERY enjoyable on handhelds.

Speaking of achievements, I was a little disappointed to see that it doesn't unlock all of them when you import your save from other systems, it only unlocks the story related ones. But it's okay, it's another excuse to pick this up again in the future.

If you're scrolling the reviews trying to decide if you want to buy this or not, don't lose any more time, just buy it. "But I don't usually like roguelites.." shut up. Buy it right now.

The game is a gem, and I'd probably put multiple hundreds of hours into it... if there was an option for full access PvE only. I don't want to PvP, I don't see why this game has such an identity crisis with thinking it's this hardcore PvP game when there's so much PvE, and it's so immersive. It's setup in the worst way--the usual way of PvP--where groups just swarm randomly smaller players and abruptly gank them. I've watched tons of hours of this game, and it's always the same thing - and it kept me from buying it for a long-long time. You're trying to make grown man-children happy which will never be the case. You cannot please PvP players because no matter what you do, negative interactions affect our emotions. And it's a rare player that shrugs it off and continues. It's bad for your brain thus... they cannot be sated.

The games getting older, it's time to embrace its strength... and that isn't unskilled, gank PvP. Allow full PvE. Once I cap my reps that'll probably be it for me... shame cause... phew... what am I gonna do with my wallet now? I gave this game a fair shot. 11 hours of pure frustration. Spent HOURS peacefully grinding, collecting treasure, doing voyages — only to get jumped by some PvP sweatlord, have my ship sunk in 2 minutes, and lose everything. This isn't "danger adds thrill," it's just unbalanced trash that rewards griefers and punishes anyone who tries to enjoy the actual game content.

The worst part? You can’t opt out. There’s no PvE mode. No safe zones. Not even outposts are protected. 

The devs Refuse to add PvE servers or passive mode despite YEARS of players begging for it. Because making you regrind means more hours played, which makes them look good to Microsoft.

The result A toxic, one-sided game where:

PvP sweats get free loot with zero effort

Peaceful players get robbed, rage, and uninstall

Real gameplay (voyages, exploration) feels pointless if you can just steal other people hours loot .

Epic Adventure!

In 2018, Sea of Thieves launched with a beautiful ocean and a whole lot of... nothing to do. Fast forward to 2025, and Sea of Thieves: 2025 Edition is no longer just a sandbox—it's a fully realized pirate adventure brimming with life, danger, and stories waiting to be written.

What started as a visually stunning but narratively thin experience has evolved into one of the most content-rich multiplayer games on the seas. Thanks to years of regular updates, narrative arcs, and now the 2025 Edition’s sweeping refinements, Rare has turned Sea of Thieves into a true pirate RPG. Whether you're chasing down a ghost fleet, charting a course for buried treasure, or uncovering the secrets of new Sea Fortresses, every session feels different—and importantly, meaningful.

The 2025 Edition introduces improved progression systems, tighter ship-to-ship combat mechanics, and new character customizations that make your pirate feel more unique and personal than ever before. New legendary voyages add depth for veteran players, while streamlined tutorials and onboarding finally give newcomers a fighting chance.

No game does player-driven chaos like Sea of Thieves. You and your crew might start off on a quiet treasure run, only to end up in a wild three-ship skirmish over a loot-stuffed fort, chased by a kraken and struck by lightning mid-fight. The game doesn’t just allow for unpredictable moments—it thrives on them.

Now, with the expanded Sea of Plunder update included in the 2025 Edition, alliances, betrayals, and reputation systems feel more impactful. The world is reactive and social, with live events and dynamic encounters creating shared stories even among strangers.

It’s worth repeating: Sea of Thieves still has one of the most beautiful oceans ever rendered in a game. The lighting, weather effects, and sea physics remain stunning—now enhanced for next-gen hardware and PC with ray tracing and dynamic cloud systems.

The music and sound design are just as legendary. Whether it’s the creak of your hull in stormy waters, the ghostly whispers in a cursed cave, or a triumphant hurdy-gurdy jam with friends, everything sounds rich and immersive.

Despite its polish, Sea of Thieves still isn’t for everyone. Solo players can struggle against aggressive crews, and PvP balance can swing wildly depending on server population. Some grindy progression elements remain, and while the newer systems are more rewarding, the game still assumes you’re in it for the long haul.

Also, while crossplay is smoother than ever, some PC-console matchmaking quirks still crop up—especially in high-stakes battles.

Sea of Thieves: 2025 Edition is the game Rare always wanted to make—and the pirate fantasy players always hoped for. It’s not just a sailing sim anymore; it’s a living, breathing world of danger, discovery, and delight. Whether you're a salty sea dog or a landlubber looking for adventure, there’s never been a better time to hoist the sails.

Pros:
-Expansive and reactive world
-Dynamic PvE and PvP experiences
-Gorgeous visuals and sound design
-Deep lore and emergent storytelling

Cons:
-PvP can be unforgiving to solo players
-Some progression elements still grindy
-Requires time investment to truly shine

If you’ve ever dreamed of living the pirate life, Sea of Thieves: 2025 Edition is the closest you’ll come without commandeering an actual ship.

Rating: 8/10

Although it can be irritating at times, Sea of Thieves is one of my favourite games since it is open world, adventurous, and I love that you never know what will happen when you play it. Now that the PS5 version of the game has been published, I play it more on the console because my computer is mid. The cosmetics and grind for certain items is a big challenge but is very relieving when accomplished, for example the skeleton curse. The game's only drawback is that it's extremely challenging and tedious for lone players. I would recommend it to anyone other than solo gamers, but if you're a video game fanatic and believe you can defeat four opponents by yourself, then by all means give it a try.

Sea of Thieves is the perfect example of how a mass multiplayer game should be.  It has passes, which allows microtransactions to occur. Also creating a whole bunch of quest and achivement tables to follow as ordinary pirates. You can experience the progress and follow the legnthy quests as you dedicate yourself to that one set of skin. And that's what makes this game impressive, the microtransactions are about spesific skins or cool season pass features but not about your damage or loot. So you always have to set sail and pirate about! 

And with your friend group this game just jumps to a new level of fun. With each new encounter of loot, enemy or chest you will experience a NEW mechanic. You can write your story while meeting and learning cool lore about the isles. Have fun out there and be nice to other crews! It helps!

I love Sea of Thieves but it pains me to say that it's a hard sell... At surface level it looks to be a relatively simple game to relax with friends over, but the reality is that many of the people playing fall into one of two categories:

1. Day one players who just booted the game up for free from Game Pass
2. Sweats who play religiously and won't hesitate to sink whatever they deem a threat OR jackpot

There's a little bit more nuance, but the combat in Sea of Thieves is un-intuitive and HARD. As a new player, this means that you will end up losing more often than not, and for many people, this is a major turnoff. You'll just have to come to terms with the fact that many a play session end in your ship, and all the treasure you gathered along with it, at the bottom of the ocean. Coupled with a community that isn't the friendliest at times (paranoia is one of the first things you pick up playing this game, and toxicity is kind of encouraged from the parasitic way that you obtain loot) it can really feel like you are no match for everything that you run into on the open seas.

Additionally, this game is secretly a pirate fashion/ship decoration game. Everything you earn in this game from doing anything is cosmetic. There are no tangible advantages that you gain for playing longer. This means that you either get good, or you get sunk.

If you are going to get into this game, I would recommend it with friends. Solo is the hardest way to play this game by a long shot since one mistake will lead to your ship sinking. It's extra helpful if you start playing the game under the guidance of a most experienced player as well.

Lastly, this game is a GRIND. I have 1k hours, there's a ton of content, but this is the kind of game where you have to set out goals for yourself and make the fun for yourself. If you aren't a fan of the grind, and you aren't a fan of losing your progress sometimes, this game might not be for you.

With all of this being said, Sea of Thieves is a one of a kind experience. The naval combat in this game is deceptively complex, and some of the most rewarding PvP I've experienced in all of the games I've played. If you are up to the challenge, and don't mind stumbling a little bit on the way, this game is amazing.

Just remember, gold is temporary, but glory is forever.

I've played this game for almost 3000 hours now, first on the Microsoft Store and now on Steam. During that time, unfortunately, I’ve encountered many issues in the game. Leaving aside the fact that most players are very toxic – that happens in every game and doesn't really bother me anymore – it's a different story when the game itself is full of problems.

For example, there have been issues with hackers in this game ever since I started playing, and with the new season, even more hackers have returned. If I were a game developer, I’d find that pretty embarrassing.

There are also a lot of bugs, which can sometimes be funny, but most of the time they’re just frustrating because they can really mess up the gameplay. A PvP/PvE game should at least be able to handle a few bugs to make the experience more enjoyable.

One of the worst things, however, is that the servers can’t handle 8,000 players, which is just plain embarrassing.

Honestly, I really enjoy playing this game, but when things end up like this and the updates do nothing against hackers, bugs, and exploits, you start to wonder if Rare is doing anything at all. Instead, they just keep adding events like Gold & Glory weekends, during which the servers are completely overloaded and you end up leaving disappointed.

I have over 3.5k hours in this game ( Most are on the Xbox app ). This game is amazing, but has its flaws. And the flaws really like to be intrusive and annoying.

First off, the game is good. Like, really good. You can do (almost) anything you want out in the world. I chose to PvP a lot. Most of my hours are PvP. And this is where the issues arise. 

The game stutters a lot. The game randomly teleports you a lot. The game decides if your shots register on random. The stability is horrible. The netcode is trash. The servers (Microsoft Azure) are trash. Basically, the game does not work 90% of the time.

But when the game actually works, it's one of the best out there.

Don't pay full price. Buy it on sale.
