I've been playing SOT since it released on Xbox, and it was an amazing experience. Nowadays the game is full of hackers and it is impossible to pvp with hourglass because you will most likely be queued against a hacker. The devs seem to almost have no ambition when it comes to the game itself. All the devs are doing nowadays are just adding shortcuts to the game. Feels like everything can just be obtained via a menu screen. The devs have not even added a single new biome in I can't even remember how long. An ice biome would be really cool or maybe some desert biome or a ghost realm. I feel like the game could use some new and inspiring elements. The main thing in SOT was the cosmetics to me. These being curses and clothing. It felt so rewarding to grind for hours and hours to get a outfit or a curse, but nowadays the clothing is just so underwhelming. I fee like the game could use better animated curses and ship sets, also allow the player to take specific pieces of clothing from a costume so we can mix and match. A hub world would be pretty cool, so players could interact with each other and communicate via gamechat while showing off their hard earned cosmetics. Game lacks ambition and if the devs don't step their game up then the game will cease to be. Also I like the idea of the shroudbreaker. It is an item that you can attach to your ship to obtain a special blessing. Maybe add some more things like that for pvp or just traversing faster. Like there could be an item that makes the ship invisible from 300 meters away or an item that increases ship speed periodically just something to spice up the game.

Very fun with friends, one hurdle i had to get over was that piracy was part of the game play loop. You obtain loot and you take it back to an outpost to sell it, but other players may try to sink you and steal that loot. With over 100 hours in Sea of Thieves, it's easily one of the most fun and unpredictable multiplayer games I've played. Best enjoyed with friends, it delivers amazing pirate adventures and constant surprises. Solo can be rough, but the world and gameplay keep pulling me back.
this shit so boring even with friends holy hell meaningless exploration hours and hours of literally nothing.

This is an ethical live service game.
Sea Of Thieves is an anarchic sandbox game where you can do whatever you want. Though the community is reprehensible, Rare does well to take in feedback - ever since their rocky launch.
Back in 2018, there was little to do. But now, you could spend years catching up on all of the content added over the years. The sandbox constantly evolves, the world changing, with it coming new piratey things to do, and new rewards to earn.
If all you want to do is go on silly quests where you unearth buried treasure where X marks the spot - then that's all you have to do. If all you want to do is strongarm people into surrendering that buried treasure after, better sharpen your cutlass. The PVP gameplay loop is a bit unsatisfying, especially in high level play, but there is a dedicated part of the community to the art of thievery. If you want PVE, or PVP.. You're welcome in this game.
Also, oddly enough, this community is simultaneously the most LGBTQ+ inclusive AND hostile community on the internet??? It's confusing. But its relaxed nature and high skill ceiling, plus its communal nature has drawn in all sorts of people you can meet (and befriend, if you're lucky to catch them on a good day!)
The art for this game is amazing. Screenshots of this game are so many people's wallpapers it's unreal(engine), as they went for a sort of cartoony whimsical painting look. There's no character creator, which forces a very unique form of self-expression wherein you pick an ugly bugger who speaks to you, then dress them with unlockable cosmetics (There are only cosmetics in this game. Every player is pretty much on the same playing field going into the sandbox. No ship with like - better cannons is going to come outclass you and ruin your day!) to communicate what kind of adventures you've been on and what kind of pirate you are. It's quite beautiful.

Its a great game and I have a lot more hours on console than on steam however, the devs have been letting the playerbase down for quite a while now. By devs I probably mean the investors who arent allowing it but, this game desperately needs and operation health season, where they sort the spaghetti code out, sort the numerous bugs and just the general health of the game. So many thingh have been left behind in the dust while we're getting new seasons that are now split probably because the devs dont have the time to release all the content on day one and that is badly affecting player retention and excitment for new seasons. I want to reiterate this game is really good and the fundamentals of this game and the foundation are fantastic but the investors {probably} are killing it as we speak. Give this game a few months of repair and then go again. As of right now every new season that comes out is buggier and more of a mess stability wise than the prior season and it needs fixing before it becomes too overwhelming for the devs

Море Воров - это игра, где вы плывете на галеоне, а два долбоеба на шлюпе ебут вас в хвост и гриву. Причем один из них прыгает будто его выебали в жопу 10 негров и пердит в микрофон. Это та игра, где нет никакого нормального боя, только ебучие крысы. Это та игра, где отличие между кораблями - это количество человек за одну сессию. Никакого преимущества на большом корабле нет, просто ТРИЖДЫ. ПЕРЕВАРЕННЫЙ. КАЛ. Разрабы долбоёбы, додумались добавить возможность приседать спустя 5-6 лет как игра вышла. [h1] Sea of Thieves is chaos, freedom and pure pleasure. [/h1]

Sometimes you're calmly carrying treasures, and a minute later you're drowning in fire, while a kraken strangles the ship, skeletons shoot from the island, and other pirates lie in wait on the horizon. Everything can happen suddenly here – and that's the fun.

The graphics in the game are bright and picturesque, the water sparkles and moves naturally, creating a real  atmosphere of the pirate world. Sunsets, storms, and the play of light turn every entry into the sea into a beautiful and exciting picture that immerses you in an atmosphere of adventure.

This is not a game about grinding or progress. Emotions and moments are important here: funny, wild, intense. One day you hunt a megalodon, another – you sing with friens, and then you shoot back, holding a chest in your teeth and sailing into the open sea.

You can play solo, but with friends it's a whole new level of fun. The game is constantly evolving, new quests, factions, and events are being added.

If you like the idea of becoming a real pirate and not knowing how your next trip to sea will end, you should definitely try it.

PvP is unbalanced, clunky and buggy. Filled with cheaters consistently for years now because the anti cheat sucks. The game is basically unplayable in its most desired element. PvE experience is awesome. Good story and quests.

The game demands a high level of cognitive engagement and strategic thinking from the player. Success relies on your ability to analyze subtle environmental clues, interpret audio and visual evidence, and synthesize that data to correctly identify the type of ghost you're dealing with. It's not just about observation—it's about deductive reasoning, pattern recognition, and making informed decisions under pressure. Additionally, the game tests your survival instincts in real-time; as the haunting intensifies, maintaining composure while navigating increasingly dangerous situations becomes critical. The blend of logical puzzle-solving with adrenaline-pumping horror creates an incredibly immersive and mentally stimulating experience.

This game is truly a masterpiece with lots of potential. The mechanics are easy to learn, but might be hard to master. Just take your time... It offers different difficulty levels, and you can even customize the experience with your own settings to make it even more of a nightmare.

It's highly recommended to play with friends, as many people do not want to play with newbies, so prepare yourself to get kicked from the lobby. 

Don't forget to support your local game developer companies! Thank you, Kinetic Games.

This game taught me that I’d be the first to die in a horror movie.
Went ghost hunting with my friends, spent most of the time hiding in a closet whispering “Please don’t kill me, please don’t kill me.”

One guy tried to talk to the ghost, got choked instantly. We laughed… until the ghost came for me next.
Also, whoever designed the sound of ghost breathing in your ear—you're evil and I hope your toast always falls butter-side down.

Pros:
✅ Can talk to demons through a radio like it's a dating app
✅ Hilarious panic when the ghost starts hunting
✅ Betraying friends has never been funnier

Cons:
❌ My soul is permanently damaged
❌ My friends lock doors while I scream for help

Would die again. 10/10. 👻

Phasmophobia is a very fun, addictive and well-designed game. Graphics are really good even if the player animations look a bit robotic (although this should be improved in an upcoming update). Maps are well designed especially the new ones and the reworks. The equipment tiers keep gameplay interesting as you arent always playing with the same stuff and you need adapt accordingly. Its nice that in 2025 they are returning to more regular updates and I am very much looking forwards to Horror 2.0 next year. Outside of the planned updates i do think there are some minor things that could be improved like making certain items like the para-mic and sound sensors more useful and either splitting up head-cams and headlights/night-vision into two separate items or having all 3 tiers of the headgear have the camera functionality in addition to their other features.

Super fun game. I'm not usually into the horror genre, but I really enjoy Phasmophobia. Game has a solid learning curve, that keeps the game challenging even for the most experienced of players. While the game is still fun to play solo, I highly recommend bringing friends along to play with, as playing with people you are comfortable with makes the game even more enjoyable as you get to share some silly moments and bring some lighthearted humor to a pretty spooky game. Phas is still pretty buggy, but honestly, it rarely takes away from the experience. Phas developers really show a great deal of love for their game and it still receives active support from the developers as they recently released a fun new update that added some really fun new content.

June 12th, 2025...
It's a day I'll never forget.
The ghost hunter inside me died that day.
And that night, Camp Woodwind was wiped out. Thanks to Baby-Man in the Red Tent.
Somehow, I made it out. But too many others...weren't so lucky.

I was 'asked' later to join a top-secret government program.
Not that I had a choice.
The training, the punishing missions nearly killed me.
But at least they kept my mind off everything.

If I could just forget what happened that night, the pain—even for a second.
This time, it can be different.
It has to.

This game is SIMPLE, fun, and easy to understand. BUT don't let that fool you, there are TONS of small details, little hints, and give aways that only more experienced players can notice, the game itself is funny to mess around on, and even MORE fun to get serious with. It boasts new tools, equipment, and even things like new menu UI's! New sound equipment! And graphical changes? Oh yes this game continues to surprise. IS IT really all that and a box of rocks? 

Simply put, no it isn't. It isn't a flashy, pretty game with amazing visuals and sunsets that blow you away. But it does have 4 player CO-OP, a single player mode, and new challenges all the time. The game has received more than one new map this past year or so and it really has been hitting home on the creepy feels we all seem to desire from a funny, ghost hunting game. Just enough serious to get the blood pumping.

A great game that involves investigating the paranormal; alone or with friends.

The amount of places and ghosts you investigate is decent and its fun to learn the ropes to feel more useful.

The variety of equipment and tier categories of them makes the player earn progression dopamine, especially when just starting.

Want to feel like Ed and Lorraine Warren going to an accursed place with a story to unfold and a haunting to solve?
This isn't very much like that. This is more to have a group of friends (or strangers) come along and work together to learn about what is haunting a location.

Critiques: Online multiplayer desperately needs some additions such as text chat, vote kicking unsavory characters mid-game, more interactions or objectives if dead (maybe a chance to come back to life with a mini game or tasks), rework on the sanity mechanic that can make the game-play more immersive and that raises the stakes. Any addition to the horror psychological atmosphere would be appreciated. 

P.S Death screen, rag doll, and character death pose are comical and look bad, not scary.

7.5/10

[h3]Scary but fun — especially when starting out.[/h3]
Even as someone who's played quite a bit and can often guess the ghost from what it does (or doesn't do), the recent update made the game scary again.

Performance-wise, it ran well on Windows, but surprisingly, it runs even better on Linux.

    Vulkan pre-caches shaders, so stuttering is practically nonexistent.

    Using the gamemoderun launch option pushes the system to prioritize game-focused performance, making everything run smoother while playing.
good game scaery

Honestly, I thought I played a lot more than 79 hours, I guess when your squeeling in fear from the a-hole of a ghost being behind you as you turn time feels to be going much much slower, I never thought I would like this kind of game, it looked cool but I thought ugh were is the replay?

I thought there are only so many times that you can find the evidence, check your book done --- boring -- I was wrong, sure it could be like that, but being able to fine tune the diffculty slowly reduce the amount of evidence, go for random on the map never knowing if your going to get the massive maps, on your own they are even more scary, in a group they are bad enough and it really was just way more fun, had way more replay than I expected.

I will say I think its more fun with others, and more so with friends rather than randoms from the lobby, but perhaps im just anti-social, but solo and with friends is a lot of fun and worth the purchase, esp with how active they are with keeping the content fresh, and adding in new things.

I would like some more ghosts, or new ways to detect ghosts so the current evidence combos are given a whole new shake up, but we will see how they go with the game, but nothing that I think detracts from the game at all.

This game is great, I think its a must have. VR support makes the game much more immersive and I shit my pants everytime a ghost hunts. I’ll admit it: I bought The Forest one night after a few too many beers. I played it for a bit and honestly thought, “What the heck is this? Trees, sticks, and weird cannibals?” The only thing I liked at the time was how it looked — and, oddly enough, chopping wood. There was something oddly satisfying about building your own little cabin in the middle of nowhere.

But everything else? It felt boring and just... weird. I expected more from an older game that so many people seemed to love. I thought it would blow me away — instead, it gently poked me with a stick and ran off.

Fast forward a bit: I gave it another shot... and, to my surprise, it wasn’t half bad.

Sure, it’s not mind-blowing. The story starts off strong, then vanishes like a neighbor who went out for cigarettes, only to reappear at the end carrying a suitcase full of emotional baggage. But as a survival game? It’s genuinely solid. Building shelters, crafting bone weapons, setting up traps — it’s all weirdly satisfying once you get into the rhythm. Just be careful not to spend too much time min-maxing every structure, or you’ll end up a spreadsheet hermit in the woods.

Yes, you fight cannibals — and yes, you might end up eating them. Survival karma at its finest.

In the end, The Forest tricked me in the best way possible. I went from thinking it was garbage to obsessing over finishing my luxury log mansion. It’s not a perfect 10/10, but it’s far from trash. I’d give it a solid 7 out of 10. If you’re in the mood for a bit of wilderness nostalgia and casual cannibal chaos, it’s absolutely worth diving in.

P.S. Play it with friends. It turns into a chaotic comedy show in the woods — highly recommended.
The game is pretty tight

Okay, so "The Forest." You crash-land on a seemingly deserted island, right? But spoiler alert: it's anything but deserted. Your kid is snatched, and suddenly you're in this terrifying fight for survival against cannibals and creepy mutants.

What's cool about it is how it blends chilling horror with classic survival. During the day, you're chopping trees, building shelters, scavenging for food – all that good survival stuff. But then night falls, and everything changes. The atmosphere gets super tense, and these terrifying, often smart, enemies start coming out. They're not just mindless monsters; they'll stalk you, try to outsmart you, and honestly, they're pretty unsettling to encounter.

You can play it alone, which is a genuinely scary experience, or with friends in co-op, which turns it into a wild, chaotic, and often hilarious fight for survival together. The story's there if you want to dig into the island's dark secrets, but you can also just focus on building an epic fortress and trying to stay alive.

It's not always the most polished game, and you might hit a few weird bugs, but if you're looking for a survival game that actually makes you feel vulnerable and throws some genuinely terrifying moments at you, "The Forest" delivers. It's a wild ride. Hope you have fun!!! :)

This is what modern day horror games should truly aspire to be. It's immersive, atmospheric, has a semi-cliche yet satisfyingly surprising storyline, and the gameplay is the survival genre at its best.

One of the biggest standouts that helps sell the horror is the AI - not inherently aggressive, but rather posturing, patiently testing your reactions, and being a lingering threat around you. They're not harmless, and sometimes confrontation may prove unavoidable, but until then they do their best to seemingly pick out the right moment, leaving you uncertain when they'll strike or what'll provoke them.

Another great aspect are the stellar enemy designs. In a post-horror age where most things 'scary' have become fairly tame, if not funny, the bigger mutants in this game are disturbingly freakish, all the more so once you learn some of their origins, or visit their dwellings.

Though not without its flaws, mostly in the form of occasional glitches, it is perhaps the best horror game I have ever played.

Alright, so you've been unceremoniously dumped into a forest survival game, and let me tell you, it's less about building a cozy log cabin and more about desperately trying to fashion a useful tool out of a twig and some lint, all while questioning why you ever thought "roughing it" sounded fun. You'll spend half your time shivering in the rain, convinced every rustle is a bear with a vendetta, and the other half accidentally setting yourself on fire trying to cook a suspiciously bland berry. Forget majestic wildlife; your main enemies are dehydration, splinters, and the existential dread of realizing you can't even make a decent fire without YouTube tutorials. It's a chaotic, absurd, and surprisingly entertaining journey into becoming a slightly damp, perpetually hungry, and utterly incompetent wilderness expert.

I wanted to like this game. The premise is good, and the mood is there, but the gameplay is bad.

The crafting is not great, and pieces do not snap together as you might expect. Even worse, one of the early "shelters" is merely a save point and cannot be entered, despite having four walls and a roof.

The survival guide is a great idea, but it lacks some important information about early resource gathering.
You would expect exploration to be a big part of the game, but it is actively discouraged with the random appearances of bad guys.

The bad guys move at warp speed, or simply superman and fly wherever they need to be. Their hunting/patrolling behavior is also inconsistent. Are they afraid of fire or not?

Most of this could be overlooked, if the resource gathering wasn't so urgent. You only have a short time to explore before it's back to the long slog of gathering water, food, and resting. If I fill my stomach, I shouldn't be hungry again a few minutes later.

There also seems to be issues with hit detection/registration. Not just on enemies, sometimes you have to look at food at the right angle to get the UI to display the option to pick it up.

Look up what Project Zomboid looked like in 2015. A full DECADE, 1/7th of a life time, the game is fundamentally a worse game. Every update is 1 step forward 2 steps back. Reminds me of Dark and Darkers devs.

This game will break you before it rewards you. My first dozen characters died pathetically—starving because I couldn't find a can opener, bleeding out from a scratch I ignored, or getting swarmed after foolishly breaking a window. But that's when it clicked: Zomboid isn't about surviving the apocalypse, it's about learning how to stop being terrible at it. The sheer satisfaction of finally securing a safehouse, wiring it with generator power, and watching the hordes shamper past your carefully built defenses is unmatched. Yes, the graphics look like they're from 2012 and the UI fights you constantly, but no other game makes finding a damn cooking pot feel like striking gold. Just don't expect mercy—this is a brutal teacher that rewards patience and punishes every mistake with an embarrassing death screen.

I think this will be the first Steam review I have ever made. 

First off, I'd like to say that PZ has been close to my heart for many years. It's brought such lovely experiences, especially when playing with friends. Taking that into account, I have to give a thumbs down here. 

I started playing this game when I was first year in university. I'm now almost 30, and this game has evolved in many ways (I will not discount it for that), but not in a direction that makes much sense... All the core elements that make a fun zombie apocalypse game (bashing zombie heads, playing with friends, finding cool weapons and bases, etc...) have been pushed to the side for so long in favour of incredibly unnecessary add-ons that I don't see much use in (like pottery... why? In a zombie survival game? Instead of NPCs? Weird). 

Additionally, the community has become increasingly brainwashed to the point where they are spurring the devs to keep up their sub-par ways instead of promoting a want for a complete product (which is so way overdue). Guys, can we please be real? It's been over 12 years. That's... absolutely insane for ANY kind of game. The worst part? There still so much to be done! When will that actualize? 2055? When I'm 60? Come on...

It's with great sadness that I give a negative review, but I fear I'm at my wits end and have no alternative to influence a speed up in development time. 

To the 'white knights' that defend this game like it's their magnum opus, please understand. Some of us no longer have the chance to play this game with our friends like we used to (despite desperately wishing we could). It's now a dream that will never come true, and that hurts deeply. If you want to say, "just load b41 and play that again", then my response would be that "I shouldn't have to". We promised that we'd wait for b42 stable multiplayer before we conjoined again. I want to say 'we' are still waiting, but that 'we' became 'I', and now, alas, nobody. 

To the devs... For the love of everyone that treasures your beautiful game, please stop doing the unnecessary, and lock down on what you already have. It's more than enough. 

I don't aim to insult, ridicule, finger-point, or shame. I'm just a frustrated dude who really wanted to see this game reach its true state before having kids (not that I have them yet XD but I'm sure I will by the time this shiz stabilizes).
Great game with a great team of devs.

This game will challenge everything that you thought you needed to feel immersed in a game environment. I've played the game for nearly 100 hours and i'm still getting genuinely scared by moments in this game. Not like "oh that was a little scary" scary. I'm talking pause the game because my hands are too clammy to hold the mouse, or because I haven't breathed once while a hoard of 30 zombies, I couldn't shake, was pursuing me across town.  If you're still on the fence, you really shouldn't be. The game is just so genuinely well made and unique. In the years to come, with the content they are adding (and have added already), this will stand out as a masterpiece in the survival genre.

-Drink bottle of bleach to "cure" zombie infection.

It’s grim, punishing and occasionally hilarious in the most unexpected ways.

Project Zomboid is a fantastic game for anyone interested in a good, open, and fun survival game. The game is completely open world with many different areas to explore and loot, the game is difficult to learn but rewarding to master, the multiplayer is great with friends, and it has an almost endless amount of play-styles with it's character customization. The only people I wouldn't recommend this game to is anyone who struggles to find enjoyment in games that have you lose lots of progress when you die. Project Zomboid uses a system where when you die all of your character's skills are reset which can take hours to recover. However there are mods that allow for a keep inventory system similar to Minecraft if you don't want to deal with that. To summarize, if you like hard, open-world, survival games, than I would absolutely recommend you try Project Zomboid.

I am writing to request a refund for the game Project Zomboid.

I am aware that my playtime of approximately 4 hours exceeds the standard 2-hour refund policy. However, I would like to clarify that this entire duration was spent troubleshooting a critical, game-breaking bug and not on actual gameplay.

The primary reason I purchased this game was to play with my friends. The issue is that it is impossible to create a multiplayer server if you have any mods subscribed from the Steam Workshop. When I attempt to add mods to a new server, the game gets stuck on an infinite loading screen and never successfully creates the server. I have waited for over an hour at one point, but it never progresses.

The 4 hours logged on my account were spent entirely on:

Repeatedly attempting to launch a modded server.

Waiting on unresponsive loading screens.

Actively searching for solutions on community forums, Reddit, and other websites to fix this issue.

Testing various methods and mod combinations, all of which failed.

I am genuinely disappointed because I would not be asking for a refund if the game worked as advertised. The core feature of creating a modded server to play with friends is fundamentally broken. You can easily verify this issue by subscribing to any popular mod from the game's Steam Workshop and attempting to create a server yourself.

To provide further context, my friend who purchased the game at the same time as me encountered the exact same problem. They have already received a refund because their playtime was only 39 minutes, as they gave up immediately and did not spend hours trying to fix the problem as I did. I was the one trying to get the server to work for our group, which is why my playtime is significantly higher.

If needed, I can provide both my Steam ID and my friend's Steam ID to prove we purchased the game together for co-op play.

My case is that I have been penalized for trying to fix a faulty product. I have not been able to experience the game as intended at all. Given these circumstances and the fact that the game is not functioning correctly, I kindly request that you make an exception and approve my refund request.

Thank you for your time and consideration.

So, you're dropped into a survival zombie game, and let me tell you, it's less about strategic resource management and more about frantically smashing rotting heads with a frying pan while questioning why you ever thought scavenging for expired tuna was a good life choice. The zombies are relentless, surprisingly agile for being dead, and occasionally wear hats, which is just rude when you're trying to escape with your life. You'll spend half your time running from hordes that clearly skipped leg day but still outpace you, and the other half wondering why your character insists on whispering "I'm hungry" when there's a literal apocalypse happening. It's chaotic, absurd, and you'll probably die more times than you can count, but somehow, it's still a bizarrely entertaining way to spend your impending doom.

If you're looking for a zombie survival game that will make you feel like an inexperienced buffoon, then this game simulates that perfectly. Project Zomboid manages to be both a game that will make you seethe with rage when you die for not checking that one corner the ONE FUCKING TIME you get too comfortable... and it's also like a cute little sandbox game where you can spend literal days creating your ideal barbie dollhouse :3. And that's what it precisely is: a zombie survival sandbox sims simulator.

And you'd think I know something about this game nearly 600 hours into it, but in reality I still am learning things constantly. Like if it's more of a sims-like or more zombie survival. Either way, I still die a lot.

10/10 would continue to lose my social life over this game

I have tried so hard to love this game. However what has finally driven me to quit and write this review is the "Custom Sandbox" mode, which gives hope but is ultimately a let down.  Like many others, I grew frustrated with the zombie re-spawning mechanic of this game.  It made no sense to me to have to re-clear hordes of zombies right outside your base every time you want to go get supplies from a building next door.  I had read others raise the same complaint and the recommendation to play in sandbox mode and turn off re-spawn was mentioned many times.  So I gave this a go.  What I found was that apparently the re-spawn mechanic even when turned off is essentially still there.  I think this is due to the "migration" element of the game which essentially moves some of the 50,000+ zombies to empty areas.  In reality, this is just another version of re-spawn which still occurs even when re-spawn is "turned off".  If you turn of migration, you essentially have the zombies just stay still.  If you leave it on, you have zombie re-spawn.  Unless this is addressed, this game is not fun to play in my opinion.  For my last character, I had almost 500 zombie kills and never left the small area in which I was trying to fortify a house.  The roads were literally filled with corpses.  I never fired a gun, nor made any large noise which would have drawn in so many zombies.  I probably saw 10 to 20 houses total in the run.  I had re-spawn turned off and had reduced total zombie count by around 50% of the default.

Its a remarkably unforgiving game with the standard settings. But then again, the game starts with saying "This is how you died" so you really shouldn't expect to Win the game at any point. You're not supposed to live forever, and you'll likely have some very frustrating deaths after days of lucky breaks.

Highly recommend, tweak the settings if you don't like it, but even on easy settings its going to be hard for your first few runs. I bought this years ago, died miserably 3 times and didn't play it for 3 years, now I love it. My biggest gripe would be the number of superfluous menus to get anything done. Good luck figuring out if you should right click the item, right click the ground or use the crafting menu itself to get what you want. Annoying, but once you've done each unique thing you'll easily remember how

Best lesson for new players is that you don't NEED to kill the zombies - 90% of the time, you can walk away. Don't run away, you'll just run into more zombies and then you'll be winded too. Walk away calmly, situational awareness is worth more than 10 boxes of bullets. One bite is all it takes to die slowly over minutes, hours, days... so do you really NEED to kill those three zeds or are you being an adrenaline junkie? There's no loot in the game worth dying for!

I had a lot of fun in build 41 although once you learn how to fight or lure hordes the game does become fairly easy even though any tiny mistake you make at any time could cost your life. Which is fine because the game does expect you to die. Which is why build 42 makes no sense at all.

Build 42 is basically a completely different game. First: they have massively nerfed the player in combat. With the new muscle fatigue mechanic and the fact that zombies now move at different speeds it has became a far more tedious process to deal with zombies, especially hordes of 20-30, as you can not simply lure them away anymore. Secondly loot has been completely nerfed into the ground. Using rosewood as an example in build 41 you can go over to the second story apartments by the church and walk out with easily 20-30 cans of food and other goodies from the fridge. You could then walk down the bookstore and be greeted with 10-15 skill books per shelf and then proceed to loot the surrounding houses for even more canned food, enough to last you for months. In build 42....... those aparments MIGHT have 1-2 cans of food. Those shelves in the bookstore are barren or only have 2-3 literature or magazines on them. MAYBE 1 skill book, maybe, if you're lucky.  Houses are often so barren they aren't even worth looting anymore. For a game that expects you to die and has the ability to kill you over any tiny little mistake you make (even been scratched by a zombie once runs the risk of being infected) they expect you to deal with these layers of extreme tedium.

Surely there was a middle ground between build 41 and build 42. While I agree build 41 can be a little too easy when you know what you're doing build 42 seems like its doing everything it can to make the game as tedious, time consuming, and annoying as possible but still punishing you with death over any little microscopic mistake you make. Of course you can always just use sandbox mode and edit/change most of these settings to be a non issue however I believe the base experience (which is the experience most new players are going to get) should be enjoyable. 

Build 42 hates you and your time.

I have never played a game for 300 hours and felt like not only did i gain absolutely nothing from the experience, but i also somehow got worse at the game the longer i played. Unfortunately i am probably going to keep playing. This is a game to play when youre angry and want to become more angry. The running into zombies and making your character spin and flip in every direction has killed so many runs. In game lore, the zombie apocalypse has literally just started and is still being reported and refuted on the news. Why is EVERY car you come across dilapidated and shitty and none of them have gas??? What the hell happened 10 minutes before the game takes place to make every vehicle like this??? Having gasoline be a valuable resource, the thing that runs vehicles and generators, what do you DO after the gas is gone/gone bad? Just cut wood and hunt rabbits forever? Theres no end to the game, no way to reach a credit scene, no NPCs, no real goal at all other than "haha youre gonna die :) you think you wont but youre going to die." And like i said about gas going bad/empty, same happens with the electricity and water supply. Which is cool and realisitc and all, but like, theres no goal at all?? No "survive 1 year and evac from Louisville" or "activate and repair radio towers to call for help" or "search military bases for radio frequencies or plans" or "clear every town to let the population grow" or anything??? just start the game with the lights on, then the lights go off, then you have to boil water, then you have to walk every where in absolute pitch black darkness and hoard batteries for flashlights, and find clothes that arent fucked so your character doesnt freeze to death in the winter and die of dysentary or other non zombie illness? Its trying to be a minecraft kinda thing where you make your own adventure, but it just gets harder and more impossible as time goes on, and shit doesnt happen and shit will never happen besides pushing zombies over and stomping their heads? But guess what???, youre physically exhausted from running, ridiculously sleepy tired because your characters have nightmares every night you dont have a cigarette before bed so you cant sleep more than 2 hours, you tore your leg open hopping over a fence, youre over encumbered because the game refuses to spawn you a bag, youre dehydrated because everytime you try to jump into a house for a drink you get chased out by zombies that attract every zombie on the block, and last but not least youre "extremely uncomfortable" for some fucking reason, so stomping a zombies head takes up to 17 stomps to kill them, which wakes up the whole neighborhood and has every zombie youve ever spared or ignored break into your windows like seal team 6 and just ruin you.

Or the game just wont register you pushing a zombie because your cursor is just a little too far away from the zombie, so your character animation pushes the zombie and makes contact, but because you were "technically aiming behind the zombie" in the fucked up isometric game with worse camera angles than resident evil, So now you did everything correct, had the right reaction time and everything, but because the games camera angles are dogshit, you just got bit by a singular zombie with no other zombies around for miles, and your run is over. Done,

 "why cant you just go back and pick up your stuff, or start a base?" reread my first paragraph. Time is valuable in this game, its not minecraft where you just go back and pick your stuff up, every second you waste going back to pick up your dropped loot is time against you, gasoline going bad/getting looted, houses getting looted by invisible nonexistant npcs that wont be added til well after gta6 has come out on the next 4 generations of consoles, water getting turned off, electricity getting turned off, and since the last update, the darkness is literally just pitch black screen. No moonlight, nothing. So if you cant get a decent run going and get a generator in time, its insanity. going back for your loot is just cutting a day off your available time with what little resources you have, and lets be real. everyone starts a new game once they die/get bit. and if you dont youre a pussy.

"but it realism"
But its a video game, made for entertainment and i should be having fun, not actually getting stressed out in real life by having to micromanage my characters health when theres no real reason to, theres no goals or endings or story or anything resembling fun to be had. Its literally just a sandbox for you to spawn in, struggle as hard as you possibly can, then watch time and time again as it all crumbles down. 

Theres dna for a great game here, however, This does just seem to somehow be a 14 year old unfinished, early access beta. Until some endgame content or npcs or anything at all gets added, this is getting a thumbs down

Recommended for people who enjoy survival games.

Welcome to Project Zomboid, the only game where the first tutorial message might as well be, “You will die. Probably soon. Probably on the toilet.”

This is the zombie survival simulator for people who think DayZ is too forgiving and The Sims didn’t have enough blunt-force trauma. It’s not about winning—it's about delaying the inevitable with duct tape, desperation, and deep, existential dread. You don’t ask if you’ll die. You ask how, when, and will it be because you tried to microwave raw chicken?

You spawn in Kentucky with a vague sense of purpose, no skills, and a pair of socks. Maybe pants, if you’re lucky. The apocalypse has happened, you don’t know why, and frankly, nobody cares. All that matters now is scavenging, surviving, and not bleeding out in a Dollar Store because you picked a fight with a zombie while holding a rolling pin.

And the systems? Oh, baby. It’s not just about eating food and killing zombies. This is full-blown simulation psychosis. You have stats for cooking, tailoring, carpentry, mechanics, fishing, foraging, fitness, strength, boredom, stress, wetness, wind chill, and whether or not you’re slightly sad because you ate stale peas in the dark again.

The combat is realistic—which is code for: slow, clumsy, and absolutely terrifying. This isn’t a run-and-gun shooter. This is a “gently shove zombie down, stomp its head in, breathe heavily, check your bitten thigh, scream internally, and then die three hours later from a mild infection” kind of game. You will lose fights. You will misclick. You will bleed out in a bush while trying to bandage with a ripped tank top.

But the beauty of Project Zomboid is in the stories it creates.

“I survived 27 days. I built a safehouse, hotwired a car, survived a helicopter event, and then I tripped on a fence, sprained my ankle, alerted a horde, and got eaten while limping into a diner.”

“I tried to live in the mall. I made it 6 days. My downfall was hubris and frozen waffles.”

“I made it two months! I was thriving! Then I forgot to turn the oven off. House caught fire. Zombies heard it. Everything burned. Me included.”

The graphics are charming in that “isometric indie game that could definitely run on a toaster” kind of way. But don’t let the simplicity fool you. This is the deepest, most punishing, most satisfying survival sandbox you’ll ever get addicted to. The devs are obsessed. The community is deranged (in the best way). The modding scene is a lawless frontier of banana suit armor and NPCs that actually talk to you before they die screaming.

Multiplayer? It’s a chaotic stew of teamwork, betrayal, and watching your friend slowly turn into a zombie because he "didn’t want to worry anyone" about the scratch. You’ll all swear you’re going to rebuild society—until Dave sets off the burglar alarm, brings a horde, and you have to kill him with a frying pan and unresolved trauma.

Final Verdict:
Project Zomboid is the apocalypse you actually deserve. Bleak, hilarious, and brutally fair. Every death is your fault, every success is hard-earned, and every moment is just one missed door lock away from disaster.

Incredible immersion

Project Zomboid is not your average zombie survival game, it’s a punishing sandbox where the real enemy isn’t just the undead, but your own inexperience. The learning curve is steep, unforgiving, and at times downright brutal. I ran through the tutorial which gives you the basics, but there is so much depth to this game that it really does take multiple runs to get the experience you need. If you don’t learn how to bandage yourself, manage your hunger, or close the curtains before nightfall, you’ll be dead within a few in-game days. Literally, my first run I made it 3 days...and yet, that’s exactly what makes it so compelling!

So far, I’ve been primarily playing in Builder Mode, which tones down the zombie threat a bit and allows more room for exploration, base building, and experimentation. It’s a great entry point for new players who want to ease into the game’s systems without getting overwhelmed by constant hordes. In this mode, I’ve gotten to the point of hoarding plenty of materials like the doomsday prepper I am. I’ve spent hours fortifying my little safehouse, crafting rain collectors, and organizing an ever-growing stockpile of planks, wires, and empty jars. It’s absurdly satisfying.

The gameplay options are impressively deep. You can focus on farming, fishing, carpentry, mechanics, medicine, and so much more. Like I've watched so many TV programs and read tons of books and it feels like there's still so much XP I need to level skills more. There’s a tangible sense of progress, however, as your character learns new skills, and watching your base grow gives a real sense of accomplishment.

While I’ve only scratched the surface of the game, I’m excited to dive into multiplayer after the numerous youtube videos I've watched multitasking my own gameplay. The idea of collaborating with friends to build a shared base, or watching it all fall apart (Dayz flashbacks incoming), is thrilling. Project Zomboid feels like it could be an entirely different experience with other people in the mix.

Overall, Project Zomboid is not a game you master in a weekend. It demands patience, persistence, and a willingness to die (a lot) before you truly get the hang of it. But once you do, it opens up into one of the richest, most immersive survival simulations out there.

Ive sunk over 6.9 hours into Project Zomboid at this point, and honestly, I still feel like Im learning new ways to die every time I boot it up. This game is brutal, tense, and sometimes downright unfair, but thats exactly what makes it so damn compelling. First off, the atmosphere is incredible. The isometric graphics might look simple at first glance, but theres a weird charm to them, and the way the world slowly decays around you really sells the feeling of an apocalypse. Watching stores get looted, vegetation creeping into towns, and bodies piling up is both creepy and fascinating. Plus, the soundtrack is perfect, eerie and subtle enough that it doesnt get annoying even after dozens of hours. The gameplay loop is where Zomboid absolutely shines. You start off thinking, “Ill just grab some food and hide out in this house.” Next thing you know, youre carefully dismantling furniture for planks, boiling rainwater on a campfire, and setting up rain collectors on your rooftop because the waters shut off. Its one of the few games where mundane things like a can opener or a hammer feel like absolute treasures. Combat is punishing, and I love it. If you get cocky, youll get bitten. One slip-up, and that character youve spent weeks building up can be gone in seconds. Theres no magical cure for zombification. If youre bitten, thats it. Game over. It makes every encounter feel terrifying and forces you to plan ahead instead of running in guns blazing. This game is fun as hell with friends. That said, its definitely not for everyone. The learning curve is steep, and it can be super unforgiving. The UI takes some getting used to, and sometimes it feels like the game goes out of its way to kill you. But if youre into hardcore survival and dont mind a bit of jank, theres honestly nothing else like it.

 Project Zomboid is the ultimate “just one more run” game. If you want a zombie survival experience thats more about realism and long-term planning than shooting endless waves of undead, this is absolutely worth checking out.

Project Zomboid isn’t just a game—it’s a merciless survival odyssey. Every scratched knee could lead to a feverish demise; every careless step might attract a horde that ends your 100-hour run. The world crumbles dynamically: power grids fail, food rots, and winter freezes your unprepared bones. But within this brutal sandbox lies unparalleled depth: intricate crafting (from barricading windows to farming), realistic vehicle modding, and skills that demand true mastery. While the steep learning curve will break casual players, hardcore survivors will discover the most rewarding, endlessly replayable zombie apocalypse simulator ever made.

When I first played Project Zomboid, I thought it was kind of cute.
Pixelated little zombies, soft guitar strumming, rainy afternoons.
You scavenge, survive, maybe build a base.
I named my first character Dave. Dave was a construction worker. He loved peanut butter.
I didn’t know what I was getting into.

By hour 40, I was living in a two-story house with a microwave, a baseball bat, and hope.
I would check the windows every morning. I called it my coffee time.
Zombies tried to break in once. I reinforced the door and left a note: “Please knock.”
I thought that was funny.

At hour 100, I started labeling all my canned goods by mood.
“Happy Beans.” “Angry Spaghetti.” “Despair Tuna.”
I only ate Happy Beans during thunderstorms.
That made sense to me. Still does.

Hour 250:
My best friend is a traffic cone named Leonard.
He guards the staircase. I trust him more than myself.
I accidentally ate my last antidepressant. Not in-game.
I started wearing a wedding dress because it had better scratch resistance.
Also because I look amazing in it. Shut up.

Hour 500:
There’s a sound in the forest. It follows me. I think it’s the jukebox from Riverside.
I haven’t played with sound on in weeks.
I broke into a house just to stare at the wallpaper.
I stayed there for three days. I think that was my honeymoon. Leonard officiated.

Hour 700:
I built a shrine made of rotten cabbages and watches.
Every watch is set to a different time. None of them are right.
The cabbage whispers when the moon’s out.
I write down what it says. Not for me. For… the Others.
They know.

Hour 900:
I died.
But I didn’t.
The character died.
But I respawned.
He remembers.
Every time.
The pain accumulates. I am 74 people now. All named Dave. All hungry.

Hour 1000:
I ate a spoon.
There was no spoon.
I yelled at the oven because it wouldn't tell me the truth.
There is no truth.
There is only fork.
I am fork.
THE FORK IS INSIDE THE WALLS
Hour 1001:
AAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAA
THIS IS HOW YOU DIED
THIS IS HOW YOU DIED
THE WATCHES ARE BLEEDING
THE ZOMBIE HAD A PEACH IN HIS PANTS I ATE IT I BECAME HIM
WHY DOES BLEACH TASTE LIKE CLOSURE
WHY DOES GREG KEEP LYING
LEONARD WON’T BLINK
THE RAIN ISN’T REAL
THE TOILET JUST LOOKED AT ME

Final review:
10/10
Would do it again
Haven’t stopped
Can’t stop

I’m typing with my teeth
